description:
I have been coming to Delica when they first opened, and I am having dinner at this place since I want some Japanese food. I was so hungry and craving for some Japanese food.
I ordered the pork tonkatsu bento box and the shrimp cake with tartar sauce, and also their Tea's tea peach ginger tea. They were near closing time, and the cashier helped me where the stuff are like beverages and chopsticks. 
The pork tonkatsu bento box was at room temperature and laying out at the counter. This is probably the last 2. I took one - so it had 3 small pieces of pork tonkatsu with sauce on top of it, soy sauce brined lotus root salad, black seaweed salad with natto, edamame and sushi rice with black sesame seeds. Then I also ordered a shrimp cake with a side of tartar sauce.
The food was really good, and ate the whole thing. I did enjoyed what I ate today late afternoon like around 5:27 PM. Then drank some peach ginger tea. It was satisfying and enjoyable dinner. 
The shrimp cake is a shrimp with little Kewpie mayo, onions covered with panko bread crumbs and deep fried. This was excellent with their mildly flavored Japanese tartar sauce. So yummy!
This is still one of my go-to-places for quick Japanese deli foods- quite a unique menu still.
author: Jade M.

description:
Everything here is authentic and phenomenal. 

Usually a long line at lunch but it moves fast. 

The salads are perfectly prepared with the right amount of dressing to add flavor but not take away from the greens. 

Build your own bento - I love the pork tonkatsu, sweet and spicy chicken and potato croquette. 

But the Japanese Beef Curry earns Delica 5 stars on its own. Without question the best beef curry I've had in San Francisco. Perfect flavor, cut with a spoon, melt in your mouth, savory, mild heat goodness. I could eat it everyday. We
author: Dave K.

description:
Like a moth to flame, I followed the crowds and found myself in a long line anticipating a yummy lunch.   Should have paid attention to the meaning of that allusion!

It's essentially a hipster bento box place that was just meh.  Definitely not worth the long lines and pretty spendy too.  Bento with tea was $20. 

So, just move along, skip the lines and save your money and calorie intake for something worthy.
author: Cindy G.

description: This is a fast way to get beef curry or Japanese food on the go. I like the shrimp cake and the beef curry with rice.  This place is good if you are waiting for a Ferry and need something fast to eat besides fast food.
author: Juan V.

description:
It was a few hours before I had to leave the city and make my way to the airport to head back to Phoenix, so I wanted to head on over the Ferry building and grab a meal and eat by the bay one last time. 

I wanted to try something different this time, so I went with Delica. They have a lot of good lunch time deals, even bento boxes and after checking out the menu I knew I had to try the beef curry and a potato croquette. 

The potato croquette was a blend of russet and Yukon gold potatoes with caramelized onions, and it was pretty dang tasty.

The beef curry had tender pieces of beef and potatoes in a curry sauce over white rice. This was the perfect meal on a cool summer day by the bay.

Glad to have given Delica a try and look forward to coming back!
author: Monica O.

description:
Came here at 4pm today. I got the eggplant salad, the miso soup and the chicken dumplings. 

The miso soup was okay. The eggplant salad didn't have much taste and the chicken dumplings were incredibly cold. Would not return.
author: Karanveer M.

description:
Soft serve was the best! I never had green tea ice cream so creamy and full bodied. felt like I drank a green tea latte. 

I'm not impressed by their lunch bento. I heard the hype, got two 9 items bento to share with bff. Meh, I didn't touch anything but my bff ate everything and took mine. It's just too fresh for me. It's a great idea, and great execution but things just didn't come together. The box didn't look appetizing. Looks great on the phone but in person it's not as sexy and def doesn't taste as good. 2 bento and 2 snack a la cart came out to be over $40. 

Probably will not return. Lunch wait was not bad tho.
author: Kris J.

description:
It's a miss for me. I came around 1:30 to grab a quick lunch and just wanted something light and healthy to take with me. I ended up in front of Delica and was intrigued by their menu -- it seems like an Asian fusion sort of cuisine. 

I grabbed a tiny smattering of sesame spinach and two chicken dumplings. Because I wasn't very hungry it okay... but if I was I would not have been very happy to find out that paying $11 only got me a tiny tiny portion. 

The chicken dumplings were pretty good -- and at $2.50 a piece they should be. They're not traditional Asian dumplings -- they're more of a meatball. I personally didn't enjoy the sesame spinach salad and I also didn't think the price was justified -- I paid $5.60 for a few mouthfuls of spinach. And when I say a few mouthfuls I'm not exaggerating! 

Ultimately a great location in the Ferry Building but too expensive for what they're offering. Also if you're looking for traditional Asian food, you won't get it here.
author: Christine W.

description:
Had a short window to eat during a conference day lunch break. Hopped across the street from the Hyatt regency and got in line for quick bite. The line moved fairly quickly and I was a little overwhelmed by the menu but decided on the Japanese beef curry as I was in a comfort food mood although the bento boxes and salads were tempting. Was feeling a bit hungry so I decided to try the salmon chowder as well. 

The beef curry was hot and the rice had a nice al dente texture. The sauce was flavorful and had a slight spicy kick. The meat was tender and just the right amount of fat. 

The chowder also had a nice salmon flavor in the broth but the fish was just a bit over cooked. The vegetables were nice but I was way too full to finish both dishes  

A great weekday option at one of my favorite SF eating spots!
author: Michael Y.

description:
Ordered Salmon chowder and Beef curry. Beef curry was great but Salmon chowder was way too runny! I mean yuck, i had to drink it like milk, except it's not! It's water down and oily. I was expecting a rich, flavorful, creamy chowder. Am I wrong? My foodie friend whom I was going to share the chowder agrees. I bring it back which I have never done before. I talk to a cashier. A Chinese (I think) woman appears and says, well that's how we cook it. I can help next!

I felt powerless and humiliated. I didn't even think to ask for a manager. I wanted to dump the chowder into their trash can but couldn't find it so just left it on the counter as I left.

I am totally disgusted by how rude a restaurant employee can be toward a customer. Unbelievable.
author: Jen B.

description: Love the wide variety and sitting in front of an ocean view for lunch. Niiiiice! Wish I had pictures but was too hungry...
author: Danielle Y.

description:
It's so convenient, on my way to work, well... my co-workers way to work. 
She's on the F and gets off and goes in. 
Purchase 2 chicken meatball ($2.50/ea)
That's insane!
But it's so worth it! 
Nice and golden, soft and tender and so extremely flavorful!
author: Fiona B.

description: I tried a few of the vegan salads here and potato croquettes. Everything was pretty tasty and I'd definitely come back again. It was very light and not overly filling. Agree with other posters that servings were small. However I was happy with it.
author: Stacey W.

description: Totally what you would expect in the Ferry Building. Overpriced, but decent food. Worth the price? Not really, but it's the Ferry Building what can you expect. The counter service was good. This place reminds me of Lemonade because you just pick what you want and then get the price. I would get the shrimp tempura w/ fried veggies. It looks like a volcano/nest (pictured below) almost. I would also recommend pork cutlet and the wasabi potato salad. The soup portion is so small. I don't think it's worth it.
author: Caitlyn S.

description:
Delica is one of the restaurants in the Ferry building plaza that I've been to a handful of times for lunch. It is a Japanese themed Deli where you have your standard Bento's, Donburi, Salads & entrees. During lunch you can do a 3-item combo where you get a soup, salad & entree or 2 salads and an entree for $10.99. The menu board is not too clear so you will see a lot of first timers hanging around trying to figure out what to get, but once you get the drift the line moves pretty fast.  

Over a period of time I've tried most of their soups, salads and entrees in different combinations. Surprisingly I've liked almost everything that I've got. The salads specially are unique. I haven't seen these in other Deli's. I thought the combinations are a little weird but they go well together. My favorites are the eggplant salad, Salmon chowder & the Kaki-age Tempura (which is vegetable and shrimp tempura). The salmon chowder is loaded with fish and is well worth the $1 up-charge.

Price is actually cheap when compared to other restaurants in the plaza especially when you factor in the high quality of the food. Delica seems to check all my boxes of quality, service and value for money so I'm going to be generous and round up my 4.5 start rating to 5.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Was starving and needed some food. Stopped by here for a veggie bento box. Looked better than it taste and a little on the pricy side ($13) but as expected at the ferry building.
author: Allen G.

description: Great Japanese place that serves good food that doesn't break your bank. The wasabi salad satisfied my spice craving. The pork cutlets were nice, but nothing to rave about. They even gave me a free extra rice. I'm going to upgrade my rating from 4 to 5.just because I spent $10 for the whole meal and left very satisfied.
author: Mackie M.

description:
I'm so torn. I wanted to love this place, but it was only a like for me. I'll def return and try some of their other items on the menu, but I ordered from Caviar and they didn't carry everything. Warning though the portions are small for the price you're paying. I spent $20+ and only received a piece of tofu and a bento box.

Agedashi Tofu Steak - This was my favorite. I've eaten this in a handful of restaurants in different countries and the tentsuyu sauce was very good. It was the right amount of sweet and savory. I ate this cold, which was fine, but I'm not sure if you are supposed to heat it up first. A little pricey at $5 a piece.

Assorted 9-item Sushi Bento - I loved the arrangement of this and the presentation, but I wish I got to pick what went inside my bento box. It was a pre-set amount of things. I loved most of the things in there, but my favorite was the chicken dumpling and the hijiki & soybean. The flavors were great and pretty close to a bento box from the corner store in japan. I love burdock but I wasn't a fan of the way they mixed theirs. The celery in the mix threw the flavors off.  My least favorite was the Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad. I was expecting it to taste like the sweet potato salad that's available in most Japanese grocery stores, but the wasab was overpowering. 

The bento also came with 4 pieces of sushi from a roll.The bento has one piece Salmon, Tuna, 16 grain, and Shrimp & Crab. Besides the raw piece of salmon and tuna on top of the roll, everything inside the roll was cooked. The roll also had pieces of raw red peppers. It threw off the taste completely. If you had to add a veggie, they should have went with takuwan. The only roll that I finished was the 16 grain and I liked that one the most.
author: Junella T.

description: Misleading and deceptive menu. A half pint salad is not a quarter pint. "I'll have a half pint of salad" translates to some mystical weight that is $2.85. Confronted, the worker was rude and offered to charge more to fill the remaining empty volume in the container. I never said "I'll have a mystical weight of salad."
author: Kevin C.

description:
I ordered for pickup today.
I was very happy last time. 
Foods were good, service was good too.
But not this time,
Unfortunately Asian lady was seems like something wrong or angry mood.
I asked chopsticks and napkin. She was WHAT?! Seriously so scary! 
Grab your self! Don't yelling me
Feel I was in China town. 
I don't like bad attitude at restaurants.
So I never go back again.
author: Ria D.

description:
This adorable little Japanese deli inside the Ferry Building is crave-able. They always have a myriad of fresh salads, both vegetarian and some with chicken. My absolute favorite is their asparagus or green bean salad with fresh carrots and light but very flavorful sesame seed dressing, I only wish they bottled and sold it! 

The croquettes range from peppery potato, creamy veggie with corn, crab and shrimp. All of them are yummy, sometimes during the lunch hour you may have to wait for them to drop a few into the oil but the wait is worth it. 

Their chicken teriyaki dumpling = heaven and they reheat really well in the oven so get a bunch just ask for a little extra sauce to keep them juicy.  They have bento boxes for lunch as well and you can get a completely vegetarian one. They offer quite a few sushi rolls including an avo roll that is 100% vegan. 

On a nice cool crisp SF day their unique MAMEstrone vegetarian soup really hits the spot, the broth is complex, lots of veggies and strange but good parmesan cheese (who'd have thought). 

If you stop by here for lunch or simply to enjoy wandering around the building this place is worth a stop even if just for a croquette, dumpling and small salad.
author: Kelly T.

description: It was my favorite place, but yesterday I saw a fly going from dish to dish in the entree section because the area behind the glass was not closed off. I don't think I will be going back.
author: William S.

description:
Pretty good quality food, but you definitely need to order the right thing.

Came here to quickly pick up some lunch during work. You can order meals or pick up pre-packaged portions of some of their dishes. I opted for the latter, which to be honest didn't save me much time as they only had one cashier for both the pre-packed and made-to-order lines.

I got a small container of the root salad, the eggplant dish, and a salmon rice ball. The salmon rice ball was decent quality, but the amount of salmon is very tiny and spread throughout the rice ball (versus an onigiri with the salmon in the center). The lotus salad was a major disappointment, as all the veggies were pretty tough and the sauce barely there.

However, the eggplant salad was top-quality. From the tiny noodles, to the eggplant and the pieces of ground chicken, the ingredients blended beautifully together. No wonder it was the most expensive item I got.

All in all, I think this is a place that is hit or miss. If you want to have an experience that mirrors the stars this place has been given, make sure you plan ahead and read others' reviews!
author: Angela C.

description: Very tasty tofu and chicken patty and spicy burdock salad. Very oily carrot ginger soup and very impatient counter person. Good to try once but friendlier options in the Ferry Bldg.
author: Abbe K.

description:
Really expensive for what it is.  This place gets to jack up their prices because they're in the ferry building, but I don't think it's worth it.  There are plenty of better spots in the ferry building to get food - and this isn't one I'd make an effort to go to.

I had a very small roll for around $8. I wasn't too hungry so this wasn't a problem for me, but it wasn't anything special.  It was mediocre, not too flavorful, and something I could've had at a much cheaper spot.  They have some grab and go onigiri which might be worth getting if you're in a rush.

Seating is plentiful during off hours, but I can imagine it being quite crowded during lunchtime.  It's a total tourist spot due to location and all those who work nearby.

The one thing I plan to come back and try is their hojicha soft serve!  I've heard this is worth getting - and I could never say no to ice cream.
author: Kenna H.

description:
Always good quality food at a great location. I commute by ferry and work near here, this is one of my favorite place to have a quick lunch with out-of-towners, or have a dinner-to-go to eat on the ferry (dinner cruises, woo hoo!) 

I love their 
- bento boxes
- veggie curry
- any salads (I like the hijiki seaweed salad and the gobo/burdock salad)
- ice creams

What is definitely worth mentioning is their hojicha icecream (soft serve) - it's out of the world. Give it a try yourself!
author: Wendy K.

description:
In the spirit of honesty, my daughter went to school years ago with the owner's son but we are in no means close. I wish we were because the food at Delica is so delicious. 
They have bento boxes with the most delicious rice green beans salad seaweed salad and lotus root salad in addition to a variety of protein choices. When I'm at the ferry building I go to Delica. The food is fresh enough high-quality. They also have sushi and you can get items deli style to go as well. It doesn't have to be in the Bento box. I love their food and I have been going there for 11 years happily every single time. If they had one closer to my house it would probably be a weekly visit. As it stands, it has to be a special ferry building excursion and I'm thrilled each time I get to enjoy their food.
author: Nettie A.

description:
This unique venue is one of the more alluring locations with prime real estate in the heart of the ferry building. I love the Japanese delicatessen concept with a menu of mouthwatering items from sushi, tempura, soups, bento boxes and more. Portions are on the smaller size, and prices are higher. During the middle of lunch rush you'll generally see a long line and a deli counter with Asian fusion menu options. Don't let the long line scare you, they have a well oiled operation that gets the line moving quickly.

Delica uses quality ingredients, locally sourced and hormone free. I went with a group of friends, and we all ordered the salmon chowder. On a positive note the flavor and consistency were just right, not too heavy. The downer was the itty bitty speckles of salmon floating in the soup. There were definitely more carrots than anything and my salmon craving left unsatisfied. The alaskan crab croquette was amazing, but for $5+, I wish it was a more sizable portion. My friends ordered the potato croquette which was substantially larger than its crab counterpart. 

Seating is available in the public communal area with the bay view, adjacent to Delica and a few of the other businesses. There doesn't appear to be any shortage of people going to Delica-whether it be tourists or locals. While this probably won't make it on my regular lunch rotation, on occasion I may stop by to grab a la carte items like the roast beef sushi or that crab croquette.
author: Nova P.

description:
A favorite in the Ferry Building. 
I have to stop when I go.
I have never had a bad thing here. 
So so good.
author: Roger L.

description: Everything here is fresh and tasty. My favorite is the Vegetarian Bento Box. Their miso soup is delicious too! Plus you can seat in the dining area with a nice view.
author: David V.

description: One of my top go-to places for fresh and delicious Japanese food. We really like their Sushi Sampler Bento Box with inventive and tasty dishes that are a terrific value for the price. Even better.....you can have the food delivered through one of the popular food delivery services and enjoy them at home (or work).
author: Dean J.

description:
Humph.

I really had high hopes for Delica after reading some fellow Yelper's reviews, but I'm left feeling underwhelmed. I opted for one of their bento box options - 2 sides and 1 main, with sesame salad, green bean salad and upgraded to a tuna roll for the whopping price tag of $15.

Perhaps it's the price tag that's leaving a sore taste in my mouth? While I enjoyed the salads, they weren't over the top and the tuna roll was really just okay and not worth the $3 upcharge.

I was looking for fresh and quick and Delica certainly delivered on that account, but I'm torn as to whether or not I return...
author: Jessica M.

description: Tasty and healthy Japanese food at a reasonable price, considering the location. You can get a 3-item combo for $11 and the portions are big enough to fill you up for sure. I'm a big fan of their chicken dumplings, eggplant salad, spinach salad and salmon chowder. I don't recommend coming for dinner though since many of their items are sold out after 5pm and the rest tend not to be fresh, but for lunch Delica is one of the best options around.
author: Carl W.

description:
Not coming here again. 

It's 3pm on a Saturday and it's not busy at all. The cashier let us order soft serve ice cream and then told us to pick it up on the other side. When we get there, there were two extremely rude employees eating their lunch. They looked at each other when we got to the counter, laughed, and kept eating. After a few minutes one of them told us they would help us when they were finished eating. Seriously? There's two of you and all we ordered was ONE soft serve ice cream that takes 1 minutes to prepare. And we were the only customers! That's such bad service and we're not returning.

Having worked in the food service industry, I totally understand needing your lunch break when you can get it....but that's why you eat in the back. That's just common sense. If you're hanging out in front of customers, don't be surprised that you're expected to assist them. Obviously.
author: Stacey D.

description:
Overpriced and served cold.

Pleasant counter service.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Pretty cool sushi rolls and salads! I've ordered the Assorted Sushi Bento via Caviar and I must emphasize that the to-go packaging was so adorable! I've heard great things about the curry, so it's definitely on my hit list.

Although I appreciate the creativity, I wish they provided larger portions. The bento was $14, but wasn't nearly as filling! I could've finished another box because it was so delicious.

I have yet to also try the other bento options, so will be back in the near future. :)
author: Jenny H.

description:
Wayyyy over priced. Also yhe food they serve is cold. And i am not talking about their premade food. 
All they do is scoop and pour. No heating up or giving hot food. Actually soup was hot. 
Also. Doesnt taste good. 
They seems like a good restaurant in the market. Thats probably why they get a lot of customers. 
Food looks nice. Does not taste good 

Also ppl are rude.
author: Onion O.

description:
Saw a sign for matcha soft serve and that was all it took to get me to walk in!

Delica offers both Matcha and Hojicha (roasted green tea) flavors. Of course, I had to try them both! So I ordered a small cone ($4) with a swirl of both flavors. 

The way it works, you have to pay at the cashier to receive a receipt for your order. You bring the receipt towards the back (to the left of the counter) of Delica. I got distracted and ended up buying a crab croquette too, but honestly no regrets. The crab croquette ($4-5?) was delicious and juicy! 

Back to the soft serve. The cone is good (sugar waffle) and both flavors are also good. The Matcha is creamy, mildly sweet, and has a mellow matcha flavor that isn't too strong although I personally would have wanted it to be stronger. The Hojicha was not too sweet and had a roasted, nutty flavor with a bitterness that reminded me of coffee. That bitterness was perfect with the sweetness which makes Hojicha my flavor of choice between the two. 

I really loved the Hojicha though, I would probably choose to get that again!
author: Sofia R.

description: I love everything this place has to offer, well except for the price. Taking a star off for the expensive pricings especially for a self serve place and considering how small the portions are, but then again it is San Francisco. But everything here is just so delicious, so I just find myself keep coming back hungry and complaining about the costs afterward.
author: J L.

description:
This is a Japanese style restaurant tucked away in the ferry building.

Parking? Ha, Ha, no. There is a loading area behind the building-that isn't marked out in any way, by where sinbad's used to be, kinda sorta by the Gandhi statue/outdoor dining section, and the never really available SF street parking. Like prettty much everything else in downtown SF you'll be best served by finding a way to come here that does not involve driving.

This is a unexpectedly large Japanese delicatessen with a world cuisine menu. You can order prepared, prepackaged items-dumplings croquettes sushi and bento to go, or order off the menu. Menu items can be to go or dine in, but there is no waiter service. They have the delicatessen style of ordering from counter and call out system. In house orders get the metal stand with  number, everybody else gets a hand off over the counter. The architecture is very contemporary lots stainless steel and wood with the lots subtle natural and discreet artificial lighting. The overall effect is very well done, the dining has a snug cozy feel, while keeping the counter area crisp and bright. The seating is varuios (Edit to self: Dude. Seriously.VARIOUS. Why can't you spell that word correctly?) dark wood table/chair combos but I can't tell you too much about that as when it comes to the ferry building, I'm all about the grab and go. The best sushi is at the sushi counter slightly inside, as the counter options tend to be slightly more basic and standardized. Tasty and awesome no matter what you chose,

The food here is excellent. It's hard to go wrong with any item. I am a huge fan of the croquettes-whether they are veg or meat. They are huge-about the size of my fist,and fried to crispy perfection. Want something healthy? Get one of the super awesome salads, or even the bento choices-those change from day to day and are more then sufficient for a very satisfying lunch. 

Pricing? Well a croquette will run you 7 bucks or so, and if you get something to drink you are looking at ten dollars at a minimum. Salad/soup/lunch combo thingys will typically be around 15 dollars and there does not appear to be a top end limit at the sushi counter. It's entirely possible to get a hundred dollar tab at the sushi sit in counter, but for those who don't roll that big fifteen bucks will get you the best lunch you'll have all week, I've focused on the most common items, but bear in mind that the menu here is quite extensive and customizable. There are dozens of items that I'm not so familiar with, and will possible not get to as it's hard for me to get past the croquettes. Did I mention how good they are? 

I consider this a must do in the ferry building.
author: Steven W.

description: This place was pretty average, in a way. Obviously they have some healthy salads and good ingredients, but low flavor profile and skimpy portions. They gave me literally three pieces of cold chicken as a "main" entree. Couldn't they have at least sprung for four pieces? Could they have warmed it up? Also adding plain white rice is $2 surcharge. Oddly the warm rice was the best part of the meal.
author: Kathryn S.

description: This is a solid place to get something to go from the Ferry Building, but one of my favorite parts is the soft-serve they offer. It's creamy, flavorful - but not too sweet - definitely lighter than Humphrey. Although I usually just try to get the hojicha, you can actually swirl both flavors. The small is more than enough to share.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I have no idea why this restaurants deserves such high ratings! Perhaps my tastes are more refined right now because I just got back from Asia, but this restaurant is terrible. I got the hijiki riceball that people raved about on yelp along with a the 2 salad + rice entree. I chose the eggplant salad, the hijiki salad, and the regular rice and my favorite part of this entire meal is the white rice. The salads were both uninterestingly presented and bland to taste. I felt like I was consuming empty calories that didn't even taste great. It definitely cannot be considered Japanese food. 

I didn't order any of the main items, but they were definitely fried ahead of time and real tempura and fried japanese (or any type of asian) food has to be done on the spot. 

For ferry building prices of $15ish for lunch, I would definitely stray far far away from this asian fusion joint. So sad =( I miss good asian food.
author: Annie Z.

description: My friend recommended this place to me. We came here for lunch. It's a Japanese deli and sushi bar. You order at the counter and it's in Embarcadero Ferry building so not very much seating around. I think most people order to go for lunch. There were quite a few vegan options and I got the agadashi tofu with rice and a salad. We ordered to go and went and ate it outside by the water. Really colorful food and tasted fantastic. It was really light, fresh food, felt pretty good after the meal. They run out of a lot of the vegan options by the evening so lunch is the best time to go. I went once around dinner time and thought they had no vegan options because they had run out of a bunch of stuff and taken away the labels. I was surprised when I came back for lunch and they had a ton of vegan options. So definitely better for lunch and they run out of the good stuff fast. Love browsing around the ferry building and walking along the piers. Good place to grab food and go for a walking lunch.
author: Keerthi V.

description:
I'm torn because I really wanted to like Delica. I will definitely come back here again and try it in person. I ordered delivery from Caviar and the food was pretty good.

However, I was very surprised when my $8 Hijiki and Soybean Salad came in this tiny little box. I ordered the bento box for $12.25 with the Hijiki and Soybean Salad in it and it was about the same size. How is that even possible? They either gave me the wrong box because there's no way that was 1/2 lb or it's a scam. Will post pictures later.

Yelpers, DO NOT order Hijiki and Soybean Salad as an entree $8, just order that as a part of the bento. It was SOOOO NOT WORTH THE MONEY. It tasted pretty good according to a coworker but I was too mad about the size to care. It SAID 1/2 lb salad.

I didn't have to pay a dime for it myself and I though it was a waste of money.

I had the beef curry which I thought was pretty well made, the meat was very soft and the sauce was good. The curry and rice came in the portions I thought was going to come in, but the salad was just super disappointing. 

The $5 shrimp each was a bit expensive but it was pretty tasty. The tonkatsu was actually better than I thought with a little bit of the sauce they put on it. The chicken dumpling looked very tasty and flavorful (coworkers ate it all :P). They were price per piece so they felt a bit on the pricier side but if you're into that, this is for you.

I hope to be able to review this place again and up the rating because I think this restaurant can do better. The beef curry was reasonably priced in my opinion. I really enjoyed my meal but I am very mad about the salad (because I felt cheated). Anyway, just order the bento and not the salad themselves.
author: Kimberly W.

description: The food is "ok" the prices are not....spending $25 at lunch just for a small sandwich and two crab croquettes (because the sandwich is not going to be enough) is not something I will do often.  Blown away to see the "$1.85/each for one tiny piece of sweet and spicy chicken"  Really?
author: Brian S.

description:
I have become quite fond of this place. A great spot for lunch.
Be sure to get in before 12. The line can get long but they do move quickly.
I often get the main + soup + salad combo. The chicken dumplings are great. I also like the Kakiage tempura. 
Carrot and ginger soup is my favorite among the soups.
Also try the Spicy Burdock and Lotus Roots Salad .
The bento boxes look good. Will try it sometime.
Overall worth the money!
author: Steffi C.

description:
It was not as impressive as I expected. The food display was cute but the taste was pretty meh.

My friends and I ordered through Caviar and here are our thoughts on each dish we ordered:
--Ginger Beef Bowl (3/5): this dish was REALLY SWEET. We did not expect this much sweetness at all. Also, it was really oily. Near the bottom of the rice, you can see oil flowing around. We were really excited about this dish until we had our first bite. Really Disappointing.
--Assorted sushi bento (3.5/5): a great variety but nothing really stood out. Considering the quality & the amount of food they gave you, we think $14.75 for the bento is at the more expensive side.
--Sweet & Spicy chicken (2/5): first of all, $1.85 for only a really really small piece of chicken, ugh... Also, the chicken was not spicy at all. It was really sweet. Definitely will not order again.
--Tofu & Chicken Patty with Hijiki (4.5/5): probably our favorite dish among the ones we ordered. The sauce was not overly sweet and the patty was really good. If we order again from Delica, this dish will definitely be a must-order one.
author: Clare L.

description:
Solid choice for food at the ferry building! There's so many options displayed in the glass casing. The people that work here are really nice and offered to make some of the food fresh for me since the ones they had left had been sitting out for awhile. 

I really liked the crab croquette ($4.50). It had crab with creamy sauce in it. It's a little pricey but very tasty. The scallop and potato croquettes ($2 each) were also really good. The chicken dumpling with sweet chili sauce ($2.25 each) were unique but I probably wouldn't get that next time especially for the price. My boyfriend ordered the large beef curry ($11). It was a huge serving size of rice with tender beef and potato curry. It was super hearty and filling.
author: Linda X.

description:
Yeah, it's been 6 years since my last review for Delica, and with this update, it still a solid 5 stars for me!  I just love coming here!

First and foremost that I should mention, I just had their Beef Curry for the first time and it's probably one of the better Japanese Curries I've had in the city.  I got the regular sized curry and it was a pretty hearty bowl with a good amount of tender beef cubes and potatoes.  And from their hot food section, their crab croquettes are still the thing the get!
Regular Beef Curry w/ Crab Croquette -- http://bit.ly/1jnb8VE

Their salads are still some of the tastiest ones you can have in the Ferry Building.  I still recommend getting the 2 salads and rice combo with their Burdock Root Salad and Lotus Salad.

Their bentos have the perfect balance of veggies, carbs, and proteins.  They're always something worth stopping by for lunch.
4 item Bento -- http://bit.ly/1OAPMkA

Other than their prices being higher than most Japanese markets, simply because it's in the Ferry Building, I really can't see any other flaws with Delica.  Their food is totally fresh and delicious!
author: Rodney H.

description:
I've come to Delica a few times for an afternoon break from work. My office was by Montgomery and I liked to walk down Mission to the piers to stretch my legs. I would pop into the Ferry Building for a quick snack and Delica is a favorite go-to spot.

I always grab a SPICY TUNA ROLL and sometimes a bottle of Japanese ICE TEA. The spicy tuna is fresh and flavorful, with a big portion of extra fish layered on top of the roll. At $11, it's a bit of a splurge snack. However, that's standard pricing for a tasty sushi roll in the FiDi area. The ice tea is refreshing and reminds me of the drinks I could get out of any street-side vending machine in Japan. 

Service is quick -- for all the premade items you can just point at the shelf and staff will grab it or for you. You can pay by card via Square.

I'll come back again for a quick snack. The onigri and curry looks tasty too!
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
LOL at Yelp for thinking I actually like this place enough to come back repeatedly...

Delica is an ideal Japanese grab-n-go place, offering plenty of ready-to-go bentos. You also have the option of ordering various sides along with rice and soup, with the sides ranging from potato croquette to teriyaki chicken to tofu agedashi, and even tempura.

However, seeing as how it's located at the Ferry Building, all items are more expensive than the usual average downtown SF lunch fare, and to be honest, the food I had wasn't too impressive. 

Ordered a bento box for $15, which came with 9 different types of food, which included 4 different sushi rolls, 4 salads, and a meatball looking thing in the middle. All the items were just satisfactory in taste to me, with nothing standing out other than the roll with the purple rice (only because it was purple). 

Maybe I'll come back after a little while, but there are plenty of other options for quick Japanese food around.
author: Viet N.

description: Went to Delica to get lunch. I ordered beef curry also got the tuna roll for $8 for a friend. I was expecting a whole roll of the tuna roll but I ended up getting a half of a roll. WTF that is a RIP OFF. Even a sushi restaurant will not give you a half a roll of sushi for $8 you will at least get a full roll. The tuna did not look fresh if I was the employee that gave me the roll I would be soo embarrassed for giving a half roll sushi for $8. You guys should take this off your menu. TOTAL RIP OFF. Do not go here for sushi. Also the beef curry is mostly all potatoes.
author: Resty M.

description:
Randomly came across this place while exploring the ferry building.
I got two salads and a main and I believed it was 10.50 .
The main dish I got was the sweet spicy chicken which was a bit cold for my liking.
The two salads I got however were amazing !
I got the spicy burdock salad and the mushroom salad and really enjoyed both . Burdock salad reminded me of one of my favorites side dishes and it was the first time I came across somewhere that made it how I liked it. 
The mushroom salad was also really tasty ~ not too salty not too bland .
Overall really enjoyed the food !
author: Julia K.

description:
Third time's a charm for my San Francisco MealPass experience so far. Got the Tuna & Salmon Rolls from Delica in the Ferry Building, and while it wasn't quite as pretty IRL as it was in the pictures, it was good sushi. Love that it also came with a cup of miso soup. The only weird thing was that the rolls weren't cut, so I felt strange hacking them apart with plastic, standard-issue corporate break room cutlery. But I digress. TL;DR: Solid takeaway sushi. 

P.S. People of San Francisco MealPass, where should I be eating?
author: Shayna M.

description:
Came here to try the beef curry since a coworker recommended it. It's a great place to go to when it's a rainy day in SF and you want something both warm and filling. Went right during the lunch rush so the line was out the door but it went fairly quickly. 

I got the small beef curry and at first bite it was delish! The beef was tender and the rice was cooked perfectly. The only con was that it went by too fast. Definitely feel like they can give you more for what you pay since there was only around 4-5 chunks of meat in the curry. 

I have yet to try other things here, but they have an extensive menu.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Delica is a super convenient place to grab lunch if you work nearby! I work right across from the ferry building, and I love coming here. They have easy "grab-and-go" lunches such as rice bowls and bentos. If you are in a time constraint, this is the perfect choice. You just grab and go to the cashier and checkout. If you have time to wait in line, do try their salads and entrees! They have a variety of cold salads to choose from and tempura. If they aren't busy  you can also ask to sample their salads. One of the employees, Alison, let me sample all of their salads and explained what was in each one to me. My favorite salad is the mapo eggplant. Their beef curry is also worth a try. My favorite part about this place is the ice cream. Being the sweet tooth and matcha lover that I am, I can easily satisfy my matcha ice cream cravings here. However, it is a bit pricey for the portion sizes, but what can you expect frim the ferry building shops? Prices are going to be high because of the traffic they get from tourists and offices workers who work nearby.
author: Z C.

description: The middle aged Asian lady named codi was so rude.  After ordering curry I asked for water for my kids... she rudely got it and talked about us with her co worker.  Places like this makes it difficult to come back to.  She should not be placed in the front.  She should be in the back cooking with her attitude.
author: Shelly H.

description:
I must say the Assorted Sushi Bento is so cute! I've been dying to try, there are preset 9 items that can be sushi, salads or small dishes. I love the idea of just trying a bit of everything. Everything was delicious and presentation was on it's A game for sure.

I would definitely come back next time to try their sushi rolls and curry!

OH CASH ONLY. Had to walk to the ATM and get cash :D
author: Natalie L.

description: really nice spicy tuna rolls and some nice salads as well. and some yummy sweet beef with fried eggs and rice. Fast service
author: Philippe s.

description:
When I first came here the food was great. Medium size portions that involve salad (Hijiki seed weed is my favorite), chicken, pork, etc. They even had a dinner night. Don't know what happened to that.

Strike one was around Friday at 5pm, I was served cold to warm Japanese beef curry. I mean really. I get you are busy, but put it in the microwave or something. 

Final strike, I found a PLASTIC PEN CAP in my Hijiki salad! I told the manager about it, and didn't ask for anything else besides watch out when you serve this. I can't believe the quality of this place. Not my place to go any more.
author: Vinson H.

description: I only tried their pre made 9-item bento as it looked so good, but didn't like it at all. One of rolls smelled badly fishy, green beans were so old and thick that were basically unchewable. Only the meatball in the middle was okay, but still.. cold and hard.. Wanted to go to that place for a long time and was so disappointed. And that box plus a bottle of water were 20$, didn't worth even half of that. If you decide to give this place a try, get something from made-to-order menu.
author: Lena G.

description:
Came here for lunch around 12:30 on a Tuesday and suprisingly there was no line.  May have just missed the rush cause the line is usually out the door for their hot food. I took this opportunity to try their hot bar and got the Beef Curry over rice with a Tonkatsu (sold seperately).  The food here is delicious and well made. The curry was really good and although not top tier, holds its own with some of the other establishments in the city. The Tonkatsu was pretty good, but on the small side, but for under $2, it was a good side to add on,

One of my favorite things here is their Wasabi Potato salad.  It taste refreshing on a warm SF day as a potato salad should, but there is that kick of Wasabi that not only makes it more refreshing, but pretty cleanses the palate effectively.

You can also get the potato salad and other prepared bento boxes on a side line, which is usually much shorter.  These boxes are prepped everyday and are pretty good in quality if you just want to grab something really quick.

A tad on the pricey side, but on par with everything else in the Ferry Building price wise.
author: Veasna H.

description:
After eating lunch here with my boyfriend, I'm confused as to how Delica has kept its 4 star rating.

Lunch combo plate ($10.50):
- Chicken dumplings: Tasted good, but it only came with two and they were both cold, even though it's under the category of "hot food" :(
- Eggplant salad: Really good flavors. Comes with ground pork, which I enjoyed, but just a note for the vegetarians out there! Probably the best tasting part of our lunch.
- Salmon chowder: It was okay. Could have used more salmon, and the soup itself was a bit watery.

The large beef curry ($11) wasn't very large, and again, it was just okay--Not as flavorful as other Japanese curries that I've had. Tender beef chunks, but no potatoes, to my disappointment.

Overall, our lunch was good, but definitely not great. My biggest complaints were the cold chicken dumplings and the small portion sizes.
author: Sara L.

description:
If you have the Paypal app, make sure you clip the coupon. You can get $3-$4 off from this place if you pay through the app. What a steal!

Depending on what time you come, expect a line and a wait. Once the line circled to the place where they sell honey, took about 20 minutes until I got my food.

One thing I like about Delica is how fresh their food is. Everything here looks delicious however, the price puts you off. They sell ONE crab croquette for $4. ONE PIECE. Please just kill me. I usually get the lunch combo, Main, Salad, Soup, which is about $9.75.

My favorite so far is the Tofu salad. It does have a heavy cilantro taste (which I hate) but there's just something about that salad that is refreshing. I also always get the salmon chowder (It is $1 extra with the combo) because I love my chowder.

For Main items, anything fried is good haha. I've had the pleasure to try the crab croquette and the pork cutlet. Both were fried well and the insides were cooked nicely. I also tried their Japanese Beef Curry. I like how big the portion is for a regular $8.50. Taste was just ok... I think I will stick to the main items on display.

On regular days, I would not come here because of how pricey it is and the small portions. However, I will take advantage of the Paypal deal!
author: Benita M.

description:
Welcome 2015 with a new and healthy you.

Delica makes it easy to eat healthy going by way of organic, gourmet Japanese-California fusion style cuisine. What does this mean to you? a bit pricey for quality food that's really good for your body. Here's a local's tip: get the bento box for a cheaper lunch option!

The eggplant salad was so delicious! I wished she gave me a bigger serving though. I love the comforting warmth of their carrot-ginger soup, packed with beta-carotene which is essential for sharp eyesight and free radical repair. Ginger is a known aphrodisiac, so no other explanation needed ;-) 

Protein is necessary for building muscle and helps delay hunger pangs longer than simple carbs. The tofu-chicken patty is filling and tasty.  Supplement it with croquettes if you're looking for a fried treat. 

Don't be intimidated by the long lines, the staff are trained well in handling a busy lunch crowd. If it's a gorgeous day, sit outside and get some Vitamin D. How about that? All the essential nutrients you need with gorgeous bay views to boot? 

Cheers to a healthy you!
author: Janice C.

description: Since it's closer to the back door of the Ferry Building, I had never noticed this place before.  But craving Japanese food today, I decided to give this place a try.  This place offers quite a large variety of Japanese foods.  While the food/ingredients seemed better than your average Japanese restaurant, the price was also higher than I would have expected.  I ended up getting the beef curry and a shrimp croquette.  The beef curry was pretty tasty, above average compared to other Japanese curries you can find in the Bay.  There wasn't really a whole lot of beef in it though.  The shrimp croquette was more of the highlight for me here.  Loaded with lots of shrimp inside, it was very tasty.  I guess tartar sauce is the usual way to enjoy this with since it's what they offered me, but I requested tonkatsu sauce instead which I thought was probably better.  Also, regarding their pre-packed bentos, they were enticing, but for that price, I would almost expect it to be made fresh instead of buying something made earlier in the day, unless I was in a rush or something.  Overall, good spot in the Ferry Building if you're craving Japanese food, just a bit pricey.
author: Bryson L.

description:
We got fried chicken and my husband and I took a bite, it was undercooked and raw inside. We told the manager right away and she claimed it's cooked. It was raw chicken!!! Funny though she said she wouldn't eat it herself. Wow. 

Do not eat here! Raw chicken is not safe to eat!
author: H S.

description:
My two "in a pinch" meals when I'm at the Ferry Building consist of either a grilled cheese sandwich at Sidekick or a curry bowl at Delica. 

For $9.50/regular portion or $11.00/large portion I can get curry that can fill me up for at least a good portion of the day. If I get a large the portion size amounts to 2 meals. 
- Their to-go containers are durable and microwavable. 
- Their meat source is Prather Ranch, which also has a space in the Ferry Building. Their stew meat is some of the best meat I've had for beef curry.

I've had their beef and veggie bowls and though I prefer the meat curry I can recommend both bowls. The mushrooms are not too rubbery and can be as dense as a light meat and there's something to be said about those addicting lotus chips, which I can easily munch on by itself. The beef bowl has super-tender meat and potatoes absorbing the thick broth. The only reason for the 4 star is that the proportions are a little off - there is a good portion of rice even for small and the dish could use a little more meat. 

The best part about this curry is that it makes good leftovers when microwaved. This was a huge plus for those long study sessions back when I was a SFSU graduate student.
author: Isabella B.

description:
Oh, Delica.

Delica is like an impossible yet passionate mutual love. I know I love Delica with all of my heart, and Delica loves me, but due to geographical differences and career aspirations and all the other factors that come with a complicated love, we just can't be together.

But in the rare moments that we are together - it's magical. 

Whether we're at an airport or in the parking lot, if I have some Delica with me, I know I'll be having a great day. Your crispy croquette kisses and sweet gomae green beans. Your sultry hijiki salads and homey, familiar agedashi tofu. 

When I look at you, Delica, I feel like I'm home.
author: Sara C.

description:
I thought I had found the only curry I ever had when I went to Muracci's. Then I discovered Delica.

Delica is one of those really peculiar places. It's a Japanese deli nestled within a corner of the Ferry Building, rather unassuming and I hadn't found it until the last of my weeks in the area. 'Tis a shame.

I was craving curry, and Yelp led me here, just mere steps from the office. I got the large Beef Curry, which came at a pretty penny of about $11+. I had to say, it was simple, but it was just solid curry. No fancy bells and whistles, but it just tasted great. I only wish I had more bang for my buck, which I do get at Muracci's with the addition of a nice kick of spice.

The various fried food options look really interesting, and I've got to try those sometime. Hopefully I get a chance to swing by the Ferry Building sometime soon, since this is a real hidden gem.

TIP: Can't go wrong with the curry.
author: Brian L.

description:
They offer delicate and a variety of gourmet Japanese fused American delights!

Their croquettes were perfectly crisp and their wasabi potato salad was a delight to the senses. Their daily soup was homely and hit the spot.  The carrot ginger soup, cleansed the palate - especially the ginger.

I like how it is fresh and yet at the same time, ready to take to go!

It's a perfect combo lunch meal and not too heavy for you to not function afterwards.
author: Tiffany D.

description: gross! ordered the sweet chicken or something like it, it was so cold and parts were pink inside! came with rice and was an extremely small portion for 10 dollars. was not impressed, will not be back.
author: Hazel M.

description:
For a deli-like outfit, it was pretty good and actually exceeded my expectations. I had the combo #4 that was the Main Entree + Salad + Rice.

Having been a cool breezy day out in the water, I was hankering for some soul-soothing soup, so salmon chowder it had to be; and included a cup, I did.

The chowder was pretty good! Lightly creamy and not too thick nor watery. I loved the little chunks of potatoes and veggies in it. The occasional little chunks of salmon (but of course) was always a welcome interlude for the senses.

The rice was jasmine, with some black sesame seeds sprinkled over it. I liked the texture so I had nothing to complain about.

The sweet and spicy chicken was decent, even more so considering that it came out of a hot plate under a heat lamp. It was mildly breaded, as most generic Asian "sweet/spicy chicken" are served, with a touch of crunchiness.

The eggplant salad was what wowed me. I think it contained crumbled/scrambled tofu that gave the dish a minced meat-like texture. There were some noodles and cilantro, and something that gave it a nice umami flavour. I couldn't quite figure out what. It was somewhat like a baba ghanoush.

All in all, it hit the spot and I'd drop in for a quick bite the next time I'm hungry, and around the area looking to not strain my wallet too much (which is not to say it's cheap either, at $15 + tax for my meal including a bottled matcha tea latte).
author: Umesh T.

description:
I got the 4-item bento for lunch, which included 2 small salads (one with  hijiki, another that was advertised as burdock--I couldn't tell TBH), 3 pieces of saucy breaded chicken, and rice; as well as a shrimp and crab roll. The bento was $13 and the roll $11.25. 

If you want sushi, I highly recommend the shrimp and crab roll. The fillings are real and tasty, the natural sweetness of the shrimp really shines. 

I was more ambivalent about the bento. The chicken's breading was kind of soggy, which was unpleasant, and the chicken itself wasn't juicy or tender, though not excessively dry either. I didn't like the salad with hijiki, while the burdock salad was really strange both in texture and taste. Not the types of salads I'd order independently.
author: Elle E.

description:
My favorite time of the day, Lunchtime! I'm especially excited nowadays because I know San Francisco has a lot of food options to choose from. Not only that, the food is awesome! Today, we decided to visit the famous Ferry business for lunch. Strolling through this place, we came across an Asian joint and you know I'm always down for Asian food, so this was a no brainer!

When you walk into this joint, you're greeted with so many options! There's sushi, bento boxes displayed or items in glass casing that you can choose from. The staff is super efficient. They're take your order, have you walk through the stanchions and pay at the end of the line. The staff wasn't too personable, but they also weren't rude, so I was completely fine with this situation. Also, it was a super busy joint so a quick run through is needed to prevent holding up the line. 

For lunch, I just decided to get everything ala carte. Rice on a plate and then the following: 

-Crab Croquette for $4.00 each. Dungeness crabmeat blended with a creamy bechamel sauce, lightly breaded and fried. The dipping sauce was a dill tartar sauce. So delicious. The croquette was super creamy but didn't ooze out. the breading was super light and crispy. I also loved the flavor the dil tartar sauce brought. So awesome.

-Sweet and Spicy Chicken for $1.50 each. This was great! The chicken was marinated with sake, soy and ginger and then tossed in a sweet and spicy chili sauce. It was so flavorful! The chicken was juicy and not too spicy. 

-Pork Tonkatsu for $1.50 each. Breaded pork with panko and deep fried. Drizzled with homemade tonkatsu sauce. I loved the texture and flavor, however the tonkatsu was cold. I think that's the point of this place but I didn't really like the temperature of the meat. 

All in all, a fantastic place to visit for lunch. It's centrally located and the prices are reasonable. I'm definitely returning to this place in the future and if you're in the area, you should definitely check them out!!
author: Rockne H.

description: I had pretty decent beef curry here, but I've had better and cheaper Japanese curry elsewhere in the city. This is the kind of place that could really benefit from some atmosphere; the food is good enough on its own, but it's frustrating to try and find indoor seating (what else is new at the Ferry Building?), so it doesn't feel like the best option around. Still, a good selection of Japanese food if you don't mind wandering or are planning on getting the food to go anyway.
author: AJ P.

description:
love this little japanese joint - get a pre-made bento box or pick from the counter like at whole foods. 

$9.79 including tax: main + side + rice

// -- the food -- \\ 
- quality, tasty food that's affordable and allows you to mix-and-match what items you want. lots of healthy options, but also lots of fried options if you're feeling like you want to splurge
- options: bento boxes, don buri, onigiri, rolls, salads (rotating but hijiki, mushroom, etc), soups (rotating but miso, carrot ginger), etc.

// -- my food -- \\ 
- tofu/chicken patty: very delicious and flavorful, loved that they added hijiki inside for a different texture / taste
- sesame salad: hefty portions depending when you come. marinated and not drenched in that creamy white sauce that some places do. healthy + highly recommended
- rice: even the rice texture was great

will definitely have to come back
author: Kristie C.

description: pretty good for a Ferry Building grab n go. cooked Japanese-style bento box-ish. you pick combos of soup, salads and a main. most of the mains are fried (potato croquettes, crab, etc.) but are tasty. the salads are the best choices. soups are decent too. there aren't a lot of great value places to eat in the Ferry Building so for $15 or so, this isn't too bad. staff is weirdly unfriendly every time I've been there (6+ times). I wouldn't make a special trip to eat here, but if you're in the Ferry Building looking for something fresh and reasonably healthy, this is a okay.
author: Bob U.

description: I like their Kakiage Tempura and the hoji softserve ice cream (served when available).  The rest of the food looks good, but I haven't tried it.   Very convenient location as it's downtown and the view is great.  No place to sit inside, so I usually just go outside in the fresh air.
author: Roni K.

description: I went here because I got off the bart for a quick lunch when we spotted this place. Tried it out, overpriced food, also Salmon chowder was way to salty I don't know if we are the only ones. Also, when we got a new soup the person was extremely rude thinking we did not have taste. All in all overpriced food with food that "looks" good
author: Taerie K.

description:
I was walking in the Ferry Building with my husband on Saturday and we were hungry, this was a little before 3:30 pm. When we saw this place, we decided to just browse the display case. We ended up getting a potato Croquette ($1.75 each, prior to tax) & a fried shrimp cake ($4 each, prior to tax). Both were good and not really oily at all. But thought the price was a little expensive for these small little fried food items. Also the restaurant seating area was closed so we had to look elsewhere for seating. 

Service was just standard. I think overall, this place is just okay. But of course this was our first and only experience of this place, so I would be willing to give this restaurant another chance in the future.
author: Vic C.

description:
Ahhh.. This place is alright. Not really "DAMN I LOVE IT" but it also isn't "UGH THIS IS GROSS" either.

Located within the Ferry Building in the Embarcadero, you can find Japanese food being served here if you're in the mood for some sushi.

Came here once and ordered a bento box here. I like how unique the box looks, especially since this place works fast (since it gets busy here during the day). 

My box consisted of potato croquette, rice, taro salad, and something with greenbeans. Overall I would say that it was average at best. Not the most amazing thing ever, but not the worse.

There's a lot of seats outside, so sit there and take in the ocean on a sunny day!

Downside is that this place is a money-sucker. Upside is that it's near even more eateries lol.
author: Jerianne G.

description:
Don't let the lineup scare you off! It moves quick, and it's worth it -- you'll get a generous serving of Japanese goodies you can choose yourself. We had the veggie karaage (fabulous!), spicy chicken wings (yum) and really awesome sesame spinach. All really tasty, and a great meal to enjoy on the picnic benches outside.

The only downside is that even though our kids usually love Japanese food, there wasn't anything here that fit in their repertoire -- nothing plain enough (all rolls, no ngiri that I saw, and generally, not a lot of sushi). The miso soup went over OK but other than that, not really a great place to eat with kids.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
3.5 STARS

Fancy Japanese fast-food type deli counter. Bento boxes on the table & in the fridge display in the front if you want the pre-selected options and if you want to skip the line.
Pricey? It seems like it at first since the bento looks small, but I was surprisingly really full from the 5-item vegetarian bento ($10.25) Everything tastes gourmet and is definitely not something you can re-create easily at home, so  it is worth the price tag.

The only thing that knocks down the 1 stars for me is the the wait and checkout process. It's seemingly designed to be fast, however, you end up in the line to pay regardless. I came here at 12 on the dot and after picking up my item, still had to wait about ~7 minutes to pay which doesn't SEEM like that long, but there was only 5-6 people in front of me.. there's only one cashier and people can still order food when they're almost by the register. NOT EFFICIENT...
WHY DOES THE LINE GO SO SLOWWWWWWWW..................

Maybe it's not that bad during non-Farmer's-Market days - I've only been here on Thursdays, so I wouldn't know.

I was a noob the first time and got a few items a la carte. DON'T DO IT. Stick to the bento boxes and lunch sets for the best value. ($5.25 for one-two servings of wasabi mashed potatoes. Good but NOT WORTH IT @_@)

Wasabi mash: Light wasabi flavor but enough to get you going. A bit chunky just asI  like it, peas give a good sweetness to it and the slight bit of romaine lettuce gives it a good texture contrast. I personally wish it was a tad more savory/creamy though.

Hijiki (seaweed) & soybean salad: I personally didn't like it.. it's a little too 'healthy' feeling for me but I'm sure it's REALLY good for you.. Stick to small portions of this. This would probably be better if was mixed with kale or something. The sea-flavor was too intense for me and the texture got boring fast. Felt like my breath stank afterwards..

Burdock salad: still don't really know what this is but this was surprisingly good and healthy! Very light, fresh, and crunchy salad. This could also get boring fast though so the portion size in the bento was perfect.

Potato croquette: didn't expect this to be crunchy & it wasn't. Came with a baby BBQ sauce packet and it went well with the croquette. Just OK. Potato was cooked all the way through and seasoned well - it's probably better fresh!

Agedashi tofu: I forgot to dip this with the sauce when I ate it so I can't judge this fairly but the texture was good! 

Surprisingly my favorite was the green bean salad. It came with thinly julienned carrots and the light sesame/mayo dressing was SO good........

Definitely coming back to try more items next time!
They also have curry and soup here which seem to be worth trying as well.
author: Emily C.

description:
Actually pretty good. I've heard a lot of good things about Delica but remember being a little turned off when I walked by once because I tend to distrust Asian fusion and they had some crazy Japanese + Californian creation that made me a little worried. Decided to give it a shot today since I was in a rush and wanted something that I could just grab and go.

They've got a pretty expansive menu actually. There're combo variations such as main + salad + rice, main + salad + soup, main + salad + salad, etc. Then they have about 10 options listed under each category so you can basically mix and match your own bento boxes essentially. They've also got a couple donburis and other options as well. I went with pork katsu and mabo tofu salad with rice and also grabbed a salmon onigiri. Quick pro tip: if you don't really know what you're getting yourself into just from reading the menu, just look at the displays since they have all the mains in the display -- e.g. I originally thought about chicken dumplings but then saw that they looked more like chicken meatballs

Overall, the food didn't look that amazing, but it was actually pretty good -- would definitely come back. Pork katsu was just pork katsu, pretty typical -- they had the sauce drizzled on it, but the mabo tofu was pretty solid. It looked a little gimpy and not delicious but actually tasted SO good. A little citrusy, very flavorful, and just a salad with tofu, glass noodles (forgot what they're exactly called in English... but the clear noodles basically) and lettuce. It actually complemented the katsu really well since it offset the heaviness of it. I really dug it. The portion size was also pretty good since it kept me full after a long day of walking around pride festivities and was only priced around $8 or so which I thought was a great bargain.

The salmon onigiri was a bit disappointing so I would probably pass on that. But besides that, the service was pretty friendly, they were really efficient, and it was a really solid deal. I'd definitely be coming here for lunch all the time if I worked near here.

tldr; japanese food meets california -- have some faith, even if the food sounds weird it might be pretty good!
author: Jasmine X.

description:
You know, I love their food. I really do. But the lunch specials they give so little food that makes me so sad. Are they underestimating the amount of food I can eat? Of the couple times I've been and ordered the lunch combo with entree and salad and things, I've only had one server that gave me enough food to eat. I'm thinking next time, I'll order their curry again because that meal is usually filling and hearty. 

All complaints about the portions aside, I really like their eggplant salad and their chicken dumplings. I was weary at first because I thought I was getting one tiny little chicken meatball but you actually get two. Yay! I also recently tried their salmon chowder, which was pretty good, too. 

Really tempted to take a star off for the portion size... but I really am a fan of their food, so four stars it is.
author: Sara T.

description:
We were having lunch at the Ferry Building and I figured I should at least try to order from a place I had not eaten at before. I had not heard much about Delica, but decided to give it a shot. 

I chose a prepackaged "Spicy Tuna" roll. It was around $12 and loaded with fish. It was simple, yet tasty, and fresh. I don't remember how many pieces there were, but the pieces themselves were large. There was also a generous amount of avocado.

Casual environment, clean restaurant, and friendly service.

I really enjoyed my meal and will be back to try their crab croquettes & soups.
author: Nelya T.

description:
MAYBE ITS JUST ME...
(2 stars) 

But I wasn't feeling this place.

FOOD, meh
PRICES, decent
SERVICE, fast 
AMBIANCE, cafe style 

HEFER STATS. 

Exploring new grounds, don't come here often and I see why!! I regret to inform myself, I wasted money. 

SALMON CHOWDER ($4/cup) - sounds delicious, doesn't it. Well it's just ok. I got excited seeing all the orange pieces of salmon floating in my chowder only to realize it's carrots. I was lucky to he 3 pieces of tiny salmon meat. Not all bites had salmon and the chowder wasn't rich (unless you get a salmon piece). AND it doesn't come with bread. 

HIJIKI RICE BALL ($2) - uhm don't buy something cause it looks pretty. Because it's not tasty. Smells like tofu and tastes LIKE HAY!!!! I can barely consume it without me saying to myself "wff". 

Will I be back? NO. 

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description: Super fun fast casual "Japanese-y" food, great value.  Selection is large and good.  Take out to common dining area or take it to the Wine Bar and order a glass, carafe, or bottle. Salads, soups and mains for $11.  Loved it and portions were large.
author: Christopher Z.

description:
Typically Delica is quite busy during the weekly lunch rush.  Luckily there is a spectrum of grab-n-go options to speed up the ordering process.  

Today I went with an actual custom order.  The #1 meal deal offers a main (these are pretty small) + salad + soup or salad.  I went with the chicken dumplings, Spicy Burdock and Lotus Roots Salad, and Hijiki and Soybean Salad.  Total lunch deal was around $10.  The dumplings were actually more like large meatballs without a doughy dumpling-style outer layer.  The salads were delicious and very original.  

Again, the grab-n-go options are great for a quick meal to go. The warm dishes tend to be lukewarm.
author: Andrea H.

description:
Eating healthy is a priority for me. Eat well feel good :) Eat bad stuff feel bad :(

Delica has some wonderful cold salads that are all vegetarian or have a little bit of meat. They also have hot dishes and sides so you have a variety of choices.

I think their lunch plates are the best deal at the Ferry Plaza especially on a busy Saturday market day.

Some of the salads are:
Chicken salad - slices of chicken with celery, carrots, turnip marinated in a vinagrette sauce
Eggplant salad - big chunks of sauteed eggplant with a little puree of pork
Hijiki salad - Japanese dish with black seaweedy looking vegetables
Burdock salad - brown strands of burdock which seems like daikon

I also enjoy the Tempura soba, croquettes, salmon rice ball and sweet and sour chicken chunks. 
Tasty and good for you food!
author: Joanna T.

description:
Bento box for $13+ is a rip off. It used to be $10 not worth it anymore.

I will never come back here and wouldn't recommend it to anyone.
author: Sahil B.

description:
A decent place for quick Japanese style bentos and sushi rolls. If anybody has been to Lemonade in LA, this is like a Japanese style Lemonade. Healthy (but pricey!).

The food isn't cheap, but my spicy tuna roll ($10.25 for 5 pieces) was PACKED with fish. I also apreciate the generous serving of avocado in my roll.

Cons: Because my roll was prepacked and ready to go in the fridge, the rice was a little hard. And the rolls are big, but they were so hard to eat... it'd be better if we got smaller sizes but more pieces.
author: Andrea L.

description:
I don't see how this restaurant garnered 4 stars - the food sat in a deli case and even hot items were cold and tasted like they sat in the case for an hour. The service at the counter is also bordering on rude and the taste of the food is on the lower end of what others in the ferry building produce. 

While it is reasonably priced, we tried the crab croquettes, salmon roll, chicken dumplings, sweet and spicy chicken and the ginger beef. Each sounded great on the menu and could have tasted good if it were warm and fresh. This restaurant is a disgrace to Japanese restaurants which pride themselves in freshness of food served.
author: Rohit P.

description: came to this spot for lunch yesterday with a friend - maybe my 3rd time here. there are so many options it's a little overwhelming! there is a purely to-go line with bento boxes and the like, and then a line for the salads and other stuff. there are a few options for lunch combinations - salads, soup, rice, main, etc.  i got a combo of three salads - corn, green bean, and mabo tofu. they were pretty yummy, but very saucy and definitely not as healthy as i would have liked. there's seating right outside delica, but i would choose some of the outdoor seats by the water :)
author: Christina L.

description: There were so many interesting dishes on the menu so I just went with the suggestion of the person at the cash counter and I  ordered the lunch menu with the Hijiki and Soybean Salad + Salmon Chowder Soup + Crab Croquette . Also ordered the Matcha Green tea ice cream which was very refreshing and different from the usual ice creams because of the after taste of green tea.
author: Anand S.

description: Food was mediocre and the cashier (older Asian lady) was super rude. Not sure about this place to come back a second time.
author: Clarissa M.

description:
One of my very favorite places to dine solo in the immediate Embarcadero area, DELICA never fails. I sometimes find myself eating here a few nights in a row when I'm in town on business (and need some downtime/alone time). 

Their daily happy hour (until 7pm) isn't particularly strong on the booze, but is incredibly generous when it comes to food specials. Different features daily, the happy hour menu is almost too good to be true. You can have a gourmet feast and a couple of beers (and enough food for 2) for $25. 

The ingredients are insanely fresh. The food takes a bit of time to get to you --but this tells you that the staff puts great care into making what you've ordered. Every item I've had I've loved and I can't wait to be back. 

Excellent service, too.
author: Mark M.

description:
Tiny portions and everything good is extra.
A typical tourist tap. The salad is okay, the chowder is thin, small and $3 extra. The sushi tool is pathetic. Avoid this place and get the empanada instead.
author: A S.

description:
Japanese quick-service deli. As of June '16, Vegan options are limited to just a few items: the agedashi tofu, the spicy burdock salad, the hijiki soybean salad, and the avocado roll.

Delicious nonetheless! My go-to vegan lunch option in the Ferry Building.
author: Andrew H.

description: Love this place! I often go here for lunch and have been pleased with everything I've tried. Service has always been good and the food is worth the wait during the lunch rush. Would recommend the roasted green tea soft serve on a warm day!
author: Skye L.

description:
Probably the worst sushi experience I've had in this city.

Ordered this on UberEats today and ordered the Shrimp/crab roll. It was a disappointing 5 pieces of sushi that were 80% of rice. I mean the pieces of crab were wrapped TWICE with rice. that's a sushi no-no in my books.

Avoid if you can and definitely don't spend the exorbitant money I did for a lousy dish. I even asked for a refund and have not heard back...

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description: This is one of my favorite places in the Ferry Building. I love getting the combos for lunch - rice + agedashi tofu + hijiki salad is my go-to. I love their fresh take on Japanese cuisine.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Stopped by on a blustery day and went right to the menu where I saw carrot-ginger soup and tempura kaki-age (vegetables & shrimp battered & fried into a compact shape) listed. That seemed like a perfect choice for lunch outdoors along the Embarcadero. Skateboarders, pedal carts, runners and tourists flew by while I enjoyed my delightful lunch for under $15. 

TIP:  This Japanese deli also does catering. If you're in the vicinity of the Ferry Building, this restaurant/buffet offers some delightful selections, a real foodie adventure.
author: Lynn S.

description: Wtf.  Typically really like the main and salad options but today,  my hijiki seaweed salad came with a ROCK inside it. Yes, a ROCK! Bit hella hard into it but good thing I have strong teeth.  Going to call manager abt this asap but be aware and chew at your own risk!  See uploaded photo for size which is abt the size of a penny wide.
author: Ben M.

description: The only reason this place gets one star is because the roast beef sushi was unique and pretty good. If not for that, I would've given it zero stars. We asked for recommendations and everything we ate was inedible. I threw $17 in the garbage. I will never come back here and wouldn't recommend it to anyone.
author: Alexis Q.

description:
Even though I've worked by the Ferry Building for nearly two years, last week was the first time that I've been to Delica.  And I went back again yesterday as well!  My friend had to explain to me the whole ordering process at this busy deli in the Ferry Building.  It was a little overwhelming at first, especially because it gets so busy during the lunch rush.  She even got one of the ladies to give me a sample of one of their salads.  I went with the #4, which is a salad + main + rice ($7.75).  Everything looked so good, but I finally decided on the asparagus salad & the tofu & chicken patty.  The portions are actually pretty good, I thought they were going to be teeny tiny.  

I loved it all!  The asparagus was cooked perfectly and came with shredded carrots and the yummiest creamy dressing.  The tofu & chicken cake was pretty hefty.  It was free-range chicken and organic tofu formed in a patty with seaweed with a sweet soy glaze.  The rice was standard white rice with some black sesame seeds topping it.

On my second trip I got the #4 as well and went with the mapo tofu salad & the tonkatsu.  The tonkatsu was excellent; they use ACME for the breading & it isn't greasy at all.  I didn't care too much for the mapo tofu salad, it was mixed with vermicelli and lettuce.  Maybe because I was thinking of Chinese mapo tofu which I like?  I also had a bite of the Kaki-age last week, which was very tasty as well, though hard to cut.  

I like how Delica uses local and organic ingredients.  Although they offer a significant amount of fried things on the menu, it's a good option for a healthy lunch for decent prices in the FiDi.
author: Cat C.

description: What can I say I've been coming here on and off for 12 years and never got the chance to review this wonderful place until now. A japanese deli that serves the best beef curry, croquets, and sushi. The roast beef sushi is delicious and the fried shrimp and crab cakes served with tartare sauce is too.
author: N A.

description:
RUDE RUDE RUDE EMPLOYEES!.  Counter guy was extremely rude to a member in my party and refused to serve her.  We were together, but for some reason, he wouldnt serve her and asked her to go to the end of line.
Then ,when i asked him why he was so rude to her, he wouldnt answer me, and when i persisted, he said "NOTHING!"  (he snapped that word at me)
We spoke to the manager, and he defended him.  He knew how long she was waiting, because he had served me and was waiting for the other members of the party to be served in order to bill us.  We were surprised he wasnt managerial.
LIED ABOUT QUALITY OF FOOD!.  They assured us the item was fried 5 minutes ago.  After we bought it, we realized it was cold and not crispy.
