QUALITY OF FOOD HAS GONE DOWNHILL.  Aside from all the unpleasant experience, my Japanese friend who frequents Delica noticed that the quality has been going steadily downhill.
author: Irene K.

description:
Salad and main combo is the way to go!!

Get the crab croquette - it's filled with crab and perfect with their dipping sauce.
Get the mapo tofu salad. Not quite a 'salad salad', as it's filled with chunks of meat and tofu, but definitely tasty!

Great price + fast.
author: Michelle L.

description:
3.5 For the concept and flavors. There's a wide variety of choices, however it's all premade! The food sits in the display, under warmers, so it didn't taste fresh or warm.

The flavors are good and unique. I would definitely recommend you try this place if you're in the area. The prices are decent, but I expected more portions. The combo box is basically one scoop of each item. Pretty much a cafeteria, but it's fast if you're short on time!
author: Diem N.

description: Love the food here, and have been coming for years. I usually order the three salad combo of burdock, hijiki, and potatoes wasabi. But the portion sizes have taken a nose dive. They've always been hit or miss but for $11 there was maybe 3/4 of an inch of salad in a to go container that's 4 inches deep.
author: Rich O.

description: The food looks pretty unique and healthy a bit here. Their crab croquettes are hecka good, but their shrimp cake is salty. All their batter and tempura items are crunchy and thin!
author: Tina R.

description:
I go here primarily for the ginger beef bowl. It's a pretty simple dish but ever so tasty (I'd rate it 5/5, easily). It consists of flavorful ground beef on top of scrambled eggs, over white rice and adorned with chopped chives. It always hits the spot and as a runner, it's one of the few dishes that my body genuinely appreciates. I feel energized and I run better when I eat it :D. 

Tip: don't settle for one of the (most likely) lukewarm bowls from the pickup stand; ask them to make it fresh (and hot!). The ginger beef bowl is much better that way. 

Their goma-ae (Japanese-style spinach salad with sesame dressing) is decent enough that I usually order it alongside the ginger beef bowl because it's such a healthy option, but it really could be much more flavorful. 

The umami levels are too weak. I can make a better one myself and have many times, but more often, I'm just lazy and want a serving of a veggie to go along with the beef ginger bowl. The rest of their salads are tastier but not as healthy as the goma-ae. I sometimes order a more flavorful salad and then mix it up with the spinach salad and that actually works pretty well. 

Delica's beef curry is very good and worth trying but not great. Rintaro has the very best version of Japanese-style beef curry that I've ever eaten although it's not always available; Murracci's is also better than Delica's version, in my opinion, anyway. 

When I was less health-conscious, I used to order the potato croquettes at Delica. Very tasty and came with a packet or two of delicious tonkatsu sauce (though sometimes I had to specifically request the sauce).
author: Maya B.

description: Love this deli whenever I go to the ferry building. A little pricey but all the food choices are delicious and prepared in such an appetizing manner.  Previously prepared to go items are conveniently placed to that you can purchase and get out quickly if needed. My friends and I like to come here before Giants games to purchase our meals before going to the ballpark. Today's cashier was a bit snooty but otherwise it was a positive experience.
author: Lorraine L.

description: Based on the photos and prior reviews, I was excited to try the 9 item bento. Loved that there was variety but everything fell below my expectations. The pieces of sushi were dry while the small bits of salad were almost the same w/ very few distinguishable ingredients. Ordered the shrimp cake, crab croquette and 3 chicken dumplings. While the shrimp cake and crab croquette were equally enjoyable w/ the deliciously moist filling, we both didn't like the chicken  dumpling. Not only did it not look like a dumpling, I just couldn't find anything that is worth $2+/piece...especially the flavor. We also shared a miso soup and the salmon chowder but the portion was ultra small for a bowl size at $7.50. Flavors were "just ok".
author: Julie L.

description:
Delica is a Japanese deli located in the Ferry Building.  They have pre-packaged and make your own bento boxes.  You can also buy individual items by the piece or weight.

I always get the bento boxes when I go there.  You can choose from 4 ($9.75 - 1 fried, 2 salads, rice), 5 ($9.75 - 3 salads, half shrimp cake, 1 chicken dumpling) or 9 ($11.00 - 5 salads, 3 salmon, 1 chicken dumpling) items. 

 I typically get the 4 item bento box:

Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad - This potato salad looks bizarre, but is super delicious.  The wasabi mayo in it is so good!  It also has edamame and snap peas in it.

Green Bean Salad - comes with a sesame dressing and is really good as well.

For the fried item, I usually get the chicken dumpling or the tonkatsu.

There's usually a line here, but it goes fast.  They have plenty of  seating.  A nice lunch option if you are in the area.
author: Tanya C.

description:
I was looking for a light meal with a friend and found this place in the ferry building. It's nice and from one side, you can sit and watch the water.
My friend an I enjoyed the happy hour offerings that Delica had.

The daily special, which changes everyday was the seafood salad, with which you can order the spicy sauce. It was tossed greens with chunks of fresh tuna and other cooked seafood. It was a tasty seafood salad, but the dressing it came with didn't really taste like anything. The spicy sauce also wasn't too spicy but didn't really add to the salad. The salad did come with a bowl of white rice which made the meal more filling. 

You can order a MAX of two smaller dishes, but ONLY when you also order the special. We ordered the mini chicken karaage and organic edamame. The chicken strips were juicy and very crispy on the outside. The edamame I had here was probably the best edamame I've had. The beans were big and it wasn't too salty. They were really good. 

It was light meal and surprisingly filling.
author: Kristy K.

description: I got food poisoning from here.  I ordered two sides of salad and the chicken dumplings.  Shortly after eating I got food poisoning and was sick for 24 hours.  The food is left sitting out into the late afternoon.  I won't be risking going back to Delica.
author: Tashie P.

description:
Where's the BEEF?


Everything looked really good.  I had a paypal deal, so that brought me here.  The beef curry looked good.  The serving size was decent.  Either I got unlucky with the scoop of curry that I got, or they really need to step up their beef selection process.  

First of all, I barely got any beef, but out of the pieces I got, some were all fat and others were primarily fat.  :(  that sort of sucked.

The fried add ons seemed pretty pricey for what you get, they had all different types of fried croquettes that you could add.  They looked good and I was tempted, but it just didn't seem worth it.

The rice was also sort of on the gummy side, but maybe I was unlucky with that too.

The food was really on the 2 star side, but the paypal deal sort of bumped it up to 2.75.

I'll give them another try and update my review and chalk this up to an off day for now.
author: Ty C.

description:
After filling my bags with wholesome, fresh, organic vegetables, I'll stop by Delica to pick up a bento box for lunch.  

They offer a variety of salads (burdock and lotus roots and the wasabi garlic potato are my favorites), rice bowls, soups, sushi and deep fried meats, seafood and vegetables.  Bento boxes contain samples of the salads, sushi and fried items.  

Although the prices are a tad high, the ingredients are fresh and flavorful.   I've never been disappointed with my meals here.  You are paying for the quality of the food, location, their attention to detail around the preparation of their dishes.

My only wish is that they offered greater variety in their dishes from time to time.  Or, I just need to pop in for dinner instead of just lunch.
author: Melissa L.

description: I love Delica! Whenever I'm near the Ferry Building, I try to find an excuse to stop by and get a bite. I love their lunch combinations. There are so many choices that you can get whatever you want. They have several salads and mains to choose from, and a couple of soups too. I like the main + salad + salad combo. So healthy too!
author: Sherry L.

description:
A Japanese influenced light meal eatery that is interesting.  Guess you must be good enough to survive/thrive in the Ferry building.

I had #4, salad, main dish, and rice.  For that I had Hijiki & Soybean Salad, Kagiage Tempura.  The salad was delicious, sauced with light and sharp Japanese sauce that has a hint of teriyaki.  The tempura has Kagiage (fried vegitable) on the bottom and topped with Tempura shrimps.  I felt it slightly chewier than I like, but very well flavored.  The rice from a Japanese restaurants are always a treat and this one did not disappoint.  I ate the to-go box while watching ferries come and go.  Very cool.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description:
Love their create your own bento idea! 2 salads, one fried item and rice. 
My favorite is the crab croquette (& tartar sauce!), green bean with creamy sesame dressing and hijiki salad!!

Their carrot ginger soup is a great way to get your veggie intake too! Would give them 5 stars if they only had brown rice...!
author: Amber S.

description:
Great selection of Asian-inspired salads.  You can get three salads for about $9 for lunch - great deal!

I've tried several of the entree dishes, but generally haven't been impressed.  They're relatively expensive - you'll get two chicken dumplings or three pieces of chicken - literally - you pay by the piece.  I'd recommend sticking to the salads.

Get your food to go and eat outside behind the Ferry Building for a great view of the Bay.
author: Greg B.

description:
February 2012 monthly special - 
Beef Steak Donburi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xlXnPitrO9Mjfq3aPAyNVQ?select=a6YzoFiG3yGC9lHz-Ujz-g) ($9.50) - Tender slices of marinated, medium-rare Filet Mignon on a bed of rice and assorted greens (think salad).  The amazing part... there is no heavy sauce or gray!  All of the flavor comes from the meat marination, though some meat pieces were a bit veiny.
Store hours also changed from weekday 10 am opening time to 11 am.
Give this one a try; I will again before the end of the month!
author: Mike C.

description:
I had a large beef curry. As a Japanese, I can say it's authentic. 
I didn't try but other Sozai looked quite authentic and as if I was in the famous department stores in Shinjuku or Ginza.
The reason not 5 stars is it's pretty pricy. Curry and rice plate is very daily meal in Japan and should not be pricy and fancy.
author: Kaori M.

description:
If you have ever wondered what home cooked Japanese food tastes like, this is it! 

I'd have to say that after going over to my Japanese friends' house for a number of dinners and doing a homestay in Japan, I might know a thing or two... Not much, but a bit. 

The meal I got brought back lots of memories of combining things that you might think don't go together , but end up being great! 

Don't go into it looking for the typical lunch special you find at most places. Just think of delica as being your mom going into the kitchen, grabbing the seasonal vegetables and preparing it in a creative way, and sending it all with you in a bento for school.

The green bean salad was a surprise fav. I felt a little worried for some reason... But it was creamy and delicious. I also loved the use of takenoko and celery in another salad! I got to sample the wasabi potato salad and regretted not grabbing some. Definitely going back!
author: Natalie C.

author: Oliver W.

description: I just saw the picture of the beef stew that is on this site. The real beef stew that you are served is potato stew. There was one cube of the "grass feed beef" that I really wanted. The one cube I had was fantastic. But one cube of beef for 11.00 plus dollars does not make sense to me. I also had the chicken tofu cake. Hard as a rock. I did go back to show them my potato stew...the nice woman gave me a few more pieces. The server actually took a long time  to fish out the beef from the vat, the chef even had trouble finding some meat. I guess the tourists are taken advantage of....cheat them...they probably will not be back anyway.
author: Flim S.

description:
One of the many food options in the Ferry Building. Kind of pricey and definitely wouldn't be one of my go-to places for Japanese as it's more Japanese/Asian fusion, but it's quick and pretty tasty. Most of the sushi is rather simple - nothing special or particularly memorable, but it's fresh and still good. I love the SMOKED SALMON and ROAST BEEF (yes, beef on sushi is odd but it's good!). Aside from sushi, they have various salads, soups, curry and deli items like shrimp cakes and tonkatsu. Their BEEF CURRY is delicious and my favorite salad is the SPICY BURDOCK & LOTUS ROOTS

====================

-SPICY BURDOCK AND LOTUS ROOTS SALAD - 5/5
If you love crunchy foods like I do, then this is the perfect salad for you! There's lotus roots and celery to make it crunchy and the dressing is nice and light. It's not actually spicy though

-ROAST BEEF SUSHI - 4/5
I oddly enough liked this. I thought it was strange to have beef sushi, but the beef was cooked well (medium rare) and I liked the hint of wasabi

-JAPANESE STYLE BEEF CURRY - 4.5/5
Really tender beef! The curry is pretty flavorful with a touch of sweetness

-HIJIKI AND SOYBEAN SALAD - 3.5/5
Interesting salad because of the hijiki seaweed but the flavors or texture weren't that memorable.

-SMOKED SALMON & VEGETABLE ROLL - 3.5/5
I only enjoyed this because I really like salmon. Otherwise, it's pretty average.

-CHICKEN DUMPLING WITH SWEET CHILI SAUCE - 2/5
The word "dumpling" is pretty misleading as this is definitely not remotely close to being a dumpling. They're really giant meatballs. Okay, but not memorable. I'd pass on these.

-SWEET & SPICY CHICKEN - 2/5
Ehhh.. not terrible, but I wouldn't get this again. Think sweet and sour chicken from Panda Express.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Californian-inspired Japanese deli catering to the lunchtime working crowd. It's a healthy and fast option for lunch, offering a mix of bento boxes, sushi rolls, salads, croquettes, soups, and noodle dishes. Everything I've had here if flavorful, tasty, and very filling. I always get combo #2, which is 2 salads+salad or soup, and at just under $10, a good lunch option.

I usually get the burdock salad, sesame spinach, eggplant nasu or mabo tofu salad. Tofu patty and crab croquette are also good add-ons.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Like this place! The food is fresh and the beef curry is really tasty! Service is a little slow, but I'm not sure if it's just the customers or if it's the staff. 

The grab and go option is so convenient. There are many options to choose from (especially if you arrive prior to 12pm). 

Great location in the ferry building. Seating indoors and outdoors is communal.
author: Ameera D.

description:
Came here for dinner on a random Friday night.  Located in the pier 2 building, the place was pretty empty.  We were promptly seated when we got there.  

Portions were very small for how much each dish costs.    And they didn't have siracha!!
3 of us ordered 6 items to share.  
1) Delica roll:$13  these were very solid rolls but there were only 5 pieces.  
2) tuna roll:$7  meh... 6 tiny pieces
3) eel roll: $7 meh
4) karagee:  I'd highly recommend it.  A lot of batter tho
5) curry seafood soup: my favorite.  very small bowl but it was very unique.  Highly recommend it.  

We ended up spending about $60 (inc tax and tip) and felt satisfied.
author: Kay L.

description:
I have to update my review because it appears Delica changed their packaging for take-out, so the presentation problem is solved.  Looks like recyclable plastic (similar to other takeout container materials).    

The food is solid deli takeout, as always.  Easy to find wheat-free here because there's so much more rice than wheat.  In the interest of 'continuous improvement' only, the most recent tonkatsu nugget was slightly overcooked and the mayo-sesame seed ratio on the green bean salad could be adjusted
author: Jaina S.

description:
Not sure how I missed this place in the ferry building for the past 3 years. Almost embarrassing. 

I can appreciate their existence in the ferry building - provides more variety amongst the  pricey sambos at cowgirl creamery/sidekick, acme and boccalone. 

Spinach and seaweed salad - yum! Could be a little more flavorful/sesame flavor heavier. Pabu's is phenomenal!

I thought the chicken and tofu patty was pretty bland. I'm curious to try the tofu steak and chicken dumplings next time. 

It's nice that they have to go bentos you can pick up and go as well as a pretty flexible bento menu of options and ways to pick and choose. 

First experience was okay, but definitely worth another try.
author: Melody T.

description:
I don't know why I even came in here... I mean Japanese food I am all in but this place
is meh! To clarify I only tried the cooked items on the far right of the restaurant. I tried the sweet/sour chicken  , crab croquette, Chicken dumpling w/side of rice. All items were cold not just a little cold ...real cold! Threw it away to be honest, they have better chicken at Safeway to go. The customer service was horrible the asian lady kept getting frustrated with customers.
author: T. C.

description:
Feeling very drained and hungry, I decided to walk to the ferry building to nourish my body. After checking out all the shops, I decided some soup from Delica would be amazing. 

When I was asked for my order, I responded the soba noodle soup. To my response, two employees proceeded to say "OH MY GOSH!" and then left the counter...30 seconds roll by and another employee asks if we have been helped and I tell her that I am going someplace else. 

Life is too short to aid yuppies dealing Japanese food. Fuck this pretentious place.
author: Ted S.

description:
A delightful Japanese-California fusion with bento boxes and salads in amazing twists.

I came here during lunch hour so we had one of those grab and go boxes which was decent enough. Unfortunately, I'm not a big fan of this kinda fusion and would very much prefer traditional Japanese instead.

I'll probably return again since the food isnt bad :)
author: Christina N.

description:
Ordered from Delica for catering and it was pretty awesome. Do note that they have a 5% presentation fee.

Essentially, there are few things more astounding than getting BUCKETS of Japanese curry delivered to your workplace. The platter of croquettes was beautiful, but I guess that a bucket of curry can only be so fancy. The truth of the matter is that Japanese curry is beautiful in itself, and I think they just knew that. The main problem is that I only wanted 2 pounds of salad, sure that no one would be so vegetarian that they'd only eat salad...but the lady was absolutely sure that I would need 5 pounds of salad. Next time, I will rely on my salad math and think, "Okay, at Whole Foods, when I go to the salad bar, I usually get way under 0.5 pounds of salad. Way under. And that's only because mine wasn't just lettuce. There are 3-4 vegetarians. That's about 2 pounds of salad. Done."

Anyway, so that's just a cautionary tale on how to order for catering. Delica is fantastic and has some damn good curry. The croquettes were absolutely my favorite. The chicken katsu was a LOT smaller than I thought it would be. I'm used to getting those huge cuts from Japanese restaurants, but these are maybe the size of 3-4 McNuggets. Not very big. I should've cut down on the salad and ordered about 20 more pieces of that, because that was gone in a flash despite there being meat in the curry (and some were veggie curries). All in all, it was a good experience, but I'm more likely to eat there on my own than go again for curry. For a small group of around 30, that was not the best experience, and I ended up going way over budget after I included the tip. But food-wise, it was delicious - my guests were all basically in love with the comforting flavors of the curry.
author: Robbin A.

description:
Not particularly sure what the hype about this place is.  I've been here more than a few times, and the only way I can guarantee that I'm not hungry still is if I order two or three items because the portion size is small for how much you pay for it.  That said, I do have to note the quality of the ingredients here is pretty top-notch.

The Japanese beef curry is pretty good and one of the few items worth coming back for.  Pork cutlet isn't too bad.  I question if the fried shrimp cake is really worth $4 a pop, but at least it is actually stuffed with shrimp so I can make a pass on that.  The roast beef sushi IS worth coming back for, if only because you don't really see too many places sell that.

Overall, it's a decent lunch spot, but nothing more than that.
author: Alexander Y.

description:
If I could give 0 stars I would. Today was my second time trying this place based on a recommendation. The first time was OK. The line wasn't long, they moved people through quickly and the food wasn't terrible. I would have given them 3 maybe 4 stars for that visit. 

Today was a different story. The person helping me seemed like I was inconveniencing her. The portion size was almost half of what i received my first visit. After taking two bites of rice i noticed something strange. There was something long and black in my rice and it wasn't a grain of wild rice. I picked the rice apart to find a really long black hair. Immediately I wanted to throw up. The manager while he understood the situation and refunded my money didn't seem to care much. Wasted my entire lunch dealing with this. 

Avoid at all costs
author: David G.

description:
One of the best bento boxes I've had so far. 

- Spinach and Sesame Salad: Pretty straightforward, but cooked in dashi broth.

- Spicy Burdock and Lotus Root Salad: Loved this. It's a mix of so many veggies; there's also konnyaku, onions, celery, carrots, and other greens tossed in there. Everything is thinly sliced, crunchy, light, and flavorful.

- Fried Shrimp Cake: You know the kind where it's all breading and there's only a few tiny pieces of shrimp inside? NOT the case here. Instead, the entire block is shrimp and covered in very thin crispy panko. Yum.

Being a person who prefers eating meat over veggies, I was surprised I liked this place more than usual, and I think that says a lot. Ingredients are high quality and fresh!
author: Jen P.

description:
Reminds me a lot of Tangerine in Berkeley, as something of a fancy and mostly healthy lunch deli that specializes in a certain type of food, Japanese in this case.

I had the chicken patty which was quite good along with some seaweed salad and salmon chowder. I also liked that you could get tiny pieces of kind of expensive ($1.50) tonkatsu which is quite tender and tasty. This is nice cause I often want a bite or two of katsu but don't necessarily want to eat a whole pork chop for lunch.
author: Misha T.

description:
This is a fancy Japanese sushi/tapas place located in the Ferry Building.  The decor feels very American, with the exposed kitchen and the pots and pans, and the high bar tables.

The food here is all about being organic and sustainable.  The menu is interesting to read because they tell you where the food comes from.  I am still not used to this kind of text in a menu so I read the text with mild interest but it's not like I eat the meal in peace or anything.

The duck sashimi was rather tasty.  I don't see duck sashimi in many places but when I do, I usually try to get it!

The tempura dish was a little bit of a letdown since they included a lot of vegetables that aren't typically included in a tempura dish.  They had some crazy mushrooms deep fried in tempura, and I am not a fan of mushrooms.

The miso soup was decent although a bit steep at $3 for a small bowl.  Usually this comes free of charge (included) at most Japanese places.

Their menu is not that extensive in terms of entrees - this place is definitely a tapas/sushi place so don't come here expecting to order chicken teriyaki.

Service was fine although why do restaurants insist on extremely small water glasses?
author: Danielle C.

description:
Great little Japanese delicatessan tucked near the end of the Ferry Market building.  

I always grab a bento box of their "sozai". Each box contains a lovely assortment of rolls and vegetable salads.  Perfect for snacking!
author: Hieu H.

description: We lunched here after browsing the entire Ferry Building market.  The food, while mostly microwaved to re-heat, was really tasty and reasonably priced.  We split a meal, my wife had curry soup, and we also split a couple of chicken appetizers (the apps were fantastic).  They've got ample community seating inside.  Definitely a good place at the market.
author: Tim L.

description:
Just a couple of nights ago, I decided to give Delica's sushi a try for dinner.  I happened by at around 530pm, during their happy hour, and started with a $3 draft Kirin and a $4 tuna hand-roll that was large, generous, and delicious.  I had mediocre expectations for sushi here- and while I enjoy the tonkatsu, chicken, and other lunch items, the sushi rolls at lunch are just ok in my opinion (I do really like the roast beef sushi, but thats a different story...).  

Basically, I discovered that the Sushi and the lunch counter are like two different businesses. I was very pleasantly surprised to see very delicious, high-quality, generous cuts at the Delica Sushi restaurant in the evenings.  The fried lunch fare & counters are all shut down, and tables are set up for table-side sushi service, although there was a very small sushi bar counter as well.

I received my menu, and was very happy to see a number of interesting fish on the menu, and not just the 'standards'.  I tried their anago, oh toro, and aburi toro to start, and was very impressed with all of them- so much so that I dipped back for more aburi toro- this was one of the best iterations of this seared toro treat that I have had in the city if not the US, to my surprise.  Usually I only get this in Japan as it is not so common (or perhaps popular?) in the states.  I also enjoyed a delicious halibut carpaccio with a dash of olive oil and other seasonings.

While the ambience is nice but stuffy, the pure fish quality and taste of their sushi will bring me back very soon- maybe even tonight.  The prices were not cheap but appropriate for the quality of fish ie- $10/piece nigiri Oh Toro... Anyways, try this when you are looking for taste over atmosphere.  You will enjoy!
author: Andy S.

description:
This is a Japanese style deli! It's like high end street food you buy at the bottom of the department stores in Japan. If you're coming here for sushi, you're not getting what this place was made for.

Get the hijiki salads and the cold spinach and the chicken meatballs. The fried foods are good too. Get the croquettes for sure. Freaking awesome.
author: Margaret S.

description:
We had just come off an average grilled cheese from Cowgirl Creamery Sidekick (http://www.yelp.com/biz/cowgirl-creamery-sidekick-san-francisco#hrid:OcrFtRfPW2dS6FSNn76JZg), but I was still jonesing for something more. Cue up the Yelp and up popped Delica.

We had walked by prior a time or few, and it helped that the line was always out the door. The concept is called Sozai, but I like to think of it as "fresh casual" Japanese.

We got the lunch special, comboing up a main with two sides.

The Roast Beef Sushi was just slightly dry on the sides, juicy in the center. It's wasabi-inclusive, which helps add a kick along with arugula and shallot, balanced by the refreshing taste of the minced radish and rice. The rice was properly packed, sushi-grade.

The Wasabi Potato Salad is more than mildly addicting. It, too, balances refreshing with a clever bite, again wasabi. The rest of the dish could be considered a palette refresher, if not for the wasabi tang. The additional greens, edamame and romaine, help add a welcome crisp to the salad.

The sneaky, underrated Chinese Chicken Salad was the perfect third wheel. It came out loud and proud with the salty flavor, a concoction with the three staples: soy sauce, sesame oil, and chili paste. The crunch of the vegetable medley yielded to the tenderness of the chicken.

A feng shui mindset is perhaps the best way to approach a meal at Delica. It balances you out while filling your stomach.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
I come here for one thing and one thing only. That beef curry.

It's one of the better curries in the area. The curry has chunks of potatoes and if you're lucky, three to four generous chunks of beef. If unlucky, there may even be no beef at all ): But if that's the case, go back and ask for some! The dish is called BEEF curry after all.

It sits on top a bed of rice in a reusable container. Be cautious not to reuse more than once! It's still plastic and can easily melt into food.

And their pork katsu is great. It's a bit pricey for the small cuts but it's nice and tender and worth it now and then.
author: Sandy T.

description:
Pretty awesome Japanese deli inside the Ferry Building. It's too bad there aren't any seats because during lunch times all the tables are taken up by tourists. You get a choice of main dish/salads/rice combinations for around $7-10 dollars. I ordered 2 salads and rice for $7. 

The salads are on display behind the glass and I pointed to 2 of them on the whim because of the lunch rush. They were surprisingly delicious--my favorite was the eggplant salad with ground chicken. It had a ton of flavor and came in a thicker consistency. This went perfectly with the white rice! Though I ordered a Hijiki and Soybean salad, when I opened my box it was the Spicy Root Salad. Woops on their part. I enjoyed it nonetheless. The roots were crunchy and the mizuna was chewy. 

I would come here to grab a quick lunch to go unless you want to walk around to find a seat and be next to pigeons. The view outside is great on a sunny day in San Francisco! Love Delica and the food here, I am definitely eating here again!
author: Elina L.

description:
I thought the food quality here was just ok. Fairly bland and not too exciting. It's a nice location, being in the Ferry Building, and all, and the service was friendly, but just the taste of the food was lacking. We had two sushi rolls and the squid and beef small plates. The squid and sushi were very basic and bland, only attractive in looks. The beef was more flavorful. 

You're up high on narrow tables and on high stools. That's how you sit here. I almost knocked over the entire table but then I'm clumsy anyway. 

So nice location, nice wait staff, not the best food, so a little pricy for what it's worth.

Food: 2 stars
Waiters: 4 stars
Atmosphere 3.5 stars
author: Jennifer A.

description:
We were craving sushi, but they had run out completely. When my husband asked for a bento instead, girl behind the counter rolled her eyes. When he asked what his options were, she sighed, 'I don't know, man..." and waited for him to figure it out. It was apparently paining her to do her job. Another guy assembled my bento, at least he smiled and tried to help me out. I got an assortment of salads and some cold, disappointing chicken. 

We were overcharged, about 30 dollars total for 2 bentos and 2 drinks. I just couldn't believe the attitude and confusion among the staff here. Apparently it had been a busy day, which I understand, but when you work in food service at a high traffic location, you figure out a way to help people and not be a total bitch.
author: Lauren D.

description: 5 stars for variety and 3 for flavor. I got the pre-assorted bento and it was probably one of the healthiest meals I've had in San Francisco! I really like how unique each of the dishes were but the food was pretty bland . My personal favorite was the potato croquette. I'll be coming here when I want a light and filling lunch, but probably not when I'm looking for food to savor.
author: Vivian W.

description:
The overwhelming consensus on yelp seemed to put the wasabi potato salad on a dubious pedestal. Tried it, and guess what. It deserves its fame. The wasabi flavor is delicate and "umami", a rich and deeply satisfying 5th taste. The potatoes are cooked to perfection; starchy yet firm, slightly crunchy. Edamame and snap peas complete the texture mix. 
Very friendly woman at the cashier! She seems to really care about your experience here. 
Great food, fresh ingredients. Miso soup had tofu and wakame that I couldn't get enough of. Must try beef curry too. Those morsels of marbled fat with potatoes and sticky rice.... Will definitely visit again.
author: Ruby W.

description: Just. Not. Good. The sushi is very bland and doesn't seem fresh. I've given them multiple visits and it's always the same. I've had the mushroom curry -but was in the bathroom the entire evening. I feel like it's such a waste of money.
author: Kiki A.

description: I just came back from Japan and was pleasantly surprised to find a place this cool and this authentic in San Fran... I feel like I am at the train stations or local vendors in Tokyo!!!
author: Augusto R.

description: I love Delica, I love that Delica is authentic with traditional Japanese salads/sides/bento boxes, and I love that it's SO close to where I work and live.  When I've stopped by for lunch, I've picked up with their Pork Katsu bento box without having to wait in a typically long line.  It comes with a few delicious pieces of pork katsu with their tonkatsu sauce, white rice, Hijiki and Soybean Salad, and their Spicy Burdock Root Salad.  So delicious! Sure the box sets you back $9.75 plus tax, but it's definitely a complete meal.  Their combos where you can order a variety of salad/side combinations is also really cool!  Anyway, this is a great place for lunch during the weekend or weekday! I highly recommend it!
author: Lisa I.

description: Tried the crab croquette and the spicy burdock salad was a nice complement for lunch...but honestly I expected a bigger portion than what I got.  Or maybe I just love food too much that one serving wasn't enough for me... =D  Regardless of the portion size, not particularly impressed...
author: Kevin C.

description: Staff is pleasant and friendly.  Had a taste test on carrot ginger soup, didn't really care for that combination.  The salmon chowder is surprisingly smooth and creamy. It tasted earthy; flavors were there.   There were chunks of salmon and did not taste fishy at all.  The cold adashi tofu was refreshing and light.  The shaved dakon and scallion are the stars to the tofu.
author: Frances C.

description:
Super confused how this place got such good reviews. I kept wanting to like it and tried it 3x before writing this review. Every single item I ate was below average. Trust me, or eat there and ask yourself it anything they offer tastes better than your average resto. 

I truly did want to like this place but its just not good.
author: Christopher N.

description:
My go-to place in the Ferry Building!

Even when the lines for lunch are long, the staff is efficient enough to keep things zipping along. The menu can be confusing if it's your first time (for example, one item is "SALAD + SALAD + SOUP or SALAD"), but it's really just that you can pick any combo of salads, main, and/or soup that you want. I usually go with the standard two salads plus a main.

The wasabi potato salad, burdock salad, and the hijiki seaweed salad are great, though the hijiki might not be as strongly dressed as people expect. For main dish, I like getting the tofu and chicken patty. This comes out to just under $10, so a tad pricey for lunch, but one of the better deals in Ferry Buildinglandia.

If you're really in a rush to get back to the salt mines, there are bento boxes and onigiri to the left side. Just snag one and head straight to the cashier. 

They also do soup noodles, but I haven't tried that yet.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Had dinner alone during a business trip.

FOOD: 4.5.  $30 special sashimi and rice.  Fish very good.  4 kinds, plus a small fresh oyster. Rice would have benefitted by being more sticky.

AMBIANCE: 3.5.  Sat at the bar facing out through the window onto the corridor.

SERVICE: 4.0.
author: Jeff B.

description: My Japanese boss recommended this place to me and it was superb in terms of taste, service, and price!
author: Amy T.

description:
This place is well known for deli and bento boxes, but you should also try dinner.
Yes, they are open for dinner from 5:00pm till 10:00pm on weekdays with happy hour for 5:00pm-7:00pm.
The owner is pure Japanese and they serve real Japanese dishes.  
I hope my review helps since they don't have much information of dinner on their website.


*Food - 4.5 stars
They have authentic dishes and some original dishes, that are perfectly arranged and seasoned, and everything is DELICIOUS!  We ordered:

- Omakase Sushi (12 pieces) and some individual sushi 
They pick seasonal fresh fish for Omakase.  
If you are into Uni(Sea Urchin), you MUST try Uni!  I would say one of the best Uni you can have in Bay Area.  It is from Fort Bragg and so sweet, rich, and it melts in your mouth. 
Saba (mackerel) from Japan was amazingly delicious when I went there. (5/9/2013). Saba for sushi is usually served after salted and soaked in vinegar, but their Saba was super fresh and it was served just raw.  We rarely have it even in Japan.

- Grilled Avocado
Great appetizer dish!  Simply grilled and served with Daikon Oroshi, sauce and spice on top of it.  Unexpectedly great combination.

- Kobe Beef Tataki
Enjoy the tender beef with a lot of green onions and sweet sauce.

- Kale Salad
Served with slices of cheese and apple.

- Grilled Squid
Typical Japanese tapas dish.  A whole squid served with mayonnaise on the side.  Tender and chewy at the same time.  

- Tsuke men
OMG, delicious! You dip noodles in the broth with a lot of mushroom.
One of the popular ways to have ramen noodles in Japan.

- Baked Curry
Caution: very very very hot!!  Ouch!  It is good, but don't rush!  Don't get yourself burned!


*Service - 3.5 stars
Unfortunately, I have to say there is some room to improve.
One of the waitresses doesn't know the menu well.  They often mix up the orders.
They have the happy hour menu and a bit complicated rules ordering with the regular menu if you go there before 7:00pm, which is confusing.


Even having said that, I am a big fan of this place!  It is absolutely worth trying if you have a liking for Japanese food.  
Enjoy great Sushi and tapas!  I guarantee you won't regret!  
For reservation, just call them.
author: Tomomi K.

description:
Delica is characteristic of a Ferry Building establishment - gourmet quality, higher priced, and perhaps slightly overrated.

Okay fine, my initial assessment isn't fair.  Though I'm staying at three stars for now, because I was underwhelmed by my pork cutlet sandwich, I am 100% excited to come back to try their other items.  They just have too many cool creations to miss.  Judging Delica for one item makes as much sense as judging the 2010 Giants season based on one regular season loss.  You just wont get the whole picture.

With respect to the pork cutlet sandwich I ordered, I thought it was too small and not extraordinary enough to justify the nearly $10 price tag.  I also did not care too much for the sauce and the pork could have been more tender and moist.  In the end, I was still hungry.  

I think I just ordered the wrong thing.  On a positive note, they really do have a lot of goodies.  Most of their veggies (maybe all) are organic.  Meats are farm raised, hormone-free, and grass fed, and everything seem really fresh.

If you happen to make it, I recommend sampling their $2-$6 a la carte items rather than going for the overpriced sandwiches.  I didn't get to try the roast beef sushi, but that's now on my hit list for my  return trip.

I would have ordered more, but my friend was paying so I was conscious about running up the bill (though here I am complaining about the price of a meal I didn't pay for).  Anyway, I vow to come back, though I wont go on an empty stomach.  I have a feeling this three star review wont last very long (at least I hope so).
author: Angel S.

description:
Uh.. Yum!! This place is really good if you want something delicious, healthy, and easy on your conscience.

I had the tofu steak and the broth/sauce that they used made it so delicious!  I don't think I'll ever look at tofu the same way again.

And I also had the spinach/sesame salad and the green beans salad.. Honestly, I don't remember when I ate veggies last so my body was really craving them.  But don't be fooled--you'll love to eat these veggies.  The spinach wasn't bitter at all and the green beans are a good substitute for a macaroni salad.

This place is clean with clean flavors and a happy staff.  I'm so coming back here.
author: Vira P.

description: Got the burdock and lotus root salad, the beet salad, and the wasabi potato salad in a 3 salad combo for $10. This was after the end of the day after 5pm, and I was trying to wait out rush hour traffic to my hotel. I'm truly glad that I located this shop. Every salad was delicious.
author: J P.

description: The chicken dumpling and the spicy chickens are fantastic. It would be nice if they introduce chicken curry similar to beef/mushroom curry. I will highly recommend this place for a good Iapanese food.
author: Pandeeswaran B.

description:
Lines here are RIDIC but worth the wait!

I love Japanese style bento boxes and donburis!

My favorite here is the Ginger Beef Bowl (Natural Japanese supreme ground Kobe Beef and ginger served with shredded egg and steamed rice. Topped with green onion) It is full of protein, filling, a good price, and most importantly SOOO delicious. 

They usually have this bowl as grab and pay so no need to wait in the same RIDIC line as those who are waiting to order from the menu whatever dish their hearts desire. 

For grab and go there's usually onigiri and premade bento boxes.

Some other items I love here are:

*Organic Agedashi Tofu Steak: Silken (Kinugoshi) firm tofu is lightly dusted with potato starch and then deep fried until golden brown. It's then served in a hot tentsuyu broth made od dashi, mirin, and sho-yu (Japanese soy sauce), and topped with grated daikon. Though it is deep fried, it does not taste heavy! It is perfectly fried!

*Spicy Burdock Root Salad: A spicy mix of braised burdock and konnyaku (mountain potato) tossed with thin slices of white onion, celery, julienne carrots, and wild mizuna.
This isn't really spicy but WHATEVER it is amazing!!!

*Hijiki and Soybean Salad: Hijiki (seaweed rich in calcium, iron, and fiber) mixed with dried soybeans, edamame, konnyaku (mountain potato), daikon, wild mizuna, fried tofu, and kuko (wolfberry) cooked with soy sauce.

Gosh, thinking about all the delicious food is making me so hungry.
author: Michelle T.

description:
If you are craving fast Japanese food, this is the place. It's located right in front the ferry building. Their food is just like their name, very delicate and deli like. The food is already fresh and all you have to do is choose what you want to eat. They are slightly pricy, but their food is amazing. I love their SEASONAL Mabo Salad, that contains; tofu, romaine lettuce, chili sauce, ginger, bean thread noodles, and chicken. It's very light but filling. I also love their SEASONAL Crab Croquette. Croquette is French for potatoes that are usually rolled in with peas and onions and then fried in breadcrumbs. Their Crab Croquette has this nice mayo flavor which is called "Béchamel sauce" and full of crab! If you every get a chance to visit them, it is worth the money!


Check out my profile to find my official blogs as well as more food reviews
author: Food G.

description: The food at Delica is so good, I can't help but eat here for lunch every day I'm in SF. They sell both vegetarian and normal fish lover's bento boxes for between 10-16$, as well as pre-packaged sushi and containers of sides and rice balls for folks in a rush who just want to grab and go. They additionally offer their glass case menu items in containers by weight, as well as at least one hot menu item, and two soup choices. I've had the chicken salad, the large bento box, the hijiki salad, wasabi potato salad, green beans, chicken dumpling, sushi, basically everything that doesn't contain pork, and it was all absolutely delicious. The hijiki salad is my favorite. You can easily let your stomach take over and spend way too much money on way too much food, so be careful. Pick one or two things and come back another time to try more. All their menu items are more filling than they look!
author: Kaia V.

description: Food is good but but customer service not so much. You would expect at least good service for such overpriced food items. Won't be going back.
author: Paula C.

description:
Love this place! 

It's the perfect spot for a quick and delicious meal in the ferry building. 

+ Must get their curry bowl = bomb.com
+ The spicy tuna roll is amaz. The rolls are actually really big and the quality of fish is really high. 
+ The crab croquette is delish.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
I love all the mix-and-matching you can do at Delica... Bento Boxes are my happy place. I had entree + salad + rice box. The green bean salad was ridiculously good, and the shrimp nest thing was tasty as well. 

Definitely a great quick spot to grab a bite for a decent price while visiting the Ferry Building.
author: Karen C.

description:
Delica is amazing I'm the #1 fan of Yazu... Great rolls at a great price 
Everything is crafted to perfection and the service is outstanding!!!!
Great views of the bridge right outside the restaurant 
High class
author: Chris H.

description: Delicious healthy food in the Ferry building. It's Japanese inspired, and tastes as such. I had the spinach/sesame salad, curry, and salmon onigiri. I absolutely savored the warm hand made onigiri. Some people say it's incredibly expensive to eat here, and although it's not cheap, I don't think it was particularly extravagant, especially since the food tastes so good, and considering it's location.
author: Dani P.

description: WOW!!! simply amazing! the food is impeccable! melt in your mouth deliciousness if u want to have a good time just stop by, take a look, browse the selection of fine carefully curated savory, delicious, mouth-watering, assortment of fine, authentic, japanese, homecooked, organic, non-GMO, no MSG, local sustainable food and i'm sure u will be pleasantly surprised by the explosion of flavor that will meet your mouth after the first bite. don't wait, act now! give it a try!
author: Poop M.

description: If you like overpriced cold food.. this is the place for you. Very small servings. Nothing spectacular. The asian lady with a pony tail and a snotty facial expression was very rude and spent time arguing and preaching to me about my order , the kakiage soup which i pointed to their overhead sign just to be clear what i wanted but instead grabbed the kakiage and placed it in a box. This woman should not be in the front wearing that white chef's uniform absolutely no personality and no customer service skills.The male cashier exhibited more customer service explaining to me and what he can offer me. Would give negative star if it was possible.
author: lenra a.

description:
This small place is really easy to miss. It's in the Ferry Building, near a Mexican restaurant. Decided to give this place a try, plus it was Happy Hour. However, don't be deceived! Though it says Happy Hour, you are actually limited to the Happy Hour item of the day. If you want the Happy Hour appetizers, you have to order from the Daily Specials menu first, and the Daily Specials are NOT cheap, and then on top of that, the Happy Hour appetizers are an additional charge, not an included charge. Basically, it's not a true Happy Hour - you have to spend more, rather than save money.

The Daily Special on the day I went was Soba, but I'm not a fan, so I skipped it. Ordered the Baked Fish from the Daily Specials. There was no description or price on the menu. Also, you have to wait longer for this item to be cooked. It doesn't come with rice, so I ordered a bowl ($1). The meal came with mushrooms, green beans, squash, salmon, whole garlic cloves, and a couple other things that I couldn't quite identify. Honestly, it was good in portion and taste, but not worth $14.50.

Also received a complimentary salad of some sort prior to the main meal. It was a little crunchy/crispy, included some type of soft beige beans and bits of meat (beef?). Tasted alright.

The only dessert available is Mango Coconut Pudding, $3.50. It's a small amount, but the it has 2 gelatinous layers of mango with sprinkles of coconut on top. I wouldn't order it again, but it looks nice. The only beer available is Kirin Ichiban, a light beer, for $4.

Long story short, if I'm going to  spend money on food, I'm going elsewhere.
author: Christina L.

description: I come here from time to time after jogs by the embarcadero. The rice balls are pretty good! I would recommend this place for someone looking for a decent Japanese meal. Nothing to write home about but does the job on keeping you full
author: Leslie C.

description: Everything is so fresh and healthy daily, and delicious! I am always happy with my meal when I come here, and the service is nice.
author: Taylor R.

description:
I was going out to lunch with a few people, and Delica was suggested.  I had no idea what it was, but I'm always down to try something new.  When Japanese curry was mentioned, my eyes lit up and my stomach growled.

I *love* Japanese curry. It's warm, filling, comforting, and flavorful. I love the thick curry, the chunks of beef, and the pieces of potato.  So I was excited, but apprehensive, while placing my order for the beef curry.  What if it didn't live up to the hype or my internal expectations?!

And, it didn't.  It had most of what I love about curry (thick, beef, potatoes), but it was missing the crucial aspect of flavor and spice.  I like my curry to have a bit of kick and saltiness. Also, it would have been nice to have a chicken cutlet with the curry.

So, what I've realized after trying Delica, Muracci's, and JapaCurry is that each place has a curry that tastes vastly different, so you can't expect something similar. And Delica is at the bottom of my SF Japanese curry list.
author: Nadeem A.

description:
I wasn't a big fan of their famous wasabi potato salad. The roast beef sushi was good but very over priced. On a good note, the seasonal corn salad was very good.

Just kind of disappointed that I splurged $9 on a small portion of really unexciting food and a big scoop of white rice.
author: Jess C.

description:
Japanese deli!

Tried my first Donburi here. It's good! :)
author: Ryan K.

description:
Why are the graphics for this little shop so adorable? I let them lure me in, yes I did. The cartoonized orange carrots, yellow radishes, and green asparagus conjure that homey, organic, and delicate feel. Hence the name Delica, I suppose.

(RyanY, I'm so glad you ate here and approve! Your mom must cook up such memorable Japanese meals.)

For the sake of diversity and equally to appease my gluttony, I ordered 2 lunch meals (I shared with someone else..).

Hijiki and soybean salad: with edamame, konnyaku (mountain potato), daikon, fried tofu, kuko (aka wolfberry or goji, the bright red berry), as well as wild mizuna (a mustard).

Spinach and sesame salad: cold spinach mixed with rougher sesame paste (slightly sweet to the palate).

Spicy burdock root salad: braised burdock (the winner! a mighty root vegetable), konnyaku (mountain potato), onion, celery, julienne carrots, and wild mizuna. (Burdock, which I didn't even know is called that, is so refreshing!)

Chinese chicken salad: with Japanese cucumber, daikon, carrot, and celery in a soy dressing. (I probably wouldn't order this one again for a lack of creativity in the flavors on Delica's part).

Agedashi tofu: firm tofu deep fried and served with a thick tentsuyu broth topped with grated daikon (served cold! that part I didn't like.. the deep fried covering was soggy and the taste of oil was too apparent).

Tofu and chicken patty with hijiki: meatball like with tofu and chicken and bits of carrots. (not mindblowing, but inspiration to something I might try to make in my own kitchen. also served cold).

Accompanying the two lunch dishes, which were carefully carried from Delica to the rustic wooden tables in the hall, were a salmon rice ball and an edamame and kuko rice ball. Our meal definitely looked the part. Now for the tasting!

I was happy with lunch, more because of the ingredients used in the dishes and the way they were presented. Everything tasted delightful: light and yet flavorful. You don't get sick of any one dish and there's the added benefit that what you're dining on is both tasty and healthful.

Certain dishes are vegan friendly, namely the hijiki and soybean salad and the burdock salad. Others are vegetarian like the wasabi garlic potato salad and the green beans salads. Price may be a hindering factor for making this a regular lunch spot, but for the most part, my long time asian food trained tongue says yes.
author: Cici T.

description:
Delica - Delica is a restaurant that believes highly in serving a good quality and healthy food.  Naturally raised meats, no hormones, no antibiotics, no MSG.  The restaurant is designed such that you can order many small dishes to help you maintain a nice balanced and healthy meal.  
For lunch till 5pm you have the cafeteria style service where you can order from behind the counter....after 5pm you have your restaurant style service.  I've been there for both lunch and dinner.  I've got to say I've enjoyed meals and have not yet had a bad experience.  The lunch menu is different from the dinner menu.  Here are some items I've had for lunch:

Salmon Rice Ball
Cured and roasted wild salmon mixed with sesame seeds and steamed rice.  Makes a good snack or you can put it together with another item(s) for a complete meal.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=QlRD2t-uqhAlXX1fnIfPKw&userid=SRnOg-4Ya4g4dUQ1x0Tdkg

Hijiki Rice Ball
hijiki (seaweed rich in calcium, iron, and fiber) mixed with dried soybeans, edamame, konnyaku (mountain potato), daikon, fried tofu, kuko (wolfberry) cooked with soy sauce and steamed rice.  This also will make a good snack or can be good to order with another item for a complete meal.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=hJibOODMFp8mKU3UYP5BYQ&userid=SRnOg-4Ya4g4dUQ1x0Tdkg

Roast Beef Sushi
Our original sushi dish with Meyer Ranch natural, hormone-free beef, topped with baby arugula, minced shallots, and julienne radish, wrapped with Nori seaweed. Wasabi is included.  This is absolutely delicious.  When ordering this I usually order at least 3 pc's for myself.  The beef is very tender, the rice does not dominate the meat or flavor.  Come early for this item....once they are gone...there are no more till the next day.  Also not served after 5pm.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=NsIXZcigmyxGLFveQnxjfg&userid=SRnOg-4Ya4g4dUQ1x0Tdkg


Shrimp Cake
Made with white shrimp and coated in our freshly made panko breadcrumbs. Served with your choice of our tomato or tartar sauce. 
Best Shrimp Cake I've had so far.  Every bite is a mouth full of shrimp.  If your a shrimp lover this is your dish.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xlXnPitrO9Mjfq3aPAyNVQ?select=6DXlvCDq7KAWLm53qbmLGg

Spicy Tuna Roll
The way the Spicy Tuna Roll is prepared ...the Tuna sits on top of the rice....this is awesome because it allows for more tuna to the sushi roll.  Got to love it!
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=6l1skAHABDdl_nl_wAnIHg&userid=SRnOg-4Ya4g4dUQ1x0Tdkg


Here are some of the items I've had from the dinner menu:

Negi Hamachi Hand Roll
Yellow Tail wrapped in seaweed, topped with crispy rice bits.  Seaweed is nice and crunchy...yet just the right amount of rice and Yellow Tail to make it an awesome Hand Roll!
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=B4TELccjTGFen-YbCSKq3g&userid=SRnOg-4Ya4g4dUQ1x0Tdkg

Spicy Tuna Hand Roll
Very much like the Negi Hamachi Hand Roll except with Spicy Tuna.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=TVFMiYsb0uJf6zijLGP-Tw&userid=SRnOg-4Ya4g4dUQ1x0Tdkg

Kobe Beef Tataki
Torched Tri-Tip from Niman Ranch with a touch of Onion and Garlic Ponzu and Sweet Eel Sauce.
This dish is a absolutely must have.  It's served only after 5pm and I've had it on all my visits here after 5pm.  Very tender, very tasty.....I can have this dish alone and leave with a big smile on my face afterwards. 
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wKin0ReDFmeA1APzpmg5kQ&userid=SRnOg-4Ya4g4dUQ1x0Tdkg

Overall, this restaurant is very nice and pleasant.  The workers here are very friendly and service is fantastic.  The restaurant is inside the Ferry Building so it makes is a very nice environment.  Many things to do before and after the meal.  Very enjoyable, highly recommended.  

One note:  It did take me some time to figure this restaurant out, but once figured out I highly recommend it!!

5 Stars all the way!!
author: Alan L.

description:
I was set to give this place a solid 4 stars. Paid my bill and then the questionable happened. Keep in mind I have had several years in the restaurant + bar industry as a server so I'm not just complaining to complain. 

The good: We walked in on a quiet Tuesday around 6 to tons of seating and friendly servers. We sat, and mind you, my friend is 8 months pregnant. Plenty to order for her and me. Something for everyone on the menu - including gluten-free and vegan items. Sashimi and rolls were fresh, miso was tasty, chicken karaage delciious. 

The bill arrived. I tipped 19% to be exact. The bill was taken away.

We sat for about ten minutes - probably less - just finishing our water, etc. The place was not packed, however a family of five came in, and because we were at the emptiest communal table, we were asked to leave the table. Not *would* we leave the table but that we *must* leave the table. She wasn't exactly rude but not suggestive either. 

I have to stay I was stunned. My (very pregnant) friend was stunned. We were speechless. I'm never speechless. We walked out so disappointed. 

I was tempted to ask for my bill back so I could change the tip but I've decided I'm better than that and I will hope that if I support them again, this situation will be handled differently.

My solution? How about, "We have a large party waiting. About how much longer do you think you'll be? How can we help move you so you can stay and enjoy our near- empty restaurant?" The way the server posed it was not the right way. 

I hope the manager or owner can read this and have a little chat with their staff about the ways to speak to paying customers.
author: Meredith R.

description:
The atmosphere really brings down the rating for me, as someone visiting SF. If I lived here, it'd probably be a different story and I imagine this makes a good lunch spot and it looks like they do some pretty legit sushi making classes too!

So back to the atmosphere, it's actually inside the 1 Ferry Building, and when we spotted it on the map near the water we just assumed this sushi spot would have waterfront seating or at least windows looking out onto the waterfront. Nope. Not the case. Instead you're looking out into the indoor mall area that is this location at 1 Ferry Building.

The rolls we had were tasty and it's always fun when a sushi restaurant's menu has fish I've never heard of and everything turns out to be fantastic. However, the truffle oiled and halved avocado stuffed with fish was the highlight for sure.
author: Megan F.

description:
I have a favorite here, the shrimp cakes. I always like to grab a couple of them and sit outside on the bench and enjoy the Bay Bridge View and the boats sailing. 

I like how the shrimp cake isn't fishy. The crunchy bite outside and the juicy shrimps clustered together inside make me come back to this place over and over. I tried some of their food, they're not bad either but this place isn't expensive so you get your money's worth.
author: Lora M.

description:
I've been wanting to try Delica and finally came here for dinner before catching a show on the Pier. We had no problem getting a table and enjoyed some Japanese small plates.
I had the fried tofu, cucumber roll and chicken karrage. All of the plates were tasty and were small- but just right. The tofu was my favorite and I liked the sauce that went with it. The chicken was also nice and crispy and not too greasy.
Service was fine and the dishes came out as they were ready. 
I definitely want to try the lunch bentos one day but would recommend this place for small plates or a light dinner if you're at the Ferry building. Prices were not too high and they also offered happy hour prices ($3-5 plates).
author: Miss H K.

description:
Delica is alright.  It's definitely an interesting and unique lunch spot

I went on a busy day, and they didn't do a good job of keeping the food stocked.  They were out of all of the non-vegetarian salads when I got to the front of the line, and I didn't want to wait for them to make a new batch.  

As a first timer as well, it was confusing to me to only see some main dishes in the first window, as you don't realize there are other mains farther down the line.  I think they should try to make that a little more logical.  

The hijiki salad was pretty good.  It had smalll pieces of beef which added a bit more flavor.  the tofu steak was cold, disappointingly, and all the other mains seemed like they were fried.  Perhaps I will give it another go some time later.
author: Alison L.

description:
This is not a review of the food because we were not able to eat here. I flew in from LA  hoping to catch a delicious dinner. 

My friend, sister, and I were looking forward to eating at Delica on Thursday 5/15/14 around 7:30pm. Anyway, my sister is disabled and needs to have sit in a designated table or at least a table that is lowered. While there were tables outside that were low enough for her to sit, the hostess said that there were no outside seating (totally understand that because it is not lunch hour). However, was sorely disappointed with the lack of accommodation inside the restaurant itself. The tables are high tops which would prevent my sister from sitting. Hostess didn't provide any suggestion and was apathetic to the situation. Anyway, we went to  Il Cane Rosso instead. 

Management: If there is a disabled area, please let your hostess point it out to potential customers. Felt super bad for my sister with MS.
author: Phuong T.

description:
I love karaage and many various sushi!
You can experience real home made style Japanese food here:)
author: Asuka Y.

description:
Stopped in for lunch with coworkers. We went early to beat the line with limited success - this place gets packed. I did a box combo and chose 2 salads (chinese chicken salad and green bean salad) with agedashi tofu. 

The food was ok overall..the green bean salad was the best. I didn't think the chinese chicken salad had enough flavor and the tofu was pretty soggy from sitting out. 

After waiting in line and paying $10+ for the small portions I was less impressed than expected. I did see some things being freshly made to order, so that might be the best bet at this place.
author: Rachel E.

description:
I enjoyed eating here because of the authentic Japanese food that they serve. It definitely reminded me of some of my moms homemade meals. Growing up some of my favorite things to eat were hijiki and burdock salads, potato croquettes and onigiri (rice balls). 

The only problem I had with this place is the price! I feel like you can get a lot of these dishes for so much cheaper at Japanese markets like Mitsuwa and Nijiya or even make them yourself at home for half the cost. IMO, home-style Japanese food should not be thaaaaat expensive. 

I think this place is great for on-the-go healthy eating and worth a visit if you haven't tried it. The food here is great, healthy (aside from the fried items) and fresh tasting. If you don't mind paying $$ then I would recommend this place.
author: Tina M.

description: TLDR: Too expensive for the tiny portions that are served. I ordered the main + salad combo for $8.75, and it consisted of a massive scoop of rice, three tiny pieces of chicken katsu, and a scoop of wasabi potato salad. While the wasabi potato salad was absolutely delicious, and is something that I would come here again just to get, I would not get the lunch combo, or anything else here really, due to how ordinary everything else tasted. Lines here are not terrible during lunch time surprisingly. If you can, check out Market Street for some better eats.
author: Austin W.

description:
Yum! I loved their eggplant salad, veggie tempura and salmon chowder! 

The ginger beef rice bowl looked great too. 

Super quick, fresh, and tasty! Perfect for a grab and go lunch :)
author: Shanna N.

description:
When I have the time, I like to take a walk to the ferry building to 1. soak in the sunshine 2. feel the bay breeze and 3. get me some Japanese delicatessen grub at Delica. 

It's fairly quick and efficient but more importantly, I really like the food. In particular, the salads are fantastic. I get VERY excited when the eggplant salad is back in season. The eggplant is tender and the sauce is so savory but clean-tasting at the same time. Simply delish! Other standout seasonal salads include the mapo tofu salad and the asparagus salad. 

The regular salads aren't bad either but since they are always there, I don't covet them as much as, say, the eggplant salad for example. But all things considered, the Hijiki and soybean salad, the spinach and sesame salad, and the Chinese chicken salads are all good bets. Out of their main dishes, the tofu steak with chicken is surprisingly hearty and the fried shrimp cake is simply mind-blowing. Perfectly fried without being greasy and fresh shrimp on the inside make it a nice accompaniment to the salads. 

Delica is a great interpretation of what deli food can be, incorporating the "clean" taste of Japanese cuisine to offer a light and delicious lunch while you soak in the sun and bay breeze.
author: Jon L.

description:
- Worst sushi in the area, way below average, which makes the nice decor a waste
- Overpriced, maybe because of the location, but anything in the Ferry building is better than this one
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I'm actually glad that they now refer to themselves as DeliCA or DELICA, which is a much more clear and straightforward name. The "rf-1" part of their name (derived from parent firm Rock Field Co.) was a bit weird. That's a name more suitable for a car, I think.

Yes, it's a little expensive, but nice place when u want something other than a sandwich for lunch. This is a modern Japanese delicatessen, selling their own high-end version of sozai cuisine (small plates of comfort food) and a few traditional dishes. The bento boxes ($9.75) are a nice way to sample a little bit of everything. Some of my favorites are the ginger beef bowl http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/G2I9_EOXAx7AUbmVPCfyCg/l ($8.75, ginger seasoned ground beef with scrambled eggs) and ginger pork bowl (grilled pork cutlets). The beef curry ($8.50) does have a nice amount of heat. The salads are a bit too expensive in my opinion ($12-$15 per pound), so I prefer to get the combinations that come in the bento instead.

Once in a while I like to buy one of the croquettes ($1.75-$4) - remember to ask for one of the sauces, tartar or tomato (only when u buy the more expensive shrimp croquette, but I manage to get it anyways). Also don't forget dessert (around $2.50), their seasonal pudding cups (so far: pana cotta, green tea, custard with fruit, avocado topped with mango, etc.) are really good, delicate and flavorful.
author: Luis C.

description:
Great place for a reasonably healthy boxed lunch. This is one of my go-to spots during the week if I have time to schlep over to the Ferry Building, and our office gets it catered a fair amount. My favorite are their 'bento' lunch boxes where you can pick soup/salad/entree. 

Recommend:
Sesame spinach salad
Green bean salad
Carrot ginger soup!!
Wasabi mashed potatoes (HOLY MOLY so good and creamy, craving them now)
Potato cakes, but only if you eat them with the tonkatsu (or whatever it's called ) sauce they serve on the side
Salmon sushi

Ok:
Chicken dumplings
Tofu triangle things

Avoid:
Roast beef sushi...just weird
author: Laurel K.

description: Tasty but overpriced. Great selection, sushi, bento boxes, soups, curries etc. Plenty of veggie options. I got the mushroom curry and it was delicious, but for $10, I wish there was some veggies or tofu in there, instead of just button mushrooms and thin lotus slices.
author: Crystal Y.

description:
Great lunch choice within the Ferry Building.

For about $10, you can choose a combination of salads, mains, and soup. I highly recommend their sweet and sour chicken, potato wasabi salad, and eggplant salad.

Great value and hearty portion size. I'm a fan!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Let me start by saying the lunch line is ALWAYS long. So if you don't want something warm and what you want is at the To Go Counter, grab and go. But the line moves fairly quick too. 

The food I think is a bit pricey for the quantity/quality. but I mean how do you put a definite price to something you like, right? So the food...

I got the #1 lunch combo - main + salad + soup (you can choose another salad instead of soup). So for main I had the crab croquette - warm, tasty, nicely breaded and fried. This is the best part of my lunch. For you only get 1 piece, so...yeah, not filling enough. For salad I got the very ordinary spinach with sesame, wakame usually it's called. It's different from what I get from more traditional Japanese restaurants, but I like this. You get a hearty amount of spinach goodness, which I happen to like. For soup I got the ginger carrot. Let me say I've had other ginger carrot soup around, I have my particular likings. This one is watery (I saw them puree with chicken stock) and looks oily (probably also from the chicken stock). Too much of stock. I like thick puree of carrot with hearty ginger flavor. This one has almost no ginger flavor. I was disappointed. And the whole set is $10.50+ tax, so about $11.45.

Over all, I'd want to try again, getting something else. Maybe rolls, curry, or sushi. But a scoop of spinach, 1 piece of croquette and 1 small cup of soup does not add up to $11 for me. And the soup was not good.
author: Lisa Z.

description: Excellent fast food...Japanese+ American meets for great quick take& go meals. The  croquet is delicious as well as the salmon chowder.
author: Sharine d.

description:
After a failed attempt at locating a proper sushi restaurant with vegan options in the FiDi, I found Delica on my handy-dandy Yelp app. There are lots of items that cater to vegetarians and vegans, all of which are clearly marked on the menu and the labels. 

I stopped by their to-go deli counter and ordered a lunch combo. It comes with one entree, white rice sprinkled with black sesame seeds, and one salad. I chose the Agedashi Tofu Steak, which is fancifully described as "Silken tofu lightly dusted with potato starch and deep fried. Served in a tentsuyu made of dashi, mirin and shoyu, and topped with grated Daikon". 

It was delicious! I would definitely order this again. When it comes to tofu, I like mine firm, so their version was a perfect fit for my tastebuds. If you prefer your tofu steak on the softer side, you might not care for it. 

For the salad, I chose the Hijiki and Soybean Salad (Hijiki seaweed mixed with dried soybeans, edamame, konnyaku [mountain yam], daikon, wild mizuna, fried tofu, and kuko (wolfberry) and cooked with soy sauce). This was a solid accompaniment, although a touch on the salty side. 

There appears to be no veggie option for the miso soup, which is terribly sad to me. Delica, add a vegan version and I would stop a lot more often!

It's a little pricey, and they give you a LOT of rice but very little salad. Understandable, since it runs for about $18 a pound (jeez!). I think I will venture back to the Ferry Building sometime soon and sample more of their tasty delights.
author: Brandi W.

description: I have walked in and out of Delica multiple times on my many ventures through the Ferry Building but finally did one of their lunch combos, and was very happy I did! I went with the burdock salad, the map tofu salad and the salmon chowder. Everything tasted great - fresh, flavorful, and satisfying. In my little to-go box, I mixed the two salads together and so I'm not sure if one was better than the other because I ate them as one and loved it. I'll be back to try more - including maybe some of their mains.
author: David B.

description: Expected the food here to be amazing, but it was just alright and overpriced just like other places around this area. The service was nice, and the matcha pudding was not as good as I expected. I had the eggplant salad in my lunch combo and that was probably the best thing. The kakiage tempura thing wasn't as flavorful as I hoped and hard to eat. The salmon chowder was delicious though! Will be back to try other things and hopefully update the review to a better one.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Not bad but not amazing either. Came with my coach (at work) and a coworker for lunch.

I took the advice of the yelpers and ordered the wasabi mashed potatoes and the roast beef sushi. Honestly, the wasabi mashed potatoes were pretty good. The spiciness with the mashed potatoes was surprisingly really good. I would go back there and get that again. The roast beef sushi was probably not worth it. I think it was good, but definitely not worth the price. 

I think maybe next time I should just just get the curry or something. I'll have to check it out again, one of the next times I make it out to the ferry building.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Love Love Love the food!  I saw all the selection for their takeout line but I really wanted to sit down and eat.  This place is very very small.  They only have a few tables and a sushi bar.  Cute and modern looking sushi joint though.  Very classy.

Service was good but very slow and they messed up plenty of times so I have to take a star off.  They were helpful and patience with us since my mom takes a while to order.  

Prices here are pretty pricey for the portion but you are paying for fresh food, amazing taste, and quality; definitely quality.  My brother kept on buying their special (a delicious sushi roll that I can't remember and fried tofu I think?) for $10 very good deal compared to the rest.  I got the Duck and the Delica roll.  It was sooo good.

I am absolutely coming back here and next time trying out the bentos that everyone is raving about.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Delicate balance.

Between praise: Sweet (chili sauce) ground chicken and tofu dumplings. Sweeter (soy sauce) chicken and tofu patty toped with seaweed and carrots. Both delicious.

And indifference: Smoked salmon and veggie roll was devoid of almost any flavor. Spinach salad and eggplant salad were overly dressed and soggy. 

Former was $2 - $5 per item. Latter $10 - $12/lb. Expected Ferry Building economics.

Your rating will likely depend on how well you balance.
author: Jason B.

description:
Frequent for lunch. 

About half the time I hit the ferry building, I come here. The salads are great. Sometime the chicken can be on the over cooked side. But that doesn't happen too often. Awesome views sitting outside. Great place to go for a quick lunch on a nice day.
author: Robert F.

description:
I don't know how I'm supposed to pronounce the name of this joint. But I do know that for a little under $10 ($11.25 with a bottle of water), you can pick one main item and two salads. (They have other lunch combos, but this is the one I went with, and I'm writing this review, not you.) And it's going to be GOOD.

I decided on the sweet and spicy chicken with the green bean and mabo tofu* salads on the side. The latter was the 2nd best decision I've ever made, coming up right behind the time I took a shot of bacon.

The sweet and spicy chicken was extremely fresh (they had just brought out another tray), and very tasty. But as I said, the tofu salad was, astonishingly, even better. It's extremely rare that the meatiest part of the plate isn't my favorite, so if I were you, I'd get you some of that tofu salad. 

The Ferry Building has so many appealing options that I haven't tried yet, but next time I come by, I might just have to eat here again. And again. And one more time, just for that mabo tofu salad. Because it isn't often that I love tofu this much.
__________

*This dish is similar to the eggplant salad they have when eggplant is in season.
author: Peter D.

description:
Pretty solid eatery, although watch out for the price, long lines, and lack of seating. Don't come here around lunchtime and expect there to be anywhere to sit. You're going to have to search around outside for an empty bench or get ready to get cozy with some strangers at the Mijita tables next door. 

I tried the potato and crab croquettes, shrimp cake, and the beef curry. At $4 a piece you can live without the potato croquettes, but the shrimp cake and crab croquette were the bomb diggity and I encourage everyone to try them. Good flavors inside and a nice crunch outside. 

The beef curry is very good as well, although I'm not sure I would call it traditional Japanese curry. Granted, I'm not Japanese, but it's not like the curry I'm used to getting in Japantown or at other Japanese restaurants. Rather, this reminds me a little more of an American beef stew. Still good, but if you're craving really traditional Japanese curry this might not hit the spot.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
This place is good but a little on the pricey side. Well any decent Japanese place is pricey but this place is pretty good for being in a touristy spot. Ordered hamachi kama, pork belly of course and Delica sushi. Overall food was good but took away one star for super slow service. There were only probably 3 tables occupied and the service was really slow. Ou waiter was really nice and friendly but the sushi chefs are slow.  I wonder how they are when it's lunch time and super busy. 
Hmmmm.... I might have to give this place another try.
author: Claudine V.

description:
I've been here a couple times for dinner now and have enjoyed both experiences from the service to the food. While the menu offers a great selection of very tasty dishes, I can't help but feel like a lot of it is overpriced. Maybe it's the location?
