I haven't eaten at any other restaurants in the Ferry Building, so perhaps my perspective is a little off. 

It's been easy to get a seat both times for dinner. As the tables are long and thin, expect to share space with other diners. Our waitresses have always been very helpful and knowledgeable about the food, and the trio of salads -- which has differed each time I've been here -- very flavorful and unique. If you're ok with splurging a bit, get some fresh sashimi/nigiri and the kobe beef: again, delicious, but I feel like I can get the same quality dishes elsewhere for almost half the price they charge here. 

I also really like the fried (I think?) avocado, and last time was pleasantly surprised by the Japanese curry -- really different than anything I'd tried and well worth the wait. No dessert here, but fortunately there's a place with ice cream and shakes just around the corner.
author: Justine M.

description: I found something here I really like!  The beef curry.
author: Esther S.

description: Stumbled upon this place and was thoroughly pleased! I got the salad- salad - salad: green beans with sesame dressing, chicken salad, seaweed salad. Yum! Delicious and fresh! I sample the spinach salad and it was alright. The hot food looked amazing! I'll have to try it sometime soon!
author: Natalie B.

description:
Who knew you could get one of the best quality Sushi at this such a casual place!? I truly enjoyed sushi at this place.

I ordered "Omakase Nigiri" this time. Omakase means "Chef's choice" in this situation. Every piece of fish was so flavorful, and you can really taste different flavor of fish. If you order sushi, please do not submerge your sushi in your wasabi/soy sauce mix. Just dub a little of soy sauce only to enjoy the real flavor of sushi. My favorite was Aji and Tai.

Rice was cooked and seasoned really well as well. I wish I could take that skill home.

I'd come back to this place when I am back in SF.
author: Nagisa A.

description: I took one of their prepackaged sushi rolls, and it was a crab/shrimp combo.  Only about 5 pieces for $10 which seemed a bit disproportionate to me but it tasted pretty good.  The others in my group enjoyed their choices also.  I liked all of the choices of boxed meals, lots of little samples to have in them!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Came here during lunch and was recommended their curry, so curry it is!

Really hearty and a great meal, with a slight sweetness (I think most Japanese curries are like this). It was so good that I literally screamed when I almost dropped my bowl of curry.

I've tried their salads as well, and really tasty (though not as filling or price-affordable as their curry). A great place to come to if you're in Embarcadero or near the Ferry Building!
author: Christina C.

description:
Japanese + Fast food (healthier version) + Deli = Delica.

I came here with my boyfriend yesterday for lunch and was utterly surprised at how tasty everything was. The options for the lunch specials were pretty simple, you get three choices (salad, main, soup) and basically any combo of those will be priced differently. The portions were sufficent enough to get you full, but the flavoring of everything was simply orgasmic.

I can not rave enough about the wasabi potato salad (with lettuce, snap peas, slices of potato) and just enough of that wasabi taste to kick your tastebuds into gear.

I also had the salmon chowder which was served warm, very thick, and creamy. 2 small cubes of salmon and a ton of carrots and celery was found amid the chowder. It was warming to the soul on such a chilly day by the embarcadero.

The adegashi tofu was good, but not out of the ordinary. My boyfriend had the burdock salad and absolutely loved it. There was definitely a lot of items on Delica that looked delicious and worthy of going back to try.
author: Ada C.

description: Yummy! I went here on a lunch date with a friend from college, and we were happy. Not very much seating (that's the Ferry Building for you), but this place has a lot of great grab-and-go bento box options, as well as great combos. The menu is a good mixture of fried treats and healthy sushi options, so you can indulge or be healthy as you see fit. All around a solid lunch option for FiDi worker bees!
author: Katie P.

description: I really like this Japanese grab and go place.  They have alot of salad and meat choices and they are really good.  I would have given this a 4 stars if not for the snotty Asian cashier lady at the counter today (lunch time) who was rude and impatient.  Maybe she was the owner that's why she had an attitude.  Not fit for customer service for sure.
author: Desi D.

description: I had their soba noodle soup with tempura...  it was awful.   Other stuff looked good but I would not go back.
author: L L.

description:
Meh... So I'm giving this place a 3-star because I like the food, but just as when it comes to most Japanese food in the US (I lived in Japan for more than a few years), it is overpriced and hyped up for its "healthy" eating. It just doesn't seem "worth it"

In terms of the food itself, it is authentic. You get some real home style Japanese dishes here (ie. something other than sushi). However, all of these dishes are very simple home cooking dishes, so they can easily be made at home. The ingredients are simple, cheap to get in any Asian store, and hard to mess up the cooking. It's not like some crazy hard to cook rare food that takes 3 hours of effort.

So everything I come here... I am conflicted. I like the food, but then feel guilty I just spent 10 bucks to get a tiny portion of something I can cook at home easily for $1...
author: Sam C.

description:
Not particularly impressed, particularly given that SF is a city where you can't walk 10 minutes without tripping over tons of fantastic dining options.

I get that this is more of a quick-service place serving people working nearby for lunch. However, this still doesn't mask the fact that it has a couple things going against it, in my opinion:

1. The attitude. The young woman behind the counter barely listened, and would sigh and roll her eyes every time we asked a question about any item on their menu -- which was self-consciously filled with unusual items like "roast beef sushi" and did not communicate portions etc. on the counter. She acted put-out and haughty that we were not familiar with the "delicia" experience. The snooty french-waiter act might have played if it wasn't basically a mediocre lunch counter with pretentious aspirations.

2. The food was no better than what you'd get at a refrigerated section of a decent market. For example, the "roast beef sushi" was ok, but because it was (intentionally) a chilled dish, the flavor was flat and bland, with nothing to activate the taste. The other items I sampled from my wife's plate were similar.

Did I mention it is overpriced?

Flat. Bland. Overpriced. That pretty much describes this place to a tee. This is particularly astounding considering it is surrounded by vastly superior places in that same Ferry building.
author: Ian T.

description:
The Ferry Building is a constant reminder that my paycheck cries every time I eat out, especially for FiDi lunches. Delica is a Japanese-fusion takeout lunch spot that gets pretty busy during lunch hour. The menu is very overwhelming and confusing if you are coming here for the first time. It repeats "SALAD" to a distressing degree. Should I have a Main + SALAD + SALAD or a triple-threat SALAD + SALAD + SALAD? How many SALADs are in the display case? What's in each SALAD?

I ended up giving a frazzled order for a Main (Tonkatsu) + SALAD (Spicy Burdock) + SALAD (Wasabi Garlic Potato), which cost me about $10. Maybe it's less stressful to just get a pre-made bento box for around the same price. The salads were quite fresh and unique, especially the wasabi garlic potato. If you aren't a fan of wasabi, I probably wouldn't suggest it. The flavors come in phases and the wasabi kicks in last.The Tonkatsu was cold and not the best, so I would probably recommend you avoid it.

You can buy salad by the pound and pay for individual "main" items. I believe there is a sit down portion of Delica? It's all very stressful and confusing for a novice. I did enjoy my food here, but the prices are high for a conservatively-filled take out box.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Running out of places to lunch at in China Basin, Paul H. and I decided to venture out and drive down the Embarcadero.  "Should we go to Red's?  The new Carmen's?  Oh, the farmer's market is goin' on today.  Let's check it out."  (I've been wanting to try 4505 Meats and Roli Roti.)

They had a handful of interesting food stands out, none of which I can remember now, but all the lines were longer than I wanted to waste my lunch hour waiting in.  (No 4505 Meats, no Roli Roti.)  We wandered inside and saw that Delica serves Japanese curry.  Done and done.

We both went with the beef curry.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xlXnPitrO9Mjfq3aPAyNVQ?select=ikbvhMWCAtOWtCk2xjO4UQ)

The meal comes in a take-out bowl and the size is decent for lunch.  Being pretty hungry, I dug right in.  It had all the fixin's I appreciate in curry:  meat, potatoes, carrots, and tomatoes.  I quickly noticed, however, that the meat was scarce.  I only had like 3 1/2 pieces.  Waaaaaah!  I checked with Paul and it was the same for him.  Worse actually, because one of his bigger pieces was all fat.  Taste-wise, it was okay.  It was spicy enough to have a little kick.  But when I asked for Paul's opinion, he thought it was totally bland.  His words:  "You could say I'm somewhat of a curry aficionado.  This curry is really bland and the curry I make at home blows this away."  And I kinda know what he means.  The rice was really good.

Anyways, I think 3 stars is accurate.  It didn't suck and I was happy with the rice, potatoes, and what little meat I did get.  They could make me happy if they added another whole piece of meat and kept out the fatty parts.
author: Joe M.

description:
Delica is right there in the ferry building. I love this spot for lunch. I usually go for the 'Main + Salad + Rice' option (I think it's #4 on the menu).

Main - Pork Cutlet - you get a few pieces of the cutlet which is topped with some of that tangy/delicious katsu sauce
Salad - Eggplant (Seasonal) or Mapo tofu salad - one of my favorite salads ever, I like dressing and feel like everything goes really well together
Rice - White rice - pretty standard and everything you expect from white rice lol

They have a wide variety of items here, something for everyone! The curry is delicious as well. Come here for lunch sometime! Good stuff.
author: Jason T.

description:
This japanese food is pretty good.  
Not the best, but it is more of a deli cafe than a restaurant.  

I think it is worth the money especially for it being in the ferry building.   All the ingredients tasted pretty fresh and everything was tasty.

I tried the fried chicken and a couple of the japanese style salads.
author: Steven F.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by this little market deli-ish spot in the ferry building. 
Didn't realize they served Japanese food until I walked inside. Love that all the food is pre-made (no waiting) and displayed right in front of you. Also love that you can order everything by the piece and try half the menu. 

Loved: 
crab croquette
beef curry
mapo tofu salad (genius)

the chicken meatballs were a little dry

would definitely come back again to sample the other half of the menu. love the pre-arranged bento boxes!
author: Nattie X.

description:
Delica is japanese food with california nuances. got some eats from the deli.

sampling: 
-potato croquette(1.75)
fresh, small potato bits, fried. fresh
-shrimp cake(4)
whole crunchy fresh shrimp with mayo based sauce.
a version of crab cakes.
-chicken dumpling(2)
fried, fresh and delicately flavored.  maybe that's why tonkatsu sauce given.
-rating 3.5 for freshness of ingredients. food not highly seasoned. . 

temakI:
-artisan salads on the high end
-vegetarian bento boxes available.
-ingredients  fresh
-outstanding service.
-will try a soup, noodle next time or.....
author: Victor G.

description: The staff is great and the food is amazing. No thin slice of fish on giant log of rice here.  The nigiris are perfect, the fish fresh and slightly wrapped around the rice. Highly recommended.
author: Lex D.

description:
Three words: vegetarian bento box. Green bean salad, hijiki with soy beans, mushroom/carrot/daikon sushi roll, lightly fried tofu with sauce, marinated daikon salad with carrots and greens. One more word: AMAZING.

Also, the potato croquette was super fantastic. 

I will most likely return and eat their entire supply of...everything.
author: Julia D.

description: Good healthy japanese food. So if you're watching what you eat this is the place to come! It is a pricey, though and if you're like me who used to come here almost everyday for lunch, you'll be broke lol. 4 stars for awesome AND healthy food!
author: Karen C.

description: Worst sushi I have ever had! I am being generous with one star. I've eaten sushi in multiple cities, states, and countries and this place was a colossal disaster. My husband and I had the salmon roll and their signature roll and nothing is special about either roll. The fish didn't taste fresh. The vegetables were old (avocado was brown) seaweed was stale.  Eat somewhere else. Spend your money on better tasting food.
author: Kerri N.

description:
Like throwing darts on a NYSE candlestick stock list, I hoisted one and came up with the Ginger Beef Bowl. Hehe, seriously, my eyeballs just stuck on the GBB and it sounded good...so order up.

Said bowl contained a lot of satisfying goodness, including ground Kobe beef alongside rice, tamago, ginger and scallions. The meal was tasty and satisfying.

The restaurant is quite clean with a nice noon-time crowd. Prices are pricey (hehe), but then we are talking about the Ferry Building Marketplace, so it is tough to eat on-the-cheap here.

3-star galore for my Delica Ginger Beef Bowl.
author: Derek N.

description: For the bento boxes. I had an appointment in the am, so was going into my client's office later than normal. I stopped at the Ferry Building to pick up a lunch to go and boy it didn't disappoint. Hello delicious tender tsukune, tastiest kinipira gobo, creamy wasabi mashed potatoes, and hijiki salad (which i normally hate) that I actually ate and would go back for. Yum yum yum.
author: Soy P.

description:
I love this place! Only reason it's missing one star is because of the way they pack their portions for the lunch combo (a bit small...) 

Regardless, their food is always fresh and yummy! I love coming here with my the co-workers at the company I work for for lunch. My favorite would be that eggplant salad, chicken tofu patty, soba noodles, and the salmon chowder!!! :-D

Oh did I mention even with a line, the line moves pretty fast~

I'm wondering how long it's going to take me to get tired of this place...? Like never?!!! :-)
author: KaYee W.

description:
I once took my Japanese boyfriend here for lunch.  When we walked in he inhaled deeply and said "smell like Japan." He loved Delica.  Thought the food was very similar to what is found in Tokyo deli style eateries.  I had finally selected a restaurant that he enjoyed and it reminded him of home. 

The food at Delica is very good.  I have lunch here at least once a week.  My favorite is the combination with Rice, Green Bean Salad (sometimes they use asparagus) and Fried Shrimp Cake.  The Burdock Salad, Wasabi Potato Salad and the Sweet and Spicy Chicken are also very tasty.  One of my lunch buddies loves the Ginger Beef Bowl.  She told me that she craves this stuff.

At lunch time during the week there is usually a line but it goes quickly.  Seating is just outside of the café in the Ferry Building at a community table or outdoors on one of the benches.
author: Donna P.

description:
Seriously in love with Delica. It's a pretty small place and gets pretty crowded. The atmosphere is pretty nice  however and it's right by the Bay. 

What I fell in love with is their deep fried tofu. It was the best tofu I had ever had. The outside was light and crispy but the inside was soft and so flavorful. AMAZING.

The other item I ordered was the Farmer's Vegetable roll, and again, AMAZING. Though it was a pretty vegetable packed sushi roll, it wasn't heavy. It was light and refreshing,  not the usual overstuffed feeling I get from eating other types of sushi. 

 Not sure if those items were just seasonal or not listed on the online menu. 

Long story short, amazing food.
author: Erica D.

description: Very sustainably harvested and prepared food that is outta this world delicious and healthy!!  Great service to boot! #organic # local #sustainable #美味しい
author: Kevin K.

description: Delica is open late in the evening and we got free drinks as we were in halloween customs. Very nice and smooth yuzu mimosa!!!! We got a comped ichiki salad also as they kitchen was very busy and the wait was long. The waitress was very nice - Maria in making us comfortable. The tuna and the veggie rolls were very good.
author: Kitty D.

description: Maybe a tad on the pricey side but pretty solid lunch option. The chirashi was fresh, and they really load up the tuna on the spicy tuna roll. The salmon rice ball is a pass, but their sushi offerings make this place worth a visit if you want to grab something quickly.
author: Kevin T.

description:
I will tell a big secret - Delica RF1 is a VERY Japanese place.  Of all the SF Japanese restaurants, this place could best compete if they sold the same food in Japan, evident by the fact that you could find RF-1 at the basement floor of department stores in Tokyo (see downloaded pic).  It is not Japanese food from 1970's (like many J-town restaurants).  It gives you a small insight into some of the popular foods in modern Japan.  I am not saying RF-1 is the most popular type of food found in Tokyo as there are vast variety of other options available.  When transplants from Tokyo finds Delica, they are so happy to see a piece of Japan they miss.  

Many people are surprised to hear this, because Delica offers food seemly Americanized.  Nope.  Americanized means taste was altered to fit the likings of American customers.  Food at Delica, along with many places in Tokyo, has been Japanized.  The taste was altered to the likings of Japanese customers - altered so much that it is now considered Japanese food.  Items in this category include: Ramen, Kasutera, Tonkatsu, Hamburg, egg sandwich, etc.

What does this mean?  Well, you might not like their food.  Selling food that was designed to meet Japanese people's preferences to Americans is a crazy idea.  But, they opened a branch here, probably more for marketing purposes rather than for profits.  Japanese companies like to show the equity holders that they are expanding abroad, just like Beard Papa.  I don't care, because I am happy that it is here.   

Like I said, 80% of the Japanese restaurants in SF wouldn't survive if they moved to Tokyo.  Just like San Francisco, restaurant industry in Tokyo is fiercely competitive, so if you are serving food that tastes like something I could cook at home (80% of SF J-Food), you are done.  All you need to know is that Delica's food is surviving the competition in Tokyo.  The food is especially popular among OLs (office ladies) (yes, the word is sexist, but I didn't invent the word).  Don't get me wrong, the traditional Japanese food like tempura and unaju is still popular in Japan, but food in Japan has done though significant transformations since 1945.  It is now quite diverse - while the passion for food has not changed.        

Delica is a creation of Rock Field Co., Ltd.   The founder, Mr. Iwata Kozo, did a direct translation of his kanji characters and named the company Rock (Iwa) Field (ta).  Although the company sounds western, it is completely Japanese company.  The company has an impressive mission - to address the environment, safety, and freshness of Japanese food.  The founder had concerns about the direction of Japanese diet and is making the effort to change for the better.  Positioning Delica branch at the Ferry Building is fitting to their theme.  Where else would you find beef curry that uses Prather Ranch Meat?  Mushroom curry that uses Far West Fungi mushrooms?     

SEATS:  Very limited.  Find a place outside to sit and eat under the sun.

PRICE:  There is a price to the environment, safety, and freshness.  If you want cheaper food, look for MSG infused dishes at cheaper restaurants.  Expect to pay $10-14 for lunch.
$9.50 - Bento box with five items
$7.75 - Regular size curry
$1.50 - Potato coroke
author: トモ T.

description:
I originally wanted to go eat at Hog Island but it was somehow closed that Monday that I stopped by the Ferry Building. After walking around the building, we settled for Delica since I saw good reviews for this place.

The croquettes were pretty light and tasty.  We got to try the potato, shrimp,, and crab croquettes.  The potato ones were the best.  I don't know why, but I also got the spicy tuna cold roll, which definitely did not hit the spot.  I ended up eating the spicy tuna towards the end, because it had way too much sticky rice.  

Maybe the curry is indeed good here.  Maybe I ordered the wrong thing!  If i ever feel like trying out Delica again, I will get their curry!  Otherwise, it was a-okay and a bit pricey for me.
author: Kathy D.

description:
DELICA rf-1 is one of my favorite restaurants among all of the chic eateries located inside the Ferry Building.  It's informal.  You order up your selections at or near the cashier station.  You get your food in recyclable take-out containers.  You grab some compostable utensils.  You find a seat or take it on the go.  The food is beautifully prepared, and the spectacular flavors will surprise you.

Everything I've tried to date has been delicious whether it be the Organic Mabo Tofu Salad, the signature Roast Beef Sushi or the Wild Salmon and Sesame Genmai Rice Ball.

The Shrimp Curry is probably my favorite selection here.  Depending on my appetite I usually go for the regular serving, but I have stuffed myself with the large portion on occasion.  In a mild brown curry sauce expect to find lots of firm baby shrimp, chunks of soft zucchini and tomato pieces nearly melted away.  They use seasonal vegetables in their curry dishes so you may not get the same zucchini and tomato combination that they've been serving up lately.  The curry is served with a generous portion of hot steamed rice to the side allowing you to eat each part separately or all mixed together.

The Potato and White Corn Croquette is outstanding.  It reminds me of the deep-fried taro root pastries found at many Chinese dim sum houses, but it is far less oily.  These are deep-fried also.  It's a smooth, creamy potato center with a delicate crispy, crumbly shell on the outside.  Bite into the croquette and you will discover soft, creamy kernels of white corn inside.  

Most of the prepared food is on display inside the crystal clear deli cases and each looks like a different work of art.  The different bento box selections will fascinate you on looks alone.  I haven't tried any of the bento box selections, but in time I look forward to sampling many of them.

It's not uncommon to see visitors inside photographing the food.  Toro E and several other reviewers have captured some of the beauty of the food in the photo section.  In fact Toro E writes one of my favorite reviews for DELICA rf-1.  This can be found at http://www.yelp.com/biz/delica-rf-1-san-francisco?q=Toro+E .
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Lovelove the hijiki salad! I'm a big fan of soy, seaweed, and edamame, so this salad is like made for me haha. For meat, I love the big crispy nest of shrimp and veggie tempura and the sweet battered chicken. 

The other salads are just ok, I've tasted almost all of them and I only like the hijiki one.

It depends on who's helping you, you can get just a tiny scoop of salad or twice as much. If you really want to be save, just buy the salad in the containers.
author: Novalina N.

description:
During my short trip to San Francisco I wanted to eat somewhere very affordable and satisfied my traveler's appetite and not disturb my great figure ^_^.  So we headed here and I truly loved their salads.  Very nutritious indeed and it kept me full for the rest of our trek through the city.  

I had the Hijiki and Soybean Salad, Spinach and Sesame Salad, and the Shrimp Cake.

This restaurant makes me want to move to San Francisco.  I can't wait to return again. 

Great for vegetarians too!
author: Dianne S.

description:
This is a restaurant that makes you happy. :)
Nice decors/atmosphere, good food, and inexpensive. What makes me the happiest is that the staff here seem genuinely happy to serve, and they don't treat you differently at all according to what you're wearing, or if you seem like one that'll tip more or less. That, is really what set a restaurant apart.
author: Grace S.

description:
Easy & tasty. Bento boxes are a terrific option on a warm SF day (you gotta time this.... a psychic may help), buy a Bento & take outside, sit on a bench (ignore the homeless crazies) and enjoy the Bento & view. Have had a few lunches @ Delica... each has been good. This is a Japanese Fusion deli, however with fresh ingredients, modern preparation, tasty options.  Their menu makes me hungry:  http://www.delicasf.com/menu.html

It ain't cheap, but unless you are a Ferry Building virgin ( ie. never entered the Ferry Building ... know what I mean?) then you know there is nothing cheap in the Ferry Building. Want cheap food? Take the F line street car, go to Market Street around 4th or 5th street. (ok, I admit to never eating "down there" but, have seen the gaudy hawking signs),

Weekends at the F. building are madness ( read crowded ). All the lonely people (oooooh there was a song like that) from Marin & the East Bay flock there, and the "foodies" looking for the perfect peach, tomato, potato at the "farmers market", some complaining "oooh, its sooo expensive."  and then exclaiming "but it is worth it".
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Great quality food with great view of the Bay Bridge, just portion size isn't even enough to fill up a 5 yr old. The Tues special was a bowl of sashimi with rice and miso soup. For $10 I could've gotten a huge bowl of Korean bibimbap that's 4 times the amount of food. But this bowl was the size of a dessert tort. The kale salad was crisp with the right balance of dressing $5. The kelp salad was awesome. I could've eaten 5 more bowls, but again, at $5 a pop.

Great place if you're looking for good flavored and quality with a view from the Ferry Building. Just come prepared to spend a lot of money if you don't want to stop at Rubios on the way home for $1.50 fish tacos like I did.
author: Steve Y.

description:
I wish we had something similar to Delica in Silicon Valley. It's fresh, organic and healthy! And SO many choices - bento boxes, sushi, rice bowls, cold sides, soups, hot sides, and so much more. We ended up getting an agedashi tofu steak, roast beef nigiri, chicken dumpling and miso soup. We enjoyed everything. The flavors were spot on and you could taste the freshness and lightness of the food. Definitely makes for a good lunch spot.

Prices are a bit pricey, but what isn't at the Ferry Building?
author: Cindy T.

description: Had the chicken meat balls, spinach sesame salad and  salmon chowder. All really good, just wished I had more than 2 meat balls.
author: Massimo P.

description: Not bad at all. Interesting concept. Japanese flair on food brought in a deli like atmosphere. There are a bunch of bentos and sandwiches boxed and wrapped up ready to go. It can make for a quick lunch. I got the ginger beef bowl. The crumbled tamago was a nice touch. Gave it a bit of sweetness to the savory beef. I also got the agedashi tofu steak, which was served cold. It was pretty good, but a bit pricey. I didn't know I was suppose to go back up to the counter to pick up my bowl so I was standing on the side waiting for someone to call it out. Fortunately for me, the bowl was still warm. The katsu sandwich was pretty good too, but I wish they would had a choice to make it when you order it. A fresh and hot tonkatsu sandwich would have been better.
author: Lan N.

description:
snack

food: tonkatsu and the kakiage tempura. the food looked great and smells awesome. too bad it was all cold. i probably shouldve asked if it was still hot or if they had any fresh ones. but we all know how fried food tastes after its been out in the open for awhile. ***2/5

service: ordered to go. ***4/5

atmosphere: it looks really nice inside the ferry building. i thought it was a bakery at first, but then saw it has japanese food in there. they have shared seating with some other restaurants nearby. hardly any when we were there. we had to sit outside by the benches where a bird almost pooped on me. but at least you get a nice view of the pier. ***3/5

value: if the food was hot and fresh, it will definitely be better. they didnt even attempt heating lamps to keep the fried food warm. ***2/5
author: Andy Z.

description:
Delica rf-1 is my go to place when I want something 1) quick, 2) fresh, 3) tasty, 4) healthy-ish and 5) Japanese-ish.

Fork over $10, grab bento box, and you are out the door in minutes.  Either back to your office (boo) or to sit outside and enjoy the sunny weather (woo!).    

They have veggie & non-veggie bento boxes with 4 or 5 items.  Like the Chinese Chicken Salad (I thought this was a Japanese deli?), Burdock & Lotus Root Salad, rice (white or rice salad), shrimp cake, etc.  

But whatever you do, don't miss out on the chicken dumplings and the AMAZING wasabi and garlic potato salad!
author: Amy C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon with my girlfriend. The staff was nice and they were pretty quick. I ordered the chicken dumplings with wasabi potato salad and carrot ginger soup. The chicken dumplings were good, but they were lukewarm and a bit small. I loved the wasabi potato salad, but the carrot ginger soup was nothing out of the ordinary. My girlfriend got the pork katsu which was also a bit lukewarm. 

Overall, this is a good place to go if the lines are short, but nothing too special. It would be much better if they kept the food warm!
author: Andrew B.

description:
I was wandering around the Ferry Building at 11:15 AM super hungry and looking for a good place to eat.  Most of the sit-down restaurants weren't open yet, and I was cold, tired and wet from the rain and walking around.  I just happened to walk into Delica and saw that they had Japanese-style curry!  I thought that it'd be a good reminder of home (curry is my mom's old standby) and decided to go with it.  

I got the beef curry with a potato croquette and shrimp cake.  

The beef curry was really good - just enough amount of heat with the beef soooo tender...  it was a BIT too oily for me, but even that was comforting in the rainy weather.

The potato croquette was delish as well - so much crunch on the outside thanks to the panko crust.  The chunks of potato inside may have been a bit too big causing some bites to taste seasoned and others to feel bland... but when dipped in the curry....  yum~

The shrimp cake was my favorite.  It was small, whole shrimps mixed with other yummy fillings, shaped into a disk, coated with panko then fried up to perfection.  The shrimps were so plump - steamed perfectly inside their yummy casings.

All in all, it'd be a great place to stop by and grab a bite if you're around the area.
author: Vicky P.

description:
Eating at Delica's is equally satisfying and dissastisfying, as in you feel good eating but you just want a burger afterwards.  You know that everything is good for you and loaded with nutrients.  I mean come on, any place that offers a lunch combo consisting of THREE salads is up there on the health meter.  Even when I tried to slightly de-healthify my lunch combo by getting the one fried item and two salads, it STILL didn't work.  

Despite my urges to get the sweet sesame chicken as my fried item, I had to veer away from my inner Panda Express and get what I thought looked the most visually magnificent: the Kaki Age.  It is probably the largest tempura fried item I have ever seen.  I mean it's definitely not something you hold in your hand or eat in one bite.  You have to break it apart and for some reason, the shredded vegetables binds it so firmly together that it becomes quite difficult to separate.  I do like that big pieces of white shrimp are incorporated into it.  Unfortunately, all these aren't fried on the spot so they've been sitting in the glass counter and is missing the aspect that I like most about tempura and fried foods in general, the fresh friedness.

As for the Hijiki Soybean Salad and the Mascarpone Corn Salad, I definitely preferred the latter since I'm a die hard corn fan.  I like the creaminess from the mascarpone and a lot of the kernels stick together so it's easy to eat even with chopsticks.  Not to sound redundant but the Hijiki was really healthy and actually makes your body feel good when you're eating it but may be weird if you're not familiar with the ingredients.

If you don't feel like waiting in line, you can choose from many of their pre-packaged bento boxes or rolls.  Everything looked mysterious but what caught my eye was the spicy tuna roll and oddly enough the roast beef nigiri.  Twisting the Japanese cuisine in this way may not jive well with the authenticians but it definitely fits in with the Ferry Building crowd.
author: Shannon L.

description: Solid choice in the Ferry Building.  I got a spicy tuna roll.  A little pricey at $9.50 but they do load the roll with spicy tuna.  Not only inside the roll but they put they put a good portion on top..   Good variety of sushi, hot bentos and appetizers.
author: Josh L.

description:
My review is just for the Ito En Golden Oolong Tea Drink.  It's a bottled oolong tea from Japan that cost $2 here. 

It's pretty strong for an oolong tea, I felt shaky all over after drinking it.  I'll try the green tea next time.  I was running low on cash, but still had enough for it.  

Credit Card minimum is like $7.  Evil.

Updated 8/11/07:
a yelper mentioned the roast beef sushi and I had to try it and finally got a chance.  I got 4 roast beef sushi at $2 EACH.  They are good but pricey.  My total for 4 roast beef sushi $8.68 and I got to use my credit card.
author: Ann L.

description: Everyone working here seems confused and disorganized. Also the food is not traditional Japanese, which is fine except that they also don't seem to have an ingredients list for their workers to share with customers.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
There are so many good options for eats at the Ferry Building.  Delica is one of my go-to's for tasty and different veggie takeout.  

The service is always friendly and very efficient, even patient for those novice customers (tourists) who have no idea what the food is about.  

I often go for the mushroom curry.  The brown sauce is heavy with flavor and texture, and the lightly fried thingys that are sprinkled on top add a nice crunch to the palate.

The salads are all delicious and there are a number of mix-and-match options for the adventurous eaters.  

Of course, what can I say about the fried shrimp cake?  It's easily the best shrimp cake in my universe.  I'm drooling just writing about it.  Chock full of luscious shrimp, it's a taste sensation!!!

Hint:  Check out the prepared to-go items on the left of the lunch line.  They rock and it's way faster.
author: Larry Z.

description: This is an interesting little unique japanese deli.  They have japanese food with a twist to it and serve different types of cool bentos and sushi rolls.  I grabbed the vegetable bento, which came with agedashi tofu, croquette and a few different types of salads, which were ALL really delicious.  The agedashi tofu was great, slightly different twist to your traditional style, but so tasty.  I would love to come again!
author: Jenn T.

description:
Was pleasantly surprised to find Delica open after arriving to the city late.  A friend and I shared tempura, the salad sampler (seaweed & wasabi-potato), the gouda curry, and the pork belly ramen soup.  It was a huge amount of food for two!!

The salads were a highlight of the evening: the seaweed salad was light, fresh, and not at all fishy.  The potato salad was similarly light, with a hint of wasabi that wasn't overpowering at all.  The curry was also really yummy; although we were suspicious of cheese paired with it, it all worked together.

Overall, our meal was delicious and the service was attentive.  Was a little on the pricey side for what we ate (we ended up with lots of leftovers), but the range of flavors was delightful.
author: Amy H.

description:
They have a wide selection of dishes both vegetarian, non-vegetarian, Vegan, and pre-made bento boxes! Fresh, flavorful, different than other bentos.
My favorite is the salmon chowder, and the Soybean/Hijiki Salad.  The food is very fresh and tasty, but it comes with a price!
author: Tanya T.

description: I love the two item lunch combo here. I usually get the wasabi potato salad, black seaweed salad, and tofu chicken pattie. The meatball and crab croquet are also very good.
author: Jenni H.

description:
SALADS amazing but don't EVER get their BOXED SUSHI.  

I've been going here forever to get the burdock root salad, the asian chicken salad and the spinach and sesame seed one.  All are delicious.  But only two stars cuz stopped in late yesterday afternoon  just to grab something for the ferry home.  And ended up with a box of avocado sushi that ended up being the foulest most horrible sushi have ever had.  Though it looked ok through the box, omg.  I never knew avocado sushi could be so inedible.  Dry and old and tasteless....truly terrible and it should have been tossed by them.  Wasted $5 on that.  NEVER EVER SUSHI FROm THEM AGAIN.  EVER!
author: T S.

description:
I guess I'd have to say the food looks a tad better than it really is, however it's still a solid choice.

I had out of towner friends who were bedazzled by the farmers market. They wanted to taste all the food and if you've ever hit the Ferry Building Farmers Market you know that can mean waiting in line for quite some time. Too long at times if you ask me.

My friends got into lines and I headed over to Delica. Thanks to their slick move of having bento boxes ready to go, I snagged the one labeled vegan, paid, and bounced back to start eating while my friends hadn't even gotten a chance to order yet.

Yes the farmers market grub is good, but sometimes those lines are just ridiculous. The bento looked badass however the tofu was lacking, the salads were OK though. Still, a solid and healthy meal for around $9 is a success in my book, especially at a farmers market where you can seemingly drop $20 every few steps.
author: Justin N.

description: Coming from LA I was a little spoiled with my Japanese food. This place is great for a quick grab and go. It's nice sitting on a bench overlooking the bay and eating a pork cutlet. The menu is pretty easy to follow. The food is already pre-made so you just pick what you want. I kinda like that. Overall the food was good...nice atmosphere...but the price for what you get could be a little less...but I was happy.
author: Jacob H.

description:
1 deli * 20 employees * Serving baby portions of food here.

What's wrong with this formula?!

*Don't serve baby portions to adults*.
 
Long line, drawn out process. The employees bumping into each other, confused, questioning what they're supposed to be doing.

Then you're given a HandFul of vegetables
How is a handful of food going to sustain anyone!   More importantly who has the time to arrange a second lunch!

1. Increase the prices

          Or

2. Layoff % of your employees!
author: Ame W.

description: I have been here twice for lunch and given my love for Japanese cuisine, this place offers great Japanese food in a clean, light and tasty manner.....  I would love to come here more often when I have time to come out for lunch.  I typically get the spinach and sesame salad along with the tonkatsu, which is cooked rather well!  If you haven't been, you must go visit and give it a try!  Enjoy!
author: Edward L.

description:
Hits the spot if you are in the mood for sushi. 
Likes:
Well seasoned rice
Frequently changing specials
Good Spicy tuna dip

No dislikes, but worth noting the dinner menu is limited as this is mainly a lunch spot.
author: May G.

description:
My buddy and I were cruising the Ferry building and as we are both fans of Japanese food, we thought we would try this place out. We picked up:

1 Tonkatsu Sandwich
1 Mabo Tofu Salad
1 Salmon Onigiri
1 Sweet & Spicy Chicken Bento

For me, the Tonkatsu Sandwich was definitely the highlight. The pork was just tender enough to make it easy to eat, but chewy enough to balance the softness of the bread (which came from Acme Bread, also in the Ferry Building). What really stood out was the sweetness of the Tonkatsu sauce. It had just a hint of sourness and really made the sandwich as delicious as I hoped.

The Mabo salad was a very pleasant surprise. I love Mabo Tofu and was unsure of what to expect from the salad. The only way to say it is, it's like mabo in a salad, in a good way. Very tasty.

My friend got the bento and the onigiri. Both were made with very fresh ingredients but I wouldn't argue that they were particularly stand out compared to the other two. The salmon onigiri was very flavorful though.

The ingredients are high quality and they have some definite gems on their menu. However, you really do pay a premium when you eat at the Ferry Building and while most of the time I'd give a place like this four stars because I loved what I had so much, the bento seems to be a bit hit or miss. I recommend going a la carte and finding things you like as opposed to buying a pre-made meal.

Cheers!
author: Andrew B.

description:
A return to the Ferry Building for a lunch landed a friend and I at Delica.  The clean, inviting interior sucked us in.  I was all ready to have soba noodles (I caught a glimpse of the words on the menu board and starting salivating like a Pavlovian dog), but then I got distracted by all the stuff in the deli case.  

And then we realized it.  We'd been had.  This place is really just a social experiment on how to get into line.  It was very confusing to try to figure out how and where to order.  "Are you in line?"  "Is there just one line?"  "Can I go ahead?"  "Did I just cut in front of you?"  are all things I asked.  Eventually, we ordered, helped the woman in front of us who was tasked with carrying 80 bajillion things back to her office, and paid.

The ginger carrot soup got the thumbs up from my friend, and I enjoyed the chicken dumplings - highly recommend them, in fact.  The chicken and tofu patty was OK - not all that stellar.  The wasabi garlic potato salad didn't wow me, but the Zuckerman(?) Farms asparagus salad was really interesting and tasty.  

I forgot about my annoyance/confusion about the line when I got outside, and it was 70 and sunny and I could look at the Bay.  I miss SF.
author: Evan G.

description: This place is delightful. The menu is simple, each dish is made there from scratch, and the ingredients are high quality. Top it off with reasonable prices, and I'm a big fan. So far I've had the salmon chowder (the cup is plenty), the carrot-ginger soup, the crab croquette (amaze!), and the wasabi-potato salad (double amaze!). I really want to try their bento boxes, which are certainly a step up from your average greasy bento box during lunch downtown. Getting to eat this lunch watching the water from the Ferry Building adds to the charm.
author: Marcel M.

description:
Had to be some of the worst food in the ferry building. I'm not foreign to new flavors and I love trying new foods. This place had ready made food displayed and it looked good behind the glass. What a disappointment. This is what we got:

Salmon chowder: watery, undercooked pieces of potatoes and just a few pieces of salmon and served with a tiny piece of bread. 

Hijiki salad: just not a good flavor. 

Shrimp cake and tempura nest thing: fried food served cold. We all know how bad that tastes. The nest thing was soggy and nasty. 

Chicken meatball thing and piece of sesame teriyaki chicken. Also cold and bland. 

Wasted 24+ bucks and not going back.
author: Dave V.

description:
************* REVIEW 99 ****************

Great place to have a light afternoon sushi snack & Japanese food. I come here often when shopping for meat & cheese at the Ferry Building, especially after buy everything I don't need at the Farmer Market.

Beside the awesome Bento box that most people like, I never ordered that here. I actually just come here for the sushi & the salads. What I love most is the special daily menu & always fresh surprises. Today was no different, before my shoot, I decided to swing by to pick up some salumi @ Boccalone,  then I ended up here. 

A few dishes I enjoy very much:

- Seared Toro with Daikon, chai & ponzu sauce - so rich in taste.
- Aji with ginger, chai - I always love this shiny mackerel.
- Hirame carpaccio - 8 pieces thinly sliced with cilantro, olive oil, & sliced of Kumquat - so refreshing & delicate to eat. My FAV dish here!
- Tonkatsu - Pork tenderloin cutlet topped with tonkatsu sauce - giant piece for $1.50 - so crunchy-ly good!

Salads that I like:

- Spicy Burdock Root Salad - very nice, sweet & pleasant.
- Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad -  a spicy kick, rich, & will get you full.
- Tofu, green bean salad - surprisingly nice, great dish for vegetarian!

Service here has always been excellent for me. I love sitting here & looking out the water.  Did I mentioned they serve cold sake in traditional glass & box? nice!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: They have a good variety for grabbing and going! I tried their salad/main/rice combo for 8.75 and it was sooo awesome! I chose the pork katsu and chicken salad but even the rice was so good- it had sesame seeds.. I don't think they have seating but on a nice day it is perfect for grabbing and going to find a place to sit outside by the bay :)
author: Karla E.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Tuesday night and had an outstanding experience all around. I am not a local but I frequent SF several times a year and I find that I really enjoy the Ferry Building at night when its halls are empty and there are only a few straggling single diners such as myself looking to unwind from the day.

I ordered the Omakase sushi/sashimi combo dinner which consisted of 5 pieces of sashimi and 5 pieces of sushi of the chef's choosing. Uni was one of the specials that night and the waitress asked if I wanted one as one of my pieces. "Of course!" I exclaimed. Bright orange and super soft, this uni was the sweetest I have ever had. My other pieces were albacore tuna, kingfish, tai, toro and scallops.

My 10 pieces of fish and rice were $35, not cheap but seriously good. I was relieved that the experience wasn't ruined by cheap fake wasabi either. This place serves the REAL wasabi and homemade pickled ginger. I also got a kick out of the sushi chef being a woman!! She is my hero! For dessert, the waitress brought me a matcha cream puff. While the puff wasn't as crunchy as Beard Papa's, the matcha cream inside was really delicious. I am a sucker for anything matcha.
author: Tricia K.

description:
The shrimp cake was absolutely amazing!! There was plenty of shrimp and it was just so yummy. The roast beef sushi is definitely unique to Delica as I have never seen it before, and a must buy. The Kakiage Tempura was okay as there were a ton of veggies,but not much shrimp. The tofu chicken was nothing special as it had very little taste. 

TLDR; Try the shrimp cake and roast beef sushi. It won't disappoint.
author: Edward W.

description:
Came here because it was the only thing open on New Years Eve.
Overall my experience was good, the food was delicious, the service was great, the only problem I had was that my roll (Futomaki I think?) was started about 20 minutes after I had ordered it. I didn't mind too much because my server ended up giving me a 10% discount as well as a free green bean salad. I would definitely go back the next time I'm in SF.
author: Susan Y.

description:
Losing a month long bus pass is painful.

Especially when you lose it at the beginning of the month or half-way into the month.

I have been a victim of these circumstances way too often.

Which speaks highly to the fact that 

1.) I need to get more organized

or

2.) The Universe is telling me to either walk more or contribute more money to MUNI

Anyways, to get to the point -  I lost my bus pass around Delica this past Friday.  Painful, yes. But I was glad to lose it in such a healthy, warm, and uplifting place. The kind woman behind the counter seemed genuinely concerned about my loss, and even tried to get my number incase someone turned it in.

Outside of lost items - Delica is a wonderland of healthy filling and diverse Japanese food items. They carry everything from a variety of healthy salads - packed with tofu and drizzled with fresh dressings, to chicken katsu, to fresh heavenly smelling curries (both meat and veggie), to take-away sushi boxes, to the most adorable unique bento boxes. 

And much more.

If you're able to steal some time away from your office - take the time to visit Delica. They've streamlined their food to make it easy to eat there, or to take your food on the go. The place is well lit, welcoming, and airy, with a considerable amount of seating room - being that it's in the Ferry building.  

Delica isn't exactly cheap - but their food is filling, fresh, and colorful. They take obvious pride in all of their dishes, and the food tastes like it's been concocted and made with love. 

Even though I've lost my magical bus pass for the month of February - I still plan on making many more adventurous trips to Delica before the end of the month.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: LIKE!   We found some of the newest Ito En Teas Tea varieties to hit the US shores.  The new Half & Half tea and juices, ultra premium Japanese drinks that we have never seen anywhere in the United States, yet.    Nice!
author: Greg D.

description:
Popped in here for lunch during a conference at a hotel across the street. Finally, a "sushi" place. Maybe this is true for dinner, but it's definitely not for lunch. A few rolls here and there, and a roast beef roll? Weird.

I had the salad and entree lunch plate.  This consisted of a small amount of corn salad, which was quite tasty, shrimp cakes, which were OK, and a ridiculous amount of bland rice.

There are many other places in the Ferry Building, and even better places in 4 Embarcadero Center to spend your money. Don't waste yours like I wasted mine.
author: Taylor A.

description:
My coworkers and I come here at least 2-3 times a week for about 2 years now. We noticed that the size of the 2 salads and rice combination have shrunk tremendously. Often times, the hand-packed lunch box feels almost empty when they hand them over across the counter. 

If business is tough (which is hard to believe given the daily long lines), either raise the price or offer 2 sizes!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Delicious food, horrible portions for what you pay for. In Japan, if you order curry or fried dishes or teriyaki, you get your money's worth ...and while I get that this is Japanese fusion, just so wrong to stiff you customers on servings. 

I ordered their curry, which was served with a ton of rice, a lot of sauce, a few potatoes and one chunk of beef. The sauce was floating with tons of tiny tender strips of beef that was sooo yummy! But it wasn't super filling/all carb and was still $11. My co-worker ordered their hot meal with one side and came back with 3 pieces of chicken SMALLER THAN A CHICKEN MCNUGGET. And it was $10. The other co-worker, who'd been here before and new the game of ordering, had asked for 6 pieces of chicken with a side, and paid $15...failing to share with my other colleague the insight, but even still WHY should you think to order each piece of chicken separate and THEN have to PAY for EACH piece of chicken??? Excessively overpriced compared to what you get at other places in the Ferry Building.

Only plus was that they had blueberry tea!
author: Alita M.

description: Still wonderful! Kaki-age with shrimp and veggies are AWESOME too!!
author: Sunny S.

description:
A friend and I passed by this place, and after seeing the line, decided to go to the adjacent Mexican restaurant. We were standing in line for that one and then we realized that we didn't understand a single thing on their menu. Cue awkward shuffle out of there. That's how we ended up here.

When you arrive here (for lunch) you can see that there's a huge variety of salads and main dishes. Oh boy! I got the main dish + salad + rice combo, which totaled $8.41. I looked for the most interesting salad that I could find, and ended up with the Hijiki + soybean salad. It consisted mainly of seaweed, so I was really excited. For my main dish, I decided to go with the more traditional sweet and spicy chicken. 

The quality of the food is really high. The salad was every bit the way I imagined it would be - not super crunchy, but sweet and tasty. The chicken was really good and quite filling. The rice was well done, and had ample sesame seeds. 

Unfortunately, I felt that there was not enough food for $8.41. At least add more rice and salad so that the box is heavier!
author: Jason T.

description:
When I'm down in the dumps, 
when my life goes a stumbling, 
when nothing's going well and my stomach is rumbling...

I go to Delica (Delica! Delica!!)
Deep fried tonkatsu pork and tangy tonkatsu sauce (d)
Sesame and bean salad (it's mixed, not toss (-ed))

A delicious pick me up, my heart is a soarin'
Meal combo #4 - it's anything but borin'.
author: Karen K.

description: I like this place...sort of fusion Japanese with meticulously prepared sushi, burdock salad, soups, chicken balls, shrimp and crab croquettes, etc. and supposedly, organic greens. However, as I was almost finished consuming the burdock salad that was part of the bento box, I saw a pink painted fingernail. I was so disgusted to say the least!! I showed and returned the bento box and asked for a replacement. The Japanese lady took a picture of the fingernail and said preparers use gloves and that she'll find out whose nail it was. Really! She should have returned my money and offer me something else! She gave me the same salad, but upgraded the sushi to salmon sushi. She should have pulled out the entire tray of burdock salad from storage! Not sure if I will order that salad or any greens again!
author: L. M. L.

description:
My favorite place to have lunch when I have little extra time to walk around the city and get a yummy Japanese dish! From hot soba to curry rice, I like the food there a lot!! Being Japanese, I'm super picky with where to get Japanese food and this is definitely one of my most favorite places in SF... well, there are not many good Japanese restaurants so this is definitely one of the top 3!! 

I would give 5 stars, but I am keeping it 4 for the improvements. 2 things I'd love to see in the future are 1) good internet connection (I run my own business and even at lunch, I'd like to check messages and be able to communicate) and 2) better customer services. I am definitely very strict on customer service when I know it's a Japanese restaurant owned by Japanese people. I guess I expect a lot. Most of the staff there are great, but some of them lack Japanese professionalism. I know I know... it is not Japan, but U.S.... but knowing they have great food, I would love to experience the whole culture there.
author: Sayaha A.

description:
I used to live near the Ferry Building and this was one of my fave lunch spots.  We were visiting this past weekend so decided to hit up Delica again...and it didn't disappoint.  I've tried most of their food, but really like the Hijiki Patty, Chicken Dumpling, and the Croquettes.

Tons of great choices in the Ferry Building, but if you haven't tried Delica, give it a shot!
author: Christopher P.

description: This place has good options for small bites. Friendly service. Great location. Nothing to complain about. Would recommend and will be back to check out what's available the next time I'm in the Ferry Bldg!
author: Siv L.

description:
I HAVE BEEN LOVING THIS PLACE FOR MY LUNCH, and that's why I attended the "SushiFest Halloween Party".  For $45 ticket ($55 at the door), I was a very disappointed to see how limiting the menu was.  

Well,,,, it's actually our faults for not reading the fine print.  Yep, that tiny disclaimers that you ALWAYS see when it comes to something tricky. 

"Appetizers and Nigiri Sushi" ONLY.  Yeah, but I didn't know we were allowed just one, only one, exclusively one, i already told you one, quit it, you're making me mad one, item each.  **sigh**

Overall, good Halloween event with great atmosphere, friendly crowd and fun music.  It seemed well planned and executed, but would people who actually paid that $45 come back next year, seriously?  Not, not a chance.
author: Kioko O.

description: Fresh, Fast, and Friendly! Picked up a quick dinner before taking Amtrak. I got the $8.95 "salad+salad+main" deal: ordered the Hijiki & Soybean Salad, Chinese Chicken Salad, and the Spinach & Sesame Salad. All were absolutely delectable and the young man working the counter was so pleasant! I'd definitely recommend Delica to anyone looking for healthy but tasty Asian cuisine!
author: Alyssa A.

description:
No happy hour at Hog Island on Tuesdays, so off to Delica it was!

My boyfriend and I shared the daily special (chicken karaage donburi and miso soup), lotus fries, spicy tuna dip, delica roll, and a glass of sake sangria. Normally, I would never spend $10 on chicken karaage, but what the hell, it's the Ferry Building. And it was freaking worth it. Fried, yet moist! The portion looks small, but is super satisfying. 

Lotus fries were also a hit, though I would have preferred them a bit warmer. Spicy tuna dip totally hit the spot, spicy with a kick, but not enough to send you running for water.

Didn't care too much for the sangria or the delica roll though. I figured the roll would be good, since it's eponymous.  Not so...way too much rice and the combination of ingredients clashed too much...broiled fish with fried shrimp on top of a salty orange sauce. Stick to the sashimi!

Even though the roll sucked, Delica gets 4 stars for having tasty Happy Hour items and fantastic service! We were seated promptly and all the food came out in less than 10 minutes.
author: Michelle N.

description: My friend and I don't look the part of the clientele here but, that's no reason to give shitty service and stare at us as we eat. We ordered a bottle of wine and sat at the bar. We were fine drinking that and got pressured into ordering food. The weds special is the mini spicy seafood salad which was a pretty good portion with a side of rice along with the grilled avocado (half of an avocado) both were mediocre . I might have given a 2 if it weren't for the snooty looks .
author: Brenda C.

description:
I'm in love.. 

I'm in love w/ their organic agedashi tofu steak and their tofu/chicken patty w/ Hijiki.  The tofu was soft yet did not break at the touch of my fork... savory, a little sweet, and so light that I would not feel guilty eating 5 of these even though these babies are deep fried.  The tofu/chicken patty was not deep fried and it reminded me of a Vietnamese dish called "trung duc" which is somewhat similar to "cha trung".  I never tasted any dish that reminded me of the 2 dishes I mentioned above so I pretty much inhaled it and was nostalgic a bit because I used to eat trung duc a lot as a kid.  

Service- awesome! 

Selections- didn't notice anything else because I'm trying not to over eat.

Restrictions- no carbonated beverages (that's right, no Coke Zero).  I almost cried.

Pricing- PRICEY but you can't put a price tag on quality!

Overall- one of the best girl dates ever.  Thanks for suggesting lunch here, Lora!
author: Tram N.

description:
Despite being a Ferry Plaza dweller, I've never noticed Delica, a bustling Japanese deli, before. Workers on their lunch break lined up to grab prepared bento boxes or to make their own combos of 'salads, mains and/or rice.' Lots of locals--an indication of good eats. 

I ordered white rice, a chicken dumpling ($2) & 3 pieces of spicy chicken ($1.50 each.) While you won't find a wallet-friendly lunch here (my gf spent $20 on a salmon roll & a salad combo), you will find Delica's flavors delicious & interesting. The wasabi potato salad is a spicy twist on the original. The Chinese chicken salad (funny, I thought this was Japanese food!) looked appetizing with its large pieces of veggies & chicken; I'll try that next time. 

Seating inside & in the general area is scarce, especially during the lunch rush, but you'll find plenty of spots to call your own outside with a view of the water to boot.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I'm a big fan of the tasty bento boxes with choice of combos. I like to enjoy them with a friend while sitting at one of the indoor large wooden tables, or more likely, outdoors enjoying the view from the Ferry Building.

Start with the rice, sprinkled with black sesame seeds. Add the Asparagus with Traditional Sesame Dressing (my favorite!!).

Try either the Tofu & Chicken Patty with Hijiki or the Organic Agedashi Tofu Steak.

I never get any of the fried options.

A filling combination if you don't want a heavy lunchtime meal. 

It's a treat for the $10 price tag, but I always find it satisfying.

The downside are the two crazy lines -- one for bento combo boxes (unless you purchase a pre-made bento outside of the shop) -- and the other for single item orders.

I wish they would put up some signage for the uninitiated to ease confusion.
author: Diana V.

description: Their scallops and crab cakes were wonderful, unfortunately they're served room temperature even though we asked for them warmed up
author: Jace C.

description:
I had my first bento box from Delica just a few weeks ago! Again, one of those Country Mouse comes to the city stories... 

If you are a soup fan, try the carrot ginger soup from Delica. Nom, nom, nom! With that I had a edamame and seaweed salad and shrimp tempura. All of these were delicious. But it's the carrot ginger soup that really sticks out in my mind.

Can't wait to go back and have some more of that stuff!
author: Abby S.

description:
I haven't reviewed this place yet?  Crazy! 

The line can get pretty long, so I try to get there by 11:45ish if I'm going for lunch on a weekday.  They have several entrees and salads from which to choose in various combinations.  Sometimes I'm in the mood for a couple of salads and some rice on the side, but lately I've been into the 3 salads + a cup of their delectable carrot & ginger soup.

So back to the salads.  They're not the typical salads you'd see at a deli, but remember...this is a Japanese deli!  The hijiki & soybean salad is a staple, so I always get that.  The spicy burdock salad is also tasty (and not too spicy) as are the string beans (tossed in a very light ginger dressing) and the spinach salad.

If you want something a little more substantial, they have a few entrees on the menu.  The last time I tried the chicken tofu patty and enjoyed that.

The best thing is that I feel really good after eating here.  There's a lot of flavor and I don't feel gross later.

As far as seating goes, you're pretty much limited to sitting outside or at one of the community tables between Delica and Mijita, so it's not a "dine in" experience for lunch.  I usually take mine to go.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Sure, it's a deli by day ... but we've been here a couple of times in the evening when it turns into more of a sushi bar/small plate place frequented by Japanese businessmen in suits.

They have the best grilled squid I've had locally, and it is hard to go wrong with the other small plates.  The sushi is very high quality, and worth the price.

Servers are very friendly and also seem very careful to explain dishes to those who might not quite know what they are ordering.

If it were only closer to home, we'd be here every week.
author: Albert H.

description: I LOVE this place!!! The ginger beef bowl is soooo delicious!!!! They also have great sushi and salads! Their staff is amazing too!
author: Jessica O.

description: Just had an early dinner at Delica. We ordered a variety of items from the menu board and the display case.  My advise is that if something on the case looks good, ask to try it first.  The cold salads were all delicious.  Salmon chowder was on the sweet side (not what your taste buds expect) and carrot/ginger soup lacked any seasoning (but was tasty once I added a fair amount of salt).  The "spicy" tuna roll was HORRIBLE. The tuna was completely without any seasoning at all...NO salt or SPICE. I think the chef literally forgot to season the fish before making the roll.  The tempura nest was completely cold and greasy (it's probably decent if you ask them to make it fresh) and the Agassi tofu main dish was as awful as the spicy tuna... Hard, bland and completely tasteless. I have to say, though, when I took the unacceptable dishes back inside and gave the manager my feedback, she graciously refunded my money, thanked me twice for letting them know that I was not pleased and offered to make me fresh dishes, free of charge. Bravo for the excellent customer services.
author: Nichole M.

description: Cold everything.  Cold rice.   Cold chicken meatballs.   Terrible.   I expect salads to be cold but not my rice and meat when I eat it in the restaurant.  One of the worse meals ever and that's after spend 60 bux for 5 people not including a drink.  So disappointing.  And now I have a stomach ache to top it off.
author: B S.

description:
***Good***
Solid sushi and vegan salads. Very tastey. 

***Bad***
A little pricey for the amount of food you get. Unideal hours, as are all ferry building places.

***Recommendation***
Crab and Lobster sushi roll and the hijiki salad.
author: Nick K.

description:
I have found my missed Tokyo Japanese cuisine flavor.  I went here during lunch time on a weekday, and there are two lines.  One to grab the prepared bento to go where as another to select the items you want.  I picked the latter and waited quite a while longer.  

I chose the eggplants and pork cutlet.  The eggplants are excellent cold dish item.  It's perfect for warm summer days.  The texture of eggplant is firm without being soggy. The minced meat and sauce on the eggplant makes this an very appetizing lunch item.  The pork cutlet are given in 3 small pieces. They are plenty stomach-fulfilling but the taste is not memorable. All I can remember is the eggplant.

Come down to Delica and enjoy a great tasting Japanese flavor with a front row seat of the bay.
author: Steven M.

description: I like that they have many vegan options and everything is clearly marked "vegetarian" or "vegan" on the menu. Went here for lunch and got the hijiki rice ball and the veggie bento box so I could try a bunch of different things. Everything in the bento box was vegan except for the potato croquettes. The only portion I thought was good was the asparagus salad. All of the other items - croquettes, hijiki salad, spicy burdock salad, and tofu steak were too bland for me. Bento box was too pricey at $10.25 for small portions and mediocre tasting food. Maybe some of their other dishes are better...
author: Kim D.

description:
First off, the food is presented so attractively that you want to buy and try EVERYTHING.  The next step is deciding what you actually can consume during lunch and since the longs are very long, you will have ample time to peruse the offerings, which change all the time and are made of the best and freshest ingredients.

I ended up getting the spinach/sesane salad, a chicken/tofu patty, and a hijiki and soybean salad.  Everything was delicious and very well prepared and seasoned.  I only wish that the chicken/tofu patty was served warm instead of cold.  I'd definitely get it again, but will ask for it to be heated up.

My lunch companions basically got everything they sell that was deep fried.  I tried a couple of sample tastes, and was really impressed, especially by the potato croquette.  Mmm......

Check it out for a healthy lunch!
author: .Hon H.

description:
One word--Chinese Chicken salad. 

Yum. Fresh crunchy veggies; sweet and tender chicken steamed with Japanese cucumber, daikon, carrot and crunchy celery tossed in a sesame oil, chili and soy dressing...kill time while watching the ferry dock....Jiù zhèyàng, hn hào ch zài dngdài yshu tíngzh..lo siento...Sore wa ame ga teishi suru no o matte iru ma ni tabete sō hijō ni yoidesu.
author: Reyz A.

description:
LOVE this little Japanese deli! The only reason we can't give them 5 stars is because they had run out of their more popular dishes by the time we got there. (Note to self: next time, go there early for lunch!)

Everything we had was awesome. It's a little pricey, but it was the perfect picnic food for us to take to Crissy Field and help us enjoy the view.
author: A -n- M.

description:
Came through here after seeing so many great reviews.  PLEASE KNOW that I DID REALLY REALLY REALLY REALLY want to LOVE this place.  But I guess it just wasn't for me.  They serve various Japanese dishes that you don't usually find at the normal Japanese restaurant.  During my visit to Japan this was the type of food you'd normally see at the HUGE markets of pre-packed lunch boxes.

The place looks very clean and a great display of items to order.  They have a great selection and everything looks and tasted very fresh.  The employees were very nice.

The place is a bit pricey, but so are all the other places in the Ferry Building.

I don't think I'll ever come back here again (or maybe I will to try the hot food, since I only tried the cold), but I will not deprive it of it's greatness. It fully deserves 4 stars in my opinion.
author: Pia V.

description:
Not the best sushi I've ever had, but a good choice for quick fix before jumping on the ferry. The agadashi tofu was actually more memerable than the sushi. The tofu was covered in sauce yet still had a nice crunch.

The regular pricing seems a bit steep to me, but the happy hour prices are a good value.
author: Glen L.

description: I've only had a few things at Delica's but I LOVE them enough to give them 5 stars.  The fried shrimp cake or crab croquette are such a treat.  However, my favorite is the chicken dumpling in sweet chili sauce.  I was just there with a group of friends.  We were making our rounds to different places in the Ferry Building and trying/sharing small bites.  The chicken dumplings were a winner.
author: Lizardp P.

description: I didn't realize this place was two separate operations at first. The deli area and a smallish restaurant. Having a discount code we decided to give full dinner a try. As we looked through the menu it was pointed out to us that they had a list of daily specials. Doing a quick calculation we decided to get one of everything on it. Sushi, fried items, and some of the deli. Very good all around. Service is really friendly and I think the specials are definitely the way to go. If you're craving some unique Japanese fare, definitely hit this place up
author: Kim N.

description: One of my favorite lunch spots. I always get the #1 Lunch Combo (1 Main, 2 Salads). You could also substitute one of the salads for a cup of their soup of the day. My favorite salads are the eggplant salad (seasonal), the asparagus salad (seasonal), the chicken salad and the spinach salad. My favorite mains are the pork cutlets, the sweet spicy chicken and the crab croquette. The salmon Onigilly (rice ball) is also a tasty add-on. I tried the soup option once - I think it was a seasonal Pumpkin soup. The soup wasn't my favorite. 4 stars also because lunch costs just under $15 which is pricey but I do appreciate that they use organic ingredients.. also it's hard to deny how beautiful SF is as you're walking towards the Embarcadero during a lunch break.
author: Nadine D.

description: This place is awesome!  I have been here nearly a dozen times in the last couple of years.  I try to go here any time we are in SF near the Ferry building.  This Japanese fusion place has the best salads and small bites.  I always get seasonal vegetable salad with the miso dressing, wasabi potato salad, and I love the tofu! My husband loves the roast beef sashimi and the croquettes.  Looking forward to going here again soon.
author: DN T.

description: It's fine, it's literally only barstools, not very comfortable but they're open relatively late in FiDi and the dishes are sort of expensive. I had salmon and crunchy shrimp roll + fried tofu + a Kirin beer and it was over $20.
author: Sonya Z.

description: We were meeting up with some friends in the Ferry Building and since it was packed with post B2B people we nixed the idea of any kind of sit-down option. Japanese comfort food sounded pretty great so we decided to check this place out. I got the beef curry bowl, fried shrimp patty, and a spicy tuna roll. My friend got a sesame chicken set, a giant vegetable tempura ball, and potato salad. Overall, not bad--the spicy tuna roll was especially fresh and large, very satisfying. The curry was delish, and the shrimp patty was a nice gut bomb to end the meal. My friend thought his stuff was OK, with the vegetable tempura being the winner. The stuff is rather pricey for the portions--we ended up spending $43 here (with a bottle of water)! Craziness, but when you're hungry...
author: Steph H.

description: Delica has good lunch combinations: salmon roll is nice and fresh and goes down your mouth nice and easy.  Potato croquette is crunchy and delicious, shrimp cake is amazing.
author: Andy L.

description:
i picked up one of the vegetarian bento box for lunch today and it was delicious! tofu steak, burdock root salad, and hijiki salad and some steamed rice for $9.75. yes, that's a litte pricey for lunch box but it was healthy and tasty. 


i also enjoyed the chinese chicken side salad.
author: Helen Y.

description: Delica offers excellent, well-balanced food, at an excellent price. If you want to get value for your money and eat some delicious and healthy food, please go to delica. This place is perfect for lunch.
author: Herman R.

description:
Imagine the perfect day in San Francisco.  It's sunny, in the mid-70s, and there's a slight cool breeze every so often.

Sure, it happens every so often, but how likely would that fall on a weekend?

I make up for it by going to Delica during a weekday lunch.

It's basically a Japanese deli with a few dishes of warm food.  I almost always gravitate towards the Japanese beef curry.  Not too big, not too small - just the perfect lunch portion.  If I'm feeling extra hungry, I'll throw in a genmai rice ball.

Now find an empty bench overlooking the ocean, and you're good to go.
author: Jenny L.

description: Wow! Food quality is amazing. Not oily, light, and refreshing. I wasn't expecting anything special but I was wrong. So good I had to post a review.
author: jeanne l.

description:
I ordered the beef  curry under the recommendation of the yelp reviews. it was decent, but nothing special. I'd describe it as kind of like a beef-chuck stew meat dish, but with Asian flavors. I'm sure it's an authentic Japanese dish but my guess is if you are a big fan of the spicy Thai or Indian curries you will probably find it a bit boring like I did. 

It's probably not fair for me to rate something 3 stars for a Japanese dish I've ever had before , but regardless $10 is kind of expensive for a stew meat dish. 

I also ordered a crab croquette which was good. I knew beforehand it would be cold since they are served ready-made sitting chilled under the counter, though I think it could be even better if served hot. 

Service was friendly!
author: Eddie D.

description:
Came here for lunch from cousin's recommendation.  I had the 3 item combo meal (rice, salad, main item) for $7.75.  I chose the Hijiki and Soybean salad along with the Tofu & Chicken Patty with Hijiki for main dish.  For these combo items, I thought the selections were a little limited, but I was surprised at the generous portions they give for the salad and rice.  

Food was good.  I thought tasted like authentic Japanese food.  I only wish they had more food selection and more seating.
author: Erica S.

description: I must have passed by Delica hundreds of times but today was the day I finally tried it out and I really enjoyed it.  I had the #1 lunch combo and got the  wasabi potato salad, Chinese chicken salad and roast beef sushi.  All had been Yelped about so I wanted to try them all out and they were great.  The potato salad and chicken salad could have been cut down a little bit but otherwise everything had a really good flavor.   The roast beef sushi was delicious too.
author: Blake B.

description: I usually tend to go to places in the Ferry Building that I'm comfortable with.  Roli Roti on Thursdays, Blue Bottle for coffee, Cowgirl for a grilled cheese, and Acme for some bread.  So then I see Delica here on the listing of options and then I get this massive craving for curry on rice.  Japanese curry is something that I usually get from the food truck Japacurry and I felt like I wanted to try something different.  So arrived here and I did something that I usually don't do.  I ordered the vegetarian curry on rice.  Yes vegetarian.  Didn't want the taste of the meat messing up with the curry and if the curry can stand up on its own, then the meat curry that they have should be even better!  After a few bites, it was indeed tasty and somewhat justifies the high Ferry Building price point of their food.  There are probably other items on their menu that I want to try but I think I can add Delica into my Ferry Building rotation until I find a worth replacement.
author: Ben H L.

description:
I can't always make it to this part of town, but when I do, I always make it a point to stop in, even if I am stuffed to the brim. The food is spot on Japanese with many modern twists. The food is high quality and the flavorings are perfect. It IS set up like a deli or take out joint. I like sampling their bento, with different and often new dishes to try out. I tried their hijiki (a kind of seaweed that looks like black grass) which is normally prepared sauteed with fried tofu sacs (abura age) and slivers of carrots (somewhat like this: http://justbento.com/handbook/johbisai/stewed-hijiki-seaweed-carrots-and-fried+tofu). Theirs included shelled edamame, which would have made me freak, since I mostly eat edamame boiled, salted and with a nice cold Japanese beer. But they got it right! The edamame was not mushy as I would have suspected, and complemented the other ingredients.
