I often don't bother getting any sushi from take out joints, because it often sits on ice or refrigeration which just makes the rice stale and hard. However, theirs are freshly made, and, if you time it right, can be quite good. The sushi is generally traditional Japanese style sushi, so if you are looking for the deep fried American style makizushi smothered in hot sauce and mayo, you would be disappointed. In fact, if that is your idea of Japanese food, please skip this place so I can hoard more. Slanted Door on the other side of the building might be more your speed ;)
author: 和子

description: I absolutely love the lunch combos here. I think the salads are fantastic for the work day because most of them have edamame (protein) but are light enough to make you guilt free and alert after lunch. Also, they are rather generous with the salad portions. I end up paying about $10 for the #2 with carrot ginger soup and it's so worth it. Just be aware that the line gets massive around noon, so take your lunch a bit later to avoid the wait.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Cons:
-insanely expensive for insanely small portions
-right next to the door that opens directly to the pier, so random pigeons just fly in and walk around as if they're patrons

Pros:
-very friendly servers
-interesting fusion

Quality of food isn't bad (the roast beef sushi was pretty good), but I feel like I would rather spend $10 on a hearty meal at McDonald's than to spend the same amount for 4 little pieces of sushi. I guess I'm not really a man of fine taste...but still, I think the amount they charge you is unreasonably high...

I don't think the place is bad, but I'm probably not going to come back here, unless every other store in the Ferry Building happens to be closing down.
author: Justin K.

description: I came here with a friend and had their chef's special spicy tuna roll and a salmon roll. While both were extremely pricey, they were only marginally good. The chef's special was a decent-sized hand roll with more rice than anything else, and while the salmon roll did have a good balance of salmon to salmon skin and avocado, it was still just mediocre in flavor. Really expensive stuff though.
author: Danny C.

description:
The new menu items caught my eye: ginger pork bowl and okonomiyaki.  They had the actual dishes on display outside the door.  The okonomiyaki was tiny ($5, 2 kinds: vegetarian (mushroom) and chicken), so I ordered the ginger pork bowl ($10).

The ginger pork was cooked to order.  I received four large, thin pieces of boneless, marinated, pan fried pork chops nestled over a bed of steamed white rice, finely shredded raw cabbage and a drizzle of ginger-soy sauce.  The portion was quite generous.  The sauce was too salty and not very gingery.  The pork was quite tough, like my own attempts to cook pork chops at home.  

I'd skip the ginger pork bowl and stick with their croquettes, rice balls, side salads (my favorite is the Hijiki and Soybean Salad but I like all of their salads) and the scrumptious chicken dumplings.  The chicken dumpling isn't just a mushy meatball; water chestnuts add a pleasant crunch, the shitake mushrooms add flavor and texture and the tofu makes it light and tender.  I love their preassembled bento boxes ($9.50 each) - a quick way to grab a healthy, satisfying, portable lunch.  Add on a Japanese bottled drink if you want.

The food isn't a bargain ($2 for one piece of roast beef sushi) but it is fresh, seasonal, high quality and elegantly presented.  You can see that they're busy chopping veggies and cooking in the open kitchen.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I really like this place.  

The beef curry is excellent.  The quality of the meat is very good.  There were several large chunks of tender beef in the curry sauce.  The potatoes tasted good and was well cooked. They used high quality ingredients.  The curry sauce had the right amount of spice. 

 The hijiki rice ball tastes really good and was inexpensive.  The kakiage tempura was good. It had a lot flavor and substance. Whereas other sushi restaurants would serve tempura that is 50% batter, this place's tempura had very little batter. I could actually taste what is in the tempura. 

  I was really impressed with the roast beef sushi.  The roast beef sushi, aside from being visually striking, tasted really good.  The roast beef is really good (I am  not talking about the roast beef you get at a Subway sandwich shop.) The meat was very tender. It literally melted into my mouth as I bit into it.  

The tonkatsu and wasabi potato salad was fine.  I will go to this place again, even though it is a little pricey.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
Whenever I'm in the ferry building, I always have to stop by here just to see what they've got that day, and most of the time, pick up a snack.  

My favorites so far have been the croquettes and the sake onigiri.

This place is small and reminds me of the 'conbinis' in Japan, just a little more pricey and fancy maybe.  Loved everything I've gotten there so far.
author: Jenna L.

description: i usually love this place but after i got my meal today (#4: salad, rice and chicken dumpling) i noticed, after i got back to work, that there was a long strand of hair in my salad. it was lodged in it that when i pulled it out, it broke, so i had to search for the other half and pull it out again. :( i know it's not may hair cuz my hair is currently blonde. place is too far to return my food or even complain. hair in $10 worth of food!
author: Maya B.

description:
I absolutely LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. I used to work in SF, and ate here almost every day. I was so broke. The bento boxes are to die for. I've never had anything that I don't like.... I am not a fan of wasabi, but their wasabi mash potatoes are delicious. 

I also love the assortment of teas. The mango ice tea is my favorite, by far. Green tea is always a classic! 

My only complaint is that this place is expensive! It's soooooo good, that I don't even think about how much I've spent. I'm just glad I don't work in the city anymore.... because EVERYTHING is ooooo soooo delicious.
author: Jenn R.

description: I've seen my coworker come back from Delica with cute and healthy looking bento boxes for lunch so I finally went and got my own. I was a little disappointed that my #1 combo (main, salad, salad - had mine with tonkatsu, spinach salad, and hijiki salad) didn't come with rice. I'm  not sure if it's supposed to, but it would've gone well with the tonkatsu and accompanying sauce. The salads were flavorful but light. However, being veggies, it was only mildly filling, hence the need for some breaded and fried meat. They put my food in a rectangular white take-out paper box and not a bento box. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing? I'd order from Delica again but will pay more attention to the menu next time.
author: Bella L.

description:
What does the name of this place even mean?!  I can understand the Delica part, but rf-1?!  I think it's another case of confused Asian people butchering English grammar, but that's okay.  I think it's amusing.  A friend once told me that in some places in Asia, they purposely hire people with terrible English so that the effect is cutesy.  You know, like when you buy stationary paper that says: "I love heart happy every day we play like me and garden friends ."  If you were ever an Asian girl, you know what I'm talking about.

ANYWAY.

I came here today thinking it would be pretty tasty, but the food was very meh.  The last time I came here, my bento box was delicious and everything was well-paired.  Maybe it was an off day for them today?  

HIT:
+ It's not too expensive, I suppose.  It's about $10 for a custom-made 4-item bento box, which I think is standard for lunch.
+ It's pretty healthy.  They've got several seaweed, soybean, lotus, vegetably salads that are pretty filling and make you feel good about yourself for eating relatively healthy.
+ I had their chicken dumplings the first time I came, and they were sweet, savory, and a nice way of getting your protein.
+  It's in the Ferry Building, always a nice place to take a stroll.

MISS:
- FOOD BLAND. NO TASTE.  DO NOT LIKE.
- The first time I had the potato croquette, it was really tasty.  Today, it was just really meh and cold.  
- Warning: The 4-item bento box is really just 3 items plus rice.  WHAT!  How deceptive!  Rice should NOT be considered an item!  

Final word:  At least the waterfront's nice.
author: Vivian C.

description:
There's always a line at this place in the Ferry Building (by Peet's) but there are so many options, I've been too overwhelmed to go before. Met a friend there for lunch recently.

I got the 2 salad & rice deal - $7, w/ tax $7.60. Hijiki and Soybean Salad & Chinese Chicken Salad with white rice. 
 Hijiki and Soybean Salad  - really nice but hard to describe. The flavors are very light & mild. Hijiki is a black seaweed that is very tasty when mixed with edamame, soybeans & cooked in soy sauce. It's a beautiful presentation with all the colors - green, black, brown, & some red.
 Chinese Chicken Salad  - nothing spectacular but decent. The chili/sesame oil paired well with it. I liked that the veggies were still a bit crunchy to counter the steamed chicken's softness. 
 White rice - standard so good. 

My friend got the salmon & rice ball & a cup of carrot/ginger soup. She really enjoyed hers as well.
author: Marissa H.

description:
I ordered Osechi from Delica this year. ( Pictures: http://www.bunnyeats.com/2009/01/osechi-from-delica-rf-1.html  ) 
 
I think almost all Japanese people who live in Japan eat some sort of Osechi for the new year celebration.  (FYI We celebrate January 1st / western new year's day).

Osechi consists of many good luck dishes. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osechi New Year celebration is one of the biggest holiday of the year in Japan.  Osechi dishes are prepared before new year's day and eaten 1st through 3rd of January (Called Sanganichi) so that women do not have to cook and can enjoy the celebration with family and guests.  All the dishes are displayed in beautiful lacquered boxes and consumed cold. They are prepared to last at least 3 days by either braised, salted, pickled, candied or dried. We usually visit family and friends and eat Osechi at different houses for the 3 days.  Each region and family have different variation for their Osechi.  The restaurants, schools, stores, and almost all other stores are also closed for the first 3 days (it is changing now 10 years ago or so and some store stay open through the new year).     .  
 
This years Osechi at Delica was $300 ($50 discount if you bring back the lacquer box from previous year).  The menu included:
 
1st Tier:
1. Seasoned Prawns - Tasted like Preservative or chemical...  May be farm raised imported shrimp?
2. Rolled Kobe style beef with Burdock - I liked the tasty crunchy burdock but Kobe style beef was too fat to be eaten cold.
3. Roast Beef - It was tender and nicely cooked medium well.  I think it could use little more seasoning and should have been sliced thinner.
4. Smoked Salmon with Fromage Blanc - Tasted ok but it's NOT Osechi!
5. Slow-Cooked Abalone - Nice flavor and nice texture beautify presented in the Abalone shell
6.  Marinated Herring Roe - It was beautifuly prepared without any membrane but tasted bitter and I didn't eat them.  When you prepare herring roe, you have to be careful not to over soak them.  If you take away too much salt from the roe, it become bitter and uneatable.  
7. Kombu Cured Sea Bream (Tai) - Tasted elegant. The tast of Kombu came through.
8. Roasted Duck Breast - Perfectly salted.  Tender and not too fatty.
9. Salted Olives with Cheese - It is NOT Osechi and made everything in the box smell like olives.  PLEASE DO NOT PUT OLIVES in Osech next year!
 
Second Tier:
10. Pickled Daikon and Carrot with Dungeness Crab - I think they shouldn't have put Crab in Namasu (Picked Daikon /Carrot).  Crab is not traditional and didn't go well with the dish.  Also, crabs had cartridges in them...  The vegetable tasted the way they suppose to be.  Sweet sour and good.
11. Braised Burdock Root with sesame - Kansai style vinegary burdock.  
12. Caramelized Dried Anchovy with Pine Nuts - I never liked this dish as I grow up but I was pleasantly surprised I liked them for the first time.  It was nutty and not too sweet.
13. Sweet Black Beans - Perfectly cooked plump and shiny beautiful large beans. I could tell they used high quality "Tanba" beans from Japan. 
14. Mashed Sweet Potato with Chestnuts - One of the best Kurikinton I ever had.  Not too sweet.  I could taste wonderful character of Japanese sweet potatoes.
15. Pickled Chrysanthemum Shaped Radish - Very beautiful and refreshing
16. Karasumi Bottarga (Salted dried Mullet roe) - Thinly sliced high quality Mullet roe. Very tasty reminds me of aged (24month+) Gouda.
 
Third Tier
17. Braised Shitake Mushroom Taro, Bamboo Shoot, Carrot, Lotus root, Konnyaku and Green Peas - I loved every bite.  Perfectly cooked in light Japanese fish broth. Only thing was Lotus root was little overcooked..
18. Baked Omelet with Shrimp Puree - Nice light texture with hint of shrimp flavor.  I ate it with soy sauce and wasabi.
19. Black Cod w/ Sweet Miso - Tasted very good cold.  Black Cod was fatty in good way
20. Minced and Roasted Chicken with Saikyo Miso Topped with White Sesame.  It was good but I think they put too much chicken fat in it.  May be needed little more saltiness too.
21. Rolled Kombu - nicely cooked soft and tender high quality kombu 
  
Overall, I was very pleased with Delica's osechi.  I had low expectation since I never had a great store-bought Osechi before even in Japan.  Except a few dishes I mentioned above, everything tasted great.  I also liked the fact they did not use too much sugar in their cooking (In Tokyo where I grow up, Ochechi have "Amakara" sweet and salty seasoning which I do not like...)  I think their seasoning style is Kansai (western Japan) style.  I will buy their Osechi again if I'm in the US next year for the New Year.
author: Chie J.

description: This place is NOT as crowded as the other restaurants/take-out in the ferry building. The quality of the food is pretty fresh; and there are plenty of options for a quick bite. The service is not the best when compared to other restaurants/take-out places in the Ferry building.
author: Ram A.

description:
I appreciated that this place served a variety of very vegetarian/vegan-friendly,  budget-conscious, healthy, and tasty options in the Ferry Building, a place that has many eateries that are not really sensitive to price or non-meat/fish eaters. Delica offered a happy medium between the cafes and the sit-down shops for clients with more cash to burn.

I bought the meal combo #2: choice of three salads or two salads and soup.
I got the burdock and seaweed salads and carrot-ginger soup. Yummy and light lunch.
author: Jung F.

description:
Delica teaches a valuable lesson-- organic does not mean healthy and neither does Japanese .  They do have salads, but the enticing fried counter by the door will bring out the inner Jennifer Hudson in all of us!  It'd taste better if these treats came directly out of the grease, but they are still decent when slightly cold from behind the counter.  Definitely leaps and bounds ahead of other pre-cooked lunchtime deli options.

Pork Tonkatsu: The outside is crispy despite not being fresh out of the fryer.  The pork inside is partially cold and dry.  The sauce on top is nice.

Chicken Dumpling with Sweet Chili Sauce: Basically a fried chicken meatball.  The outside is really awesome with good seared meat and a nice chili glaze.  This one is small and went down a bit too fast.

Potato Croquette: Executed well, but could use some filling.  The potato and onion get a little boring, even with soy dipping sauce, after a few bites.

Fried Shrimp Cake: Yay for mainly being large pieces of shrimp instead of some crab cake-like filler!  I could do without the unimaginative tartar sauce.  Tastes better with soy or sriracha (from my desk).

Kakiage Tempura: Basically a cluster-funk of tempura vegetables and shrimp.  Major kudos for innovating on the rather common and boring tempura veggies.  I especially like the inner onions that didn't seem as deep fried and offered a more potent kick.  And the soy beans are an awesome taste and texture addition!

Hijiki Rice Ball: Too fishy for my tastes though I appreciated all the textures and flavors coming from the veggies, beans and seeds.  Perhaps a little less seaweed next time...

Cream Puff: When eating a cream puff, you know who I must compare to-- Beard Papa!  The cream was spot on, good vanilla hint and super creamy.  The puff itself was too chewy and tasted like something from a bodega snack section.  PS, I love how sugar is missing the organic prefix in the ingredient list... come one now, couldn't splurge on that one?
author: Adam B.

description:
I have been coming to Delica for the past 6 years, since I moved to SF.  Although I do not go as much anymore, but I cannot believe that I have not written a review of this place by now.  

Personally, there's bento boxes and a salad side, but I only come here for their curry.  I love the lamb curry when they have it,  but they do not have it all the time.

Expect to wait if you come here around lunch time and find a place to sit sometimes sucks.
author: Omar L.

description:
Bleh.

No flavor and cold. So much cold food that should be served warm. The fried food aren't hot. The chicken balls are cold and covered in cold gelatinous sauce. The sushi lacks flavor. The salads are flavorless. I only liked the beef curry.

For that price point, go somewhere else.
author: Kiristen R.

description: My co-worker went to Delica for lunch to get her favorite dish a ginger beef bowl but she was told by a female cashier it was all sold out. But immediately, young man who was taking care of another customer asked her that if she can wait for a few minutes he will prepare a ginger beef bowl for her. Since she was pregnant and was craving  for it she was very delighted by his offer! The young man' s name was Sean. Thank you Sean for making my co-worker happy!!
author: Mimi Y.

description:
I love their great food here! I am always impressed with their flavors and you cant beat the great staff!

The price can be a bit pricey but worth the fresh food and ingredients, which you can definitely detect if you eat here enough.

Although portioning by the staff needs a little bit more uniformity. Often staff puts in more and then there will be instances where the portion is so small that if you get the three item combo there is enough space in the box to land land a small airplane.

Make sure to get the amount you are paying for, which can be on average 10 bucks. Although what's nice is they will more than happy to oblige if you ask nicely.
author: M S.

description:
Tasty enough, simple food for lunch, 3-1/2 stars. Vegan friendly - everything is well marked, including clearly marking one item that looked vegan/vegetarian as not being vegetarian. 

This review is for dinner:

I supplemented it with an avocado maki. It was decent enough.

But what's prompting me to give it 4 stars and write the review is the mushroom meshi, which is apparently a dinner special for May 2014. Since Maki closed, I've missed their vegetable wappi meshi, veggies steamed over rice in a basket.

Delica's version is steamed in a metal bowl. This makes the rice crisp on the bottom, similar to dot sot bi bim bap. The mushrooms and veggies were perfectly steamed. (Just so there's no confusion, there's no egg in Delica's meshi - it's noted on the menu as vegan.)

This is not a dish for someone who wants bold food. This is a simple dish prepared perfectly. That said, the mushrooms were quite flavorful. The dish was a delight.

Just a warning: as it says on the menu, it takes at least 1/2 hour. Even with the warning, they were nice enough to comp me some edemame, and stopped by every so often to reassure me the meshi was coming.

Portions are not huge, although there was more to the meshi than was visible at first glance.

All the tables are those annoying high ones. That's the only thing that would discourage me from trying them regularly (unless I happen to be in the Ferry Building and hungry, which is mostly a desert for vegans).
author: Charles B.

description: This is just one of many gems in the Ferry Building.  However, for under $10 I got a great medley of salad, fresh crab meat croquette and carrot ginger soup.  Everything was so fresh and delicious that Delica really is an appropriate name!
author: Hannah A.

description:
"Please to take off shoes before entering"

...ok, so there's no kimono-clad hostess who tells you that in this rather pricey deli, but hell, I can get away with that 'cause I am Japanese-American, dammit. Honestly, they could use a little more of the homeland ambiance to justify some of their ka-ching, ka-ching pricing.

I never seem to be here when it's open, but I happen to be working nearby now, so I met a friend there for lunch. After both of us hemmed and hawed, we both ordered the $10.95 Bento Box, non-vegetarian division. There were five compartments of food - some marinated green beans, potato salad topped with edamame, a chicken salad, a rice salad and in the center, some croquette of some sort. Can you tell I wasn't too impressed?

Maybe it's because I love the boxes and goodies you can get in the basements of the big Tokyo department stores. And while the packaging may be prettier here, the food is not quite up to snuff. But it's my peeps...so I have to come back and try their sushi rolls or their miso soup sometime, right? They ate moths and roaches on Iwo Jima according to Clint Eastwood, so I could tolerate a non-descript croquette once in a while.

Oh and by the way, good luck finding a seat at lunchtime during the week. And curb your talking trash about your boss, because you just don't know who you're sitting next to now, do you?

BENTO - 3 stars...BANZAI!...BANZAI!...BAN...!...oh never mind
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...yes, the Ferry Building rocks...but it does get crowded
SERVICE - 3 stars...you just pick up and go, grasshopper
TOTAL - 3 star...middling bento for the busy worker bee...with lots of discretionary cash
author: Ed U.

description:
Stopped by to have a quick snack and this place wasn't bad at all. 

Got the Ginger ground Kobe beef bowl with rice. Came with crumble tamgo which gave it the perfect sweetness to the meat and rice. Like it!

Also tried their beef curry, wasn't any different from most Japanese restaurants, but the beef was super tender and chunks of it. 

Overall, great spot to grab a quick lunch.
author: Annie D.

description: Delica is a unique and reliable spot for a quick takeout lunch.  It offers boxed lunches, noodle soup, curry over rice, vegetarian rolls, and a variety of other sides such as the panko shrimp cake or a modest side of pork katsu (my favorites, since you can enjoy the modest portions without feeling guilty).  All the food I've had here is above average, though the prices are somewhat high and you will have to scout out a seat in or around the Ferry Building unless you plan to take your food to go, because Delica offers no dedicated seating.
author: Chris T.

description:
I was told we were having sandwiches for our work lunch meeting so imagine my surprise when the sandwiches turned out to be bento boxes from here! And not just any bento boxes, but perhaps the best bento box I've ever had!

There were about 9 different foods (fish, veggies, dumplings, etc) in my bento box and I enjoyed every little bite. Everything was so incredibly fresh and we even got a green tea/mango pudding for dessert- it looks gross,but tastes incredible!

My only complaint is that we don't have a Delic rf-1 in Chicago....if we did I would for sure be their best customer!
author: Andrea R.

description:
Delica rf-1 catered lunch for a group of around 20 of us earlier this week... it was awesome!  We had the 9 piece bento boxes and they also came with a green tea/mango pudding dessert.

I cleaned my plate (or box in this case).  The fish in the maki was fresh and delicious, and the veggie items were all tasty.  I love different textures in food and so I was pleased with the variety of textures, and the colors too.  Also, I wasn't too full after - it was just the right amount of food so that I was satisfied after but didn't get a food coma.

Can't wait to visit Delica rf-1 in person and try some of the other menu items as well!
author: Gabi M.

description:
Wow! I have never seen tempura like this before! Imagine, all the veggies they use to make tempura clumped into one ball (including edaname) Sounds a bit weird, but this tempura was goood! Next item, the roast beef sushi! Yes, I did say roast beef sushi. Looks great when you see it in the window...but not too tender. Perhaps it would be better if it wasn't so tough. Potato ball....lightly breaded potato ball...mmmm it was good, but have had better. Then had some spicy chicken, another great item! 

I didn't eat all this food by myself (which also includes the the food from Mijita)...it was a group outing. It was a grab whatever you want kind of event. There was bread and cheese there too!!
author: Ninja N.

description: Really pleased with the variety and freshness of all we ordered. We were fortunate to come during happy hour. In addition to the good prices, the serving size were quite filling. My husband had a pork belly don, (which he really liked), and I had spicy tuna dip and a very good negikanpachi roll. We were surprised by a complementary bowl of wasabi Potato salad. We live in SF so don't often eat at the Ferry building- but I'm glad we decided too tonight! I read some other reviews that were contradictory to what I experienced- which is why I decided to write this one.
author: B B.

description: Very pricey lunch for very little food. After waiting in a long line, I got a wasabi potato salad, small salmon chowder, and two pieces of roast beef sushi. All portions were very small.
author: Harrison T.

description:
When i walk to the Ferry Building along the embarcadero, i get really hungry but don't always want a sit down meal so i go to Delica and get the Kaki-age: Fried Shrimp Cake Potato Croquette $4.00/ea

A mixture of shredded vegetables (burdock, carrots, onions, and edamame) and white shrimp in a tempura batter.

I just copied and pasted the description from the menu...Because I didn't remember the name but thought of it as "birds nest tampura with shrimp". 

I like my name better. But never mind, just get it. it's a perfect little snack!
author: Bill W.

description: Absolutely love the vegi curry & the potato croquette thought it's on the expensive side.
author: Sasa L.

description:
In-season vegetable: asparagus.

How did I know? Because of the waitress at Delica.

And that asparagus roll was damn delicious. So was the halibut carpaccio (FOR 12$??!!!)

Very fresh, very good, and service was great.  Happy hour is awesome, my friends.  3$ beer!
author: Laurance L.

description:
Let's see...how to sum up this place....
 - Overpriced,
 - Japanese cuisine for people that have not had it before, and
 - SLOW service.

The service was the most appalling thing about this place. Zero attention to customers - no water offered, not taking orders until flagged down, AND....with about nine customers in the place and TWO waiters it took me two times to ask for the check and then an additional - fifteen - minutes until I walked up to the counter to have him take the money and ring me up. Absolutely pathetic and unacceptable. Will not visit again.
author: Rich S.

description:
Got Beef Curry ($9.50) and Green Tea ($2) 'cause I didn't feel like going bento. Maybe I will try one next time. 
The meal was simple and satisfying. Not heavy at all. Thumbs up. Will return again.

The Potato ($1.50/ea) and Crab ($3.75/ea) Croquettes looked tempting. 
I think I would feel fairly healthy eating most anything on Delica's menu. 
This restaurant is a good place to bring vegetarian/vegan friends if you want to eat with them near the water. Lots of good options for them. (Notably the Hijiki and Soybean Salad ($15/lb), Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad ($8/lb), Tofu Steak with Miso Sauce ($4/ea), Organic Vegetable Sushi Roll ($7.75/two), and of course the Potato Croquette).

Next visit: 
maybe a Bento box 5 items ($9.50), Summer Bento 9 items ($11), Croquettes, Shrimp Cake ($3.75/ea), Seared Tuna Salad ($10) or Spicy Tuna Genmai Rice Bowl ($10), Hijiki and Soybean Salad or Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad and/or........

Roast Beef Sushi ($2/ea), Sushi Rolls ($7.75/two), Tonkatsu/Pork Cutlet ($1.25), Chicken Dumpling w/Sweet Chili Sauce ($1.75), Kaki-age/Tempura ($3.75).
author: Kay N.

description:
YUM!  this japanese deli place is the yummiest deli food in all of SF.  you can get light food (salads) or heavy (fried, meaty dishes).  my favorite salads are the eggplant and the japanese hijiki salads.  the eggplant salad has bits of ground pork and vermicelli noodles in it and the hijiki is totally veggie, super light and good for you!  i also got the fried spicy chicken, which was OK, nothing super about this chicken...reminds me of general tzao's chicken.  i will probably try the roast beef sushi or tofu steak next time.  

it's a bit pricey, but you don't feel super heavy after you eat food from delica.  it's fresh food!
author: Wendy S.

description:
I actually got by for $6.50 here. Here's the breakdown:

$2 for an exquisite "roast beef sushi" roll. 
$1.50 for a tastes-pretty-much-only-like-rice wild salmon and rice ball (note to self: avoid in the future)
$1.50 for a perfectly fried (yet slightly too cool in the middle) potato croquette
$1.50 for a lovely light green bean salad in a sesame dressing (note: I scored here by asking for $1.50's worth because he didn't weigh it by the pound and gave me about double the portion I should have received)

Overall: Light lunch but pure flavors. I'll be back.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
mixed feelings for varying selections....dilemma of non-standard....delica rf-1 straying from american typical find....sense of "fast food"....already made bento (pre-packaged meals) stacked.....with availability of ala carte behind glass counters.....preference to build a meal.....balanced selection of tofu, spinach, tofu chicken, spicy chicken, potato croquettes, roast beef sushi and rice....adding of green tea bottles from 'frig' and total of $thirty five handed for special two...

quality being fine...but, hindered by pre-made selections....self not accustomed to cold cooked.....roast beef sushi interesting and tasteful....wrong to want beef warm?.....cold tofu "steak" with sweet miso onion topping delicious....slight dream of warm fried tofu smothered in hot sauced topper.....tofu chicken patty similar to dumpling filling texture....a frown for cold patty served...spicy chicken hard...potato croquettes room temperature....at last, saved by warm rice...finding baked curry fresh and favorite...rich, hot and delicious....and, great happy hour 'til seven pm...gave in to $three kirin, $four handroll & thirty% off wine...
author: Hen A.

description:
Combo 4: Salad, Rice, Entree $8.25! 

probably the best deal.  Their salads are good, very small portions. The sweet chicken meatball things are delicious, so is the sweet and spicy chicken.  the katsu is also very good.  

the chicken curry is a huge portion and was a little too greasy for me. 

overall, it's a great spot for lunch!
author: Jtina K.

description:
to be fair, we tried to dine here but were on a time crunch bc we only had a four-hour layover.

the place was full for a wednesday night... and after waiting on line for what felt like an eternity, we get to the waitress, and she informs us that they don't do take out. FAIL.
author: Kat W.

description:
This a review for the dinner only. 

I came here a couple of times for dinner and I love this place. Being Japanese I am a bit picky of the Japanese food that I eat, but I definitely approve of this place. 

Some dishes that I recommend are the following:

1. spicy tuna dip - they serve the spicy tuna they use in their roll on a plate with avocado and tortilla chips. The spice of the spicy tuna is complimented very well with the avocado. The chips make it easy to share with other people. I don't recommend actually dipping the chip in the spicy tuna because the chip will break. 

2. yaki curry - this was suggested to is by our waiter, and he was right this dish is so delicious. Basically they put rice and Japanese curry in a dish with cheese on top and bake it in the oven for about 15 minutes. I've always loved eating my curry with parmesan cheese, but baking it with cheese, I've never thought of that. I think baking the dish allows the curry flavor to infuse into the rice while the flavor of the cheese infuses into the curry. It was a whole lot of great flavors mixed together, and this dish definitely warms you up on a cold winter night. 

3. toro roll - I love toro (fatty tuna), and I love how it just melts in your mouth! This roll consists of toro and green onion. Must I say more? This roll has been a constant repeat everytime I come. 

Aside from the dishes noted above, Delica usually has an assortment of fresh fish. The selection changes from day to day, but they have unique types of fish such as king fish that you usually don't find at the fake Japanese sushi restaurants. 

If you are ever in the ferry building, stop by. They also have happy hour from 5pm to 7pm.
author: Ayaka S.

description:
Pure, unadulterated culinary delight. You're lured in by the chic, utilitarian decor and by the cases of bento boxes, freshly tossed salads, and assortments of sushi, dumplings... My mother, brother, and I stood for awhile, wondering what to eat, and a little confounded by the prices.

 2.00 for one dumpling. 2.50 for one beef sushi. 1.75 for a potato croquette. But order we did, and the result was completely worth it. 

The novelty of the food is a lure itself. Everything was refreshingly new to the taste and the senses. The beef sushi is something born out of my bf's own brain, combining his two favorite foods - beef and sushi. The potato croquette was like creamy Thanksgiving mashed potatoes in a fried carapace.. And the chicken dumpling was just amazing. I can't explain what it is, but the fusion of flavors is so memorable. We three ate outside, among the birds and overlooking the ocean.
author: Jennie T.

description:
Yum! One of my favorite lunch spots that's close to the office, yummy, and not going to break my wallet.

I adore the green bean and miso salad as well as the spicy chicken. Mmm. Now I'm salivating and most likely going to eat this for lunch sometime this week.
author: laura f.

description: We sampled a bunch of their dishes, the summer bento, various salads etc. I thought each was tasty, but these dishes are the real deal. Many of the taste combinations and ingredients were unfamiliar, so the meal wasn't as comfy for my stomach as a typical sushi place. But, definitely worth it for the culinary adventure.
author: Jeremy S.

description: This restaurant is a blend of fresh California and Japanese cuisine, so think healthy and refreshing with interesting flavors.  I've been here for lunch and dinner and had two totally different experiences.  For lunch, I did the one of the combo specials where you get to pick between salads and soup.  The salads here are wonderful--especially the burdock(?) salad.  There is also a great selection of ready made or special order sushi if you want to go that route.  The dinner menu has great options as well.  You can sit at the sushi bar or order off the regular menu. I ordered the baked fish which was absolutely amazing.  The fish comes with an assortment of seasonal veggies wrapped in parchment paper--a great healthy meal!  They also have daily dinner specials for $10 which sounded pretty good.  Early in the evening you should be fine getting a table, but for lunch, I would come here a little early as the line out the door can get long (especially on weekends).
author: Tanichka B.

description:
This is really a place for tourist. 
I came here with a few colleages and we all agreed that even though the food is good, the portion are ridiculously small for any normal human being. 

The ration food / price is bad. 

I will not come back.
author: Antonin L.

description:
This is a great place to either stay and eat, or grab and go! 

Food: They have a range of fresh foods -- sushi, salads, fried goodies, etc.  I always get the spicy tuna roll and the sesame spinach salad.  mmmmm! The spicy tuna is super fresh, they give you lots of tuna, and portion size is good.  The sesame salad is a cold spinach salad, marinated in yummy sesame seeds and a light sauce.  They also have a great tofu salad, wasabi potato salad, and a bunch of other cold dishes to choose from.  I have never got any of the fried choices, but they always look yummy.  You can either order from behind the counter, or grab one of their to-go sandwiches, sushi rolls, or bento boxes.  Very convenient! 

Ambiance/Service: The place is very clean, modern, and arranged in a way that allows the line to flow well.  It is nice that you can see all the food they have to offer through the glass.  I like that they have two separate lines, also: grab and go vs order and go.  The service is always fast and up to par! 

Price: Its a little pricey here for sushi, but hey, its way worth it! I would definitely recommend this place to someone who is looking for somewhere great, yummy, and quick to check out.  

You must check this place out if you are in the Ferry Building (or around the Ferry Building, or no where near the Ferry Building)! :)
author: Ashley M.

description:
Had the Ginger Beef Bowl here today and was very pleased with the quality of lunch I got.  Great atmosphere and ambiance here.  Friendly service too.

The bowl was pretty simple with ground beef, egg and rice topped with ginger.  The flavor was great without being overpowering with the ginger.

Only qualm with this establishment was the price.  $9.24 for the bowl along is steep.  It's not that different from other places in the Ferry Building, but still.  I will definitely be back, but only when I have the cash to drop ten bucks on lunch without a drink or side.
author: Brian G.

description:
Quality is equivalent to one of those deli's in depachika (underground of department store) in Japan. People who have been to Japan only know what I mean. I wish we have more of those here.
Anyway, I've only tried once and I know that the chefs know real Japanese food. I heard the owner of this store is a son of big deli chains in Japan.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Not your average deli, it's a Japanese deli. I'm a bit iffy on deli foods that sit in a display fridge all day. But I trust and know the Wasabi Potato Salad here is always served fresh! 

The Kaki-age and Potato Croquettes are awesome, and I don't even use the word "awesome." The Bento Boxes are cute and make for a good snack, cause the portions are really small. It's a good and bad thing that it doesn't fill you up, but leaves a lot of room to snack on other goodies in the area.
author: S Y.

description: This review is only based on food quality. I had it at a work luncheon and it was amazing! Curry was on point, salads were tasty and fresh and some meatball thing was fantastic. Yay for yummy free food!
author: Lisandra M.

description:
It's around noon on a flawlessly sunny day in San Francisco. I'm with three co-workers who are tired of sandwiches, have a hankering for something "ethnic" and wouldn't mind sushi. I no longer live here but my taste buds often long for the city that trained them so to the ferry building we go! I explain that there were many options to be had as I wander toward DELICA rf-1. Smartly, they join me to view the many delights in this modern Japanese deli.

After much deliberation I chose the:
Green Beans with Sesame Dressing
Potato Croquette
Spinach and Sesame Salad (Goma-ae)

I found the goma-ae a touch disappointing but the wonderfulness of both the green beans and the croquette made it easy to forget the relative blandness of the spinach salad.

We eat our food outside, looking at the Bay and dodging the occasional pigeon. A lovely respite from the windowless dungeon!

Next time I'll try the:
Japanese Style Curry
Roast Beef Sushi

Sid note on the interior: Modern design enthusiasts will appreciate the Wishbone chairs by Hans Wegner (a favorite among the Japanese).
author: Miriam W.

description:
3/5 takoyaki

this review is actually for the takoyaki at the thursday farmer's market. it was okay, the inside was a little more undercooked than i would have liked. the octopus speck also wasn't very impressive. overall, not bad, but not good either.
author: Alvin D.

description:
A cute little Japanese woman asked us what we wanted and I watched her carefully and daintily filled one to-go box with rice and topped with beef curry and another to-go box with soba noodles, broth, and some fried medley. She was so careful with placing the food in the boxes, it almost made me want to admire it before digging in. Well, I did look at it for the few seconds before my fork broke the surface. The soba noodles are pretty fresh, still has that al dente. The curry was the best!!! It's actually such a comfy food.

The spicy tuna roll was ok. There was a lot of tuna on the roll, but it was pretty flavorless, no spice and no fish taste.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I had high expectations for this place... I tried the Roast Beef Sushi and the Agedashi Tofu Steak and the Potato Croquette. 
Everything was mediocre but the Roast Beef Sushi was NOT good. 
It was flavorless and so chewy that I had to spit it out. (UGH!)  
It looks really good but the texture of the beef is not great at all and they need to add some sort of flavor to it. 
i dont know if I'll ever try Delica again.. there are far better places that the ferry building has to offer
author: Jessica S.

description:
I am an absolute sucker for Japanese food - not just the sushi sort but the bento box sort too.  And Delica has the most beautiful and widest variety of Japanese (lunch) food I've seen in the downtown area.

I've only ever been to the Ferry Buliding on the weekends, and, in the madness I must have overlooked Delica.  When my friend suggested a "Japanese deli" at the Ferry Building, I was sold.  This is my equivalent of a candy store - the huge refrigerated section filled with all sorts of fun salads and goodies and pre-made, REAL bento boxes.  It was hard for me to choose, but I went with the tonkatsu and eggplant bento box.  And I don't even like eggplant, it just looked that good.  Yes, the eggplant had pork in it but if everybody made eggplant like that, I would eat it.

I polished off everything - it was actually a little embarrassing.  And even though I have a big appetite, I had zero hunger pangs all afternoon.  True, the lunch was a bit spendy (just a tad over $10) but worth it.  

The Ferry Building is a "hike" (when I write "hike" I mean a flat, 6-block walk) from my office, but it would be dangerous if it was any closer.
author: Wendy L.

description:
D e l i c a t e 

Flavors, that is.  And definitely paying tribute to traditional Japanese in the fact that most of the dishes are subtle in textures and flavors.

However, given the fact that I grew up eating nothing but Japanese food (yes, I had miso shiru and gohan - hot rice for breakfast complete with tsukemono) and having to endure my share of this coveted ethnic cuisine for pretty much 20 years of my eating life has pretty much gotten on the nerves of my tongue.

I love Thai food and all that spiced up savagery beat upon my palate.

My main dish (chicken patty with daikon oroshi and hijiki) was slightly bland, but eating it with the green beans tossed in a light mayo wasabi mix was good.  The Chinese Chicken salad was ho hum in that it resembled more of the Chinese Fast food variety.  I was, however, much impressed with my $7.75 purchase of 8 pieces of sushi wrapped not in seaweed, but clear rice paper.  The salmon was fresh and tasty, combined with the slightly sweet sushi rice, crunchy bits of cucumber and sprouts with a wasabi mayo dressing.  Mmmm.

I just knocked up another star for the yummy sushi roll as well as for the excellent and kind customer service the fellow (in addition to the rest of the staff, the owner was present and helping out as well) treated us while we waited patiently for the fresh batch of green bean salad to be brought out.
author: Miika M.

description: I am terrifyingly addicted to the burdock salad and shrimp cake here.  It's worked its way into my diet on at least a weekly basis, even though I no longer work across the street.
author: Nicole L.

description: I ordered the Tempura Shrimp noodles and it was absolutely the worst tempura I have ever had at any restaurant. The batter on the shrimps were thick, chewy and soggy, the shrimps were tough and overdone, and the broth tasted like soy sauce mixed with water. The bowl of noodle with the shrimp has been in the display case and they just microwave it. The food quality is very poor, would definitely not go to this restaurant again!
author: A Y.

description: First time trying this place lady weekend. We got their kind of late but they still seated us. I had the spicy sashimi salad which was good, but the server told me it was big enough for TWO people. Not exactly. I'm a pretty big eater and I left hungry. The place itself is a deli styled sushi spot in the ferry building. Probably would have had a better experience had it been daylight but all in all it wasn't bad.
author: Al S.

description:
Perfect lunch/snack stop.
Foods on display look great but just that much....
author: JK C.

description:
I was hungry and craving for something not too crazy unhealthy.... so when I passed by this storefront and saw "sushi" as one of the items they sell, I considered it.

I want to sit down, in front of a mirror, and tell myself the following message:

"I know you were hungry.  I know you were desperate. I know you were too lazy to go to a place you know serves good sushi, but I also know you want to try something new.  But... spending $9.50 on a less than mediocre salmon sushi roll?  stupid.  absolutely stupid.  I guess you should've trusted your instincts.  Forget the fact that the people selling the sushi were also Asian, but that doesn't mean anything, really.  Don't be fooled by their cheerful faces.  The hard sushi rice and super thin/dry salmon slices are just too mats to ignore.  Even dipping it in the tonkatsu sauce that came with your potato croquet did not help with the dryness of the sushi at all.  Next time, trust your palate and your gut. You are special, but this time, you are just dumb.

if you want to make the world a better place, take a look at yourself and make that.... CHAAAANGE!"

(  |  )
author: Grace M.

description:
I spent most of my middle and high school years in Japan and often get homesick.  Happily, I'm in SF about once a month for business and Delica is always a go-to.

I've only done take out, but their food is authentic, light, fresh, and completely delicious.  The burdock/carrot salad is one of my favorites.  Tonight, I had a sardine salad -- wild sardines that were fried, then marinated with rice vinegar, onions, red bell peppers, and likely a little sugar.  It was *outstanding*. Really.  I also had the kale salad (ordered without Gruyere).  Delicious.

While waiting for my order to be ready, I went around the corner to Wine Merchant and picked up a half bottle of Duckhorn Sauvignon Blanc.  Took it all back to my hotel room and was the happiest. girl. ever.
author: R. O.

description:
The sushi was amazingly fresh and the ingredients were SUCH good quality. Definitely worth the price. 

The ambiance is nice - minimal and quiet but still has personality. 

The chicken dish just tastes like fried chicken but otherwise everything on the menu was unique, fresh, and delicious. 

They serve you pretty fast! Although some dishes say they take 20 mins to make, the dishes came out within 10! 

Great for vegetarians, gf, or meat eaters.
author: Tara G.

description: I was very happy to find this place in the ferry building! Whenever I visit the ferry building I'm overwhelmed and frustrated by the long lines and unhealthy choices. Not only did Delica barely have a line at all, but they had healthier options (not all healthy of course, haha, but there were sushi options that weren't greasy). Not the best, but great for a day out with some visitors to the city.
author: Katie V.

description: Delica served one of the scariest things in the universe to me: funky uni. I'm sorry, but this is not something your can skimp on freshness with, its just too scary!!! What really killed it for me was the most horrible disorganized weekend dinner service of any restaurant I've been to in SF: they forgot about us, forgot half of what we ordered, tried to give us the wrong food, were impossible to flag down, and it never occurred to them to bring the check. However their kale salad, rolls, pork katsu, eggplant salad, spinach miso, and banana pudding were solid. Take my advice and order from the counter, take it to go, and if you have any sanity, do NOT, I mean do NOT, even think about ordering the uni.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
This is my default place to go if I am not craving any other restaurant in the Ferry Building. How shall I describe this place? I'll start with the items I have tried here and let you, the readers decide what kind of food they offer. I've tried the Roast beef Nigiri which was cooked on the outside but raw in the middle, 3 item box with potato salad fusion with chicken meatballs and seaweed salad. I would say this is a mix between japanese, american organic, and italian deli.

Food Highlight: Salmon triangle shaped roll
author: Rich L.

description: Just tried this place for the first time. Seriously pricy, but decided to go with the Garlic Wasabi Potato Salad. SO GOOD! The wasabi is still tickling my nose, but I thought was a really nice alternative to your average over-mayoed potato salad. The lettuce was really fresh. Definitely want to try some of their other stuff!
author: Rachel F.

description: My boyfriend met me for lunch yesterday and I was so excited to try this place out. What a let down.. I got the the first combination; 1main, salad, and a soup. I chose Spicy chicken, the Hijiki salad, and miso soup. When I sat down and opened my box I was immediately let down. Four tiny pieces of chicken, wrong soup, but the salad looked ok. (I did go back and exchange my soup for the right one.)  The food was so bland and I didn't even eat my soup, because it tasted like it had gone off and was cold. Will not be coming back that is for sure.
author: Sarah k.

description:
Too expensive. $12+  for

Wasabi Potato salad -- Whoops forgot the potato. It was limp romain lettuce with a potato slime all over it. The one piece of potato was so undercooked it was crunchy.

Sweet and Spicy chicken -- 3 tiny bites of chicken. Sauce was alright. It had been around for a while. Very dry.

Salmon Chowder -- About a half cup of thick flavorless soup. What you would expect at a Red lobster. The "salmon" consisted of about a 1/4 teaspoon of Smoked salmon sprinkled over the top.
author: Mabel S.

description:
The spring roll sushi was delicious.  Usually the merging of different Asian flavors can fall flat.  But this one tasted like it was meant to be. 

The other dishes they had were okay.  The tofu steak could've used more sauce or marinade for a more even flavor.  

It made my stomach happy, but was not really worth the price.
author: Wendy H.

description:
This is deserving of best cheap eats in SF!  Located in the trendy and crowded ferry building, it takes a lot to stand out here, being in the same place as the slanted door (SF's most reserved resturant -- and tourist trap :-)  and the farmer's market.

I got the bento for 9.95.  This is not typical bento box, more gourmet sauce (katsu with a twist) and unique sushi (seared beef is exceptional).  The box comes with  spinach sesame salad, a main item (tempura and I paid extra for the katsu- unlike any katsu I've tried) and sweet sushi-like rice.  All of it unique with Delica artistry.  

Fresh, flavorful, different than other bentos.
author: Surai J.

description: Delica has some very yummy albeit pricy Japanese dishes but when I went there last time I was in for a rude surprise. I ordered their mushroom curry which was pre-cooked as all their other food. It was in a big pot and I got it on top of rice. 10 minutes into my meal when I brought it back to the office, I noticed something that shouldn't have been there - a strand of hair! I was so repulsed that I took the time to go back to them after work and made complain. By that time, the lunch shift has ended and Delica turned into a sushi place. So the lady said she can't do anything for me then, but will call me back. Guess what, one week later, NOTHING! I will never eat here again as they completely lost my respect on how a food business should run. When a customer takes the time to go back and make a formal complaint, standard procedure will be to follow up.
author: Sheri T.

description:
Yum. I came here for a weekday dinner and was surprised by how many others had the same idea. I had made reservations for the sushi bar, which seats only 5, and I'm glad I did as the other tables looked like something out of the Ikea restaurant. The only drawback of sitting at the bar is that it's so small that the wait staff will constantly put their orders to the sushi chef over your shoulder if you sit at the right end.

When ordering, I liked that the staff made sure to tell us which fish was the freshest (the sea urchin from Monterey, and it was deliciously smooth and buttery}. We also ordered the 9 nigiri chef's selection, spicy tuna roll, Delica roll and Toro roll. Everything was very clean and presented well.

The wait staff is friendly if a bit slow. In general, there's only one sushi chef and an assistant, who I think makes the rolls, so it can get backed up really quickly, but it's worth the wait if you're not in too much of a hurry. The sushi chef when I went was a woman, which I've never seen before, so it makes me want to support Delica even more.
author: rosanna c.

description:
They used to have great katsu, but they've gotten smaller, thinner, and aren't as tasty as they used to be.  By reducing them, the meat:breading ratio has changed, as has the texture.  Smaller portions to reduce costs is one thing, but they're no longer of the same quality.

Of course I'm sure most of the tourists who try them won't notice the difference.
author: T C.

description:
I've been going to this place for over two years for lunch. I've never had a bad experience with the food. It's a simple Japanese food to go place, but the food they have is consistently executed flawlessly. They are true professionals.

My favorite dishes:
1. The bento box with chicken katsu. This is a perfect bento box. You get rice, 2 pieces of chicken katsu that's breaded and crispy on the outside and moist on the inside, and two types of salad.

2. Any of the breaded food or tempura dipped food is great

3. The rice and curry dish with a selection of meats.

You can feed yourself for under $10. Great value and great food!
author: Jim B.

description:
When I come to Delica Rf-1, it is for two things, and two things only: beef curry and tonkatsu. I usually get 5 or more tonkatsu because they are like potato chips- you simply cannot eat just one. The meat is completely free of fat, perfectly fried, and drizzled with a delicious squiggle of sauce. Amazingly, it goes great with the beef curry, which has a pleasant kick to it. The employees working the counter are friendly, and will always ask if you've been helped yet. If what you want is all gone, they will make it for you fresh if you're willing to wait (I did this once for some extra tonkatsu). 

My only gripe about the place are the prices. When I go here, I get a regular beef curry and 5-6 tonkatsu. The curry is around $8 and the tonkatsus are $1.50 each, so I end up spending about $16-$20 (depends on if I get a $2 bottled apple tea or not). But I am willing to shell out the dough because this food is really just that good. 

Since I've moved from the city, I ALWAYS make it a priority to come back here for my curry and tonkatsu fix when I am in town, even if it has to be right before I'm to get on an Amtrak bus bound for my train in Emeryville. I will gladly stink up that bus with potent curry fumes if it means I can eat it while it's hot and fresh. (I apologize in advance if you end up on that bus with me.)

P.S. Since I don't live here anymore, I have a feeling I may spend $30 bucks here getting my usuals and then trying the other menu items I've passed on all these years. You just don't get this kind of food in Chico, alas!
author: M S.

description:
A Japanese delicatessen. Awesome.

Where else can you get wasabi garlic potato salad? Sadly, I didn't try and now looking at all the good reviews here, I wish I had.

Tried the shrimp and crab roll. Saw that it didn't have an expiration date but rather an expiration time! That's how fresh it was, and it tasted very fresh. 

Also tried the katsu don sandwich which was creatively prepared and quite delicious. The organic tofu miso soup was also good.

Definitely recommended.
author: Steve S.

description:
I have eaten almost everything here and it's all delicious!  My favorite is the mushroom curry, savory steaming hot and kinda spicy, with yummy fried lotus root chips on top.  The rice served with the curry is perfectly cooked.   Very satisfying on a cold SF day. 

I also love the burdock root salad -- refreshing tasty and interesting.  When I go to the Ferry Bldg there are so many wonderful things to eat, but Delica is my favorite! (with Acme Bread a close second).  The Karaage Chicken is good too.  My least favorite thing is probably the soba noodles with the fried tempura thing on top -- the broth tastes kinda sour to me.

Service is excellent -- everyone who works here is so polite.
author: kathy c.

description:
I liked their chicken karaage, and the lotus chips.   The tempura was also good.  The sushi was decent but not great.

The waitstaff and customers were very exuberantly friendly, but that might be because the SF Giants just won the World Series tonight.
author: Niniane W.

description:
I feel like I'm halfway crazy because none of the dishes I recently had at Delica are showing up on their website's menu -- but maybe they have a special Happy Hour menu that's not listed?

We started with a vegetarian bento from the deli (we were able to snag one before Happy Hour started): hijiki, soybean salad, fried tofu, burdock root salad, and a veggie roll. Pretty good, a little pricey ($14). 

At HH, my friend and I each ordered a temaki - tuna and salmon. Pretty standard, but tasted fresh. We ordered some sweet potato fries to start, which came with a tasty dipping sauce. We also shared a baked salmon roll which was incredible, and I swear we got a fried crab roll, too. The drizzled sauce on top tasted like potato salad, but it worked.

The coup de grâce was the yaki curry we ordered when we were too full to finish it. Yaki curry is basically the French Onion Soup of curry bowls, with a bed of rice topped with curry and egg under a layer of ooey, gooey gruyere cheese.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
hits:

* WASABI GARLIC POTATO SALAD (from someone who does not like potato salad)
* asparagus salad
* burdock and lotus root salad -- not sure why it's called 'spicy' as it's not at all, but still good
* shrimp and crab roll -- they were generous with the real crabmeat mmmm
* chicken dumpling

misses (not horrible, just mediocre):

* hijiki and soy bean salad 
* rice balls -- a little bland and was completely falling apart

overall enjoyed my lunch but out of all the foodie options in the ferry building, not at the top of my list. I'm at 3.5 stars...and as much as I liked the wasabi potato salad, it wasn't good enough to bump everything else up to a solid 4 :(
author: Dee R.

description:
3.5 stars. rounding down because of price. it were only a little cheaper, Delica would easily be a 4 star place.

came early on a saturday so beat the lunch crowd. i was attracted by the beautiful display. i suppose it would have been easier and cheaper to get a "bento" set but i opted for a la carte:

- Agedashi Tofu ($4.25 per square): this was a nice big block of fried tofu with seasonings. i enjoyed it but then i always like agedashi tofu.

- Sweet and Spicy Chicken ($1.25 per piece): they said this was one of the most popular menu items so i decided to get 3 pieces. honestly, it was just ok. and at $1.25 per nugget piece, it's not really worth it.

- Kaki-age ($4 each), which is a mixed tempura, really attracted me for its presentation. It was shaped like a crown, with greens and orange colors from the veggies and carrots. Their versions had shrimp, mixture of shredded vegetables (burdock, carrots, onions, and edamame) and potatoes (I think). Pretty good.
author: Cindy W.

description:
While my sister and I were eyeing the place for lunch, the free sampler of Curry and Seaweed Salad got us in for sure! A cozy corner eatery with some sushi bar seating, but mostly grab and go was excellent.

Pros:
~ Tasty! We had seaweed salad, a veggie roll and a chicken meat ball and all of it tasted fresh and savory. 
~ Attentive, professional and friendly staff who did a nice job packaging the food in a speedy fashion

Cons:
~ Sushi was wrapped more for form than function. The rice outside the nori wrapper fell off and made it difficult to get a complete bite.
~ No place to sit. The sushi bar was closed for Sunday lunch so we were able to sit there, but there are only 5 seats there.
author: Alex S.

description: Ate here a couple of years ago and thought the food was good. Stopped by craving onigiri today. Dry salmon rice ball - yuck. Disappointing.
author: Urban C.

description: Okay so heard about this place and decided to walk over and try...I liked the bento boxes and looked good but combinations were not my taste! I did see that most boxes were gone so I guess that's good. As for what I decided was spicy tuna roll pack with huge spicy tuna rolls 5 and do big I could not pick up with chopsticks!! Also instead of tuna on inside like most sushi the tuna was a ball on top of roll...weird. And was 9.50 plus tax $10.33..really high priced but it's SF. So I decided to make my way to Acme bread...oh boy
author: Dana D.

description: Delica is authentic Japanese food.  Lots of great, healthy items on the menu.  I'd give it five stars, but today my lunch was a bit off.  There were too many good things on the menu and I couldn't decide, but ultimately my selection was not good.  My SO had already selected what I wanted (the eggplant salad), so I went with the green beans, tofu steak and rice.  I guess my disappointment was that I expected the rice and tofu to be warm, but both were cold.  Nevertheless the eggplant and pork cutlet (tonkatsu) that the others ordered were much better.  So thus the 4 stars.  But i still like this place because the food is authentic Japanese, fresh, and healthy.  And the location is prime.  Grab a bento lunch and eat it on the deck overlooking the bay.
author: Rick K.

description: While the glass cases look aesthetically appetizing, I found that it's all just a facade, as everything I tried was merely okay. Maybe I just chose the wrong stuff, or perhaps I visited near closing time. Overall it is a nice concept that I'd revisit to find out why so many people gave it 4-5 stars.
author: Suany W.

description:
Tasty, fresh and unique, Delica is one of my favorite places to grab a quick lunch to go during work. Their bentos with salads, rice and meat/fish/tofu options are a delight and I can't help but always add a few salmon rice balls to the bag for a snack later. 

I always pick one up around 11am to avoid the lunch rush, but from what I can tell they have a to-go line and an order line to keep things flowing. Delicious!
author: Tiff C.

description: One of my favorite spots for a quick lunch during the workday. You can skip the long-ass line, and just grab one of the bento boxes...you will not be disappointed. I'm particularly digging the shrimp cakes!
author: Holly R.

description:
Delica is now my favorite destination in the Ferry Building.  I actually ate here 2X this week.  Man can you tell I like their food.

The first time this week I had their mushroom curry.  That's one delicious plate of authentic Japanese curry!  Please don't tell me that is not real curry, as in Naan n' Curry, or Thai coconut green curry.  I like all three varieties of curry equally, and Delica serves up the best Japanese version--- a bit tangy, a bit spicy, with the texture that is just thick enough for the rice to absorb all the goodness.  The second time I came this week I had the ginger beef.  Very delicious.  I also love their salmon rice balls.

I might go again!  That would make it 3X in one week.  Ok I'll wait.  Don't want to seem desperate.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
I'm pretty disappointed. A slow Monday night would have been a reasonable way to get some delicious, quickly made sushi from the ferry building. It took longer than expected but the free hot green tea was a nice gesture while I waited. 

Unfortunately, the sushi roll was poorly made. It didn't taste fresh at all, four of the six pieces of were falling apart (see uploaded photo) and the ginger was totally dried out.
author: Kelly F.

description: I'm addicted to their wasabi edemame potato salad and their sweet & spicy chicken.  It's my perfect lunch.
author: Juv C.

description:
A Japanese deli called DeliCA?  What a strange concept!  

I was intrigued because being a New Yorker at heart I think of Katz's or Carnegie Delicatessen with pastrami sandwiches when people say deli.  I was pleasantly surprised when I tried DeliCA.

Basically the whole premise behind DeliCA is a top-notch selection of specialty Japanese dishes made from fresh local ingredients, that you can pick from to create a combo meal.  I opted for the bento box filled with spicy chicken, lotus root salad and asparagus salad with sesame dressing. 

Some may say that a $10 bento is a bit pricey but you get what you pay for.  The food is fresh, delicious and healthy. The quality of the the ingredients speak for itself.  The asparagus salad and sesame dressing is DELICIOUS!

Healthy, tasty Japanese deli food...perhaps this concept will migrate to the East Coast.

This foodie is a FAN!

Tip:  Try the asparagus salad with sesame dressing.
author: Lis A.

description:
Yes... I am from Japan and actually my family owned restaurant business in Tokyo so I am confident talking about Japanese food. I love Delica. Quality of ingredients and all the thoughts and care go into their food in the kitchen is amazing. Delica recently added sushi bar and their sushi is the best I had in San Francisco. 

I also love Delica provide catering starting 10+ people, and starting around $9 per person. I highly recommend it:)
author: Mia I.

description: i used to visit here for lunch and used to love their food, which is pretty good for take-out. But you can probably not buy their food for dinner time when they have too many customers. A woman said, "Sorry, we have too many guests now, so we can't do take-out..." It's ok, I can understand. However, at least they should say like, "Yes, if you can wait for xx minutes, we can offer you....." Please do not let us down!
author: A J.

description: These guys are pretty much my go to spot everyday Saturday afternoon after working out at the Y. Their bento boxes are near perfection. Highly recommended.
author: Daniel H.

description: Not sure if I'm misisng something here but the food was not great. Except for the spectacular scenery, I didn't like that all the food was just sitting out. i understand that its part of the experience to see the food and what not, but even if its cold, i like my food to be fresh. nothing tasted particularly good, what is everyone having? i had the curry, it was blah.
author: Thach N.

description:
The Spicy Burdock Root Salad is authentic and delicious!  The rice and the Sweet and Spicy Chicken (they used chicken breast) are also fantastic.  The service is friendly, the place is clean, and the price is fair.  I got all three items for a low price of $7.75 before tax ($8.43 after tax).

Unfortunately, I didn't have the time nor the stomach to sample more dishes.  Nevertheless, I will be back to check out more dishes at a later date.

This place is truly a gem.
author: Food S.

description:
I come here at least twice a month for lunch - everything I have ever tried is delicious! My ultimate favorite things to order are: the Mabo Tofu Salad (seasonal so they don't always have it in stock) but it is the best salad I have ever had! I also love their chicken dumplings - very tasty and a steal @ $2/each! For a beverage, make sure you get their Apple Tea Drink - yummmy and I have yet to find any other place in the area that carries it!! The biggest plus is that this place has lots of organic ingredients. Everything is so fresh!

Prices are reasonable meaning I can get a full meal under $10. Lines are generally long, but move fast. The only downside is there isn't much seating inside of Delica, but it's in the Ferry Building so there's plenty of outdoor seating available. :)
author: Joy B.

description: the foods were good, I considered it more like fast foods and convenient for visitors that area.  They have a good selection of foods, and we tried more than different 5 items, we like 4/5, so its worth the try.  It was not a good place to sit and dine in, its good for you to grab something quickly and enjoy walking around which was what we did, we liked the foods :)
author: Nikki P.

description: Nice atmosphere as it's right by the ocean but the happy hour is not that great.  On the day we went there was the seafood salad with rice which didn't sound too appealing to me.  I went with the scallops dish which was a very small portion with only 2 scallops.  If you want to order the HH drink menu you have to had ordered the meal as well which is restrictive.  The rolls are decent .
author: Jennifer S.

description: I'm docking a star because of the damn line outside this place, but I guess that is what you get for such great food. The eggplant salad is to die for. I love the burdock too. Lots of vegan and vegetarian options. I usually stick to the salad combos, but they have delicious fried foods too and donburi. They also have sushi, but it's not that great. Stick with the deli food.
author: Katherine D.

description: I like this place for the food and the happy hour menu. The ambience is not bad, but there is not a lot of seating. On balance this is an excellent place to go for lunch or dinner.
author: Harry P.

description: I occasionally get lunch here.  I usually get the shrimp and crab croquette with the Japanese beef curry.  There's usually a line weekdays lunchtime but it goes by quick.    No place for sit down.  Buy it to go.
author: Cj P.

description: I like that they have Japanese food that's not teriyaki nor california roll.Who knows if they really have wasabi potato salad in Japan, but it's good stuff. I enjoy the bento boxes because you get to sample a lot of different foods. The salads are inventive, fresh and always delicious!
author: Susan B.

description: Terrible. Every visit. Fishy salad, rubbery food, no flavor. I gave it three tries.
author: Peebee J.

description: It would be nice if they had some seating, and their food is a little pricy, BUT the quality of the food is fantastic, and it is consistently delicious. Love getting my lunch from here and being able to feel like I've had yummy, healthy lunch!
author: Christine B.

description: Hmm...what can I say about this place?!  The bf and I were in the area and hungry.  We turned to good ol' Yelp and found this place.  It's a unique Japanese fusion restaurant.  They have two sides, a deli side and the restaurant side.  We ate at the restaurant side.  The menu was....interesting.  Not your typical Japanese sushi menu.  I really was craving spicy tuna and didn't see it on the menu.  But I asked the server and he said they can make it for us without a problem!  I also inquired about the potato croquettes that I read on Yelp but unfortunately they only sold it on the deli side which just closed!  But to my surprise, Chris, hooked it up!!  He told us it was worth a try cause it was good...and he was right!  It was deeeelish and I wish we got more haha.  We also ordered the salmon roll and the delica roll (shrimp tempura roll) and both were good!  Everything tasted fresh and delightful!  Chris was an awesome server, paid attention to our needs and was just so easy and friendly to talk to!  He even comped us for the potato croquettes (because I boasted that it was my bf's birthday which was also NYE)!!
author: Jenn N.

description:
Awesome Japanese deli!  They've catered for lunches at my work, and they are fabulous!  Delicious items worth mentioning:

1) giant VATS of curry: yes, i do mean vats...delicious tubs of yellow goodness
2) wasabi garlic potato salad: who would have thought that romaine mixed with garlicky wasabi mashed potatoes was so delicious?  i was suspicious...but it totally won me over!

I know we had two lunches in a row from Delica, but I can't wait for more!  :)
author: Fontane L.

description: Although located in the touristy Ferry Building, Delica serves up great quality sushi at non-touristy prices. The chirashi sushi special was served with a wide variety of artfully presented sashimi including red clam, unagi, and salmon roe (in total about 12-15 pieces) for $30. The $8 fresh wasabi was a worthy add-on. Note that the trick to getting a good amount of wasabi from the fresh stalk is to grind it in a circular motion on the provided board.
author: Arlene M.

description:
This place rocks!  If all vegetables were prepared this well and this tasty I would seriously consider becoming vegetarian.  I got the seasonal veggie bento box and the variety of vegetables, not to mention the creative and yummy preparation simply blew me away.  I like my vegetables fresh and tasting like vegetables (because I do have tastebuds and can appreciate subtle flavors instead of drowning everything in salt) and this place hits all the right spots.

Despite $10 for a bento box it was very filling as well.
author: Jean K.

description:
After several co-workers recommended this place I had to try it.   I think this place is great for people who work in the FiDi for lunch, or for people looking to lunch outside on a beautiful SF day.  The atmosphere is not much (albeit stark and clean), but the food is amazing. 

This place is truly a little piece of heaven.   Fresh ingredients prepared well.  

I had two salads (Chinese chicken and asparagus) and a main (roast beef sushi--phenomenal!).  I thought that t was possible that this wouldn't be enough food at first, but I was stuffed at the end. 

All items are put in a compact box. I LOVED the fact that the person who composed my meal separated each piece so that all the flavors did not mesh together. 

I want to go back and try the bento boxes, but I am a bit concerned the line.  There are two lines in the place which makes serving very efficient.  The bento box line is always significantly longer than  the salad/sushi line. 

My only complaint: 
The sesame spinach was NOT good. It was very bland and flavorless.   I will skip it next time.

This place has a lot of veggie and vegan options, so it is good for all diets.  

I found this place to be a relative good deal as compared with other lunch choices in the FiDi and Ferry Building.
author: Katharine A.

description:
Maybe it's the rebel in me that needs to always go against the grain. 
But yes, you FiDi yuppies, I am giving a two-star rating to your beloved Delica rf-1.
(Can I even say how pretentious the name Delica rf-1 even sounds? 
                         But that's a whole other issue). 

Normally, I love me my Japanese food. I just don't love me some Delica. 

Don't think I'm just hating because this place is always filled with FiDi lunchers, and their bentos sell out by 12:30. Because while annoying, it's something I've come to accept in the FiDi. I've given this place many a chance. But have always walked away disappointed. 

Their food looks pretty, but I haven't found a flavor combination that I've liked. It's like they're trying to hard. Most seem bland to me. 
  The ingredient combinations in their salads just don't jibe with my palate. 
  Their croquettes are delicate, sure... but also bland. How do you make a fried snack item bland?! That just seems so wrong to me. 

Perhaps my favorite item I've found here is the salmon onigiri (rice ball). But at $2 a pop, I can't justify it as a frequent purchase. Especially since the Chinese lady across the street at the Teriyaki Express in the 1 Market food court sells her own salmon onigiri for cheaper (and it's bigger! and has more flavor!). 

I understand Japanese food tends to err on the 'delicate' side and definitely trends more expensive than other Asian food. 
   But is it wrong for me to ask my food to have flavor?
  I'll take the Americanized salt-laden Teryiaki Express across the street over this over-priced blandness. 

I'm such a hater.
author: Vic C.

description:
Okay, I don't know if I didn't order the right items, but I wasn't impressed with Delica.  I came here for lunch today, and my throat was hurting so I ordered the hot soba noodles.  It was okay..but nothing spectacular.  I also got a salmon rice ball, which was lacking flavor, and I didn't even finish it because it was so boring (I generally don't like to waste food.)

My boyfriend ordered the chicken and tofu patty with rice and Chinese chicken salad.  He ate the food but wasn't very enthusiastic about it.

I give it 5 stars for the presentation.. but other than that, I wouldn't eat here again.
author: Patti F.

description:
I truly did want to like this place -- a Japanese deli!  What a great concept -- sadly, the deli folks told me the wasabi mashed potatoes contained dairy (a bad allergy for me).  I settled instead for a tofu steak -- a slab of tofu the size of 4 servings (think "deck of cards") covered in black bean sauce that was really just chunky black beans (also an allergen for me).  The side salads that were vegan were not impressive -- I'm usually a big fan of hijiki but this was pretty flavorless and mushy.  The black beans made me nauseous and I ended up throwing away more than half my meal after the leftovers sat in the fridge for over a week.

If you're vegan - there are better options at the Ferry Building.  If you are a vegetarian or omni, this place should tickle your fancy.  I'll save my vegan Japanese dining out points for Cha-Ya (or get my sweetie to whip up a deliciuos vegan Japanese feast for me).
author: Jenn C.
