description: Service is prompter and food tastes fresher than before.  The prices are not so bad when you consider how dense the food is.  I just bought a $16 lunch, but there's no way I'll be able to finish all of this food.
author: Otto D.

description: Curry tasted a little generic, beef was better than mushroom; salad portions seemed a little small
author: Sudeep K.

description:
Came here for a lunch take out and found it to be ok, not WOW!  Guess I am not much of a health conscious person nor do I like to order salad for lunch as you can tell below! =)

We ordered:
Kaki age- shredded onions, carrots and edamame on a tempura batter. Nothing to rave about, it was cold! Imagine eating tempura cold, yup, that's how it taste! 
Tonkatsu-yum, fried piece of moist pork topped with tonkatsu sauce! Can't go wrong with this one! 
Sweet & spicy chicken- perfectly fried and marinated but meat was a little dry.
Chicken dumpling with Sweet Chili Sauce- probably won't order this again.
Hijiki and Soybean salad- it didn't have much taste, a little bland
Spicy burdock root salad- pretty good, had a nice crunch to it! 
and DRUMS ROLLING:
Roast beef sushi- definitely highlight of our meal. Watch out, there's wasabi in it! I will be back for THIS, it's the BOMB!!! yeshh!!! $2.50 a piece!
author: Leeseuh K.

description: Ten dollar for the combination lunch (main + soup + salad), which was so not filling that I ended up having to look for a second meal! The two pieces of chicken dumplings were small, cold, and not impressive. As was everything else. I don't get the hype. And I am still hungry!
author: Donna W.

description:
I've heard many a rave about Delica from my work colleagues. I finally got something here after we had a pork sandwich adventure fail. 

I ended up buying a bento box with rice, tonkatsu, and the wasabi potato salad. The tonkatsu was perfectly crispy and the tangy sauce was the perfect accoutrement. Though it was a fried item, the tonkatsu tasted very light- probably a result of Delica's fresh ingredients. I was a little more iffy on the wasabi potato salad. I thoroughly enjoyed the crispness of the potatoes, but the combination of romaine lettuce leaves with the potatoes was a little weird for me texture wise. Overall, a great lunch, even though it was on the pricey side (~$10).
author: Angela L.

description:
happy hour with a coworker after a successful business meeting. 
sushi, nippon style small plates, $2.50 pints of kirin beer and a flight of sake. these are makings of a good time. but let me get into the details and you will see why it's 3 and not 4 stars.
the sushi offering was only aight, not stellar. the most memorable and expensive dish was the seared toro (tuna belly). at $10/piece it was good but not OMG melt in your mouth better than s*x great.
the omakase (chef's choice) sushi that i ordered was BORING (see my posted photo). not much imagination. the fish quality was something i'd expect at a floating sushi boat place not a Ferry Building Foodie Heaven location like this.
the lotus root chips sliced super thin and salted was a great bar food side dish but the kaarage style deep fried chicken gizzards were like chewing on rubber grommets. my drinking buddy liked them but the texture was a bit difficult for me to adapt to.
the atmosphere here will always be relaxed and stylish but again i was a more than a little disappointed with the food offerings.
the servers and staff were all friendly and hospitable.
the flight of sake was enjoyable - a ginjo, junmai and a specialty unpasteurized sake were wonderfully served for $12.
in summary, i expected a little more WOW, but all in all it was a pleasant dining experience. just remember to bring extra cash. we dropped $120 for two during happy hour. 
it was really a happy ending more for Delica investors than us though.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Food is fresh, delicious, but don't wait 'til noon for lunch - gotta get there early before the long line.  
Fabulous food, but it's expensive!
author: Marcia K.

description:
$20 for two is about standard.  $30 if you are really hungry.  The #4 lunch plate is pretty good (1 main item, 1 salad item, and rice).

The spicy burdock salad, wasabi potato salad, and asparagus salad are all fantastic.  I also really like the potato croquette.  They used to have crab croquette, but discontinued it.  They lose one star for that in hopes that they might bring it back!
author: Ryan W.

description: Great japanese food! My favorite are the shrimp cakes and pork cutlets. Great location in the ferry building...
author: Danielle M.

description: Too expensive for what it is...but it's in the ferry building so comes with the territory. Had a smoked salmon roll, pork katsu w/rice and a croquette. Everything was tasty and well seasoned. Wish it was a bit cheaper, but overall a good experience and a unique lunch spot.
author: Ken W.

description:
Dear Yelp Journal,

You'll be so proud of me.  I actually paid for this meal, all $17 of it.  I know, it's a little bit pricey, but it came from the Ferry building.  I can only imagine what the overhead is like in there.  Regardless, I had a good experience.

I came here with my managers after I had researched a sushi place that was near the embarcadero.  I couldn't find one.  If someone reading this review wants to drop a really good and authentic sushi place near Folsom and Embarcadero to me that would be much appreciated.  Thanks.

Anyway, I came here on a Thursday with my managers and we all just grabbed bento boxes and ate.  They had some really good stuff in it.  There was their potato salad type thing with wasabi mayo in it and I really liked it.  The heat was not unbearable and just enough "BAM" to impress me.  Their food was tasty and original.  I knew this.  It's not what my managers would have liked, which is more traditional Japanese.

Overall, the staff behind the counters were very friendly and the food was good enough for me.  It's a little pricey, but worth it as an occasional eatery.  It's not even expensive enough to justify calling it a splurge.  I would recommend this place, just be careful of the pigeons flying around inside the building.
author: Wilson K.

description:
Good food, but Definitely Way Overpriced for what it is

I love bentos, but almost $10 for a simple bento? That doesn't really fill you up? Ummmm...expensive.  Bentos should be around $5-6!

Recently, they renovated and opened an evening tapas + wine bar...the curried potato croquettes were yummy, but waaay salty. The Lotus chips were Great...but $3 for a tiny bowl...

Why can't it be YUMMY And Reasonably-priced?! 
Please???
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I don't get to eat at Delica's that often as I would like, but everytime that I do, I am quite pleased.

I always go for the bento box that has yet to disappoint.  Here are the bento box options:

4 Items $9.75 
1 Fried + 2 Salads + Rice 

5 Items $9.75 
3 Salads + Half Cut Shrimp Cake + Chicken Dumpling 

9 Items $11.00 
5 Salads + 3 Salmon Roles + Chicken Dumpling

Awesome selections.  Some faves?  Hijiki and soybean salad.  Green bean salad.  Tofu steak.  Chicken dumpling with sweet chili sauce.  Fried shrimp cake.  

Definitely a great lunch spot if you're by the Ferry Building.
author: Carmen Y.

description:
Delica describes itself as a deli serving prepared Japanese meals to take away but it serves Japanese food I've never seen elsewhere. I'm not sure whether that's because I'm not that familiar with Japanese food or because they've invented some new fusion dishes

Whatever the reason, they have a wonderful way of presenting the food and making it all seem very tempting. The dishes are also well labelled, which is good for some of the less familiar looking dishes.

There are pre-packed bento boxes but also hot dishes plated up as you order them.

I've enjoyed dishes ranging from the roast beef sushi to chicken Okonomi Yaki (griddle cakes) to Japanese curry. All well flavoured and seasoned with some offering a twist on the food found in most Japanese restaurants

Not the cheapest but not terrible for the Ferry Building
author: Yee Gan O.

description: Avoid at all cost! I got food poisoning today during lunch after eating a salmon rice ball, potatoe croquette and chicken katsu from Delica:( my tummy still do not feel well. I suspect it was the salmon rice ball from here. It wasnt even good which is the sad part. Never again!
author: Kelly C.

description: For the price, I was expecting the health inspection score to be higher than an 85!!!!  This is a "deli".  How can the score be so low?  Please up your game and improve the score.
author: Monica P.

description:
I love Delica's ethics and aesthetics. This 'deli' has always captured my attention with its artistic appeal. Each item is so irreverently beautiful that what you're eating feels irrelevant- you're eating art!

This is not to say the food isn't good; it is. But being Chinese and unable to reconcile w/ paying $10 for an "organic chicken patty over soy sauce rice" I've only ever tried the kaki-age tempura basket, and the potato croquette.

I imagine that the potato croquette would be delicious if it were hot. Unfortunately, mine was a little south of warm, and cold fried foods just aren't my thing. 

However, the kaki-age was both beautiful and yummy. The perfectly-fried tempura batter complemented, rather than overpowered the bites of shredded vegetable and shrimp. Though $4 is a hefty price for one piece of tempura, it was satisfactory.

It seems irrational to give 4 stars to a place that serves cold potato croquettes, (even McDonald's keeps its fries crunchy and hot w/ a heat lamp) but... I just like this place. Maybe it's a you-have-to-be-there sort of liking. Maybe I'm just a putz for clever marketing. I'd still recommend it any day.

Bottom Line: Very alluring in a California-chic sort of way.
author: Tianyi S.

description:
Went here and got the #4 lunch special. Which includes one of their main dishes, a salad and rice.  I got the agedashi tofu with the spinach and sesame salad. It was only $8 which is pretty reasonable for downtown SF. 

The food was okay, they claim to be a Japanese place with a California twist. I didn't find too much of the California twist.  I am usually a fan of agedashi tofu and this one was just lacking in the flavor department.  I liked the spinach and sesame salad in little doses, I ended up leaving about half of it. 
 
I am definitely going to go back to Delica and try one of their curries. Maybe thats there specialty. There is usually a long line outside so they have to be doing something right.
author: Analisa S.

description:
I've always avoided this place in the Ferry Building because I once tried a sample of the carrot ginger soup and I almost gagged. I'm no fan of ginger.

So, last week L and I were having a long internal debate on where to eat and chose Delica because it had the shortest line.

The scene:

Much like every other store in the Ferry Building, Delica was fancy. They've got 2 lines out the door - one for salads and one for hot foods. We automatically got into the hot food line not knowing the difference. Each of the food items are on display behind a glass case that stretched throughout the entire restaurant. Items such as chicken dumplings, tonkatsu, tempura, and other fried items as well as ginger kobe beef rice bowls, bento boxes, sushi and salads.

The food:

I totally was not craving anything hot because it was such a beautiful day in the city, but I went for the veggie curry.

Veggie Mushroom Curry - Oh my GOD it was good! It was the best Japanese curry I've ever had. It was very hot, creamy and... crunchy? Yes! The curry was topped with thinly sliced lotus roots that were fried so they have the texture of chips. The two types of mushrooms used in the curry were button and oyter. The taste of the dish as a whole was so unusally satisfying. I've never had any other curry like it. It seriously beats Muracci's and Hotei out of the water.
author: Sam L.

description: Nice choices.  Clean & neat.  Sort of pricey, but it's the Ferry Building.  Seaweed salad is good.  I've been there dozens of times, it's always good.  Lines move fast.  Nice views of the bay.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description:
Crab croquettes!

Potato croquettes.

Can't wait for corn croquettes to be in season.

Some day I'll eat something else from here that isn't fried.
author: Poppy C.

description: Outstanding!  Everything I've had here has been great.  The staff is super friendly and helpful.  They put so much effort into the flavors of each dish, and its so nice to see it all before you make a decision.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Pretty much everything I've ever eaten here has been amazing. I have dreams about their mushroom curry & wasabi potato salad.

Loses a star for the prices, which are a bit high for Japanese food, even though I get that it's inflated for the Embarcadero location.
author: Anna G.

description:
3.5 stars.

TIPS:
- Spicy Chicken is good but they only give you 3 pieces - and they're small!
- tarter sauce is to die for.
- Eggplant Salad (Not always available; seasonal?!) is delicious!
- customize your own bento box (on the left) instead of waiting in the line to the right.

Whenever we walk to the clock tower, we find ourselves here! It's pretty expensive but what looks to be small portions is actually pretty filling.

Always a favorite for a nice, (cheaper) leisurely lunch ... :)
author: T L.

description:
Fresh and fun Japanese-California fusion! I've been here twice now for lunch. It may seem expensive by normal standards, but it's actually one of the cheaper places in Ferry Plaza to eat.

The first time I went, I got "two salads and rice": eggplant and hijiki/soybean. It was definitely a 4 or even 5 star experience. But, I went and sat in the side seating area, which was open, and then this grumpy employee went over and closed it off, WHILE I WAS STILL SITTING THERE! I don't know why they don't put a sign saying no sitting if they don't want you to sit there, not to mention leaving it open. The eggplant and hijiki salads were both tasty, and the rice was good too. But I was hungry pretty quickly.

The second time, I didn't dare sit in that seating area, even though it was wide open! I got the tofu/chicken patty, the burdock salad, and the corn/marscapone/tomato salad. And a potato croquette. The potato croquette was COLD. I expected it to be hot, since it was in the hot area! Good thing I didn't get the tempura entree or anything! The tofu/chicken was pretty disappointing too, as was the burdock salad (underseasoned) and the corn salad (good, but does not go with the food at all!) The whole thing was 12 bucks and there's nowhere to sit.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I got a Bento box and it was around $10. You can choose pre packed bentos up front. I got the one with chicken dumpling (it had sweet sauce on it), rice with sesame seeds, salad and green beans. The vegetables were good but it didn't seem fresh. The whole bento box filled me up but I wasn't satisfied.

Too bad I didn't get to taste the roast beef sushi, next time!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Awesome destination in the Ferry Building indeed! If you expect authentic Japanese food, you should bolt for the door. There is an amazing selection of fusion Japanese food here. It's fairly simple fare, and usually I prefer to eat here at the sushi bar with my friend rather than do a take out- which I see lots of people doing. 

I adore their sushi rolls- anything with spicy tuna of course. It is a must for me to go for the vegetarian selection of spicy eggplant, miso spinach and the occasional wasabi potato salad. Their Agadashi Tofo is Ok, nothing special but you pay for what you get since it really is rather large. I wouldn't say its for sharing, if not they would have made it smaller pieces. They use American Tofu, which is much firmer and doesn't give off the gingery taste you can normally achieve with soft Japanese/Chinese tofu. 

Other than that, service, ambiance is very nice and it never gets too crowded since they only have barely any seats anyway :)
author: Denise T.

description:
Went here for lunch. Shared the crispy chicken, with rice and the eggplant salad and some pre-packed sushi box with a friend. I was blown away with the flavors especially in the eggplant salad. YUM! Lunch for two came out close to $20,  which was fine. Loved the displays and everything looked so delicious. 

Definitely coming back here again!
author: Mika D.

description: This deli is very good.  The carrot & ginger soup was delicious.  The miso soup was a little too salty.  The rest of the dishes (there were too many to mentioned, we ordered a lot) were also delicious.  Good and fresh.
author: t d.

description:
Came by for take away lunch, dropped $12.26 plus tip on a bowl of good soup, piece of meat sushi, and .3lb pile of cold spinach.

Carrot Ginger Soup: 4 stars
Tasty.  A bowl of this for $5.50 will fill you up for lunch.  I didn't really pick up on the ginger, though there was enough to counterbalance any potential bitterness from the carrot.  Tastes remarkably like the kind you can buy in a box at Trader Joe's.

Roast Beef Sushi: 2.5 stars
It's what it sounds like.  Meat sushi - a chilled piece of cooked roast beef on a ball on sushi rice with a little wasabi glue.  It was ok, but it really left me wanting something else to help bring it together.  The reason such a simple thing works so well with good cuts of fish is because the natural flavor is so much more complex than cooked meat.  I think a little minced garlic and/or scallion shavings could have really helped.  Not worth $2.50.

Sesame Spinach Seaweed Salad: 1 star
I like cold raw spinach and warm wilted spinach.  Having tried this, I can now say I dislike cold wilted spinach...or at least how it's done here.  It was dense pile of cold wilted spinach hit with a splash of sesame-inspired liquid.  I felt like Pop-Eye realizing he's hit rock bottom.  There wasn't any seaweed in my serving.  Absolutely none.

Several items look/sound good here.  I'll be back for the soup and try a little bit of something else next time.
author: Dave H.

description: Not sure why this place is so highly rated. This is our second visit, the first visit we had curry and rice. More rice than curry. Curry was old and rice was hard. Today we got a few items here, eggplant salad, agedashi tofu, soup and tofu+chicken patty thing and a side of rice. Unfortunately the portion of the rice is again significantly greater than everything else I listed. When I asked for more eggplant salad (cus it was only two tablespoon worth in a huge box where a 2/3 of it is just rice and blank space) she said I can buy it in a pint. It's also inaccurately labelled salad cus it's a completely cooked dish just served icy cold. Either it was ok. Agedashi tofu was not agedashi tofu. Agedashi tofu is meant to be served warm and is soft. Delica's version is everything opposite. The label, IMHO, could use a little warning that it's icy cold and hard. Completely disappointed our expectations. Soup was bland and patty over-seasoned. Oh well, we visited cus Out the Door was closed. Third time is never going to be a charm cus third time is not happening.
author: May G.

description:
the food here is expensive.  i got a main plus 2 salads and a drink for about $12.  and there was no meat!  haha

ive always likes the hijiki and the burdock salad here.  the other stuff not so much.  i had the agedashi tofu here and it was cold and i was embarrassed to ask for soy sauce.
author: claudia y.

description:
Luckily, the rice ball with Goji berries had a label on it, but most of my review for this place is under the Ferry Building.

I just want to add the photos. This place makes innovative Asian-fusion cuisine. Roast beef sushi, fresh, and reasonably priced.

See photos or read my other review.
author: A H.

description:
Ah yes, back to the Ferry Building, and another prime contender for a lunchtime grab-and-go is Delica, which I've visited on several occasions.  I have to admit that I was a little leery of a Japanese deli, because I thought the food wouldn't be substantial enough to satisfy my hunger pangs.  

But it's quick (that is if you can figure out the system of lines), the food is reasonably freshly prepared, and the variety is pretty decent, and the quantity is surprisingly generous.  The last time I was there, I even ordered a salad trio, which was outstanding!

I'll have to return soon, so I can report back with a more detailed review.
author: Evelyn K.

description:
85 degrees and Sunny in SF?!?!? Definitely the time to grab something from the ferry building and eat on the benches by the water! 

This was the case today. Tried one of their grab and go bento boxes- $10, yes it was expensive but it's hard to spend anything less than that at the Ferry Building so just suck it up. I had the sweet n sour chicken bento while my friend had the chicken dumpling. I really liked the fact that the bento boxes were still warm when i picked it up, so it probably haven't been sitting out for hours. 

I really enjoyed my food, there were 3 huge pieces of chicken (tasty) a good portion of rice and two types of salad. There was just enough of each thing  to keep you full but won't make you feel disgusting afterwards. This place was highly recommended by my friend and she seemed to have enjoyed her lunch as well! The dumplings looked delicious,,, definitely have to try it next time. 

There wasn't a line at all when we went, a little after 12 and it was a great place to pick up freshly prepared for an ok price. Eating lunch out by the water is priceless! Get out of the office and try it sometimes!
author: Tenny W.

description: Expensive and tasty (which I expected) but they didn't disappoint me on portion sizes (which was unexpected).
author: joe b.

description:
Delica is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I always get the 3-salad combination -- the portions for salads are generous and the salads are all really exciting that I can't decide which three to get... 

My favorites are: 
. Hijiki and soybean salad (if you like seaweed this is the best salad ever)
. Spicy burdock root salad (my friend loves this)
. Green bean salad (a little crunchy and with creamy sesame dressing -- yummy)

On top of that, the service is impeccable, friendly and beyond helpful: my server suggested a combination salad which would cost less than buying my salad per pound.

Delica gets points for giving consideration to sustainability and humane treatment of animals (e.g. from Prather Ranch which is certified humane http://www.certifiedhumane.org) not to mention making veggie food delicious. 

If Delica was open for dinner I'll be here everyday -- I usually don't make it here by 6 (weekdays) or 5 (weekend) before it closes. I love the food and highly recommend this place to anyone who likes healthy and tasty food.
author: Yvonne C.

description:
With a good selection at a reasonable price, there isn't much to fault Delica with.  I've always been a fan of building your own bento box, as well as having the option chosen for me (the pre-made ones are available).  

My only gripe with the food here is that if you do get a bento box, it'll be cold.
author: Jeff N.

description: The atmosphere is contemporary and the setting is different from most of the sushi bars. However the experience was quite bad, the green tea wasn't fresh, they gave you a really small cup and never came to refill , had to ask for more tea every single time. The worst of all was when we ordered a combo plate where we clearly stipulated no salmon. The waitress wrote the order correctly but the chef put salmon in anyway, which is no big deal if they could just fix it. But I watched the chef just took the salmon out and had the plate sent back to the table and told us they had "replaced "the salmon with another fish, which was simply a lie. I had to tell them that I saw the whole process and the fish they claimed to be the replacement of the salmon was in the plate all that time. The waitress did admitted the wrong doing and apologized.   The sushi was average, the price was quite high ( 2 people about 100bucks), but I certainly didn't appreciate being treated like this.
author: Dom S.

description: The salmon chowder only had one tiny salmon in it, and I looked very hard for my salmon in the soup. There are many carrots which tricked me into thinking they were salmon at first. I did not like that feeling. The taste was expected, nothing special. The beef curry bowl has 60% rice and 40% curry, when it should be at least 50/50. Did not like that at all.
author: Diana C.

description:
Ever wonder what would happen if the US got all xenophobic again and started closing borders and barring immigration? (Wait, we're on that road already, aren't we?)

Ever wonder what would happen to all the great ethnic food we have here? Won't all that food be stuck in a time capsule, while the ethnic food in the home country continued evolving?

Yeah, me neither. Who thinks about useless topics like these anyway? Wait though - I'm getting somewhere.

Most of the Japanese food around these parts seem to be stuck in a time capsule, teriyaki chicken and breaded pork chops and what not that seem to beckon back to a past age. Classic Japanese comfort food, as it were...

In the meantime, Japanese food from the motherland has evolved, gained new influences, incorporated new ideas. That's the type of food Delica serves up. Contemporary food from Japan that's not the food that mom used to make, well, because mom hasn't been back to Japan since the 1950s or something.

What does that say about Delica? I'm not trashing teriyaki chicken and all that good stuff, but Delica does bring a breath of fresh air to the plethora of Japanese joints in this town.
author: Ken L.

description:
This place was ok.  Very mediocre bordering on barely adequate.  Delica is americanized and does not have a big menu.  The items they do have are not great but better than edible.  

I thought this was a sushi restaurant and was disappointed at their weak selection.  This definitely contributes to the rating I am giving Delica.  

Ordering and paying for a meal is also confusing which was weird and the food is expensive.  My friend only ordered a prepackaged sushi role and it cost  $14.  

I might come back here but because of the proximity to my work and to eat outside on the Embarcadero.  If I find another sushi place near Market street and between Sansome and Embarcadero I probably won't.  

Nice location, and not an unpleasant experience is why I give this restaurant 2 stars instead of 1.  Can get 3+ stars by having a decent lunch special, increasing efficiency at POS or other.
author: Brandon E.

description: Fun and simple Japanese food perfect for lunch. Make a combination plate and try three different food items on one plate. Great flavors and some unexpected ones too, like the roastbeef sushi. Modern and price worthy, do not miss this place!
author: Linn L.

description:
A Japanese deli lunch place in the Ferry Building.  I really like their various salads, especially the hijiki/tofu salad and the mapo tofu salad.  They taste fresh and have nice light flavors.  You can tell the ingredients they use are high quality.  The fried foods are good too. :P  I like the croquettes and the vegetable tempura ball.

Prices are a little expensive (around $9-10 for a bento, but you get to mix and match the items that you want, which is nice), but this is kind of expected since it's in the Ferry Building.  I still come here whenever I'm in the area.  Yum!
author: Cassie H.

description:
Delica is a fabulous restaurant/deli to enjoy a quick, tasty, and relatively well priced meal. The average $10 price is steep compared to suburban standards, but not bad for a tourist destination. The chicken salad and chicken/tofu patties are amazing. I enjoyed every single bite. The seaweed dish was pretty good...I'm sure that someone w/ vegan sensibilities would love it more than me.

You might be thinking - "Wait John, all this sounds great, why only 3 stars?" Well, there is one major downside - good luck finding seating. We had to rely on the kindness of a father that offered to give up his chair for us so that we could sit while he stood behind his son. Another very minor minus is that there aren't too many selections to choose from. Again - this is minor - but it would be good to have more options. I think that the limited selection is part of their effort to keep it simple for guests that aren't accustomed to Japanese cuisine (like me!).
author: John Z.

description: I had the soba noodles with Kakiage tempura and I honestly feel like this is the most delicious soup I have ever had in my entire life. It was $8 and extremely filling. I don't know if the other items are very filling but this one packs lot for the $. I do not want to eat white rice so I thought this would be a better choice since its buckwheat noodles and my tummy is happy. I have very low knowledge and exposure to Japanese food and what is constituted as authentic vs. not but people say this place is very authentic so it makes me excited to explore Japanese food moving forward. I have had the carrot ginger soup a few times and that is very creamy even though there is no dairy and i have had a few dumplings here that were good but little however the noodle soup is awesome. The broth itself is so flavorful. I picked up a rather large piece of tofu steak that is fried with ginger paste and I am excited to try that out tonight for dinner. I am still way full from the soup
author: First L.

description:
I don't usually eat lunch but when I stopped by here for lunch one day I licked my plate clean. Well not literally, but you know what I mean.

I'm not sure what I ordered exactly but it was just so goood. I was skeptical about ordering the seaweed salad but it's delicious. The food is fresh, healthy, and doesn't make you feel like you ate the entire world.

Only downside was paying $20 for lunch. Yikes.
author: reiko o.

description: My latest addiction, love the bento boxes.
author: Sydney L.

description:
Two words: Eggplant salad.  Try it.  The flavors are fantastic.  I could eat a tub full of this salad.

Chicken tonkasu sandiwch (they don't have this all the time) - sooo good.  the Chicken is perfectly fried on the outside yet so soft on the inside and the tonkasu sauce adds that punch of flavor.  Only problem is that it's kinda too big to fit properly in your mouth.

The dumplings, the pork tonkasu, the tofu and chicken, and the patty thing...all good.

The only CON to this place is that it is SO expensive for the amt of food you get.
author: C A.

description:
Healthful, fresh, and fried all in one order - I'm definitely a fan! The ferry building overwhelms with choices - seafood, mexican, pork, local, sweet... You can find a meal for whatever mood you are in - if you are willing to pay a pretty penny.

Delica delivered great food at a decent price. The #1 (two salads and a main dish) offered plenty of food for just over $10. The sesame spinach was garlicy and just a pinch too salty. The chinese chicken salad was crunchy and fresh. And the Kaki-age (fried vegetables topped with shrimp in a tempura batter) was even better than I expected.

To top it off, I ate outside on the water on a warm, sunny day. Great find.
author: Katelyn M.

description:
Just what Nobu-san said...

Spot on.

CHO (super) TAKAI (expenisve) and food that you will fina at any local market or department store (yes, many of the fashion oriented department stores, have a floor or 2 dedicated to selling deli style food and a market).  

Love the concept but totally glorified to make it appeal to the American Eye.
author: Shiho F.

description: Their curry is delicious! Perfectly flavored and with a hint of spice. Salmon onigiri (rice ball wrapped in seaweed) was okay, a little dry/not as flavorful as we expected. Spicy tuna roll was delicious too, the spicy tuna was piled on top and it tasted really fresh & flavorful!
author: C K.

description: The food here tastes great. I wish the portions were bigger and the prices were a little lower.
author: Olivia P.

description:
On a cold San Fran afternoon when the fog has rolled in and you want something to warm you up, get the beef curry bowl - totally clutch. The food is good overall, great if you need to grab something to go (they have 2 lines, one or quick ready made to-go things and one for hot food). 

The food is a little pricey (~$10) but its worth dropping by every now & then.
author: linda t.

description: My coworker and I were looking for something special and unique that we wouldn't eat usually for lunch and found Delica. It was during the lunch hour and boy, was the line LONG. We waited about 10 minutes in line. However, we were amazed by the various and unique items to pick from. We were pretty indecisive. I chose the Japanese Style Beef Curry, which came with steamed rice. I also had the Kaki-age which was a mixture of shredded vegetable and shrimp in tempura. My coworker had the Seafood Donburi and also had the Kaki-age. We both decided that our main entree was alright and not that great. However, the Kaki-age was delicious! We both agreed that instead of getting the entrees, we should've gotten the chicken dumplings, tofu steak, and etc.! Everyone seemed to be getting those items instead. Menu prices were a bit pricey, but it's expected since we are at the Ferry Building.
author: Philana C.

description: Quick 'japanese' food.  The tonkatsu and potato croquette were fried well, but wasn't very hot.  The hijiki rice ball was okay.  Rice didn't taste very fresh, and it contained a good amount of veggies.  I tried my friend's tofu salad, which was drenched with a tasty sauce.  Overall, I wasn't impressed.  Extremely unauthentic.  Prices were as expected of for the ferry building.. However, the value of the food for what you get is pretty off, as most of their dishes are just veggies and extremely light.
author: Tramy V.

description:
Today, huddled around a freezing cold table behind the Ferry Building, three lunch buddies made their 2009 New Year's Resolutions.  

Among these resolutions were vows to payoff bills, compete in a triathalon, exercise regularly, and get a sole-proprietorship off the ground.  (Okay, so those were my friends' goals.  Mine were a little more shallow and of the "drop 25 pounds and don't be a slut" variety).

Our lunch at Delica RF-1 was okay and close to what I had expected.  I never know what to order here, because there are so many options and the line confuses me (go to the right, now go to the left, now stand in the center).  I used to get beat-up as a kid because I sucked at Simon Says and today I half expected to turn around and see Trailer Park Rhonda ready to pummel me with mismatched mittens.

My bento box contained a very good mushroom salad, fishy seaweed salad, tasty rice, and three small pieces of sweet & sour deep fried chicken.  If I could do it over again (and if we're getting re-dos in general, I'd liked to have not hooked up with Minnie Driver's opening act that one time - you know, the Carrot Top body double who made me rock-paper-scissors for the check?) I would order the mushroom salad, chinese chicken salad, rice, and umm... well... maybe some more salad.

It was a good thing there's limited seating inside Delica RF-1, because it led to the three of us making some great goals (losers buy shots for the others) and gave me a newfound respect for the seagulls who shivered loudly at our feet.

I didn't finish my lunch today.  Which, coming from a girl whose parents had to lock up junkfood in a safe, says a lot.

Oh, and I sat in seagull sh*t.

At ~$11/person for our small lunches, I doubt we'll come back here to unveil our results at the end of the year.  In fact, if my resolutions come true (they're like wishes, right?), I'll be a 125-pound supermodel with platinum blonde hair and an English accent in no time.  I'll be able to sit in my own sh*t, thankyouverymuch.
author: Janney B.

description:
I've been traveling to San Francisco on a regular basis over the past year, but only made it to Delica rf-1 for the first time today.  I had the shrimp curry, which was delicious, (but could be a little spicier), as well as the wasabe potato salad.  The jury's still out on the salad.  

Although the Ferry Building is awesome, Delica rf-1 needs to get some tables!!  It's one of the only restaurants that doesn't have "reserved" seating, so it took my girlfriend and me about 20 minutes, and two laps around the building, until we managed to spot two chairs where we were subsequently wedged between a door and a glass wall, and surrounded by loud swedish women.  

They also don't sell any soda; just bottled iced tea.  I realize Diet Coke may not be healthy or "authentic," but it's delicious.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Pretty good take and go food with nice fusion flavors, though a bit steep on the price!

My favorite so far is their mascarpone corn salad.  It's creamy without being too rich.  Tastes great cold.  The corn has a nice sweet bite to it and the creaminess from the mascarpone wakes up each spoonful.  I also like their boneless sweet and sour chicken with the black sesame seeds giving it a nice toasted afterbite.

I've had other dishes before and they were all good.  Flavor-wise, very refreshing and not the MSG / saltlick thing you'd get from other Asian food vendors.  Delica kind of lives up to its name with that balance of subtleties that make for a good quick weekday lunch.
author: Eileen P.

description: The sushi - it was fresh, it was crisp, it came prompty, and it was also very expensive. I've had sushi that was just as good from places that were much cheaper.
author: Melody L.

description:
i have visited this place several time.  AWESOME food  !!!!  GREAT presentation, specialized Sake (that only 2 sushi bars in san fran have)  Personalble and smiling staff.  The owner insist on QUALITY.  BEST EVER .!!!!  
You cant go wrong with this place.  :)))))))
CEO ClearWall corporation.
Norm
author: Normand M.

description:
As my favorite weekday lunch spot near my office, Delica deserves to be my first review on Yelp. Selections are typically moderately-priced, but you definitely pay for quality. I recommend cutting the long noon-time lines by ordering a custom boxed lunch of the Crab Cream Croquette, Chicken Katsu and Chicken Dumpling (with a side of rice, of course). All three are delicious and relatively healthy.

The drawbacks?: 1) Long lines between 11:30-1pm, 2) Over-priced, poorly-selected variety of Bento Box options, 3) $10-per-lunch average.

Regardless, this is still my favorite noon-time spot in SF. 

Oh yeah, and on Mondays theres a pretty hot cashier that works the lunch shift!
author: Joseph F.

description:
My co-workers took me to the Ferry Building for lunch and I decided on Delica.

I ordered the Beef curry and it was just A-OK.  My order came with a lot of beef and they were tender, but the curry lacked taste.

I would give it another shot (when i get the chance!) to try their other hot foods as they look yummy!
author: Terry C.

description:
Delica can be very tasty, as long as you don't over do it and have it on an almost daily or weekly basis--as I did this past year. And when you do go, make sure to go by 11:30AM or after 1:00PM to avoid the lunch rush.

Things that you should try are the shrimp cakes, chicken dumplings, tonkatsu, wasabi potato salad, and the black seaweed salad. They also have curries, soba noodle soup, and sushi rolls. If you can't decide, get a bento box. After eating, you won't feel like crap because everything is pretty healthy.
author: Maureen B.

description: Like coming to this place for weekday lunch because it's a nice break from the office to take a stroll down to the Ferry Building. The food is different than the "traditional" Japanese style lunch usually offered in the Financial District (i.e. don't expect teriyaki chicken with steamed rice or california roll), which is one aspect I enjoy about this place. The food seems healthier compared to other lunch places and has a pretty good variety: bento box style which included small portions of about five items or order from the counter for one main + two sides for right about $10.  There's s small counter space you can eat at but since just a few steps outside the door and you're at the bay, so I've only ever eaten along the water.  Quick service, clean, and helpful staff.
author: Kent W.

description: You pick and choose which items you wanna buy (some are a little pricey). Their packaged crab (real crab meat) and shrimp sushi roll was really good.  It's almost better to get the packaged combo bento-like meals because you get to try a little bit of everything that way and price is more reasonable.
author: Wendy T.

description: I got the Ginger Beef Bowl and Spicy Tuna Roll and was so relieved that it was a grab'n'go and that I wouldn't have to wait in the line. The Ginger Beef Bowl was much more than I was expecting and I ended up taking back to the office for the next day's lunch (it was still good!). Spicy Tuna Roll was so-so and uncomfortably large sizes - The city has enough great sushi that I wouldn't ever get sushi here again. If you wanted to get something on the deli side, you have to get their really early before the lunch rush to avoid the crazy line. The grab'n'go section had a lot of variety and I would definitely recommend looking there first.
author: Rachel N.

description: A lot of people seem to love the ferry building - the concept is great, but given its location and the tourism, you can't expect much value or quality of food. With that said, this eatery fits perfectly - the food is either cold or fried and overpriced. I wouldn't come out of my way to eat here, or anywhere in the building, but it's not a bad place to eat if you're already here.
author: Leily P.

description:
Uh, honestly?

I've lost trust in a lot of my fellow Yelpers because I went here because of many glowing recommendations.

I can officially say that this place is a joke.

But if you're a "hipster" who thinks this kind of shit is trendy and it actually makes you look cool, go ahead. Be my guest.

I'm thinking that a lot of the people who have reviewed this place have never tasted legitimate Japanese food. The flavors are decent but not spectacular and the deli portions are ridiculously meager. You'd fare so much better at a full-service Japanese restaurant (and you'd probably pay less too). Come on. 2-3$ for a tiny tonkatsu? It's the size of a f**king chicken nugget, and not nearly as tender and juicy and thick as tonkatsu is supposed to be.

Everything is overpriced and the majority of the people I saw there looked as if they thought D rf-1 was the mecca of gourmet Japanese. A group of 3 blond girls even spent 5 minutes posing with all the "ethnic food." Please, by location alone I should have known this place was touristy and Americanized by all standards.

When I ordered the items with their proper Japanese pronunciation, the girl behind the counter said "What was that? I'm sorry?" about three times. TONKATSU. I'm sorry I don't say it "Tun Cats You." I prefer saying things correctly. Should have been another warning sign right there, but alas, I was hungry, and for the wonderful price of about $25, I got 3 tiny pork cutlets, 3 pieces of "roast beef sushi" (which is literally TOUGH roast beef on rice wtf is the big deal) and the mushroom salad. I left still hungry (and I'm not a big girl, either). Went to In n Out after and just wished that it had been my first stop and not my second.

If you know and truly appreciate Japanese food, this is not where you would eat. Ever.

(I'd stop right here but I'm actually so pissed I dropped $25 dollars here on my food alone that I can't stop ranting)

This is the last time I trust anyone from Yelp that says "My Asian friends think this place is great too!" Unless those "Asian friends" are native Japanese people, never, ever again. I normally do not believe in racial profiling, but 'm looking at photos and the last names of reviewers the next time I freaking pick a place like this.
author: Euni L.

description:
If you judge favorites by the number of times you return to a place, then out of all the food choices in the Ferry Building, DeliCA is my clear-cut #1.

They have outstanding bento boxes with main choices including tonkatsu, shrimp cakes and chicken dumplings and various side salads (my favorites are the hijiki and soybean salad and the green bean salad). 

They also have curry options, ginger bowls and interesting sushi roll arrangements.

Avoid going at peak times due to long lines but otherwise, it's a good, quick option for take-out.

It loses a star b/c of the relatively high prices (which is expected being located in the FB, but still ...)
author: F. P.

description: I love simple Japanese inspired food. This place was fast and tasty. I got the carrot ginger soup - just the right viscosity and flavor punch. I also got the spinach sesame salad and agedashi tofu. Clean, tasty, and enough to fill you and not give you the crazy large portion that we think should come with the price we pay ( for those of us who are frugal deal seekers).
author: Felicia T.

description:
This place is a dream lunch for vegetarians and for raw foodies (of course they cater to carnivores too). i don't really know (or care) how authentic the food is, it is good! and good for you. i recently lunch here which consisted of a tasty baked slab of tofu, a lotus root salad (YUM!!) and a hiziki seaweed salad. these are all things i love and would make for myself. the portions are decent, and for $9 i think it is a great deal.

i must note also that they not only have clearly marked bins for recycling, they compost too (and use compost-able cutlery and takeout boxes). i only wish there was more seating in the ferry building at peak lunch hours.
author: Isabel C.

description: The Kakiage Tempura was good (See my photo).  The fried tofu was meh: the fried outside was good, but the inside was the same old bland tofu.
author: Scott F.

description:
Lately this has been my go-to spot in the Ferry Building.  

This is probably the best fast/casual Japanese lunch spot within walking distance of the Embarcadero.  I tend to get either the tonkatsu (pork cutlet) or karage (fried chicken) bento, along with the sesame string bean/asparagus and spicy burdock salads.  I'll usually follow that with two pieces of the roast beef sushi.  The roast beef here is such tender goodness.

I've also had the curry here on a few occasions, and have loved it as well.
author: Allen K.

description:
I know you all have opinions about who I am and what kind of guys I'm attracted to. To wit: you think I'm a fucking Potato Queen, right? RIGHT?!?! 

Look, look, it's okay, you can say it, who can blame you for thinking that, after all I skew towards the Occident in my bedside reading and The Ex was a white trash wunderkind, so it's easy to picture me trolling for DL tricks at the Aryan Nation compound or something.

HOWEVER, you're 100% wrong so to put it delicately fuck you. I've used ALL the crayons in the box, kids. I mean, I fucking have the Rainbow Coalition on speed dial, my ass is practically a Benetton ad, and my mouth is a branch of the Equal Rights Commission. I'M EQUAL OPPORTUNITY BITCHES! I like it all, especially my Asian brothas! 

Oh yes. I'm not one of those gaysians who recoil at the very thought of hooking up with another gaysian -- WHAT THE FUCK IS UP WITH THAT?!? Shit, I LOST my virginity at 15 to another Japo boy who, curiously enough, shared my first name which, now that I think about it, is a touch disturbing and probably fodder for my next therapy session and I should print this review out for my shrink, so I'll just do what I always do with traumatic incidents and pretend that never happened. 

I suppose I could chronicle all my sexual exploits in diversity in this review, but I'd probably be sued or something, so I'll just say that the delicious sozai food at Delica Rf-1 has been a consistently excellent performer. In fact, if I could describe to you all the wonders of Delica Rf-1, I'd have a composite of my ideal Japanese lover, who is... 

...SEXY. There's something about driftwood + sleek steel surfaces + glass that makes me cream my pants.

...MEATY. While I know that sushi purists may recoil at the thought  -- and for the record, I too hate California-Unicorn-Dragon-Dropping-Mayo-Surprise Jive Ass Rolls -- please understand me when I say that the Roast Beef nigiri sushi is a gustatory revelation of hormone-free local beef topping a lightly vinegared shari mound. Also, the Tonkatsu meets all expectations and the Chicken Gyoza (dumplings) are worth cheating on your spouse for.

...HEALTHY. Even though I'm an avowed carnivore, I often load up on the vegetarian/vegan items here. I love the vegan crunch of the burdock and konnyaku in the Spicy Burdock Root Salad, the Potato Croquettes have always been lightly fried and crisp (at least for me), and I seriously want to eat the Hijiki and Soybean Salad off someone's crotch -- the marvelous, delicate kelp flavor is enhanced by the snap and color of the soybeans. 

...EXPENSIVE.  Pre-packaged bentos range from $9.50 to $11, or you can prepare a plate featuring two salads and a deli item for $9. Toss in some Roast Beef Sushi at $2 a piece or some freshly fried items (Kakiage Tempura, etc.) and you're looking at a rather expensive lunch. BUT please keep in mind that I have a chronic case of A$IAN CHEAPNE$$ (TM Ken K), so the fact that I will happily hand over $10-$15 for a spread here really says A LOT.

Delica Rf-1, WILL YOU MARRY ME?!?

Wait, how big is your penis again?
author: d s.

description:
You know you're infatuated with a place when you start having dreams about the food. My dream was that I was juggling those delicious crab croquettes and chicken dumplings while popping them into my mouth. 

Dr.Melfi: "What is this dream trying to tell you?"

Me: "Well, two things. I either need to make a huge decision and get a job as a juggler or get down to Delica rf-1...and eat chicken dumplings and crab croquettes NOW."

Dr.Melfi: "What kind of work are you in?"

Me: "Waste Management" 

Dr.Melfi: "Do you work for Tony Soprano?"

*silence*

Dr.Melfi: "We'll come back to that."

*silence*

Dr.Melfi: "You mentioned juggling chicken dumplings and crab croquettes."

----------------
This place is one of the many things that I love about the Ferry Building. The flavors of these dishes are a wonderful event of deliciousness on the taste buds.

Lets not forget fresh and healthy.

Few of my favorite dishes (drum roll)
-The Green Beans with Sesame Dressing
-Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad
-Hijiki and Soybean Salad
-Chicken dumplings w/sweet chili sauce
-Crab croquettes 
-Sushi

My advice is try one of their bento boxes for $9-11 to try a variety of their tasty bits.

I have yet to try the curry, so you know I will definitely be back.

My only gripe is that it's a bit pricey. I subtract 0.5 stars for that. But, since it's not an option - LUCKY 5 star review! WooWoo!

Overall: Crowded, but the line moves fast, service is friendly and helpful, one of the best take-outs in FIDI, great food, prices slightly high. Quality rocks over price.
author: Liz K.

description: Pretty decent for a fusion cafe, but in comparison to a sit-down dinner restaurant, you really can't compare. With that being said, their roast beef sushi was amazing and I very much enjoyed the spinach salad. The mix of cheese and spinach was put together really nicely; no one taste was overbearing. The pork katsu I ordered as my main dish was average, but then again, how do you really rate pork katsu?
author: Erica J.

description:
Bloody Hell, It's a FXXXin' DEPA-CHIKA Food!!!!
DEPA= department store, CHIKA= underground floor

But This DEPA-CHIKA foods are OVER PRICED!!!

Depa-Chika= Underground floor of any department store in Japan is always food floor.
And the Mecca of JAPANESE FOODS. 
They have everything actually.
Actually, underground food isn't just in department stores.
Many cities in Japan have subways and subway stations are sometimes connected to large underground shopping alley where you can go right into DEPA-CHIKA.
Underground food in Japan is pretty good shit.

But, when you see a guy in DEPA-CHIKA, the guy might be a "Loli-kon" loser.
Loli-kon= Lolita Complex man. 
There are many man in Japan who are well educated but their sexuality.
They don't know how to express the feeling. 
You better be careful with Japo "Loli-kon" men.
They are ugly as FXXX.
So, a grown-up man who goes to DEPA-CHIKA alone, he may have a problem. That's why you won't see many men customers in DEPA-CHIKA. It's all ugly rude Japo Oba-chans.

When I was a kid, going to a department store was such a big deal because dining out was very rare.
But once in a while, my dad brought some already made food like "tenpura", "sashimi" and "chicken katsu", or shit like that as a side dish for dinner. And it was good.
I grew up with that shit.
Basically, it was all ready to eat street food. And street food in Japan was good and DEPA-CHIKA foods were a bit high-end version of street food, for crying out loud.
You just pay more, that's all. 

DEPA-CHIKA foods were always something special for me, same as Japo street foods.
This place reminded me of DEPA-CHIKA street food.

Chicken+Tohu+ Hijiki Dango = meat ball,
Tohu Dengaku = soybean paste over tohu,
Roast beef Nigiri,
Chicken karaage,
Beef-katsu,
Sake-Onigiri (omusubi) = salmon rice ball,
Grilled Asparagus, 
Hourensou-ohitashi= lightly poached spinach,

It's not just another high-end gourmet shit place.
It's pretty much regular Japo DEPA-CHIKA street food kind of shit.

My GF and I spend about $50 all together just for lunch but it was worth it for the 1st time. 
I think the ferry building asking for high rent for sure.
author: Nobu K.

description: Been here multiple times.  Nice, convenient location in the Ferry Building.  Service is quick and friendly.  I haven't been unsatisfied here yet.  Good salads and sushi, and all for a reasonable price.  Now...to find seating... :)
author: Ethan R.

description:
How come nobody ever told me there's a Japanese delicatessen in the city? Wowww, what an amazing concept! The 9 piece Bento Box from Delica is so beautifully prepared, it seemed a crime to actually eat it. I instinctively wanted to frame it when I first saw it. 

For around $10, you get three pieces of sumptuous sushi, hijiki and soybean salad, a chicken dumpling, seaweed salad, and a couple of other special treats. Everything is organic and fresh and even better, wonderfully good for you. 

And...  I hear they have roast beef sushi. What the ??? Not to worry, I have a passion for raw meat.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I work with a bunch of assholes. A bunch of lazy assholes. A bunch of rich lazy assholes. They're rich men, what do you expect? But I love them.

What I don't love, however, is hearing them complain. Often what they complain about is lunch, even though our company buys it for us. So as the only girl in our department, I'll take on the role of wife (they all call me Wife Number Two) and make sure they are well fed just so I can have my peace and quiet and continue to waste time on the internet. When the lunch menu comes around, I don't like them to interrupt my Yelping with questions like "What do I like from this place again? What do I usually order?" Since I know them so well, I know what they eat from every one of our lunch spots.

Delica rf-1 is a perfect example. These boys in my office wouldn't even begin to know what to order, but they sure can bitch if they fuck up their own orders and don't like what they get. So I order a bunch of stuff for us all to split and everyone is happy and I can get back to being non-productive. This is the list: 

Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad - so unusual and so delicious!
Chicken Dumplings - I'm pretty sure they put crack in these
Roast Beef Sushi - YUM!
Soba Noodle Soup - great flavor

So I order this, everyone is happy, and the guys are so appreciative that they make it up to me with dinners at Boulevard and bottles of Radio Couteau. Being Wife Number Two isn't so bad - especially since I don't have to put out.
author: Suge K.

description:
Super tasty Japanese bento boxes and seaweed salads and tofu goodness.
They surprise with the flavor.  
I think the sushi rolls (wild smoked salmon with cucumber and green onion wrapped with rice paper) and the mixed seaweed/hijiki salad are my favorites.
Just crazy good and a great light lunch.
The prices are a bit high, but the quality is stunningly high for a takeout place.
author: Kev M.

description: Its a very cute spot.  Its Japanese fast food, but still classy and sheek.  All the cutie Asian chicks are behind the counter, with the chef suit on.  They have a variety of goodies, from curry, to sushi to salads.  I order the mushroom curry (which was a little over salted), and my friend had the beef.  His feedback was, its not the best, but its alright.  He also ordered the chicken cutlets, which he said had no taste.  I also ordered the tofu steak (which was cold, and would much prefer warm), but my fav was the Kaki-age tempura.  It was like shredded carrots, onions, sweet potato fritters, topped with shrimp.  Super oily, but super good.  Who cares. . . but I would definitely go again.  Its adorable. . . .ewww, I'm getting all warm and fuzzy up in here.  Lol!
author: Janice F.

description:
good god, this place reminds me of tokyo department store food courts. AND IT IS GODDAMN GOOD. i've had their lunch bentos twice and each time, they were just enough in quantity, light and extremely tasty.

i can't wait to try some a la carte items, but my man and i can't stay away from our faves:

for him: the shrimp croquette bento (comes with asparagus salad, lotus root salad, steamed rice, a couple of large shrimp croquettes and a tasty tartar sauce). 

for moi: the vegetarian bento (potato and soybean salad, lotus root salad, kelp salad with cucumbers, braised tofu with miso/bean sauce)

at $10 per bento, it's pretty much as expensive as dining in a tokyo department store food court. 

also, they have bottled apple black tea. i haven't had stuff this good since living in taiwan. 

we take our bentos out to the back, and either sit on a bench or on the ground next to book passage and enjoy the goods with the gorgeous view before us.
author: May T.

description:
Delica rf-1 is an interesting experiment in Japanese deli food. It's high-end (i.e. expensive), they use fresh ingredients and even utilize some of the vendors that reside in the Ferry Building (Cowgirl Creamery and Prather Meat Company). I was lucky enough to end up here with my wife and sister in law, so we were able to get a pretty good sampling of food between the three of us. $47 later, here's how things broke down. 

For all their talk about fresh, healthy and balanced meals, Delica's strength is definitely in their fried foods. The Potato Croquette was really nice, but the Crab Cream Croquette is even better. Tonkatsu was smaller and bite sized since it's made with pork tenderloin, a smaller, leaner cut of meat that benefits from being fried in panko. They're all perfectly fried, not greasy and still crispy after sitting in the display case for awhile. 

We also tried both curries -- Mushroom and Ground Chicken Curry and Beef Curry served with hot steamed rice -- and they were good, but they also weren't anything special either, although the beef curry featured some perfectly cooked Prather Ranch Meat.

But the real star at Delica is the Roast Beef Sushi. A rare piece of Meyer Ranch meat on top of sushi rice and topped with baby arugula, shallots and julienned radish. It not only looked beautiful, it was absolutely delicious. And to think it was almost an afterthought because it was in a separate box from the rest of the food and we were all pretty full by the time we ate them.

We also ordered the Spinach and Sesame Salad (Goma-ae), which was very bland, but my sister in law said that that's what it's supposed to taste like. The Sweet & Spicy Chicken was good but nothing mind blowing, as was the Chicken Dumpling with sweet chili sauce. 

I really wanted to try the Tofu Steak with Miso Sauce and Kakiage Tempura (mixture of shredded vegetables, white shrimp in a tempura batter), but we already had too much food, but I think the next time I go, I'm just going to get three orders of roast beef sushi and call it a day.
author: Arnold G.

description:
Haiki for uhhh whatever this place is called...

yum, roast beef sushi
how do you pronounce the name ?
ooh, chicken dumplings !

Interesting variety. I will return and take my honky friends and pretend that I knew all about this place forever ago, even though I just heard about it a week ago. It's scary to be the one they trust.
author: Shannon C.

description:
Came here couple times and I love this place. Clean, fast, creative, healthy and good quality......Although it is kind of overpriced but I think it is still worth it! 

All of their salads are so good, especially Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad. It is so unique and yummy! Besides salads, they also have fried and deli items: 
1. Tofu and Chicken Patty with Hijiki (seaweed) $4.25 each - sounds like a good combination but not taste good 
2. Chicken Dumpling with Sweet and Chili Sauce $2.00 each - small but yummy; good to try 
3. Carrot & Ginger Soup $3.50 cup/ $5.50 bowl - rich, very creamy and flavorful; good to add it as side dish 
4. Roast Beef Sushi $2.50 each - really want to try this one, always looks fresh but too bad I don't eat beef @-@ 

The only thing that I don't like is lack of seating. It is quite difficult to find a seat during peak lunch hour! They should have some more tables so we can all enjoy a good meal there!
author: Liza T.

description:
I don't know about you, but having deli sandwiches catered to the office is a bit boresville. What a reFRESHing change to have bento boxes delivered from Delica rf-1 for our team lunch!

We each got the 9-item Spring bento box (wasabi mashed potatoes, hijiki salad, seaweed salad, asparagus salad, sushi, dumpling and more) which was extremely light and tasty. We brought the bento boxes to YBG and had a nice picnic lunch on the grass. The mango and avocado dessert was surprisingly yummy!

Forward this to your office manager for the next time your company caters lunch. They offer free delivery to FiDi with orders of $250 or more, otherwise there is a $25 fee for deliveries. It's so much more healthy and exciting than deli sandwiches and chips!
author: Connie C.

description:
I was just in Japan to visit the country and one of my favorite hapas ever, Hanae.  Hanae makes some mean ass rice balls, which have become one of my favorite snackies EVER.  But unlike Japan, where you can find tasty rice balls (more like triangles) wrapped in nori at every corner mart, the only place I've seen these tasty treats in SF was at Delica rf-1.  And they were cheap...only $2.00.  Now, if they started to serve up some takoyaki, I might be here everyday.  Please sprinkle my fluffy puffy balls stuffed with octopus with green onions and ponzu sauce.

I think the Japanese are about as obsessed with balls as they are with California and surfing.  Cowabunga!
author: Christina S.

description:
4 stars for this

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xlXnPitrO9Mjfq3aPAyNVQ?select=HFinPIFit5kSK7PRocOEcA

Hijiki, edamame and what appeared to be natto (without the gooey sticky and stinkiness!) with some fresh mixed greens and a nice light tasty dressing. The other bento items were not as interesting or unique, but this hijiki salad alone is worth it.

If you treat the Ferry Building like a Taiwanese or Asian night market snackapalooza fest, where you basically go from store to store or vendor to vendor to eat something small, if you were to pick only one item from DRF1, make it the Hijiki salad to get your greenz in, then binge all you want on oysters, gelati, caviar, bread, cupcakes, meat, cheese, and whatever is tasty and edible nearby (and don't forget the Hong Kong hot milk tea from Out Tha' Door). 

About a week or two before New Year's, you can pre-order osechi sets here, though it is best to call ahead to reserve and ensure. It will be the most expensive "bento" you will ever pay for (3 digits). But heck, it's New Yearz.

Wikipedia's definition:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osechi
author: Ken K.

description:
I have recently been living beyond my means. I make a modest teacher's salary, but my card activity reads like I should be working in the FiDi and getting lunch complimentary at some swanky restaurant because of a benevolent client. My last paycheck was broken into thirds - 1/3 rent, 1/3 necessities, and 1/3 clothes and expensive meals out.

Oops.

After a recent shopping trip, my roommate and I decided to explore the Ferry building. We were tempted by the freshly baked Acme bread, the sweet Scharfen-Berger chocolate, the sumptuous Cowgirl Creamery cheeses, and the little stand that serves a half hundred of the finest olive oils. We were so proud of ourselves, because we resisted them all. We wanted an inexpensive dinner, and neither of us make enough to consider $40 "inexpensive."

And so we settled on Delica, a sleek Japanese deli. We must have hit the place just before it closed, because it was nearly empty and the shelves were sparse, at best. For a very reasonable $12 (including tip) I had wasabi garlic potato salad, asparagus with sesame dressing, rice, and a fantastic crab cream croquette. 

It was a perfect end to a pleasant evening, as we ate our classy and cheap dinner while the sun set on the bay. Not bad for a couple of overspending junkies.
author: Devon S.

description: Small and casual spot to grab lunch or dinner. A little on the pricey side but they have a good selection of items. Its worth shot.
author: Huy T.

description:
Decent lunch joint for enjoying organic Asian (more specifically Japanese) food.  The price isn't too bad ($9.75 for one bento box), considering the quality of food as well as prices around this expensive Financial District.

I haven't tried any single item like Vegetable tempura, Okonomiyaki, or Kara-age, but they all looked very fresh.

Worth a try, if you would like to take a break from work, and have simple yet healthy Japanese lunch.
author: Misty C.

description:
Skip the Lamb Curry, it's gross!  Rosemary has no place in J-Curry!

I still like the format and the people were more with it this time.
author: Jared L.

description:
ima get all zen and shit.

balance. harmony. 

harmony of taste and flavor.

balance between healthy and rape your ass ferry building expensive.

ohm bitches
author: Euge L.

description: The salads here are awesome, as are their fried items. The only issue is that the line can get long, and depending on who happens to be working, you could be in for a long wait.
author: xxxx x.

description:
Let me just start by saying, WASABI POTATO SALAD! woo!

Okay, now that that's out of my system.. Delica is a delicious Japanese inspired delicatessen in the Ferry Building. The ingredients are fresh, the decor clean & beautiful, & the prices.. a bit high.
Bento Boxes? Tasty. 
Potato Croquette? Yummy. 
Vegetarian & Vegan options? Hell yes!
WASABI POTATO SALAD?!?! Amazingly good with just the right amount of wasabi not to burn your mouth off, but give it a mouth watering ZING! love it!
author: Melisser E.

description:
Only had their Beef Curry and I have to admit that it's nothing like Mom's homemade curry, but for the $7.91 w/tax that I had paid (if I'm not mistaken, after 6pm, their food is 15% off, otherwise the curry is $8.50), it was pretty decent and the amount they give you definitely fills you up.  It was quite a chilly night so the curry hit the spot even more!!  In the Beef Curry I received, there were mostly pieces of potatoes (could tell these were the good kind), some tomatoes and around 5-6 chunks of beef which were very tender.  

I got here after work and it was 6pm when I arrived so obviously most of their fried food items were gone, but they otherwise appeared to have a few of everything left and with the 15% off, I have to say that it was not bad at all, for dinner.  It's a bit inconvenient for me since I don't work around the Ferry Building area, but I wouldn't mind making the time to come here again to try some of their other stuff out.
author: Kahanalei M.

description:
Japanese food in the Ferry Building?  Thiiiis is gonna cost me.

Or is it?  Those $9, 5-item bento boxes, which look exquisitely dainty, pack a surprising amount of food, from the incredible fried scallops in tartar sauce, to the dumpling of minced pork(?), to the Asian-style potato salad.  And if it's still not enough, you could toss in one of those fist-sized shrimp tempura clusters for $3.75.  All told, Delica Rf1 may be the best way to taste the legendary Ferry Building innovation without the bitter aftertaste of an empty wallet.  There's even enough variety to keep things interesting for multiple return visits, which is more than I can say for Mijita.

One suggestion: how about doing the earth a favor and serving the food in wooden bento boxes that you return when you're done?  Just put one of those radio tags on them like they do at clothing stores...
author: Wes M.

description:
I like their salads, particularly the burdock root and the hijiki. Their other food is okay but I always order  their salads.

A little overpriced, but so is everything else in the Ferry Building.
author: Jolie S.

description:
Well let's see here.  What do they say about the best laid plans of mice and men?  I know it's supposed to mean that plans often go astray, but truly, do mice actually plan anything?  I thought they just....you know....do....to keep alive.  If that constitutes a plan then those magic 8-balls must be time machines.  Anyway, I digress (and talk of mice and restaurants usually don't go good together).

The point of all this is that after planning a City excursion with a stop at the Ferry building, we wanted to go stop by Hog Island and decimate another batch of helpless little oysters (and grab some chowder and clams along the side).  Since the Ferry building is so full of good places to eat, we decide to spread the love first and go to Delica for a quick pre-oyster orgy snack.

Something musta happened on this Easter Sunday cause the food was more than a little inconsistent, and on occasion, just plain bad.

Plan 1:  Don't serve any tempura dish as a deli-style a la carte item.  It's deep fried with a batter that doesn't hold up to storage in the cold or the heat.  You need to fry those suckers and serve immediately.  Fault us for ordering this dish.  Skip the Kakiage unless they've just made them.

Plan 2:  Don't add the aforementioned Kakiage to the hot soba udon noodle dish.  You take an otherwise good noodle dish and torture it with the Kakiage.  I'm not a huge fan of soba noodles in hot udon broth, though.  These noodles don't seem to hold up to broth as well as other types of noodles.  Either way, the dish would have been better with a minimalist approach.

Plan 3:  Croquettes are, again, better left as a made to order item.  Fried dishes in general benefit from serving just-made.  Ever seen hot oil coagulate in a fry pan.  Well picture that in your fried items as it sits in a deli window.  The crab cream croquettes are decent enough flavor-wise, but just don't cut it as a deli item.

Plan 4:  Chicken dumplings in sweet & spicy chili sauce.  This one works,  Being a dumpling dish (i.e., no frying), this seems to hold up well to storage.  The sauce is not all that spicy, but has enough kick to do the job.

Plan 5: Roast beef sushi.  Okay, the thing is pretty to look at, but anything beefy and 1/2 raw, kept in storage in a fridge is bound to be inconsistent ("Salmon...meet Nella").  The first one was very good.  The second one had a gamey aftertaste.  Ewwww....should've known better.

Plan 6:  Tonkatsu.  Okay, so this came right out of the fryer, and it makes all the difference.  Tender, tasty, crisp on the outside.  This is how items like this should be made.  Excellent.

Plan 7:  Salmon and sesame genmai rice ball.  Okay, not bad.  Still cold, it doesn't make must sense.  In Korea, noo loong gi is awesome (the deep fried rice that is usually formed on the bottom of the rice cooker when you make rice).  Once it cools down, it get's hard and sometimes inedible.  This wasn't as bad, but a lot of the fun of have fried rice balls is lost in the deli context.  Hmmmm...puzzling.

Plan 8:  After this disappointment, head on down to Hog Island.  I purposely skip finishing a lot of the stuff at Delica to save my stomach for the oyster carnage.  Run on over to Hog Island.....just as they put a "Closed" sign in my face.  Easter.

HOLY SSSSSH........., okay, I won't say it on this day.

Hate mice.
author: James K.

description:
The price is not bad considering the amount of food you get and the location you are buying it from.
Love the bentos boxes with the various types of salads. Yummy salmon rice balls. Tender roast beef sushi.
author: Evan W.

description: food is ok but the portion is tiny...i guess if you are a busy, working adult who has only around 30 minute to eat lunch, delica is right for you. i probably would not go back again.
author: Louis O.

description: I want to like this place bc it's fresh/organic etc, but it's never my top pick because the rolls are just too big!  You can't eat in one bite and everything falls apart.
author: Anna V.

description: Going to the ferry building and can be mind boggling. So many tasty things under one roof and you really don't want to walk away ordering the wrong thing or missing out on something amazing. I hate having plate envy too. I decided to go with Delica because it looked awesome and tasty. I ordered the lunch special and picked the spicy burdock root salad with the fried shrimp cake, sweet and spicy chicken and rice. The salad wasn't spicy in the least but was tasty for being vegan- the celery gave it a nice crunch to it. The shrimp cake was probably my favorite item very tasty and filling and the chicken was yummy but they only give you 3 small pieces. I would definitely try Delica again, but it is a bit much for lunch $15 for a small box of food. I might recommend their sushi or soup next time.
author: Kristy H.

description:
The osechi set here is $300 for 3 layers delica style.  Limited to 50 osechi sets for oshogatsu.

osechi=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osechi
oshogatsu=new years.  

tadaaaaaaa
author: Wakako U.

description:
This place is so amazing, it makes the trip from LA to SF complete for me.

Got the Ginger Kobe Beef & Scrambled Egg Bowl ($8.75) and it was delicious! Very filling meal that I shared w/ my bf. Their bento boxes are so so good too, especially the Asparagus one.
author: D S.

description:
Any guy would have been in heaven to be in my shoes today!  I had the pleasure of having lunch with the two most fabulous girls of Yelp, Janney B. and Anna K.  i know. I know. I'd be jealous of me too!

A little confused and disoriented from the cold outside, we moved from the front of the line to the back of the line, then to the Bento Box line and finally to the front of the cashier line.  Where to all of our dismay, we payed a little more than we wanted to.  For a Bento Box and a cup of tap water, I paid $10.  Luckily for me, it was very tasty and I am definitely full. 

I may have shivered off all of the calories from my meal already since we were forced to sit outside.  Today is not a warm day... at all.
It's FREEZING outside (okay, I'm exaggerating a little, but just a little).

All of the tables inside were full and although I really wanted to cuddle up w/ strangers at the big tables, there was no room.  

Outdoors w/ the seagulls was our destiny. We enjoyed the view of the bay and listened to the seagulls squawk while we discussed our new year's resolutions.  

A common theme was to save $$ and budget more wisely.  With that said, I think we'll be meeting at Subway for their $2.99 turkey sandwich Meal Deal.  Jared would be so proud!
author: Lauren C.

description:
As I contently walk through the Ferry building, I noticed this perfect looking cafe shop with sane lines of people and thick yummy looking Japanese food. I wanted to get so many things. I couldn't decide while waiting, I had to wait till I was forced to order. 

I got two of the 19 things I wanted to try. Regular Beef Curry Bowl and a Corn and Potato Croquette on top. The Beef Curry was perfectionism in a bowl. I want to make curry like THAT. Oh and the Corn and Potato Croquette was SO yum, I could have eaten 3 more. They are large too. 

I can't believe I have never been here before today. Where have I been the last 2 months while I've been working just a 10 minute walk away? I am so eager to go back! 

The only thing I would change is to improve their drink selection. It looks like they only had about 3 choices of tea and Japanese drinks. 

I couldn't take pictures because I haven't had my phone on me for two days now. I was bummed about that and still am, but I will go back and fix it.

I could take my whole family here for a meal.

Beam me up, Scotty!


Update 9.31.07
The lines get long between 12 noon and 1pm. You have to wait in one line to order and another to pay. That is a pain in the butt. I still love the food though. Too bad they don't have any good desserts.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
Delica is Japanese style with organic, local freshness.

Their menu has a lot of healthy and delicious options, such as organic vegetarian sushi and salmon brown rice balls. 

There are also the less healthy choices that are equally mouth-watering. Their fried pork cutlet is light and crunchy on the outside, tender and juicy on the inside. In fact,  the meat is so soft and tender that I am convinced that it must came from a newborn baby pig! 

A beautiful 4-part bento box with seaweed & soybean salad, mixed marinated root veggies, rice with black sesame and pork cutlet is the special work day lunch that made my day! 

Go for a sweet treat at Miette Cakes afterwards, there is no such thing as a bad day!
author: C L.

description:
Love Delica RF.  Couple things I've gotten, which are solid:
Soba Noodle Soup:  ~$9.  Piping hot, with a fried Kariyage (don't think i remembered the name correctly, but basically a giant tempura mixture of veggies & shrimp, typicallly $4 each) boxed separately (i requested it boxed separately so it doesn't soggify in the soup).  The soba noodle is tender and cooked to perfection, and the broth is gery good, not too salty, and not too sweet.
Bento Box:  ~$10.  2 sides plus the Shrimp Cake.  I highly recommend the Asparagus salad & the Burdock & Lotus Root w/Konnyaku salad.  Asparagus salad is creamy and light, and the Burdock salad is really flavorful and well put together.  The Shrimp Cake is crispy, filled with good amount of shrimp, and not soggy.  It is a perfect combination, and great portion.

The only complaint i have (not really a complaint, but i will say it anyway), is that it is a bit pricey.  But then again, everything in the Ferry Building is a bit overpriced.
author: Laura C.

description:
