Since I was up visiting from Cancun, my mother decided to take me out to this place. I had never been to the Ferry Building before then and I was pleasantly surprised at the variety. You can get informal sit-down eats to upscale haute dining by the sea in this building and yes, it could be premeditated but I rather like this particular restaurant.  

I would classify it as: easily accessible haute cuisine. 

I got the Lunch Dish #4, which consisted of one salad, rice and a main course type food but in a smaller serving. The Mabo Tofu Salad is great (esp. because I'm a huge fan of mabo tofu) and the ginger is tangy but not too overpowering. The rice is piping hot, sprinkled with black sesame seeds and as for the main dish, I've had both the potato croquettes and the sweet and spicy chicken. 

Now, I've lived in Mexico for 13 years and I can tell you that if I were a Mexican (and for all practical purposes, I am), that the bottle of Valentina Hot Sauce was sneaking out of one pocket, looking for its way to the so-called spicy chicken. Perhaps for others, it would be spicy. I can't at all agree.  

In spite of all this though, if you consider the savoriness of the dish along with the view of the chilly bay, I'd say any amount you pay is well worth the trip. 

Food is very linked the different experiences of life, throughout, as I have learned in Mexico, where you can pig out on tacos de guisado (which can range from pork rinds to chicken tinga) at a Sweet 15 or recover from a hang over with menudo. 

Delica, for me, is comforting, kind of modern and familiar at the same time. It's a place I'd come back to when I want to remember what it's like to stop and smell the roses and to remember that life is not about a job or a salary but about a destination and the journey.
author: Fumiko N.

description:
Well overdue revue... 
I've been here over a dozen times and when possible I catch the underground train from Van Ness Ave towards the Ferry building just to grab my fried side orders to go. 

goods that i suggest would be;
-Fried Shrimp Cake ($4.00/ea ) just two can really fill you
-Potato Croquette  ($1.75/ea ) good sizes too
-Chicken Dumpling with Sweet Chili Sauce  ($2.00/ea ) this is my fav!

There's a rush line during lunch hour break but it runs by very fast. Server/Registry people are nice too. The flavor is consistent because I order this all the time and it taste just the same as ever.
They offer validation for parking which is a plus.
Overall I'm just ok with it and not yet a fan.. I might come back but not too often.
author: Ateh M.

description: I am not a frequenter to sushi places since they normally don't have a lot of vegetarian options. But this one is an exception. Not only did they have a decent size of vegetarian options the taste is also really good. I had the mushroom curry and it was amazing.
author: Anand G.

description: Always a treat to eat something healthy that tastes good. I really like this place. It's worth the walk from SOMA.
author: Vonn C.

description:
I had a hard time deciding between 3 stars and 4- obviously the quality of food here is high, but I wasn't completely blown away by the food I had.  I wanted a light lunch without spending too much money (preferably under $8), but that's just about an impossibility in the Ferry Building.  I had heard about Delica rf-1- kinda hard to forget a name like that so that was my first stop.  I browsed through their selection first before deciding on what I should get- a potato croquette, a piece of tonkatsu, and a roast beef sushi.

The potato croquette and the tonkatsu were very good- the panko breading was very crisp and not oily at all.  They were very good examples of what deep-fried foods should be.  The potato croquette was flavored with caramelized onions, which added sweetness and depth to an otherwise plain piece of mashed potato.  I really wish that I had asked for some ketchup- I think that would have made the croquette tastier.  As for the tonkatsu, the pork was tender and came with a tasty squirt of tonkatsu sauce.  I could have eaten a few more pieces of that with some steamed rice and called it a day.  The roast beef sushi, which was a last-minute addition to my order, was the big disappointment.  While the roast beef was tasty and the sushi rice was all that it should be, I just wasn't wowed by it the way some other Yelpers have been.  

3.5 stars rounded up to 4 because it is one of the less expensive lunches you can get at the Ferry Building and because I was impressed by their deep-fried foods.  I would be back to try some of their bento boxes as well as their other croquettes and the ahi tuna salad, which looked delicious.
author: Angela H.

description:
Delica rf-1 chronicles Part 6 in the saga "Stephanie Takes Over the Ferry Building, One Bourgeois Boutique at a Time." In Part 5 we had Frog Hollow Farms http://www.yelp.com/biz/frog-hollow-farm-market-san-francisco#hrid:LiiryHj5X_gtPU6w8mMfcQbut now what do we say about Delica?

No line at Delica this afternoon, which was a surprising treat. I got the 5 item custom bento box for $9.50, which included a green bean wasabi salad, a seaweed edamame salad, a renkon salad (I think the english word is lotus root), chinese chicken salad and a chicken dumpling.  Yes, I did make sure to memorize what I got so I could give a thorough play by play.

The renkon salad was the standout of the meal. I could eat a whole meal of just that or the seaweed edamame salad, which mixed subtle flavors, interesting textures, etc. I prefer more cabbage in my chinese chicken salad (this was just a couple pieces of overdone chicken with carrots and celery... which was tasty but not worth it).  The green beans were surprisingly good yet the chicken dumpling was lackluster. Like a little lump of mashed chicken, tofu and water chestnuts with a too sweet sauce on the top. Again, not my favorite.

However, I now know what to order next time--the salads are great. I give them an extra star for great customer service and alerting me that they can replace the potato salad that normally comes with a bento box for a different salad (because I just don't eat mayonaise... period). No real ambiance to the place, just a cold sterile steel environment in the ferry building...but the food is decent and well proportioned...just the right amount but not worth $10 in my opinion. 

I may go back, and I may bump them up a star if their croquette beats my Obachan's... but that is highly doubtful.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
If only this place was cheaper...but like so many other places in the Ferry Building, the prices are for the tourists and not for the regular office worker.

I love their crab croquette (eat fried food, die young), their precious bento boxes, and that I can easily buy the Japanese style curry (which is neither like Indian curry nor like Thai curry but something made from a large bar resembling large chocolate bars... who knows what's really in it...it's a little like loving spam...but hopefully Delica's version is made with other ingredients?).  I try to stay away from their soba noodles because it always irks me to pay so much for just soba noodles. 

I also adore their signature roll which is some rice rolled around a fried item and then wrapped with rice paper.  Very yummy.  

Great lunch food, bad lunch prices.
author: Sooj O.

description:
I felt like this place was cafeteria style Japanese food.  Sloppy, cold, and tasteless.  We tried the tofu steak and chicken/shrimp patty.  We took a couple bites of everything and decided to find another place to eat after we trashed our practically full plates.  

me no likey...!
author: Candice M.

description:
So, I couldn't resist eating here again today, since I will be back working in suburbia next week. Ha!

Today I opted for the 2 salads + rice = $6. I chose the wasabi garlic potato salad and the eggplant salad. Both were to die for! 

1) I loooooooooooooove Japanese potato salad and Delica's version, just took it up another notch with the addition of edamame and the subtle flavor of wasabi which was not overpowering. 

2) The eggplant salad had ground chicken and glass noodles in it and had a yummy seasame-soy sauce on it. 

I wish I could bring Delica back with me to Pleasanton....(sigh)...
author: Maritel C.

description:
A Japanese deli - you bet.  Their bento boxes are imaginative and the ingredients beautifully prepared.  Yes, it is a bit expensive but the food is wonderful.  They have a potato salad with wasabi in it that is amazingly good and their panko coated fried items still taste light.  

Stop complaining about the price, get a nice bento of your choice - I'm sorry 9 items for $11 is still a good deal - sit by the bay and enjoy the amazing variety of textures and subtle flavors.
author: Jon R.

description: Yummy! All the fish was of excellent quality. The service was terrific. The tables and chairs a bit wobbly, but of little concern. Yelp says it is kid friendly but the tables are too high for high chairs. There is no kids menu but they were very accommodating of our kids. We would definitely come back again. Delicious!!
author: Michelle Z.

description: I get the idea of sustainable gourmet foods.but everytime I've gone there I've waited in long lines...and frankly the food ALWAYs look way better than they taste...
author: Mimi T.

description:
Like Japanese tapas in a box.  No need to lunch with a crowd in order to get variety.  You can choose to have tiny portions of up to 9 different items all by yourself.  I love that! 

I usually go for bentos containing my favorites like hijiki salad, the burdock root salad, the goma-ae and the chicken meatball.   When I feel extravagant, I'll get one or more of their fried items like the shrimp cake or the crab cream croquette with my salad items.  For a lighter fare, go for the seared ahi bowl served over spinach and rice.

The food is of high quality and the prices reflect that.  The prices also reflect the amazing location.  You can grab your bento and a bottle of fancy green tea drink, head out the door and enjoy your food on one of the benches overlooking the water and the bay bridge.  Then you deposit all the refuse from your meal in their respective RECYCLING bins.  Unique and healthy food, a beautiful setting, a diverse and progressive city... also included in your lunch - perspective, free of charge.
author: mia s.

description: I was taking one of my long walks when I stopped in front of the ferry building late in the afternoon, it wasn't my first time there so I knew there was some grub to be found. This time, me and my walking partner-in-crime wanted to try someplace new. We stopped at delica, and since it was way past lunch, the selection was slim. In the end I think we got a bento box, a japanese style curry, with a side of potato croquettes.We also split a green tea pudding. Our overall reaction to the food was meh, bland, bland, bland. I've had better tasting japanese food at the mall. Maybe we just got there late and we got the rejects no one else wanted.The only good thing about this meal was the eating the potato croquettes while admiring the sf bay.
author: X marks the spot ..

description:
Delica RF-1 is one of my staple favorite restaurants...

All of the fried food choices are fantastic.  They generally fry a batch and then serve from a plate as people order.  If you are lucky enough to get a freshly fried batch, you are in for a treat.  My faves are the tonkatsu (tonkatsu sauce is perfect, the meat is alway tender, I've never bit into any gristle or fat) and the croquette (yum!).  The kakiage tempura is probably my least favorite, tempura is never good when it sits around.

The tofu steaks are pretty damn good, if I do say so myself.  I've always looked at them in the case thinking, those look nasty!  But one day I tried the one with miso/mushroom topping and it was hella good!  Sometimes they do this agedashi style, which is just as good.

The japanese curries are decent, I like the ground beef and mushroom the best, although they are kinda chintzy on the rice.  Definitely hits the spot when it's cold and rainy.

The only thing I don't like from this joint is the okonomi yaki which I thought was sub-par.  Probably has something to do with the fact that they are pre-made and sitting there on the griddle all day until an unlucky chump orders one.

Rounding out their menu offerings, Delica RF-1 has a large variety of interesting salads, my faves are the green beans+sesame dressing and hijiki+soybean salads.  I like to order a bucket and eat it thru the week.

Note: They will sell the fried items by the piece and the salads by weight, but you can also order combo plates and bento boxes with your choice of entree (fried item, tofu steak, etc) and various salads which you can mix and match to your heart's content, great for lunch.

One time I walked by eating a cheese sandwich from Acme, the Japanese owner told me that my sandwich was not healthy and proceeded to give me a sample of his carrot soup.  For a place that deep fries 1/3 of the items on the menu...Sounds kinda hypocritical, what a dorkus, lucky he can cook!
author: Burrito M.

description: OK, a busy Friday night. I'm sure they're trying hard. The waitresses were nice. I ordered the "Red Spicy Dragon Roll" (at a spicy $16.00), and for some reason ate the whole thing even though it was clearly past its Sell-by date. A self-respecting sushi restaurant should not serve tuna that old. The mushy stuff inside featured mayo, I think. Try something else.
author: Mika J.

description:
Quick and yummy, who could want more?

Tofu & Chicken Patty: Yes
Mushroom Salad: Yes
Spicy Burdock Root Salad: Yes
Roast Beef Sush: More please!

I'm a fan!
author: Steve S.

description:
Okay, I read a few reviews and just had to try this roast beef sushi and wasabi mashed potatoes w/edamame to see what was the big deal.  Dude!  This combo is not only the perfect coupling, but it now warrants a whole new category in my "specific craving" bank.  It's not the cheapest bite, but it's completely satisfying and incredibly tasty, and worth a special trip.

Thanks, Yelpers!
author: Sheila G.

description:
Umm....can you say uh-maze-ing? 

After a long bike ride around the city, we were famished. Delica rf-1 was closing, but we were able to order a main dish + 2 salads before they closed (at a reasonable price of under $10). I would characterize this place as a healthy, earth-loving Japanese food-inspired joint. 

Ordered the eggplant salad, the tofu steak, and the hijiki and soybean salad. the eggplant dish was a huge success - my friend and i were fighting over the last bits. the tofu was very firm, but still moist. and the soybean salad was surprisingly good, with bits of kelp and some kind of noodle.

This place is kind of tucked away in one of the side aisles so don't miss it!
author: Jen C.

description: Ordered the three-salad combo here to taste as recommended by a friend who swears by this place.  Got the Hijiki and Soy Bean Salad, Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad, and Spicy Burdock and Lotus Root Salad.  All three were different but in a good way.  My favorite was probably the Lotus Root salad since I do enjoy Lotus Root.  I liked the flavor of the Hijiki, which came with jelly slivers.  The Wasabi salad wasn't too spicy but I just don't enjoy the taste of wasabi very much - I did like the beans that were mixed in, though.  Also got one Roast Beef Sushi but that was basically roast beef on top of rice - I can make that myself!  Portions were a bit small for the $8.25 we paid for the three salads.  They were also out of two of the salads we really wanted to try and said it would take another 15 minutes - no thanks!  Their cooked food looked delicious, so I'll have to try out one of those next time.  If you're in the mood for something different, eat here!
author: Caroline K.

description:
After a morning of errands I met my omnivorous sweetheart for lunch at the Ferry Building. Somehow I had never eaten here! Delica looked like a fabulous option - clean and pretty in a minimalist way. We hadn't eaten Japanese food in a while, plus never Japanese deli food, specifically, so that was kind of exciting as well. Looking - belatedly! - at other reviews now, perhaps it is because we grabbed the pre-made bento boxes rather than ordering a la carte items  that we were not nearly as satisfied as other reviewers? I honestly have no idea.

We both got the vegetarian bento - which is actually also vegan as far as I can tell, even though it is labeled "vegetarian" - which came with hijiki and soybean salad, spicy burdock root salad, agedashi tofu steak and rice with black sesame seeds. The rice was the best part, which I think is a little bizarre. I mean 

1) I like good rice and 
2) bad rice can certainly ruin a meal, but 
3) I don't know that rice should be the best part of any meal. 

So. The rice was the best part, but not amazingly great, zowie-powie, rock 'em-sock 'em rice. There was no subtlety to the other dishes, and no medley or mixture of flavor - everything was weirdly, overwhelmingly sweet, and the tofu wasn't fresh at all. All that for $10 - each! - makes me a little sad.

I had started this review with two stars but had to take it down to one because I just can't even. Boo.

Veg*ns take note: the spinach sesame salad is prepared with traditional bonito flake dashi - they mention this on their website, but I am not sure if it is clear at the deli.
author: Madeleine T.

description:
Expensive. Delicious. Japanese... deli?  That's the Ferry Building for you.

I'm a creature of habit and here, as with so many other places, I always order the same thing.

Hijiki salad, wasabe potato salad, crab croquette.

One day I will succeed in duplicating their hijiki salad, and I will undercut them. I will dominate the hijiki salad market, and from there, the world.

Until then Delica, you can count on about $9 each week from me.
author: Shawn S.

description:
Coming to the Ferry Building is a very different experience during the week vs. weekends. Lots of locals and people who work in the hoods, pick up food and enjoy the Vitamin D outside.

Delica had a long line as most places in the FB do. But they have an express line that carries bento boxes. $10, cash only and with a good selection of drinks (Cafe Sepia Matcha Latte that is actually Green Tea milk tea was good.)

The bento box contained Hijiki and soybean salad, asparagus with creamy seasoning, chicken dumplings that were mixed with water chestnuts and sweet chili sauce on top, in addition to a good portion of steam rice. All were good and service was fast so that you would be enjoying the food and the weather rather than waiting in line for 15 mins...
author: T L.

description:
I love this place.  The curries, udon soup, bento boxes, seaweed salads, shrimp or potato croquettes are all delicious.  You can taste the freshness in all of their ingredients.  This is the only place I've been able to find the Japanese apple tea.  And I love the apple tea pairing with the beef curry.  This is one of my favorite lunch time hot spots in the ferry building.   

The line to order or pay can be confusing but they try to alleviate the lunch time rush by setting up a bento box and cash payment on the side of the venue.

You can also purchase the salads by the pound and occasionally I've ordered it to bring to potluck dinners and it's been a hit with friends every time.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Delica rf-1 is worth a stop to try out.I have to admit I was a little stuffed after eating some of Acme's bread.I did find the place quite nice,clean and a polite guy behind the register(this helps).

Upon entering I notice salads on display.It seemed that this is the only thing I did see at the time,but then I noticed the fried items.

-Fried Shrimp Cake(tasty,but didn't finish)
-White Corn and Potato Croquette(I enjoyed than the previous,but didn't finish)

Both overall,were quite tasty and I didn't find the prices overall outstanding,the guy again was quite nice and patient while I thought about the salad(ugh) or indulging in my fried food fixation.

I will come back to try the Chinese Chicken Salad,Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad and Japanese Tea.


Worth a stop during the week or weekend.
author: Dani D.

description:
Let's put it this way I'm Japanese and this is the worst overpriced
Japanese food I've had in my middle aged life.

Portions are embarrassing small and way overpriced.  Not only that
they overcharged me by 2.00 on an appetizer, and instead of offering
to refund over the phone, they expected me to go there  for a  charge refund, they could have easily taken over the phone.
Thats a bad mistake, not changing menus prices.  I wonder how many
tourists didn't notice.

I realize rent is high, but that is no excuse to skimp on fries!  There wasn't enough for my 4 year old nephew to snack on.

Just ridiculous.
author: Tiki D.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!

I have been coming here for awhile and it is most certainly one of my faves. One can definitely taste freshness and quality in the foods. 

I have tried most of the items they offer and all are very yummy. My personal fave is the curry! I grew up in Japan and I LOVE curry! I was never able to find curry in a stateside restaurant that tasted like it was made in Japan until now.
author: Deanna J.

description: Good food. It's not a sit down place like we expected, and they don't have a full menu. The sushi is in to go boxes. If you know what to expect it's good, but a bit pricey for what you get.
author: Jessie P.

description: Most people know Delica for their to-go lunch boxes but I love going there for dinner. They have tall tables and a full menu. The Ferry Building gets quieter in the evening and this is the hidden gem you should try when everything else goes silent in the building. Their Sushi Chef is a lady with definite talent! Her sashimi creations are not only beautifully presented but also very fresh. All the food there is made using fresh produces from the stores at the Ferry Building.. If you start with high quality ingredients, you end up with some of the best Japanese food around. The staff is always running around to help people quickly. They have dishes for everyone; very authentic and great drinks to pair with the food.
author: Jean-Francois R.

description:
I have eaten here already three times during the last three weeks. The salads (Hijiki and Soybean,  Spicy Burdock Root, Tofu) are fantastic and truly rich combinations of flavour, the Tofu & Chicken Patty with Hijiki is interesting but not extraordinary, the roast beef sushi is simply ... addicting. 

The last time, I have tried their sushi and it was absolutely fabulous: the amberjack/green onion roll  and, above all, the albacore tuna tataki with truffle were outstanding! Prices are reasonable, the staff is rather friendly and the location is optimal for taking away and enjoying a bit of sun and bay views.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Just had lunch there a week ago. Limited range of quality japanese lunch-type food. Salads were particularly good. The tempura was good but kind of wierd that is was one large peice. My friend had a curry/soupy combo and both were decent.

We were still hungry when we left.
author: David P.

description:
In a hurry the other day, I decided to pick up a spicy tuna roll to go.  Almost immediately, the challenges of eating said spicy tuna roll while walking became abundantly clear.  Thus, I changed my mind and decided to sit down on a bar stool.  The place was EMPTY, mind you.  Well, before I could split my chopsticks, a waitress comes running over to me to inform me that despite my having spent money on their food AND despite the utter lack of clientele at 3:30PM in the afternoon, to-go eaters were not allowed to mingle with sit downers and then she kicks me out.  So rude...

But in all fairness, the spicy tuna roll was exceptionally good and fresh for a to go item.  Too bad I won't revisit on principle.
author: tina t.

description:
Lovely Dianne D.  accompanied me to this place.

Very fresh and flavorful ingredients.  Wonderful selection.

Tried:  

Crab croquette -- Wolfed that down.  Light and crispy but not greasy.
Asparagus salad (part of Dianne's $9.50 bento box) -- Super good.
Roast beef sushi -- This works.
Lotus root salad & chinese chicken salad -- really good, really fresh ingredients and very flavorful.  But probably won't get if I go here again.  As much as I'd like to think I am partial to good for me stuff.  That is sheer DENIAL (Don't Even (K)now I Am Lying).

Almost forgot:  indifferent service.  I ordered the RBS (that's Roast Beef Sushi) when I was paying for my BB (that's Bento Box). And I swear the guy's exasperation was palpable (that's They Don't Pay Me Enough Here To Make Nice To You).
author: Natasha S.

description: Oh Delica, how I love you and your Karage Sandwich.  But what's up with the overload of avocado? I mean, don't get me wrong, I'm a huge fan of avocados.  But your sandwich put me over the top.  Next time, I'm going to have to get some of the side dishes.
author: Cathy B.

description:
hm.. it was good. just not great. 

i had the tofu chicken patty.. which was pretty bland actually. i didn't want to finish eating it and it's pretty small.

also tried their crab croquettes.. too mushy inside. i wish it had a bit more chunks for some texture. the inside is like mashed potato.. except it was whipped into a cream... 

asparagus salad was cooked well. crunchy. but also kind of bland... 

i liked the wasabi potato salad but i thought the romane lettuce wasn't very well blending with the potato salad. seemed and tasted really unnecessary.. 

it wasn't bad at all. i wouldn't mind going back if it wasn't so overpriced. don't go all hyped up like i was. it will be a disappointment then.
author: Amy S.

description: I went on a rampage in Ferry Building and wanted to try all the different things that Yelpers have reviewed which I had bookmarked previously. So ended up picking a  Summer bento box which consists of 9 items for $11 from Delica. It was rather pricey considering most of the items (morsel-like) were different kinds of Japanese salads with 3 slices of  vege/salmon roll and a chicken dumpling. Was a great way to sample the different salads.
author: Yan M.

description:
Delica lightly breads a top quality (Kurobuta) pork fillet in homemade panko breadcrumbs, deep fries it, then finishes it with a light layer of fresh cabbage and just the right amount of zippy Tonkatsu sauce. Assembled on fresh pan de mie, a generic, slightly sweet variety of French bread, the sandwich stays together just long enough to eat without making a mess.

If it was "heart smart," which it's not, this is a sandwich that I could eat everyday. The best word to describe this sandwich, other than delicious, is balanced.  Though fried crispy, the savory cutlet - the star -isn't greasy and is complimented perfectly by just the right amount of sweet and tangy sauce, crunchy cabbage, and soft, sweet white bread.   If you're  a sandwich person, put this one on the list.  It's unique, thoughtful, and, most importantly, incredibly satisfying.
author: Sam S.

description:
If I didn't bring my lunch to work, I'd eat at Delica rf-1 everyday.  And I will probably order the same thing, the bento box with tonkatsu.  I might try different side dishes because they have all been really good, but tonkatsu will probably stay the same.  Even though I know their corn croquette is delicious too.   But how do they make their tonkatsu so crunchy?  Extra large panko?  Cuz my home-made tonkatsu doesn't have big golden flakes like that. 

If I were to become a housewife ever, I aspire to be the one that can duplicate bento boxes like this place.   I wouldn't care if my husband gets sick of it, or if my kids hate it, I'd still be a successful housewife in my mind.
author: Candice B.

description:
I was just going up to visit friends in Pasadena for a couple of days when one of them says, I'm going up to SF for the day, come with! OKAY!

I love the Ferry Building even though it's tourist central but my favorite spot there is Delica rf-1.  

Bento Boxes, Dumplings, Wasabi Potato Salad (super delicious), Croquettes, Curry, Sushi, Green Tea!  This place is just rad.  Great Japanese take away that tastes fresh.  If you love anything Japanese, you must go!
author: Alenna S.

description:
I went here for lunch today. This place is absolutely delicious and very, very fresh tasting. I had the spring bento which had like 6 different items including mushrooms, spinach, green beans, edamame wasabi potato salad, salmon spring roll, and something else. My personal favorites were the green beans and potato salad. So good!

The only thing is that it's a bit pricey, but great for a payday lunch!

This is the best fast food restaurant I've ever been to.
author: Paweena P.

description:
MY goodness this place is fantastic. Fantastic, Sally!!!
Asian fusion if a nice high-caliber (your wallets will concur). I do not agree with the review that says everything in this place is deep-fried or over-sauced. If you chose something deep-fried, chances are it's going to have been deep-fried. The over-sauced items, though few and far between, tend to need the extra sauce. Granted, I'm sauce biased, but it's an honest review.

This food is so fresh, very vegetarian and vegan friendly, ample selections to chose from, and excellent bento boxes for taking out to the docks and enjoying some sun.

As soon as your alimony, year-end bonus or tax refund comes in - go and treat yourself people.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
Mmm... I love this place.  When I'm in the mood for GREAT bento, this place does it for me.  

The Tonkatsu has to be the some of the best I've had in my lifetime, and I'm Japanese... a twinkie to the fullest extent, but still Japanese.  The Tonkatsu is tender, juicy, and perfectly crunchy on the outside.  Simply perfection.  

I also have a deep love for the Hijiki Salad.  Delicious!  With soybeans, konyaku (yam cake), age (fried tofu), and edamame.  Even the Lotus and Burdock Root salad is tops!

Now onto the Potato Croquette... divine.  Now with corn, a wonderful addition, however I do miss the old version from time to time.  Hopefully they bring it back in the winter.  We shall see.  

Beef curry is also sublime.  It depends who serves though.  I heard them training one day, and they stated the regular size is to have ONLY 3 pieces of meat, and however much sauce, potatoes and carrots that seem reasonable.  3 pieces of meat!  What a bummer.  Today I had the beef curry and I must've had at least 6 pieces of meat.  Tender, juicy, and full of flavor.  Thank goodness for the indiscretion of the server today, because beef curry ought to have plenty of beef... but maybe that's just me.  

Anyhoo, you can find me there at least a couple times a month, if not more, much more.  I'm always down for a #4 lunch plate, a salad, main item, and rice... this translates to Hijiki Salad, Tonkatsu and rice.  YUM!  LOVE IT!  

This Japanese Twinkie LURVES me some Delica Rf-1...  ayup, yes I do, indeed!
author: Kelly K.

description:
I am such a fan of this place. I always find myself craving their seaweed salad. They have a great selection of veggie and vegan salads, and if you're a meat eater their roast beef sushi is a very cute idea as well. Other than some fried stuff on the right side, everything they have is perfect for a light meal after you (if you're like me) have been eating your way through the farmer's market on a Saturday. 

A little pricey for what is offered but not compared to the rest of the Ferry Building. Cute little gem inside of a great spot. God I love that place. 

Yeah, the seating isn't great but for a grab-n-go place, what can you expect?
author: Alex H.

description:
Yummy food, so glad to discover this Japanese deli! If you want to make a custom bento box, wait to add your salad at the end of the line -- didn't notice all the extra choices! 

The chicken dumplings are good, and actually their rice is really good :) You may have some trouble looking for seating in the area, as the Ferry building is a bit crowded.
author: Susan T.

description:
Another ultra-cool eatery in the ferry building?  say it ain't so!  Their service is cafeteria style but one look at the food and you know they're striving for quality (the prices say the same of course).  

I had the lamb curry, it was spicy and full of flavor with the lamb being nice and tender!  The chicken dumplings and crab croquette are delicious and really well done too.
author: Shyam P.

description:
Really quick service since most of it is already prepared. Extremely high quality at slightly high prices. They use non-hormonal beef (in other words: whilst alive, the cow didn't "have a cow" hahaha... ha...    ...sorry) and fresh Acme bread to make their panko. 

I tried the Ginger Beef bowl (sweet, sweet meat at $6.50) and the roast beef sushi ($2 each). Both were good and required no wait. Prices are almost as high as the quality.

Second trip: I'm eating the Summer Bento Box right now. It's really good. It includes a small sample of nine of their items. Great for trying different things. The seaweed in the seaweed salad is a little more cooked than I'm used to (almost melts in the mouth). $11.94 after tax. 

Third trip: Tofu patty with 2 Salads Lunch Combo (I chose the Hijiki and Chicken salads) for $9. Chicken salad has a good deal of celery in it = me, pissing off the guy in the next cubicle with *crunch*..*crunch*....I also added a Corn Croquette. All very good, especially the croquette, but it seems I'll never spend under $10 here...

Would come here more if it were cheaper. It's busy during peak times but very fluid on the off. 

Excepts credit cards (including AMEX).
author: Keane L.

description:
Welcome to de-pa-chi-ka!: "depachika" refers to the food section of department stores in Japan. Department stores in Japan generally have their food section at the basement level ("chika" means underground/basement). Hence depa (short for "department store") + chika. A depachika generally has, among other things, stores that sell "osouzai", variety of small pre-made dishes ready to eat that you can buy by piece or by weight. 

Long story short, Delica rf-1 is exactly like popular depachika osozai stores in Japan. And I highly value its existance within short walking distance from my office. Their pre-pakcaged $10 lunch box , for example, gives you a couple of relatively healthy (some stuff my mom made me eat because they are good for you, like hijiki sea weekd salad) side dish type stuff and deep-fried goodies, like tonkatsu.  Here, variety is key. Neither depachika-osouzai food or Delica rf-1 food is meant to be super high quality gourmet food per se; it is more like comfort food that mimics your mom's cooking in an upscale-fast-foodish kind of way. 

Admittedly, one extra star was given because of my nostalgia. But really, the depachika food at Delica sure is a welcomed deviation from the boring salad-or-sandwitch weekday lunch routine.
author: Nana N.

description: DELICA offers good, high-quality, Japanese deli cuisine. They have wonderful and well prepared bento boxes, as well as Japanese curries, sushi to go, and many other items. My one complaint would be that it's a bit pricey for what you get. Nevertheless, I go here at least twice a month.
author: Brian M.

description:
I heart Delica.

This is a fantastic Japanese deli in the Ferry Building. Fresh salads, great flavor, excellent quality.

I had their lunch special of one main and two side salads - an agadashi tofu, with a hijiki edamame salad and a wasabi potato salad. Excellent quality! If I lived closer, I would eat here all the time.
author: Christine P.

description:
Ehh....

maybe I ordered the wrong things. 

Booooorrring.
author: Pamela B.

description:
Wow. The Japanese really know how to do tasty and healthy food. I love this place so much, the only thing from stopping me some days is the cost. I drop about $12 each time I go here and I am a tiny woman - I don't eat a lot! 

The seaweed salad is very good and full of Iron. All of their meats are flavorable and cooked perfectly. I recommend skipping the bento box because it always seems to have 2 great things and 1 just ok thing. Go for a la carte and then sit on the pier and eat lunch. A great treat during the workday!
author: Kimberly H.

description: My cousin and I were hungry after a days worth of shopping and we wanted to eat sushi.  30 minutes later, we found this place! Boy were we happy.  However, they don't really serve the kind of sushi that you would find at other sushi bars.  There were only a few rolls and each were very simple rolls at that.  Both my cousin and I decided to get the Delica roll, which was very good.  It had cucumbers, lettuce and tempura in it. (And maybe something else that I'm forgetting). We also had the potato croquette and the tonkatsu. The potato croquette was SUPER good. It was very crispy and the insides were very hot.  It had just the right amount of seasoning too. MMM, I think that the was most memorable part of the meal.  The tonkatsu was good as well, I enjoyed it as well, but not as much as the potato croquette. 4 stars!
author: Maggie L.

description:
Delica RF-1? What the hell is this? A sister series to New Mobile Report Gundam Wing? A new Toyota sports car? A really awesome Japanese radio?

While all of those things sound like they'd make more sense, what Delica really is about is ROAST BEEF SUSHI. While it sounds weird and looks weird, it's awesome. If you're not in a mood for such a bovine delicacy, grab one of the Bento boxes. They're good too.

The only reason I'm knocking off a star is because the place is a little expensive, but the ambiance of the Ferry Building may make up for it.
author: Eston B.

description: Really delicious, really interesting food.  I only wish it were a little less expensive, so I could justify coming here for lunch all the time.  But everything I've tried has been very good, including their wasabi potato salad, potato croquettes, pork cutlets, and a variety of unique salads with ingredients like burdock root, lotus, seaweed, edamame, and daikon.  Still need to try their roast beef sushi - it looks delicious!
author: Leslie L.

description:
Delica rf-1 is simply an amazing quick-stop restaurant.  After a very disappointing dinner the night before at Drunken Sushi on Clement Street, I was looking forward to having my faith restored in San Franciscan Japanese food restored.  I didn't know it was going to come so soon.

We ordered several dishes, the most memorable were the lamb curry, the seared tuna salad, and the potato croquette.  The lamb curry was interesting, it actually tasted more like Indian curry than japanese, and they actually give you more curry and lamb than rice.  The seared tuna salad was amazing.  While it wasn't that big, the four slices of tuna were very fresh, and the texture was perfect.  Coupled with avocado and crispy lotus root croutons, the salad was both savory and refreshing.

The one dish I wasn't too crazy about was the kakigage tempura.  It was a little soggy/chewy since they pull it from a display case.  Had it been fried fresh, I'm sure it would be a different story.

If you're looking for a quick bite and you're in the area, Delica is definitely a kick-ass option.  Highly recommended.
author: Tony L.

description:
Great concept; their bento boxes are a nice, convenient lunch on the lighter side. Good potato and pumpkin croquettes too; try one of each. Grab a cold Oolong to go with your meal and you are good to go.

Pricey for deli food but they do have a lease in the Ferry Building.
author: Adam W.

description:
If you want something already packed in a bento, pick it up and pay on the right, If you want something from the cases, get in line to the left. The individually pre-packed refrigeration needed items are also on the left.

I liked the tempura veggie fritter - which I thought was similar to filipino ukoy - it was good. 

The eggplant salad  was tasty, but there was a lot of sauce, I should've ordered some rice to throw it on. Delicious!

The tofu chicken mound with onions was good, but served cold - I think it would be better warm.

The Meyers roast beef on sushi rice(refrigerated =P) was OK, tasty, I dont think I'd pay $2 each for it again. Maybe made fresh at dinner in a sit down restaurant.

Most of the time my lunch here ends up over $15 (I order everything seperate without rice and a drink). The best deal here is a combo box, and although the poritons may seem small, flavors and ingredient quality make up for it. Plus the view... *sigh*
author: Cheryl D.

description:
Oh yum!  We were heading to Sacramento around lunch time, so we decided to wander through the Ferry Building to find road food.  I got a great cheese sandwich from the Acme Bread Co., husband got a sloppy pork sandwich from the Golden Gate Meat place (really, BBQ sauce, when you're DRIVING?  Good thing it was a rental car.)  My daughter was the one who really scored with the shrimp bento box from Delicia rf-1.  The shrimp cakes were incredible, and the two salads she had were great. We also got a tempura with soybeans and a few other things that really should have been eaten while it was still warm.  

We completely messed up our order and the young woman who was putting it together was very nice about it.  The man working the register wasn't too happy, but hey, we ordered MORE food, and gave him MORE money, so once he realized that, he smiled.  

I'm so glad my daughter shared some of her salad and shrimp with me.  It would have been sad to push her out of the car on the freeway just to get a taste of it.  

We were sitting here at home this morning, drinking tea, reading the paper, when my daughter sighed and said, "I really want another bento box from the Ferry Building."  Guess that will be our first stop on our next trip:)
author: Mary C.

description:
So I was kinda skeptical, but figured I'd try it based on the recommendation a friendly Yelper. It really reminded me of the basement level of a department store in Japan, but with all the shops squished into one tiny one that tried to sell everything. Here are my impressions: 

hijiki/soybean salad - slightly above average, though a little bland. personally I could do without the dried soybeans which were hard and the fresh soybeans which were hard too.
burdock/lotus root salad - again a little bland. I'm used to it with a bit more bite.
spicy chicken - kinda dry and they had just brought out a new batch from the kitchen
tofu/chicken patty - was good, though the texture was a tad heavy/dense. the daikon was flavorless.
chicken dumpling w/ chili sauce - may be the best thing I had. typical sweet chili sauce, no real chili kick. 
crab croquette - ok, this was probably the best. I'm a croquette connoiseur. scratch that, I'll eat the frozen ones so I'm not picky, but I know what's good. this one was good. I'll stick to the croquettes next time for some fried goodness.
author: The Sock S.

description:
I walked by and they were getting ready to close.  Should I stop in?  No?  I walk by this place every day going to/from the ferry, but I never thought to get anything.  How weird that I chose their closing minutes to take the plunge.

I got what was left in the case: a potato/corn croquette, a shrimp ball and a chicken dumpling.  $8 for three pieces of ood.  Ouch!  The guy also gave me some sort of white tartar sauce, but I didn't know which thing it went with and it didn't look tasty so I threw it out.

Feeling guilty for getting fried food when I've vowed to stay away, I decided to leave my box of yumminess intact while I hit the gym first.  I ran 5k and came home to chow down.  I made a nice plate with the goods, a side of quinoa, and some sauteed kale.  Yeah, I'm that girl.  Anyway, the food from Delica was EXCELLENT!  The crust was light and crisp.  The corn was super sweet.  The dumpling had a nice flavor.  The shrimp ball had huge shrimp in it.  Three pieces didn't seem all that much, but I was stuffed!  Yay for good food!

I can't wait to try some of their other dishes, like the mango and avocado dessert!
author: Lynnie P.

description:
This place got me thinking about it from time to time just because the salads there are amazingly good!

All I can say is I highly recommend the wasabi potato salad, the green beans and sesame dressing salad, and the corn and mascarpone salad. ALL GREAT SALADS!

The wasabi in the potato salad definitely adds a subtle kick to it. You can never go wrong with the green beans and sesame dressing salad, and the combination of corn and mascarpone is abosolutely delicious. The sweet corn mixed with the refreshing mascarpone makes for a great combination. YUM!
author: Diana Lyn Z.

description:
Totally expensive, but worth it.  This is the kind of food that I loved the most at 7-11's (yes, 7-11) in Japan--healthy, delicious, and delicate.

If I could, I'd eat here everyday.  But then I would have no money for my mortgage.  We always say we're going to try other places in the Ferry Building, but I can't get past this place.

It's "real" Japanese.  For those used to stronger flavors (read: more salt) go elsewhere.  This place is the real deal.
author: Penny P.

description:
Wow - good Japanese food to go. The food is fresh and presented very well. 

I wanted to be a little healthier and got the Chicken Karaage Salad (around $10). Very good and fresh. The bentos look really good too and they have seasonal bentos that capture the art of Japanese food.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Cute, somewhat upscale Japanese deli in the Ferry Building. There are options to purchase individual items, combine them into a bento box, or get salads by the pound. I sampled the hijiki and soybean salad ($15/lb) as well as the green beans with sesame dressing salad ($12/lb). Both were delicious and tasted healthy...must get more next time!

I've always wanted to try okonomiyaki ($5) so I ordered the chicken one...there's a veggie one with mushrooms too. It's like a savory Japanese pancake made with some kind of batter, eggs, cabbage and topped with Japanese mayo, this sweet sauce, as well as fish/seaweed flakes. The okonomiyaki was just sitting on the griddle so I didn't know how long they had been out (minus 1 star). 

Nonetheless, $5 for a fairly filling, tasty lunch wasn't bad at all. I'm glad I tried the okonomiyaki even though the chicken was a little dry...I really enjoyed the sauces and toppings though. Service was quick and wasn't very busy for lunch hours. Will be returning to try their curry!
author: Karen Y.

description: Sunday lunch hour, strolling through the Ferry Bldg between a somewhat touristy crowd & we needed to duck in to find some pleasant eats. Where do I b line to? Delica of course. This Sunday on our picnic list was a couple of roast beef sushi, beef curry, carrot-ginger soup, spicy burdock salad, sweet & spicy chicken (because we witnessed a staff member freshly toss and serve those bad boys onto the display tray) & of course we couldn't leave without having one of their potato croquettes! All was good in our hood from beginning to end.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Weekday dinner. Kobe beef tatake was great, daily special Toro Saba nigiri style was excellent, but omakase combo was very basic and not interesting. Solid 3.5-4 stars, nothing bad to say, but a bit short of expectation.
author: Sami L.

description:
12:00PM
4.2.2007

***NEW DESSERT!!!***  Mango and Avocado delight...

Also spotted a crab croquette in a bento box....give it a try next week.

Bomb...

1:25PM
3.21.2007

***NEW SALAD!!!***   Asparagus Salad in a creamy sesame dressing!  

Bomb....

3.8.2007
12:00PM

I come to this 'deli' at least once a week for their spectacular tonkatsu bento.  I have tried everything short of their tofu patty (which still looks delicious) but will opt not to do so since everything else there is so good!  Drop a 10 spot and you'll get 3 perfectly fried pieces of pork cutlets, 2 side salads, and a serving of rice; all neatly compartmentalized in your 'bento' box!  

ALL of their salads taste fantastic and are made with fresh ingredients.  (Wasabi mashed potatoes, hijiki salad, lotus root salad, asparagus salad, chinese chicken salad.)  They also sell Japanese style curry (which is bomb) and cold soba noodles with a side of shrimp cake.  Their 'hot' items include my all time fave the tonkatsu, spicy fried chicken, chicken meatball, kakiage (mixed assortment of tempura battered veggies and shrimp), potato croquettes, and shrimp cakes.

I don't think most people who come here understand how good this place is; it's truly amazing how well they prepare their foods!  Probably the best Japanese food in the City; we are blessed to have Delica-rf1.

Expect a line during the week.
author: William R.

description:
Clean flavors, fresh ingredients, and great service!

I recently became obsessed with the seared tuna salad, with avacado and lotus roots and a really tangy vinniegrette....YUM!!!

The wasabi potatoe salad and croquettes are to die for too!!

yum!
author: Keila E.

description: I came by here for bread not long ago and still find their selection to be of high quality. The honey butter bread is delicious.... Service is just fine, nothing stellar. Sometimes they throw in free dinner rolls if you buy a lot. It's nice giving good small places your business and I still feel that way about this place.
author: Al B.

description:
J says: love the beef curry, and the wasabi potato salad. very limited seating, but it's nice to take the food outside and eat by the waterfront. 

K says: good japanese food, criminally over-priced. but we keep going back anyway. probably my favorite lunch place at the ferry building.
author: Jen Ken H.

description:
Ok so maybe Im a little crazy.. I choose to eat here for brunch on tuesday. I know I know, Bento box at 10:30 am? It obviously didnt work for me.

I could see why this place is rated so highly by other yelp users, but honestly I just couldnt get into it at this time in the morning. Actually I dont think I could get into it period. 

I had the five piece bento box with the chicken dumpling, shrimp cake, salad, wasabi potato salad and cheddar rice pilaf.

The shrimp cake was pretty good, but Im pretty sure it was because it was doused in tartar sauce, and the rice pilaf looking dish with almonds was good. The chicken dumpling was awful. Im not sure exactly what the salad was but it was like  weird ginger/teryaki with tofu creation that I didnt really enjoy.

Overall I had to balance my rating, because I think people will enjoy it, but my own experience was not that good.
author: Tom V.

description:
Well, I've been here only once... which makes me a little nervous, I mean... what if i go back again and again as my buddy CS does, only to discover that they aren't what they appear (soylent what?).

I had the #4 with Spicy Burdock and Lotus Salad, Tonkatsu, and Steamed Rice. The salad was great. The pork was... average, but the Katsu Sauce was tasty. The rice, was, well... uh, steamed.

I was impressed though and will go back. Stay tuned for more....
author: Ryan F.

description: Nice spot for a quick lunch with the bento boxes. But if you wanna eat something light and delicious I recommend Chinese chicken salad and the green beans salad. So yummy!
author: Pat M.

description: So, over the past year or so I tried out some other stuff and it was all fantastic.  You can either buy pre-made, fresh Bento OR make your own.  The Bento Box comes with 2 salads, rice, and your choice of one other item.  I always double up on the green bean salad and get pork nuggets too.  My husband usually orders the triple salad and picks a variety of 3 different salads.  If I had to make a list of my top 10 favorite foods of all time, the green bean salad would make the list.  Yes, it is that good!  They also have a variety of other vittles like roast beef sushi.
author: PictureGirl F.

description: This Japanese spot in the Ferry Building has the quick service of a deli, but its food is high quality and delcious. The one item I always order is the beef and mushroom curry. I'd also suggest getting the corquette and the edamame salad. The portions here will fill you up and prices are fair. The only bad thing I'd have to say about it is that seating is limited.
author: Lynn V.

description: I grabbed a california roll-inspired type thing for lunch one day and thought it was way expensive for what it was. It wasn't very exciting, it was $9, and I was still hungry. I know, I probably shouldn't have gone with the grab and go section, but I was hungry. It was hot and the other food options looked good, but way too heavy (beef rice bowl on a 70 degree day? pass).
author: Karena Q.

description: Great place to come for last minute hunger pang induced food cravings.  It isn't a cheap place however the quality is consistently high.
author: Jim J.

description:
So, the first week after WLB got married (congrats to WLB & WLB's wife!) we decided to head over to the ferry building and check out Delica rf-1...we had seen it on another weekly lunch outing and surprisingly WLB had yet to eat there!

according to it's website, delica rf-1 "offers a variety of beautifully prepared meals to take away. Side dishes, main courses, fresh-fried foods, and substantial salads. Signature dishes include wasabi garlic potato salad, spicy burdock and lotus root salad, green bean salad with a sesame dressing, DELICA sushi rolls, hijiki and soy bean salad, Japanese curries, and Kobe-style deep-fried savory croquettes filled with potatoes, Dungeness crab in a bechamel sauce, or shrimp. " 

to put it simpler, in this foodie's terms, delica is a good place to get some japanese-CA fusion cuisine, made with organic and fresh ingredients, offering a yummy lunch that's flavorful and not heavy.  they have decent-priced lunch combinations where you can pick a combination of salads, main dishes, + with or w/o rice...their menu changes so the variety is never boring or repetitive...

additionally, the presentation of the japanese deli is clean, visually pleasing and just makes you want to order their food...and on that note, item to order next time? -- pork cutlet sandwich and a cream puff for desert!
author: Grace O.

description:
My girlfriend Amelia planned a birthday outing for herself here last year... I fell in love with this Japanese style Deli, and if it wasn't for a parking issue, I'd be there more often... I wish we had this here by Lake Meritt!  

FAVORITES: Chicken Dumpling, Soybean/Hijiki Salad, Green Bean and Sesame Dressing salad...

Great for vegetarians and non-vegheads alike! and where else can you eat yummy food like this and sit on a bench during a gorgeous day beneath the Bay Bridge =)
author: Chrysantha C.

description:
Fresh, inventive Japanese food at a reasonable price, considering you're in the Ferry Building.  There are many choices for the lunch specials, several salads to choose from and mains.  The lotus and burdock root salad was delicious.  I also had this awesome thing I can't recall the name of----a big tempura ball which consisted of shrimp and some veggies.  Yum! 

Mister B had the pork ginger curry and was very satisfied.

Beats the line at that sammy joint around the corner ;)
author: Aimee B.

description:
Scrummy with a capital SCRUM!  I stopped in the Ferry Building the other day to do a quick pick up of my wine shipment (holla!) and grabbed a bento box to go.  I did NOT expect to be blown away by a pre-packaged lunch box place with a short line and great prices.  All of my squares were excellent, particularly the eggplant with meat sauce and the potato salad with soy beans and wasabi!  

Highly recommended. I've grabbed the catering menu too to go over options for some events I have coming up, so I'll get back to you on this end.  All in all, some serious lunch time yumminess at this place!
author: Claire C.

description: Vegetarian grab-n-go bento - with a bottle of green tea, you have one of the most delicious, healthy, Japanese-style lunches available in the city. But the veggie ones sell out quickly, so get there at the start of the lunch rush.
author: Ashley H.

description:
I thought I wrote about this place already but I guess not so here it goes ; )

This place has a decent representation of the kinds of food we Japanese people like and what one might be able to find in grocery store deli isles and  OK cafes in Japan... granted I have yet to find a Japanese place that serves any food as delicious as food I can get everywhere in Japan.... this place is pretty good.

I tend to go for their eggplant/ground beef curry or mushrooms/ground beef curry as a main meal.... I've tried ordering both regular and large sizes... regular box does not look like much, but trust me, it WILL be plenty to fill you up.  Large was so big I had to turn half into my lunch next day.

I also like getting their crab creme croquettes (with really good tartar sauce!) or shrimp cakes.  Right now I am leaning towards shrimp cakes than the crab croquettes... I've had better crab creme croquettes back in L.A. but Shrimp cakes are rather new to me and I am liking the texture of it quite a bit.  

I have yet to try their other deli foods as I don't frequent this place enough and when I do, I usually end up ordering my staple curry rice and shrimp cake and can't fit any more food in my belly. lol.  But I am hoping that some day I can convince myself to try their other foods and be able to update this review : )

As for the overall experience:
The venue is generally kept clean and pleasant to the eyes.
They don't have much seating.  We usually go out to the communal tables between Delica and the neighboring Mexican food restaurant and eat there.
They (along with most places in the Ferry Building) closes really early.  I mean WTF? early.  You'd think they can rake in more sales if they opened late enough for the commuters to come grab dinner before they get on the ferries.
They had a price increase as of Feb 2009... due to the economy.  Ordering two regular curry rice, 1 shrimp cake, 2 pieces of chicken and 2 drinks tallied up over $30 bucks with tip.  For take out??? errrrhmmm yeah~~ that's a bit much.

Would I come here often? No, because price/experience/level of food don't quite balance out.  

Would I come here once in a while? Definitely yes, when I have a craving for croquettes and curry.
author: Sascha O.

description: I did not eat at this restaurant but the wait staff was very very helpful when it came to help.  I needed to help my friend with a small cut and they were nice enough to drop everything and give me a bandaid. Very nice people!
author: Greg W.

description: I have come to this site a number of times and am always pleased.  The prices are a bit more frugal than some of the other Ferry Building eats.  At my last visit I ordered the salad, rice and main dish meal for around $8.  I got a spicy burdock salad, chicken tofu patty and rice meal.  The burdock salad was so yummy, the rice was too white, and the patty a bit under seasoned; but overall delicious.
author: Naida E.

description: We decided to go for a walk by the embaracerdo on some random sunday. we stroll into the ferry buildng looking for a SNACK. We ended up with a large beef curry over rice. I murdered it with the quickness. I wasnt even hungry.  I guess that happens.
author: Kitty K.

description: I am giving this place 2 stars because it's not terrible, just not fantastic. I agree with the whole 'Meh, I've experienced better". I'd rather stroll through the Ferry Building and go just about anywhere else.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Got the chicken and rice which wasn't bad, but it could be much better. My friends didn't like their curry and their vegetable sushi so the experience wasn't so great.
author: Vicky N.

description:
I had no idea what to expect. I was looking for a light dinner to take back to my hotel, and wandered through the Ferry Building looking for something interesting.

I ended up with a 5 item bento box from Delica.  It lives up to its name - the flavors of the items in the box are delicate and subtle and delicious. Light, but highly rewarding to the palate.
author: Doc L.

description:
If i'm near the Embarcadero, chances are i'll be stopping by here for a snack.

I first came to check it out when i heard they had vegetarian okonomiyaki, unfortunately, i guess the menu has changed and i've never seen that item but the good news is that there ar so many other fantastic options!

vege-japanese curry!?!  yes! delicious!
asparagus salad, for sure!
croquettes, why not?

super adorable and friendly staff as well.
author: Sean R.

description: Went here for lunch today and had the ginger-carrot soup, the ginger beef bowl and my friend had the beef bowl.  Very good and only $22, not bad for lunch at the Ferry Building.  The also have an array of salads (which, I'll try next time).  Had to wait in line for about 10min (got there at 12:50 got our food by 1:05) which isn't awful for the lunch time rush.  I'd go back again.
author: Ashley L.

description:
overpriced. though expected.

i had the meat + 2 salads meal for lunch. which included about a cup each of whatever 2 of the few selections of salads they have. i had the asparagus and this soy bean one with these black twiggy things in them...they were ok, kinda bland though, and had a little too much creamy sauce/mayo for my liking...i picked the "chicken dumplings" as my meat...which were more like chicken meatballs...kinda tiny (size of ping pong balls) and cold...i thought they'd be hot...the whole meal was pretty disappointing considering how much i paid for it.

i dunno why i acted like such a foodie amateur (i'm no connoisseur but i've had my share of eats, hence the elite status)...and i dunno why we didn't explore the farmer's market right outside for food trucks/stands...i had to slap myself mentally a few times for this hindsight...lesson learned...
author: Jenny C.

description:
The glimmer of light bouncing off the glass case blinded me.....

While at the slanted door for happy hour my stomach began to consume its self waiting ever so patiently for the waitress to take our order.  Surrounded by customers enjoy their delectable delights I couldn't wait any longer for sustenance.  I was a man on a mission to quench the thirst of hunger my stomach roared.

Bursting through the non slanted doors of Slanted Door I ran for salvation.  The glimmer of light bouncing off the glass case blinded me as I hurried by.  I perked up with interest and irritably seeking the source.  To my salivating mouth's surprise I found salvation!  Now mind you, in that state of mind your primal emotions take over.  I couldn't begin to tell you what I ordered from the case, but it tamed the beast and it was GOOOOOoooood.

Maybe next time I'll enjoy my meal.  Now back to Slanted door to tame my other beasts.
author: Po L.

description: Walked in and asked for spicy tuna roll...I was told it was conveniently located in the case in a container to my left. Uh huh.   I added miso soup to my order. Carried it myself to cashier. oaid with credit card and cashier asked me about a tip. I didnt know credit card swiping warranted a tip but I sheepishly threw a buck in to the can. I found a sead and opened my plastic container of sushi. The spicy tuna had like a blended, mushy clump of tuna atop a traditional spicy tuna roll. Upon putting it in my mouth I immediately spat out the contents in to a napkin. It sucked. Worst sushi I have ever had. Worse than publix or kroger. I was too embarrassed to get my money back so I ate at the mexican place next door.  The ferry building is vwry touristy.  Other than the hog oyster co which is fantastic...I didnt find any good foos. DELICA sucked. I wouldnt take my worst enemy to this place.
author: Chris C.

description:
I was here today because  I love their Potato Croquettes. Fresh, warm, and crispy!  At $1.50 each, they make a perfect afternoon snack. I can't speak for anything else on the menu (yet!) but I would definitely come back again to try a Bento box or beef bowl :) 

The only other place I've had croquettes was in the Roppongi Hills Shopping Center food court in Tokyo. Delica rf-1 reminded me of those *nostalgic sigh*
author: CHERiE Y.

description:
On my plate...
Sweet and spicy chicken.
Crab Cream Croquette
Rice topped with sesame seeds.
= $10.00 (approx)
Taste....pretty good!  Real crab in the croquette.  Sweet and spicy chicken has it japanese flare to it (which I love).  Staff was very friendly.
Atmosphere is awesome.  Very clean and has a "sterile" modern feel to it!!!
I would come back!
Parking is across the street or adjacent.  Validation is available so don't forget!  $6/hour w/o.  $2/hr with validation!
author: Elisa O.

description:
Delica rf-1 has some many fresh, delicious looking choices and combinations that at first try it's almost overwhelming. I opted for the sushi, which was a combination of smoked salmon, veggies and wasabi sauce wrapped in rice paper and tempura shrimp with sweet sauce and veggies also wrapped in rice paper. I absolutely preferred the spicier salmon roll, but both were fresh (a feat for premade, pre-packaged sushi rolls).  
I also got to sample one of their fresh salads, thanks to my friendly dining companion. The mushroom salad was absolutely delicious!  Marinated to perfection with a little kick to make it memorable. 

The price is really my only hesitation. Yes, it's the Ferry Building at lunch and yes, it's fresh, but $11 with tax , etc for three modest servings of veggie salad seemed like overkill...
author: Jenni D.

description:
The cash-only-table-with-discount outfront gives me a quick option for a gourmet lunch fix at the Ferry Building.  Easier than getting the ready to go items (buns, spring rolls) at Out the Door.

It's got the freshness and quality you can easily taste.  Everything is really good, and the salads in the bento box are exciting not filler.  It feels subtley delicious the way that good Japanese food can.  Delica is true to it's first name.  (rf-1?  Who knows...)

Oh, and a shout out for the compost/recycling options in house.
author: Leo C.

description: Love this place for a quick lunch.  Fresh and tasty, what more can you ask for?  The Tonkatsu is always perfectly cooked.  It's very easy to overcook pork but these guys have it down to a science.  Highly recommend the Green Bean Salad.  Yum!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Delica's aight; you can get a decent, healthy lunch and enjoy the Ferry Building.  It's quite expensive, and quality is mixed.  
I enjoyed the roast beef sushi and asparagus salad, but did not really like my huge tempura mixture of shrimp and veggies.  It didn't taste very fresh and was difficult to eat.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Update 11/16/07: Bring back the Kabocha Squash Croquette PLEASE.   My life depends on it. 
This is now a regular to go spot for me.  Super Tonkatsu (fried breaded pork cutlet), Spicy Burdock and lotus root salad, Green Bean with sesame dressing, Tofu and Hijiki Patty,Shrimp Cakes, Delicious mushroom miso. 
1/18: Just tried the chestnut bun. Totemo Oishii!
I love love love the little fried stuff and the little dumplings. perfect for on the go snacking. my favorite ever was the fried cream corn.  they must have read my mind.
author: sarah C.

description:
Seasame Green bean Salad -  I have a love-hate relationship with this dressing.   I wish I could make a seasame dressing as tasty as the one coating the green bean salad.  But I can't.  

Oh wait, I don't have to!  They sell it separately.  

The eggplant is pretty dank as well.
author: Monica L.

description:
I first went to Delica when my ex-boyfriend was still working there. He couldn't stop talking about horrible his managers were. I found out he worked there after the first night I met him... He called in "sick" from the bed that we were in telling his manager that he was jumped the night before. Hey, I wasn't complaining... I wanted him to stay...

I really like Delica. The food is always super fresh, and there are plenty of options. Hot food, cold food, salads, and soups. A tad pricey though.. One sushi roll (which is never enough for me) goes for $7.75, and a small side salad can tack on another 3 bucks. Worth it though? Yes. And I must add that the Ferry building is always a delight to visit. Great scenery, and it's always full of hot FiDi boys. Super Cruisy!
author: Reza A.

description: I'm not as big of a fan of the curries as most are but I love the salads (they have an amazing one with lotus that is easily 5 stars), the rolls (the salmon rice roll is so bomb, also 5 stars), and the chicken dumplings (probably 4 stars). It's also a quick stop so I like coming here when I wake up at 12PM on a Sunday and need food in mah belly nowww.
author: Lilian W.

description:
Order the seasonal bento box lunch. It contains small samples of different yummy dishes.

Food is fresh and tasty.
author: Erica A.

description: over-priced quasi-japanese food missing something completely. i don't miss it.
author: Denise C.

description: Delica serves quality foods at decent prices. The pork katsu sandwich was yummy as well. My only qualm is that their foods are mostly cold dishes. I would have loved for their pork katsu sandwich to be warm. Nonetheless, everything was delicious. And if you're only going to eat one thing here, eat the eggplant! The eggplant is really really really good =)
author: Minda w.

description:
This is one of my favorite lunch spots.  It's essentially an upscale take out serving contemporary &  traditional Japanese food.

The items that stand out are their fresh Japanese salads.  Usually there is a Hijiki (seaweed) Soy Bean salad, Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad, Eggplant salad, lotus root salad, Chinese Chicken salad and wild mushroom salad to choose from.  There's also a variety of cold small entrees such as tofu steak with sauce, chickent and tofu patty, roast beef sushi, etc.

Hot items are mostly fried - shrimp cake, potato croquet, chicken dumplings, sweet & sour chicken, crab cake, tempura, tonkatsu (fried pork with breading).  They also offer beef/chicken curry over rice.

YOu can buy salads by weight and many items by piece.  For lunch, you can get  2 salad item with rice for about $7.  You can also get a deep friend item with a salad and rice for $7.50.  Curry chicken/beef will run you a bit more around $8.50 or so.

Delica is located in the Ferry Building across from Pete's Coffee.
author: Paul K.

description: Fantastic bento style lunches in the ferry building.  On the pricey side but worth it for a special picnic. Note to foreigners - bentos are box lunches are are meant to be eaten cold.
author: Karen N.

description: Great crab croquette.  Tasty Japanese deli style dishes.
author: Jennifer A.

description: My favorite place in the Ferry building for lunch. They use a lot of fresh, organic ingredients so the prices are a bit high for daily lunch but the quality goes in hand. I really like their tender lamb or beef curries, which is a hearty portion for lunch. I also love their croquettes, pork cutlet and wasabi potato salad. The flavors are always balanced but not too heavy.
author: Lainy C.

description: Delica rf-1 touts itself as a Japanese deli, but it reminds me of the best and freshest offerings from a food court in the basement of a Japanese department store.   They have several salads, koroke and tonkatsu, curry rice, and "sushi" rolls, which use mainly cooked ingredients bar the smoked salmon.  The salads here are all excellent, especially the gobo, and I like all of the koroke, except for the crab.  The curry rice is a little weak, but it is a little different from what I had expected, i.e. not as viscous as the usual versions.  The service is top notch and one afternoon, right before closing, they made me a fresh batch of spinach goma-ae, even though they were out.
author: Peter L.

description: This place is divine!  I loved the shrimp cakes, the wasabi potatoe salad, and most especially, the sweet corn salad.  Everything was beautifully presented and appeared freshly prepared.  It is a good thing I don't live here, I'd find myself obsessed with eating here every other day!
author: Marie B.

description: I havent had this good a hot soba noodle in a LONG TIME. They also topped it w/ a fried kariage (fried shrimp/veggie) which melted nicely into the noodles and soup. I never realized the wonders of the Ferry Building until this past weekend. And I'm glad this place helped me realize it. Prices are also reasonable for Japanese food. I'm coming back for the katsus and other bento boxes. Do not pass this up. Plus you can fill up on some Petes coffee across the hall in case you get food coma, cuz next time I will be ordering  A LOT of food.
author: Thomas L.

description: Really good japanese salads and snacks. Tons of flavor and a great environment.
author: Andrew L.

description: For those that have lived in Japan or grew up in Japanese kitchens this place smells like the real deal.  Thankfully I like to follow my nose.  Of the few items I tried, most tasted the way I remember them tasting in my childhood--the tonkatsu is particularly yummy when fresh and the crab cream croquette is also delish.  The plain potato croquette on the other hand, is too peppery and dry to be a success.  Unfortunately, the prices are quite high--even among the other pricey vendors at the Ferry Building.  $4 for the crab cream croquette and $1.50 per tiny piece of tonkatsu makes it hard to justify the wallet damage after assembling a hearty meal at this deli style establishment.  Thankfully, for the next few weeks I can still claim to be a "tourist" and splurge whatever I like.  I have a feeling that after I move in to town, I'll be less willing to shell out on a regular basis.
author: Candace C.

description: Everyone else has covered it - pricey, but oh so yummy and also healthy.  My favorites so far are the sweet chicken dumplings and spinach sesame salad.
author: John H.

description: I love the wasabi potato salad the sushi is delicious also nice and clean and pleasant staff
author: lyn m.

description:
Oh wow, bento boxes ftw here! Admittedly I'm a bit of a Japanese-food "newbie" so boxes filled with random foods was a bit scary for me. But they turned out so delicious! My favorite was the wasabi mashed potatoes (pleasantly hot) and the chicken dumpling. I do wish things were better labeled because I didn't know what I ate until I looked here!

Miso was DELICIOUS; giant chunks of tofu, not the piddly chunks other places have. And fast; pick up a box and pay... no waiting for a server.
author: Tracy O.

description: Came here for lunch during my first time in the Ferry Building and it was pretty good! Basically an Asian fusion takeout place, with assorted entrees, soups, salads, and combos. I had a lunch combo with fried pork cutlets (delicious), Chinese chicken salad (chicken strips with celery and carrot sticks and some other veggies I don't remember - it was great though I wish it had been warm instead of cold), and salmon chowder. The salmon chowder was basically chowder with a small chunk of cooked salmon added in, but it tasted amazing!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I like the place (at least the atmosphere and the clean, zen-like layout), but it's rather expensive for very little food... $9.50 for a 4 side dishes of your choice.. you can choose from the delicious potato croquette, different kinds of salads and other side items. .. my favorite and cheapest eat is the Curry beef over rice, which runs about $7. .. the curry is a bit overly salty for my chinese taste-buds, so may have to purchase a bottle of green tea from them for another $2..

Only 4 / 5 stars simply because the food is expensive, but the food tastes good and will get you quite full, quite fast.
author: Wilson L.

description:
I got taken here by a SF insider. Never would have happened upon this on my own! 

Trendiest quick-Japanese food I've had stateside.  The line structure is a little confusing (we kept looking at one another suspiciously wondering if we were either breaking line or not realizing we could have soooo been in that shorter line) but after getting out of the frenzied ordering/paying area, the food tastes quite zen-like. 

Super yum healthy tasting quickness.
author: Deanna J.

description:
So I'd heard this place was supposed to have the closest thing to authentic Japanese curry in the area.  Having sampled it, it's reasonably close, but doesn't have the richness I came to expect when I was in Japan.  Also, it's really oily.
The salads are quite tasty, and they've got some nice lunch specials allowing for a selection of salads and hot dishes, ranging from $6-10.
The croquettes are reasonably tasty, and the breading light and crisp as it ought to be, but not of quite the consistency I remember from Japan (a little too chunky I think) and the flavor seemed not quite right.  But definately pretty good.
author: Don H.

description:
This place rules!  It's a healthy creative japanese deli disguised as a pricey ferry building soup and salad lunch place...you'll walk in and be surprised at what it actually is and how well priced the lunches are!  The bentos definitely reminded me of the packaged bentos in Tokyo's mall food basements.  The salads are creative, original and DELICIOUS.  On a beautiful day, take it outside by the water and you can't lose.

Note:  I still love the food here but I'm peeved at the credit card policy.  I'm usually 50 cents below the credit card limit, I've gone here dozens of times, 2-3 times a week without an issue but the last time I went the guy gave me a hard time...I understand he's just doing his job.  But I can be stubborn and I hate paying cash ,so I always choose Out the Door over Delica nowadays, I miss the hijiki salad.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
Really good tofu chicken patty and sides (especially the asparagus as well as the wasabi mashed potatoes)....I also like the ginger beef bowl.  

Its a little overpriced, but I'm sure rent isn't cheap at the ferry building and the quality is great.
author: Aaron M.

description: It's like a fast food Japanese joint minus all the unhealthiness that entails fast food. Everything on the menu, all the sushi rolls, bento boxes, and deli items looked so healthy and fresh! I was contemplating what to get for the longest time.  Since I wasn't too hungry I got the combo sushi roll- with smoked salmon and shrimp wrapped in rice paper.  The rice paper really did it for me because it actually made me feel good after finishing all 6 pieces.  The roll was very fresh and lite.  For $8, kinda pricey, but I think it was worth it.  I'd definitely want to try their deli selections and bento boxes the next time I'm here.
author: Lisa C.

description: I'm a fan of their salad. I can be a vegetarian if all I eat for my whole life is food from Delica. No sorry, I kid. Their cream crab croquette is so gooood too.... I can't really decide whether I want to be a carnivore for my whole life or a vegetarian. Their tofu salad is purfeeect. Combined it with wasabi salad..... oh... that's an ideal lunch for me. With a view of the bay bridge and lazy ambiance of the Ferry Building, you get a killer combination
author: Cliff T.

description:
