what's wrong with me... why didn't i come here sooner to savor and enjoy all the delicious goodies delica has to offer? very reminiscent of the "depachika" (department store basement food delis) that i saw in japan but was too timid to actually order from, except with fresh local ingredients and a california twist to things... oh yes, and i actually CAN order from here without feeling like a fool!

we tried the 1 main + 2 side salad combo with the fried shrimp cake, chinese chicken salad and green bean salad. the shrimp cake was still nice and hot and was served with a little bit of tartar sauce. i can't resist fried foods, let alone japanese fried foods, so this was a delight! the chinese chicken salad was super crunchy and tasty, with the daikon and cucumbers having been marinated in the dressing (i think). the green bean salad was also crunchy and amazingly creamy.

coupled with the ito-en tea apple drink, delica served up one of the nicest feel-good lunches i've had in a while. the perfect alternative to the hectic crowds that floods the ferry building farmer's market sometimes. man, i really wish i worked closer to here!!
author: Andrey C.

description:
usually i steer away from restaurants that try to inject western influence into east asian cuisines, but i was pleasantly surprised at how good this place is! for example, i was a little turned off  and confused by the loaves of bread lined up in a "japanese" restaurant until i overheard the waitress say they make their own breadcrumbs. cooool 8)

everything's really fresh (the sashimi in particular) and they emphasize the use of as many local growers/producers as possible. the fried chicken (chicken karaage) was actually mostly chicken, compared to other places that serve 80% fried batter, 20% chicken. the oyster gratin was so hot and juicy, i wish one order came with more. our server was very energetic and knowledgeable and treated us like we were the only customers in the place. a little pricey, but for the quality and the location, i think it's quite reasonable. i will definitely come again.
author: Veronica L.

description: I really like this place for what it is - a Japanese deli. I'm only here for lunch, so it's a grab it and go type of deal for me. It's all stuff made with organic beautiful ingredients and they have an interesting variety of salads ranging from wasabi potato to hijiki to mabo tofu. There's also some fried foods, like karaage tempura, croquettes and katsu. I usually get a bento but the katsu's been less than impressive of late and sometimes they're a little skimpy with the rice and/or the salads. There's also some japanese curry which is good, but not nearly as tasty as muracci's and some sushi rolls. it's good, but not necessarily at their price point.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
How come no one thought of this before? A japanese-style restaurant and DELI! I love the setup and location immensely. The food, is heart-breakingly artistic and beautiful... because, in the end, you have to eat it. 

The bento for $11 is a little heavy on price but well-worth it. What you get is not only filling, tasty, and worth a picture or two... it tasted fresh! Which is very important for my bento box affections.

I have to come back for the curry... maybe, tomorrow? :)
author: Andrew W.

description:
What a great concept!  Think Italian deli or small plates tapas, but Japanese style.  I am sure these are a dime a dozen back in the motherland, but for us Californian Japanese food luvers we must admit that our range of Japanese cuisines is very limited.  Sure we've all had our lunch boxes, raw tunas and fancy rolls.  A few creative souls probably tried out some Japanese curries and udon/sobas/ramen but DELICA rf-1 is fun, unique, clean and you just feel this is a whole different type of Japanese food that the locals in CA haven't had before, but would try once they go.

DELICA rf-1 is a perfect lunch place (especially once summer comes and this damn rain goes away).  I had the Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad and its yummy -- who doesn't like a mix of wasabi mayo + edamames and for the sushi fans try out the Roast Beef Sushi.  And for bento box fans take a look at the bento boxes they have here.  When I was in Japan as a kid once (I was 12 yrs old) the thing that stuck out to me the most was the lil neatly packed bento boxes.  Seeing the bento boxes here brought back some childhood flashbacks.
author: Sherman H.

description:
FERRY PLAZA FRUGAL:  Lunch curry specials rock the house and always a vegetarian option, usually under $10.  SO crazy good was the eggplant curry with GROUND CHICKEN ($7.75), I felt like I was rising out of my chair.  And, you can certainly make a meal out of their little fried goodies.  At 2.75-3.75 a piece it seems dear until you get that first bite of panko goodness.  Add in 1/2 pinto of edamame or green bean salad with miso dressing and a pro bono view of the bay and you're stylin'.


People!  It's all about the PANKO!  (those yum-licious breadcrumbs that fry ever so delicately to encase delica's fried specialties: potato and mushroom croquettes, shrimp cake, tonkatsu, et al).  

The panko-fried items get 5 stars, but the unfortunate (fast japanese food hazard) BLANDNESS of some items like sweet-n-sour chicken (chunks of orangey chicken, had it today), hijiki and soybean salad (not sea-salty enough-- this is seaweed, isn't it??) and glazed chicken meatballs (apparently, the glaze is COSMETIC) brings this super-sanitary and well-run by happy-shiny-counterpeople upscale deli down to 4 stars.  

However, 4 stars is by no means bad in my book-- MAKING it worth the jacked-up ferry plaza prices ($9.50 for bento, approx $3.75 for panko-fried items).  

Notable items (aside from the amazing FRIED MENU) include:  Chinese Chicken Salad, made with the delica touch:  julienne veggies and chicken, the best use of baby celery I've ever tasted and DEAD-ON chinese chicken salad vinaigrette without all of the fuss of an americanized chinese chix salad.  

Also, wasabi, garlic and edamame potato salad:  who the hell thought of this?  It's crazy good.  Half-mashed wasabi-garlic potatoes, whole fresh edamame beans in a cold potato salad-- great intimate picnic food.  

And, another one of my personal favs, the roast beef nigiri, just like it sounds, thinly sliced rare roast beef atop a finger of japanese sushi rice (the rice it pretty decent, not gross or cheap or sticky), maybe some scallion garnish.  

They also have other sushi, some wrapped in rice paper rather than seaweed, that I have yet to try...

Those bento boxes (various items, always a healthy, square meal) sure are handy for buying to-go and finding a people watching or bayview perch in the back of the ferry plaza or the nearby Embarcadero.  

Also, Japanese style cooking and dining is engineered to be 'systematically beautiful' and therefore a non-messy, organized and tranquililty-inducing eating experience (think Zen...) which explains why some items lack the flavor kick. (Gloppy, sloppy sweet and sour sauce? No way, sensai!).  

This Japanese tradition of food presentaion carried out at Delica also explains the CALM I feel even when I'm CHOWING on one of their panko-fried mushroom croquettes and dipping them in the delicate tomato or herbed mayo sauces-- with chopsticks!

Can't beat the bayview location, friendly staff (and very cute asian guys).  Ferry plaza standard.
author: E L.

description:
This is a great Japanese deli and could be my new favorite quick lunch / take-out place in the Ferry Building.

Lots of choices, including a few vegetarian items and even a couple of vegan items.  More bento boxes than you can shake a stick at.  And lots of tasty little bites.  My faves are the fried shrimp cakes and potato croquettes.  Lots of healthy choices too; salads, soups and sushi.  The beef curry sauce is super tasty, but because the meat is organic, you'll only get a few pieces.

While everything on the menu is slightly less than $10, you'll probably spend around $10-15.  Just like tapas and dim sum, those little plates add up fast.

It gets busy at lunch.  And with all the people trying to choose from the many items, do yourself a favor and show up before noon.
author: Marcus W.

description:
Mmmmm, I love to go here and get the bento boxes - full of stuff I know I like, and maybe a new thing or two that's guaranteed to be tasty.  Delica rf-1 is a delicious, healthy way to jolt yourself out of the weekday lunch doldrums.  The flavors are interesting, and the food is fresh - it won't make you feel like you need to take a big nap under your desk.  It is on the slightly pricier end of the lunch spectrum - a box is around $10-$11 - but it's a great treat, and you can fill up there for less if you're content to try only one or two of their offerings.  As for me, if I'm going all the way to the Ferry Building, I'm determined to sample several items.  It's all good but I'll mention a few offerings so you know what you're getting into . . . 

Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad (with edamame!)
Corn and Mascarpone Cheese Salad
Eggplant Salad (with chicken and onions)
Crab Cream Croquette
Chicken Dumpling with Sweet Chili Sauce (and water chestnutes and mushrooms)

it's pretty deli-style - I'm such a visual person that I usually just go for the stuff on display, but evidently they have sushi rolls, rice bowls, and several kinds of soup.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I live on a strict budget so I can afford a home in San Francisco by the year 2046.  Because of that, I can only afford to go to this place on days when I don't drive into the city and pay $$$ for parking.  

Of course, once you pay for that meal, you realize you pretty much blew the savings you had from not parking that day. But I have no regrets, damn it!  Life is too short to pass up good food like this even if my budget is blown in the process. :)
author: Angela K.

description:
A sunny warm day in downtown calls for lunch at the Ferry Building. Since I don't work in Downtown, I don't have the luxury to visit Delica too often. The food is always fresh and reliably delicious.

I really enjoyed:
*Salad Trio for $8
- Hijiki and Soybean Salad
- Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad 
- Corn and Mascarpone Salad 

*Sushi Roll $7.75
*Roast Beef Sushi $2
*Fried Shrimp Cake $3.75
*White Corn and Potato Croquette $2
*Mango Tea $2

Find a bench in the back and enjoy the perfect lunch with an amazing view.
author: Katie K.

description:
One of my favorite places to splurge for lunch once a week. I work upstairs in the Ferry Builidng, so Delica is a hop, jump and a skip away. 

My favorites are the Tofu Steak w/ Miso Sauce, Green Bean Sesame Salad and Wasabi Potato salad.  I try to avoid this place during the lunch hour rush because the lines get crazy. The best times are after 1pm. Plenty of vegan and vegetarian options.
author: Joshua C.

description:
The food here is a tad more than I would like to pay, but it's the Ferry Building so it's expected.

The food is always good and fresh.  I always go for the tonkatsu bento and beef curry.  It's also nice to be able to eat by the water on a nice sunny day.

My only complaint is the confusing ordering system.  I tried to order bento in the hot food line and was told by a lady to order from the cold food line.  When I moved over to the cold food line, the same lady ended up taking my order, hmmm?????  

I've also had an experience when I tried to pay for my food, which they held at the register, they had sold my food to someone else. 

Other than the confusing ordering system, I'm happy with the food.
author: danny m.

description:
Don't get me wrong, this place is good. you'll love your first time there.  but the variation isn't much and everything starts to taste pretty similar after a while.  so as long as you don't eat here too frequently then this is a 4 star place to you.  it's when you're like me, become addicted and go 3 times a week for a few weeks, that you start to not like it as much.

also their sushi rolls are really good.  they don't look super filling, but they are. and tasty!
author: Andrew r.

description:
I had some time to kill after work recently and needed a snack that was more than the vending-machine variety to tide me over until my post-work dinner. So I guess I had pre-dinner (a late merienda?) at Delica. Normally I just eat lunch here and it's fine, albeit kind of expensive. My only experience with their evening menu (prior to my late snack that I am now describing) was being told it was too early to order from. 

I get to Delica at 6:00 and try to order dinner from the counter, which is how it works there at lunch. Apparently it's sit-down for dinner, ie there are waitresses. Ok fine, I go sit down at a spindly table (imagine the tallest bench you've ever seen) on my spindly chair and a very nice pair of servers come over to give me the (evening) menu and go over happy hour specials. I (still) appreciate that there are clearly labeled vegan items, which there are at least three of for dinner -- avocado roll, cucumber roll and fried tofu. I order edamame ($3) and an avocado roll ($5). Now, I like avocado rolls. I like them a lot. But $5 for six pieces of vegetarian sushi made me think, "a five dollar avocado roll had better be pretty damn delicious" and guess what? It was. Which makes me feel weird, because I don't want to feel ok about spending $5 on an avocado roll but I kind of do because it was actually really, really good. So while it was the first $5 avocado roll I've purchased and eaten, it was one of the better avocado rolls that I've ever had.

Awkward: The hostess and waitresses seem like they're constantly telling people who come in that they may only sit down if they order off of the dinner menu (I guess as opposed to ordering the deli stuff from the counter?), which is not the friendliest way to greet people or introduce them to dinner service/offerings at Delica.
author: M M.

description: The Asian Fusion here can be sorta pricey. For the roast beef salad ($10) and Chicken Karaage (a piece) for $8. Not worth it, but the food is good and service is good also!
author: Vivian L.

description: Authentic Japanese bento boxes. Great kare rice (kare, not curry). When I want Japanese food like the kind of food I would eat at home, I come here to select one main and 2 salad items or 3 salad items. Sit on a bench and eat by the water. It's not cheap, but it's worth every penny. My only complaint is that the menu doesn't change, so I'm getting a little sick of the items . . .
author: Su K.

description:
oishi-i-i-i!!

As others have noted, the food at Delica is just like the food sold in department store basements in Japan.   

On my most recent visit, I had the bento with the hijiki and soybean salad, lotus root salad, chicken meatballs (2) and steamed rice.  Everything was delicious!  Fresh and healthy.  Nice presentation in the bento box.  The bento was $9.50.  

If anyone over at Delica is reading, can you please put kabocha on the menu?
author: Miu M.

description:
I love it here. The food is tasty and interesting. Pricey but worth it.

I've tried most everything. The items I keep going back to are the soba noodle salad, wasabi potato salad, the white corn salad with a cheese vinaigrette (sounds weird buts it really good. It's also seasonal, I think), shrimp cake, potato croquette (can't go wrong with fried items). The bento boxes are a good way to go if you want to sample a few things in one fell swoop.

After you've made your selection, have a seat outside. Nice.
author: cyndi L.

description:
When I arrived at the Ferry Building starving I was really glad to see this place.  I was so happy to see they had curry, and my all time favorite donkatsu (fried pork cutlet).  Although I enjoyed their donkatsu, crab croquette, and fried chicken thingy, I did not like their soba salad (too much radish shavings), and other fusion items. 

I don't know may be I'm old fashioned. 
As others have stated, it is little pricey, but I would still get their fried items, and the likelihood of my coming back is pretty high.

Bon Appetit
author: YJ H.

description:
One of my favorite Lunch spots at the moment.  I've never been let down by anything at this restaurant.

It's easy to splurge and end up paying for than 10 bucks for lunch, so if you're on the cheap tip, grab the 2 salads and rice box.  It's 6 or 7 dollars and is basically a trough of food.

As skeptical as I was about pre-packaged sushi rolls, Delica's are THE BOMB!  Shrimp temura and salmon rolled in rice paper... grab a tofu steak and you're good to go!
author: Zachary B.

description:
We tried the miso marinated tofu steak and the eggplant salad and it was really good and healthy.  

My fellow Yelper, Wakako U. has recommended the curry, so I'll follow her advice and try that next....to be continued...
author: Michael F.

description:
High end Japanes deli w/ a fusion twist - yes, mouthful but that's my take on this place.

I can see how it can be a popular lunch spot since you can order according to appetite and/or wallet size.  

Interesting place and food.  We were determined to try other places in the Ferry building so we only had the roast beef sushi ($2/piece) and the tofu & chicken patty with hijiki ($4/piece).  The sushi was interesting but not very flavorful.  The tofu/chicken patty was ok, a bit too densed, the sweet soy sauce helps with the flavor.

We will need to come back and try the other interesting looking snacks.
author: Gloria H.

description:
This is a great place to go if you are in the area and need a lunch that is good and healthy.

The bento boxes are pretty nice. They are right there, ready for pick-up, and range about 9 or 10 bucks. Not too bad, if you want to eat some good food.

They also have food that you can pick and choose from in their deli which is also a good treat. 

My only set-back is that I like to eat (alot actually) and so the food isn't always as filling as I'd hope. This is definitely a place to go if you want a semi-filling lunch, because you had a late breakfast or are planning an early dinner. Perhaps grab a small deli item to go with your bento box if you think you might be starving.

Overall, great place.
author: Nicolas H.

description:
There is nothing special about this place. The food is fine but really nothing I couldn't live without. The sushi is probably what I would buy again if I had to; the bento boxes are alright. Sure the food is fresh but my mouth was not "wowed."  

With all the other options in the Ferry Building I doubt I will end up here again.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
Another authentic Japanese place!! Owned by Japanese, this is a japanese delicatessan chain from Japan.  It's so hard to find a place in SF that serves home-style Japanese food, like Mabo-dofu, hijiki, and potato corokke.  Delica has all that stuff!!!

Everything was YUM! I used this place for catering for our company, and I couldn't be more happy with their service and level of concern.  Our staff was raving about the food the entire week!
author: Mellie P.

description:
3.5, but erring on the side of 4 because they have onigiri!

Delica's great for a nice light lunch.  Never had the bento boxes or the sushi rolls (pricey), but the brown rice ball with salmon is delicious.  Roast beef sushi is also good, as are the chicken dumplings.  There's a fried potato/shrimp thing that would be better served hot, but refrigerated it's just OK.  

It's hard not to want to try everything, but it is possible to eat cheap if you're not that hungry.  Example: get the burdock salad (light and refreshing) with a rice ball (or two or three or four... but then it's not so cheap).

I can't recommend their beef curry over rice, though.  It's good, bit tastes like it's made with those store-bought roux blocks.  Save your money and make it at home.
author: Amy N.

description:
LOVE this place!

i was taken here by a friend for a work lunch and now i take friends that come visit me during work lunches as well! 

fast, simple, easy and tasty! what more can you ask for? authentic japanese food is done to perfection here. Lunch goes for $9-$12, a lil more pricey for lunch but it's a nice treat once and a while.

you can pick bento style lunch boxes: rice, a protein and a veg. or you can pick and choose a-la carte. seaweed-spinach salad and tofu in a miso glaze is my fav! good options for vegetarian diners!

lovely views of the bay bridge and treasure island for the out of towners too.
author: Lorraine T.

description:
Yum! 

I enjoy their lunch specials (1 main, 1 side and rice for about $9)

They use local, organic, free range meats/veggies whenever possible and their food is tasty. I love the seaweed & burdock salads, Chinese Chicken salad & tofu/chicken patty (heated).. deelish! Go early to skip the longer lunch lines.

Some stool/bar seating and then additional seats in Ferry Bldg & behind it.
author: Abby W.

description:
I love the hijiki salad (burdock root with seaweed), i love the eggplant curry, i love the tofu miso patty.  I love the apple mango ito-en drink too.  $12.00 for a lunch. Slightly pricey but worth a try. 

 Who knew healthy food can taste this good?

We sat outside the dock to eat our lunch. One thing I hated were the pigeons surrounding us.
author: Jboogie L.

description: The most interesting tempura I've ever seen. A big, fried ball with shrimps and string beans streaming from the top like they're trying to escape. I had to eat this. Delicious and light, and so were the bentos. Be prepared to spend over $10 for your lunch. And walk away feeling not too stuffed but satisfied.
author: Alex H.

description:
LOVE EVERYTHING HERE!
Beef Curry, Mapo tofu Salad, Roast beef nigiri, to even the Croquettes.  All good choices and made fresh.  
The Staff that works there are also extremely nice and patient
I take every chance to come out here for a meal either to eat there or togo
I'll admit, the price are just a hair high but definitely worth it for the quality and fresh ingredients they use.
author: Ken Y.

description:
Ferry Building yummy munchies!
 I really like the steak "sushi" which is basically nigiri but rare steak instead of fish. The shrimp cakes was excellent with homemade tartar sauce. The man had the crab croquette which he loves but, I felt it was way too rich and heavy. 
  The selection was extensive and almost overwhelming. I really wanted to try one of everything. I will definitely be back and try some of the yummy looking salads.
author: Douggers M.

description:
My favorite lunch place in SF.
Derica rf-1 is operated by a Japanese department store and has been reputable for quality in Japan. The bento box is a little pricy as 8-11 dollers but still much much better than random Japanese places in the city. We don't have to pay for tips, just buy one bento box and sit down outside of Ferry Building. The view is even gorgeous. 

My favorite is chicken pate and 2 salad plate. Yummy.
author: Yoko S.

description:
I used to think this place was a pretentiously lame... you know...  "Japanese Delicatessen." Wha?? 

Until I discovered their Bento Boxes and their roast beef nigiri... imagine a succelent thick slice of Niman Ranch roast beef over sushi rice with wasabi topped with coarse salt... it's like a heartier sushi... 

They have unique little fried concoctions like the dungeness crab croquettes - made with acme breadcrumbs and cowgirl creamery cheese - and the shrimp and veggie "nests." 

Most importantly, they are super-sustainable and devoted to using local ingredients. Their parent company, Rock Field (hence the rf) is a very green Japanese company, so I don't mind paying a little extra for organic Japanese goodness! 

I'm glad this unique little place is doing well.
author: BroSauce J.

description:
Good food, good quality.
The Hijiki reminds me of sitting in Granny and Gramps' dining room in Kaimuki, eating chazuke and other tsukemono.
Sometimes even just a hint at easier times is all you need to become a fan.  Nostalgia is very important to me.
We enjoyed Delica's bento.
In my opinion, any visit to the Ferry Building warrants a visit here.
author: Barry A.

description:
Well, it's more 4.5 stars b/c of the wasabi in the roast beef sushi but given I'm coming back to this place, I'll bump it to a 5....  (The price is not THAT bad!!!)

Delica has become one of my favorite places to eat when I'm at the Embaracadero.  Their lunches are very tasty, yet light.  The fried foods I did have (small amount though. I know... BAD me on blowing my diet...) is very tasty w/o being greasy or heavy.

I like their salads too!  I particularly like their corn and mascapone cheese salads, their potato salad with the edamame and the eggplant salad.   I would like them to be a bit lighter on the wasabi for the roast beef sushi... but otherwise... also VERY tasty too!!! YUM YUM!!!  :-P~~

Try their peach custard with almond slivers dessert too!!!  (And if you really don't like dessert there, Ciao Bella for gelato is nearby.)  ;)

Have yet to try everything else, but I sure am looking forward to it.  :-P~~

Note: Go during non standard business hours!!!  Yes, it's THAT POPULAR during weekday lunch hour...
author: Joanna R.

description:
Visiting this place during the summer season was quite an expedition as hoards of people congregate to the Ferry Building to sample fine wine and cheeses from the myriad of other stores.

Upon first arrival you come across two separate lines, one which is for Hot/Deli Items and the other for Boxed Items.  However, if you're looking for a quick line, I suggest having cash at hand to fork it over to the guy in the front of the store passing out bento boxes.

The relatively long wait during the lunch hours are worth it as the Roast Beef Sushi is excellent in presentation and taste.  Many people have the misconception that sushi has to be fish, which they would be promptly corrected.  Sushi, literally translated, just means rice vinegar--denoting that if you put it on top of rice, it's sushi. But I digress.

I always enjoy getting the Number 4 combo at the Deli which includes one Hot Item, Rice and one Salad.  With a wide variety of vegetarian items, the Chinese Chicken Salad, Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad, and Spicy Burdock Root Salad are good choices.  However, I would love to try the Corn and Mascarpone Salad.

As far as the curry and fried items, the beef curry wasn't anything too special, as I could easily attain this from any other place in Japantown.  Also, the Kakiage Tempura was what seemed like a "hot mess" as it is filled with pretty much anything in my fridge currently, but not much can be said about things that people say are "authentic" to Japanese cuisine.

The food here, though, is fairly cheap, fairly tasty, and of good quality for the Ferry Building, and because of it, I continue to come back, as most other places in and around Market charge you an arm and a leg for good food.
author: Renee Y.

description:
Oh, Delica...so delicious, yet so inefficient. Yes, charging per piece for everything is very inefficient.

First of all, whoever designed the way the line works was seriously trying to make it the least efficient process ever. This is the least Japanese element of the place. Things in Japan are efficient, and Delica is anything but. People from Japan would be laughing hysterically at how inefficient the service is here. Since they charge per piece for things, they have count each one by one. It's tedious.

Putting that behind, the food here is actually really tasty. The roast beef sushi tastes as yummy as it sounds. My favorite was the potato croquette. I don't know how they make them so crunchy! My only complaint is that mine weren't very warm and I had to ask twice for the tonkatsu sauce, which they should have given to me automatically. I mean, come on...how do you serve it without the sauce?

It is pricey, considering a lot of these are deli/convenient store type of foods that you can get dirt cheap anywhere else. I think my meal was around $10...it was a small portion. Despite the price, the food is hard to resist.
author: Kristen R.

description:
Love this japanese restaurant! Where else can one go for authentic Japanese food made with organic, local & sustainable ingredients??? Everything is of fine quality..What a find!!

 Thank you for the amazing delicious food. Spent $16.00 - best miso soup ever, delicious Delica roll-very substantial- plus tax and tip.  For dinner, what a deal!
author: Belle C.

description: My gosh I spend so much here getting random stuff.  Everything seems to be really good.  Some stuff does not really taste as good but i just dip it in their tarter sauce for the shrimp croquettes.  For some reason it makes everything taste good...
author: Sonja P.

description:
I came here with a friend who was visiting from Indiana. I work in the city but a little too far from the Ferry Building to visit with any regularity. I'm not a tourist hating elitist , so I actually feel like it's kind of a treat to go there when someone is in town (but that's fodder for another review) and I don't mind spending a little extra money to try something new.

At Delica rf-1, I ordered a bento box and asked the man behind the counter to surprise me. He chose rice, seaweed salad, mushroom salad and a crab and cheese croquette. My friend got the same seaweed salad, I think a lotus root salad and the tofu steak. We saw some people eating tempura; it looked delicious, so we went back and got some of that, too.

With the exception of the tempura (it looked a lot yummier than it actually was.), the food was all quite tasty. I got the feeling it was pretty healthy, too. But, that was just a feeling. What do I know? Not much, that's for sure! Also, it was filling. And, that's pretty important to a girl like me!

I noticed that some people complained in their reviews that the food at Delica-rf1 is expensive. It's definitely not a place I could afford to eat at every day, but I tend to think it's unique enough that it doesn't warrant everyday eating.

If you want a dollar menu, go to McDonalds. If you want to try something a little different, check out Delica-rf-1.
author: Sarah R.

description: I went all out when I saw all the delicious food displayed.  I had the wasabi potato salad, soba noodles and a potato croquette.  All were fresh and light.  I absolutely love the croquette.  Lots of potato and curry flavor fried to perfection.  The thing that made me squeal was the nice touch of giving a pouch of tonkatsu sauce to go with the croquette, it was so Japan.  There are still so many items to try, can't wait to come here again.
author: Yun W.

description: When I used to work in the Embarcadero Centers, I loved coming here.  I used to always get the bento boxes.  My favorite was the vegetarian ma po tofu and the wasabi potato salad.  This place is a little expensive and I usually left a little hungry but everything tastes so good that I almost don't care.
author: Brent G.

description:
If I worked close to Delica I would eat here for lunch every day.  

The food at Delica is delicious. I have eaten here with very discerning Asian friends who love this place as much as I do. The food is fresh, delicious, perfectly cooked and presented, and healthy. No wonder Japanese live such long lives, their food is wonderfully balanced and nutritious.

I usually get the bento box - i love all the salads, wasabe potatoes, everything!
author: Spoon G.

description: L-O-V-E their selection of salads, from the Wasabi Garlic Potato to the Spicy Burdock Root Salad to the Spinach and Sesame - always freshly made!
author: Y L.

description:
Most people do not understand there exists an art of frying and that this place has mastered it.  All the fried goods, from scallops (yum) to croquettes are so exquisitely fried.  

They also have soups, salads and curry.  With the exception of the fried goodies and meat, all is healthy.  My macrobiotic nut sister would approve.  Their green bean sesame salad is so very tasty, though I don't think it's that hard to make since M Cafe in LA has the exact same thing.  The tofu steak is lovely with rice.

The only reason I don't give this place 5 stars is the price.  We're going broke eating there so much!  But then again you have to take in consideration the quality of their ingredients (as well as the care and attention put into everything from preparation to presentation.)  I think practically all of it is organic; they even buy their beef from the organic meat vendor in the building.   

Plus they are never short-staffed.  You don't have to wait long to be assisted and the staff is terribly nice because 1. They let me change my mind several times, 2. They give me samples, and 3. They look pleasant yet professional.  Same goes for the decor; I always feel so very cool hanging out there.  (But why do they need that giant plasma TV?)
author: Miss K.

description:
Four words: wasabi mashed potato salad.

It's addictive. I'm telling you.
author: Fawn F.

description: I went here last weekend for the first time.  I love the concept and the food was excellent.  It was a bit pricey but the view and the sleek, modern interior made up for it.  Their service was pretty bad, though.  Being that it was the first time I had ever been there, I was a bit confused (do I grab a pre-prepared bento or do I order one? where are the drinks?) and the cashier was anything but helpful.  A smile and a "can I help you?" would have made this a 5 star instead of 4.  But it was so good, I'll be back.
author: Noor A.

description:
Compared to beef curry at On the Bridge, Muracci's, and Osakaya, Delica rf-1, had the yellowest sauce and small portions of beef, some cubes of which were dry or tough. I ordered a regular-sized serving. Neither beef nor rice were as moist and tender as On the Bridge's beef curry but it did have more meat and even included potatoes. I don't recall having the standard ounce of magenta-colored pickled veggies on the side though.

Salmon onegiri was bland but healthy - it used brown rice with flecks of salmon interspersed throughout. I was expecting a salty lump of salmon in the center, but that's not how they make onegiri here. No seaweed wrapper either, just a single band-aid strip of seaweed.
author: Lum P.

description: Came here with a group of co-workers for lunch. I went for the freshly cut spicy tuna roll and miso soup, while others went next door to the mexican restaurant. We joined together outside to eat along the water which was absolutely beautiful on this not-so-cold day in San Francisco. The spicy tuna roll was great, a little too big, but still tasty. The miso soup was the perfect way to keep warm. It's a great quick lunch spot, but probably wouldn't come back if I'm looking for a relaxing sushi spot with a big variety of rolls.
author: Casi C.

description: I've never been here before until we decided to browse around the Ferry Building for a place to eat.  We decided to give this place a try and and I'm glad did.  This place is fantastic there is a great selection to choose from health yet still flavorful and appetizing.  They offer some unique food selections that I haven't seen before - next time I will try it out.
author: Regina N.

description:
I love their Katsu sandwich. 
We ate curry rice.  Rice was dried, meat was hard. Looks like left over.I was not able to chew the meat. Means they don't do test the quality for their product before they serve. Means they don't care bout customers, they care about money stealing from customer. This small thing is the reflection of their attitude, they don't care about customers.  Shame on you.

 Regarding Japanese style curry, Ebis and  Muracchi's are much better because of its freshness. I know Delica's one was so good at their beginning days while ago. This curry rice quality was completely down and no value. Don't choose curry rice.
author: AI T.

description:
Their deli food is ok. some of them are innovative. Their presentation is good. Good sense. 

The problem is price. Retatively expensive for what they offer. After all, they are "DELI" food. High price is more for look than for actual taste.

Another problem is a customer service. One guy clerk is so arrogant. His attitutede is like "I am superior than you.". I felt like buying "DELI" food from a rich CEO.

 Female clerks are better. They are helpful and no attitude problem.
author: Dove P.

description: I love the curry here! They have mushroom and beef and both are equally awesome! Served with either brown or white rice, this meal is very satisfying! Potato croquettes and wasabi mashed potatoes are also on my list for come backs! A bit pricy so I limit my cravings to once a month.
author: MiSa S.

description: The wasabi potato salad and mushroom curry w/fried lotus is sooooo good!
author: Denise A.

description:
pros... love it here, reminded me of a trip to a japanese super market, but a good one of course.  it's like bento boxed lunch heaven.  just love the care and presentation of the food and the boxes.  it's just great, and the food looks so fresh and tasty as well.  had the tonkatsu, just something simple and tasty. also had the green tea drink to go.  all good.

cons... wish we had something like this in san diego.  a bit on the high side for prices.  but the food, i believe is worth it.
author: Joel G.

description:
Upscale, fast Japanese.  The food is good but the prices come at a premium.  I definitely like the interesting combos they think up, like wasabi edamame potato salad.  The tempura is yummy and if I recall, made with organic veggies.

This place is great for bento boxes, but if you want a discount with the same quality, go to Nijiya Market in J-town.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Consistently delicious Japanese inspired and Japanese food. Hurray!
Consistently over the top -sell my house and dog to afford to eat here - prices.  Boo!
author: K N.

description: This place is ridicously overpriced for the portions and other than the spicy burdock root salad the food is kind of mediocre. In fact you can go to Nijaya supermarket and get just as good food which I think says a lot. I think this places stands out given that it is the only Japanese place in the Ferry Building but if you were to locate it in, for example, Japantown you just know this would just bomb huge.
author: Procter F.

description: I love this place! You taste quality in each bite! Had the 5 item bento, and really loved the potato salad and chicken dumpling. I learned that they also have dinner now. Will definitely come back for dinner. I just love this place!!
author: Michael-Paggy W.

description: Have been here several times for a more special lunch experience, and often order the curry. Am a little sad, I swear they had a lamb mushroom curry that was absolute luxury and was a little confused by comments made in my Muracci's review about a shrimp curry but... went recently yet once again to meet a friend over some Ito-En green tea and lucious bentos and was satisfied with their regular beef curry! Still, after two years of patronage Delica has failed to disappoint. It's efficient line system, it's variety of obento options and smaller take-home dishes, and it's loyal relationship with delicious, cold refreshing Ito-En teas just makes Delica my place of choice to go to while lunching in the FiDi, or before a day out to the farmer's market on Saturdays. About $10 a person, it is a bit pricey but still somewhat normal for city rates and totally acceptable as an occasional treat.
author: Jessica L.

description:
An excellent find for true sake connoisseurs. Try Ban-ryu! And if you think it doesn't get better than that, then try Sui-jin, which is simply beyond awesome. Just ask for the sake sampler  - Oka, Okuden Kantsukuri and Yamahai 50 Nama. 

I liked the sushi and their tapas preparations a lot. Very reasonable.
author: Ben B.

description: This place is bomb, even for a vegetarian.  Healthy seaweed soybean salad along with a tofu steak (is that an oxymoron or what?  what's with meatifying tofu?) and rice all for $7 - can it get any better?  Yes, it can. Eat outside on the top deck overlooking the beautiful SF pier with a friend, and maybe you'll have as a divine time as I did today.  Or you might just get checked out top bottom by a lady walking by.  Oh, San Francisco.
author: Megha S.

description:
my numero uno complaint about this place from the get-go has been remedied: the lines.  they moved cash registers and made it happen and its much smoother and less complicated in there even when packed to the gills.

couple things are still overpriced (read: sushi rolls) but everything else is so, so worth it.

oh delica, i am so glad you won me back.
author: Jen H.

description:
Highly recommend this place for lunch !
Had the Curry Shrimp over rice 
Very fresh ...
Somebody --- anybody --- Go to this place and tell me what you think ?
just walk straight down Market street till you hit the Ferry Building 
Go in the front door --- straight ahead to the right ...
author: Roy L.

description:
Good clean fusion Japanese food that your stomach will thank you for eating.
$10.00 for lunch and yummy.
author: Ricardo O.

description: I wish I live right next to Delica!!! I can have everything from Delica for lunch and dinner... everyday and never get tired of it.  It's one of the best fusion deli places for lunch.
author: Shirley Z.

description:
This was the only place on Monday during lunch hour that didn't have a huge line so my friends and I decided to go here. I would say that the food is pretty good but expensive.

What I ordered:
 - Rice triangle thingy: Edamame, some other stuff, rice, seaweed...actually quite nice and light.
 - Roast beef sushi: YUM, this was good. The ground radish on top was a nice touch
 - Sweet chicken bento box: Filled with veggies and only 3 pieces of chicken, it would not be enough alone

My other friends got some of the other items but I didn't really try it. The consensus was that it was very expensive for what you get, my order was over $15. There are definitely better values in the city, but if you are in the Ferry building craving Japanese food, Delica it is.
author: Matt K.

description: I got food poisoning yesterday. I immediately didn't feel well after eating. Had the tofu steak, wasabi potato salad, and the eggplant salad. I suspect it was the eggplant salad because it had chicken in it. Which sucks because I'm a vegetarian and didn't think that eggplant salad would come with chicken. They should have called it chicken eggplant salad. Who expects meat in salad? Anyways, avoid this place unless you want your kidneys to hurt like hell.
author: Greg M.

description:
This is the only place that we get served at our office for lunch that i've actually taken the initiative and visited on my own time. It helps that i live nearby i suppose.

Anyways, let it be brief: i like the curry here and their fried finger foods are delicious. I wish they'd be more consistent and make the eggplant salad year-round because that is probably the most flavor you can pack into one bite. Delicious.
author: Steven L.

description: Awesome Japanese fusion foods along with delicious traditional Japanese dishes. One thing I really miss that they apparently don't make anymore is the crab croquette...
author: Brian T.

description: Bento with seaweed and crabcakes, enjoyed with compostable chopsticks, sitting overlooking the bay, in the company of my favorite young poet.   Good food, healthy food, lovely weather, great company.  Delica can't claim credit for all of that, but I'll give it 5 stars anyway, because it was a 5-star lunch for me :)
author: Joe C.

description:
wandering thru the ferry building on a weekday afternoon w/the mr is always enjoyable. on this particular day, i was ready to slab a baguette with butter and call it lunch. mr x mandated i have some "real" food so i begrudgingly approached delica. im not a fan of bento boxes, too many compartments and too complicated. the bentos here are definitely some of the better one's you'll see around. very fresh and unique selections. the deli case had so many interesting and pretty items i decided to sacrifice my carbs and butter and give them a shot. 

i nibbled on some chicken pieces, age-dashi tofu steak, tofu salad, and the wasabi potato salad. all delicious...not overly flavored just the way japanese cuisine should be. and service was top-notch with the guy behind the counter patiently waiting while i spent a good five minutes walking back and forth deciding what to get and if i should really settle for healthy fare instead of my beloved acme bread. total came to around $10...which is not bad at all for what you get. i'm definitely adding delica to my list of favorites!
author: helen l.

description: A japanese tapas deli?!  That's exactly what this is.  A smorgasbord of small bites.  So many clever dining choices at the Ferry Building.  The sweet and spicy chicken is delicious, albeit a little pricey at $1.25 for each little hunk!  But what else is new here?  Its almost impossible to escape the Ferry Bldg. without spending $40.  The chinese chicken salad is a little oily, but has some nice crunchy veggies in it.  The roast beef sushi is unique; try one ngiri's worth.  There are numerous other items that look intriguing, including a generous selection of vegan and vegetarian items, and a great cold case of flavored teas (try the apple).  The communal tables out in the hall are fun.
author: Rick H.

description: One of my favorite spots in the Ferry Building. Chicken dumplings, green bean salad, eggplant salad are great. They used to do a high-protein quinoa lunch bowl that i loved. I hope they bring it back. Soba noodle soup is just okay.
author: RK L.

description:
i will gladly pay you on tuesday for a bento box today...

jesus h.christ this place is delicious.  i think we spent $47.00 on the most amazing dumpling i've ever eaten and a hot tea.  i don't care, if i'm ever homeless i will seriously panhandle outside the ferry building for three days just for one of those fucking dumplings.  

but can whitey get a fork and not be forced to steal one from the mexican restaurant?
author: Jessie J.

description:
I've had lunch here at least ten times.  If I lived close by, I'd come here all the time.    

PRE-REVIEW RANT:
I'm going to rant for a moment so skip this if you don't want to hear...

It drives me crazy when people complain about food prices when the food is always fresh, made with the best ingredients, and the environment you can get this type of food is beautiful both design and location - beautiful bay view.  Enough already!  This is the Bay Area.  We are darn lucky to have access to any of this.  AND, it drives me crazy when people bash on the Ferry Plaza as being a tourist crazy whatever.  Yes, there are a lot of tourists but if you didn't live in SF, were visiting, and loved food, wouldn't you want to visit the Ferry Plaza?  Wouldn't you marvel at how LUCKY San Franciscans are to have such a beautiful view when buying fresh organic produce from local growers, and then can simply walk inside to buy a cast iron skillet at Sur la Table to cook the organic, totally in season, butternut squash they just bought?  I was in Burlington Vermont a few years back and you wouldn't believe how hard it was to find fresh arugula and baby spinach.  Stop complaining please.  Sheesh!

Okay rant over.  Smile, happy feelings, think about cupcakes, and opening presents, and your favorite song. . .okay we're back in a happy place. 

So yes, I love this place.  The hijiki and soybean salad is one of my favorites.  The chinese chicken salad rocks.  I could eat the fish cakes every day.  I've even had the roast beef sushi. . .I know sort of strange but it's really good.  

If you're the type of person who likes to eat healthy but also likes to eat fancy, AND you don't have a problem shelling out a little extra $ for something different and good, you'll like Delica rf-1.

Oh yeah, the people who work there are nice!
author: James M.

description: They seem very clean and care about the food they serve. Some vegan options, recommend for lunch!
author: 0 L.

description: Sushi was very fresh the salmon roll was awesome. The other rolls were very small, not impressive, i think this place is more for nigiri and sashimi. Atmosphere is nice, wait staff is courteous. However, food wasn't as impressive.
author: Dennis K.

description:
Look, I apologize in advance that this will be an annoying review.  Maybe not the most annoying ever, but I'll be pushing it.  I can't help it.  Here is the usual caveat:  My family is from Japan so I am compelled to measure Japanese places, however it is spun (I dunno, is fusionified a word?), with my extremely fine-tuned and calibrated meterstick.  Oh no no, I don't even use a yardstick to measure Japanese food.  It's gotta be metric.  

But I must include an additional caveat that I studied postmodern critical theory.  So, really, instead of reading this review, I think you ought to read Roland Barthes's "Empire of Signs"--his excellent mini-book about his trip to Japan--especially the chapter on Japanese food.  He can talk about signs and signifier/signified mumbo jumbo better than I, in a poetic, poignant writing style to boot.  This place really makes me think of all that crap I had to read and spew out in 20 page term papers.

Delica bills itself as a sohzai/okazu-ya, a prepared food deli selling hot and cold Japanese dishes.  There are about 4-5 salad selections (my faves:  hijiki salad and green bean/sesame salad) and 4-5 fried food selections you can get individually or in a multi-item bento box.  Also, they have items like curry and soba that don't quite fall in the "sohzai" category.  The cold dishes are healthy and are pretty much vegetarian.  The hot dishes are fried and meaty (I haven't tried the potato croquet, but traditionally those have ground meat in them so if you're veg, ask first.).  I think the food is pretty tasty, but definitely not make-a-special-trip-to-Ferry-Building or call-my-Mom-and-tell-her-I-found-a-replacement-cook good.  I also have a beef (and not delicious rare beef sushi) with the fact that they count rice as an "item" in the bento.  Apparently, one of Delica's twists on Japanese is not getting the math right.  That's like a BBQ joint saying a three-way is chicken, ribs, and bread.  Or Panda Express telling you that a two-item plate is orange chicken and rice.  In Japan, rice ain't an "item."  It's a blank, if you will, to cleanse palates, catch dripping sauces, and dilute strongly flavored foods.

I think what makes me feel really "whatever" about this place is that it's wishy washy in whether it wants to be a haute fusion fast food joint or to be as true-to-form sohzai-ya as one can be in the Ferry Building.  I would embrace either extreme in its fully fledged form, but for now, I wonder why a kakiage (bits-n-pieces tempura) is cylindrical instead of flat and round.  Or why they put daizu (mature soy beans) AND edamame (young soy beans) in the hijiki salad.  Meaning, the twist they put on the original version doesn't elicit an "aha!" reaction, in that it's not functional to the actual flavor.  If they're gonna be half-assed about coming up with their own version of Japanese classics, why not go authentic and show everyone a new facet of the cuisine that's not sushi or ramen or teppan-yaki?

So yes, it's annoying that I am not really critiquing the food or the service, but the concept of the restaurant.  But what can I do?  I gotta do something with my college education.
author: maiko h.

description: It was YUMMY food.  But when we first got there the ordering process was a little bit confusing.  Thankfully we were with a pro, who helped us figure out how to get the food we wanted.  The drink selection was a bit limited.  But I would totally go back!
author: Nikki c.

description: wonderfully filling and delish bento boxes!  a bit pricey for what you get compared to LA prices, but still tasty and worth the experience.
author: Janice M.

description:
the ingredients here are fresh! and the food is good asian fusion.

always great when its sunny out, stroll around the pier, and grab some food and sit outside.

however, this place is way overpriced (as is probably most of the places in the ferry building)
author: Jh M.

description: Delica is delicious, type-R. I had the beef curry BC-076 and it caused irregular heartbeat due to savory overload X. I also got a neat reusable bag with the deli's logo on it to help me carry the backbreaking amount of curry back to the office. VTEC kicked in and I was soon covered in golden gravy.
author: Kevin L.

description:
a second chance for delica rf-1 bumped them up from 2 stars to 3. they no longer have the corn cream croquette on their menu, or maybe it's just a seasonal thing. who knows. but i felt like giving them another shot and tried their crab cream croquette, salmon and cream cheese spring roll and wakame salad.

the breading of the croquette was perfect and not too oily; the filling was a bit too creamy but quite flavorful. the salmon spring roll was rather interesting since i wasn't too sure what to expect when i bit into it. and the wakame salad looked different from what a typical one looks like but it still tasted basically the same (plus it wasn't even on the menu but they were able to make it for me anyway).

there's variety to the menu, but not much that i'd actually want to order. so that puts a ceiling on their rating, at least for me.

10/13/06 Original Review:
overpriced, bland pseudo-japanese food.  maybe i'm just bitter because they didn't have the croquette when i wanted it.  i'm never coming back here (unless they have the corn cream croquette, then i'll consider it)
author: spiff e.

description: When you walk into this place everything seems to be methodically in place and organized not to mention impeccably clean. You get to choose from a couple of bento plates that are pre-packaged, but fresh off the oven or fryer or broiler...I ended up having one of these bento plates with fried shrimp cakes, organic asparagus with sesame dressing, some sorta noodle thing, and rice...although it was very tasty and delicious the price was kinda on the steep side for a small little bento dish, nevertheless still worth it...I want to try out their chicken dumpling next time, which looked pretty tasty as well and i'm sure it is...very cool place to check out
author: murs.one ..

description:
This should be a 5 star rating. The food is worth five stars. 

That being said, I found it INCREDIBLY irritating to come in during a busy lunch rush-hour and not have a CLUE which of the three lines I needed to stand in. As I waited in line about 30 minutes, I concluded that the right-most line is for "hot lunches". The middle line is just to pay for things, and the LEFT line is for "cold lunches". If you by chance wait in the wrong line, only to find they have what you wanted pre-packaged, they will not even humor you by scooping your 1/2pint fresh from the deli case-- they go and reach around the counter and pick up one in the self-serve case and hand it to you. Well, if I could've actually seen how this procedure should've gone, or (and, imagine this) if they'd have had the lines MARKED, I could've done just fine with the self-serve and the "Pay only" line in the middle. Assuming I could've transversed the ten thousand people between the two. In fact, I think I'd have had to walk out the door (THIEF!) and then come back in the OTHER door in order to do that. 

The employees were curt and I don't like that they have a sign warning a credit card minimum as it goes against their merchant agreement with Visa/MC. They really should've just humored me by taking my order and grabbing it out of the deli case like I stood in line waiting for.  And get some damn signs to instruct the flow, already!
author: Jen S.

description: I ate here for lunch today and was pretty impressed.  I had the 3 salad combo for $8, and the food was fresh and flavorful!  My favorite was the hijiki salad- vegan, super healthy and very flavorful.  The seasonal eggplant salad was also delicious, but the seasonal green bean salad was a bit bland.  The service was fast and friendly.  The food was not cheap but the prices seemed fair for the quality of the food.  Most importantly, I loved, LOVED the chopsticks.  They were really smooth wooden chopsticks- not the splinter variety.  Another nice feature- all of the veg and vegan options are clearly marked, making selections easy for the non-meat eaters.
author: J O.

description: This place is my dream lunch spot. I miss working down on the embarcadero because this was so convenient! The veggie roll is amazing- like a combination of veggie sushi and raw spring roll (wrapped in rice paper) with just the right amount of wasabi mayo. And lord knows I love the mayo. I can't get off that stuff. Anyways, I have also partaken of several catered lunches for work from Delica and they put together a very nice spread for a pretty reasonable price. During the summer, they had a really yummy sweet white corn and tomato salad made with cow girl creamery mascarpone. I also love the hijiki (sp?) salad and I dream about the green beans in that creamy miso dressing topped with sesame seeds. MMM. Plus, you can pig out on this stuff and really not feel guilty about it. I should get myself a Delica fix soon...it's been far too long...
author: Rachael S.

description: I came here for lunch with a friend and tried to go healthy, foregoing all the fried options. I had the #2 lunch combo.. 3 kinds of salad of your choice. I had the spinach, gobo, and seaweed salads. YUM.. pretty pricey, but I think it's typical of lunch at the ferry building.
author: tessie n.

description: Killer shrimp cake. They have some elegantly prepared food that taste very good and health. The 9 compartment bento filled with well prepared veggie were pretty good. I am not a heavy veggie eater too!
author: S.K. Y.

description: When the Farmer's Market isn't here, the Ferry Building is just  kind or boring. Delica breaks up the snoozefest with its awesome Japanese deli offerings.  The perfect snack consists of a potato and corn croquette, a piece of tonkatsu and a super cold ITO green tea.
author: Maria D.

description: I love the mushroom salad -- it's very refreshing! The potato croquette and pork cutlette are very tasty.
author: Joanne B.

description:
We stopped by on a Sunday morning and got a couple salads and the chicken/tofu burger.  

Spicy Burdock root salad:  Had greens, and some lotus root.  The sauce was vaguely sweet and very tasty.  Ate it all even without knowing what "burdock" really is...

Hijiki  & soybean salad:  Also vaguely sweet and very tasty.  

Tofu/chicken patty:  They give this to you cold, not sure why.  It looked better than it tasted.  The sauce on it was still gelatinous, not very appetizing.  Would not get this unless they are willing to heat it up.

Kaki-age: wonderful fried goodness.
author: ann l.

description: This place looked promising.  I was a bit intimidated and confused on the menu and the glass case, and not quite sure how to order.  I ended up getting a bento box from the glass case.  It was just okay.  I was definitely expecting better.  No plans to return.
author: Erin L.

description: Only one experience here so I couldn't try all they had. I ordered their lunch special plate #1, which had some baked tofu and two kinds of salad. Tasty and Healthy for not too much money. I have to get back!  Limited seating.
author: Phil T.

description:
My office used to be located 30 seconds from the ferry building, so I was a regular of Delica . 

Their food is excellent, gourmet Japanese home cooking.  Their tonkatsu is made from quality pork and panko.  The meat is very tender and the skin is perfectly seasoned.  It come with some source, but I prefer no source on their tonkatsu to enjoy the flavor of the tender meat.  I was searching for a good tonkatsu in the United States and finally found it at Delica.
author: Deb R.

description:
Probably one of the strangest restaurants I've been to in a while. The decor is half-way modern (seating) and half-way old-school (food prep area). For instance, the old school butcher-shop weighing machines are completely at odds with the contemporary island/bar seating which is completely at odds with the 50's music playing in the background which is completely at odds with the fact it is a Sushi and Japanese Tapana restaurant with a strong emphasis on local and sustainable food choices. THEN, even though it is bar seating you get waited on by wait staff who walk around and have no comfortable place to stand when talking to you except right over your shoulder.

I felt like I was Alice & I fell down the rabbit hole when I ate at this restaurant. It was a very confusing experience. I wasn't sure what Delica is going for, and I don't think they are sure, either.

3 stars only because the food is good quality. It isn't very Americanized though, so hopefully you like eating raw fish and raw scallops, raw squid and raw sea urchin. Not for the faint of heart.
author: Vanessa B.

description: Excellent desu. Fresh, delicious, healthy, fast & priced right. My kind of place.
author: Kathy Y.

description: I feel compelled to give a little shout out to Delica today after going to Muracci's on Kearny and comparing the Japanese curry at these two fixtures of the "FIDI Japanese curry scene". While both have equally yummy curry sauce, the meat at Delica was definitely much higher quality (Muracci's contained several pieces of pure fat and some other weird non beef stew, but supposedly beef type pieces) and the portion size at Delica was about 50% larger, although about $2 more expensive. Overall though, no doubt that Delica will forever be my choice for curry while in FIDI.
author: Jeff L.

description: I'm downgrading from 4 stars to 2 stars. In the 2 years I've been going there, the menu hasn't changed at all! But, more importantly, the quality has proven to be incredibly inconsistent. Today, I spent $9 for a "beef curry" dish. It was 50% soggy white rice and 90% curry sauce and 8% potato and 2% beef. That brings the cost of the beef to something like $200/pound. The only real food in the whole thing was two tiny small pieces of beef. Ridiculous! I've often also had miso soup there that was undrinkable. Once, it was literally 30% wakame. Wakame should be just a few strands in a cup of miso. There's just no care given to the food anymore - it's like a factory on auto pilot.
author: Eater S.

description: I'm both fascinated and frustrated with Delica. This marketplace boite is cool and stylish but I just can't figure it - or the food out. I think I have fairly sophisticated tastes but every time I walk in here I end up walking out empty-handed. Why? I guess I'm a bit intimidated by the selection and lack of familiarity I have with what's on offer. While I stand at the display cases looking at all of the pricey Japanese delicacies, I feel that someone - from the business side of the counter - should take note of my confusion and step forward with a smile and offer to help; yet they never do.
author: John B.

description: When I'm in the city and craving an exotic salad, Delica is where I usually turn to.
author: J H.

description:
yum~~!!

roast beef nigiri - a lot more wasabi than i expected but still love it
wasabi potato salad - faint taste of wasabi wonderful~
chinese chicken salad - tastes good and proportional to each other
green bean salad - tastey and crunchy, nice sesame flavor
tofu steak - had bits of bamboo i think on top tastes really good with rice
crab croquette - warm and creamy crunchy on the outside
tofu n chicken n hijiki meatball - tastes like grandmas!!! yumm!!

forgot what the name of the fried vegetable thing with shrimp was but that was also really good...almost the same as my grandmas tooo~~

i want to come back more often but it closes after i get off work ARGH~!!
author: phillip w.

description: soba noodle soup, mushrooom curry, didn't care for either tho people seem to like it on yelp. did enjoy the potato corquette and salmon. maybe we didnt get the right items. either that delica is just not our cup of tea.
author: Helen L.

description: I always eat at Delica when I am hungry for tasty food but I still want to eat healthy.  I love their salmon brown rice balls.  I once took 7 and the workers there gave me a dirty look since it was lunchtime.  But don't worry, I didn't give a damn since I live in the east bay and I hardly get over there.  Everyone should also try their hijiki salad and the ohitashi.  Fresh and delicious.  I don't eat any red meat, so that's about all I can vouch for.
author: Annie F.

description: We had the vegetable mushroom and chicken Japanese style pancakes from this little delicatessen.  They were tasty, but a little on the expensive side at $5 each.  They had a very sorted and convenient recycling bin group, for every kind of trash.  Eating our pancakes with the view of the bay was relaxing.  We'll be back to try out other dishes when we are in the area.
author: Daniel H.

description:
straight from japan and quite successful
so good, wish i could add it to my lunch rotation.  refreshing small bites, healthy, and tasty.  go for the seasonal bento and you'll be hooked.  oh yeah, the crazy looking tempura thingie is a bit soggy rather than crispy

bentos really good, try the one with the chicken meatball
interesting potato, lima bean, wasabi
also good veges, just a solid place
author: Rob C.

description:
Last time we were at Delica, one selected the food at one counter, then got in line to pay for  it at another counter.   But we bought a  big pile of stuff, and they said we had to move it WITHOUT HELP  to the check out counter.  Our hands were full, but they specifically said they could not help us move it to the check out counter.  They had no other customers and the sales girl behind the sales counter watched us struggle to move these items to the cash register while saying that this was more efficient to have us struggle to carry it all ourselves than to  offer help.  And she specifically explained this was more efficient than had she had she helped us &  there were her empty hands.

We have come here for years and each time they have a worse check out system.    So, the new check out system is ludicrous.   And hearing this from a sales associate/princess when there are no other customers & she can't pick up a container of the food that is sold on the  premises and bring it to the register.  

The management obviously abrogated its responsibilities
author: Deborah W.

description: Japanese deli!  Fantastic!  Every 'fusion' dish I've tried actually works.  The beef sushi is awesome.  The wasabi potato salad is great.  My favorite - the beef (now lamb) curry.  This is not really a fusion dish; it's made in the Indian style, but it's very good.  Kinda pricey, but hey, the Ferry Building is a tourist trap.
author: Anthony R.

description: After working nearby for near 3 years, I finally got around to trying out the Vegetarian Bento Box. It was tasty and there were a plethora of interesting flavors in the various small sides that made up the box. I would have loved a bit of rice with my veggies, though. If they'd included that and dropped the price of the box $2, I would easily have thrown them another star.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description:
During my entire trip up and down mid to southern Japan, I did not go a block or two without passing a convenience store with a plethora of various flavored Onigiri. And it is this reason that it remains a wonder why there aren't more Japanese restaurants offering more variety, or making it a staple on their menus. That is, instead of offering various sushi rolls, that you do not find very often. I'm quite aware that Onigiris are found in convenience stores and as such I should find them in the Japanese markets, etc... but still it leaves me to wonder.

So with Eto En green tea, a cup of Miso soup, Hijiki and Salmon flavored Onigiris in hand, I was ready to take my first bite. I had the Hijiki to start, and expected something fabulous, something magnificent, and to my disappointment didn't quite get that or well something that awful. I wasn't sure what to make of the rice ball. It was mild to taste, and not as flavorful as I would have liked it. I had relatively more tamed Onigiris in Japan, because I was afraid to make the dive into the more tasty varieties, but this takes that to a whole new level. I figured it was just that particular one, and went onto my Salmon ball. I still distinctly remember my last few bites of my Japanese fare, and expected nothing less here. Again, disappointed. Unlike the Japanese variety, the salmon is mixed with the rice, and so bits and pieces are scattered, you see it, and you can make out the taste of it, but it didn't affect the overall quality. 

I'm going to be making a couple more rounds of Onigiri tastings at various other restaurants in Oakland and SF in the next couple of days, by this time Sunday, I will have a better grasp on what to expect of the American fare. 

Oh, and the miso was something quite forgettable. I don't think the sun had anything to do with it.
author: Angela C.

description: This place has quality Japanese food for a nice price tag.  Even the name looks expensive.  I had some kobe beef sushi pieces that costs about $5 each.  That $5 tastes good.  I will go back once I win the lottery.
author: Fatty A.

description: We use to go to this place all the time when we were done with the Farmers Market.  But recently, we found the food and service has declined.  Still like the Bento Boxes they offer, while still overpriced for the amount of food you're getting, but it's the city so that's part of the deal.  I wouldn't recommend it if you're hungry at lunch time since it will not fill your appetite.  It's ok but use to be much better in the past.
author: Neil K.

description:
the beef and mushroom curry?  authentic and hearty.

the soba?  light and tasty.

the crab croquette?  creamy and rich.

definitely a must-try, if you're a japanese food snob (or just a foodie in general), like me!
author: Jill k.

description: Delica is my go-to for lunch.  The food is always fresh, tasty and consistent.  The ingredients used are high quality.  My favorites are the green bean or asparagus (seasonal) salad with sesame dressing, tonkatsu, various croquettes, wasabi potato salad and chicken dumplings.  The logistics could be improved (lunch plate line can move very slowly) but otherwise, great!
author: K L.

description: I love their roast beef sushi!  Prices here are a little expensive but I am willing to spend out a couple of extra dollars for some good Japanese food.  The mushroom curry has a very sweet distinct taste and like the other reviewers, it reminds me of food that I could buy in a  department store.   I like the casual atmosphere and the extensive display of salads, rolls and bento boxes.
author: Jen L.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!  i love the causal ambiance... fusion style... light and healthy food.  The bento box idea allows you to combine different side dishes and main entrees together.
author: Mandy C.

description: Yum!! I got the fried crab croquette ($3.75), which was so tasty. It is crab mixed with bechamel sauce and fried in tasty panko breadcrumbs or something. Delicious, warm, rich. I also like getting the $2.00 salmon sushi rice balls, made with wild salmon and brown rice. Drizzle some soy sauce on it and you're good to go.
author: O K.

description: THE BEST shrimp cake and chicken dumpling you'll ever eat in your life!! fantastic. one of the best things about the fairy bldg...healthy and not at the same time.
author: shanestar h.

description: Delica's "Sushi Bar" is now open!   I was already a big fun of Delica's OBENTO but, I must say, this is "THE BEST" sushi in San Francisco!!  Super Fresh, Light and Clean!  Thanks to Yasu and his team for superb cuisine!
author: Eiko T.

description: I've never seen a Japanese deli, but this one certainly has sold me on the idea. I had lamb curry over rice the first time I went, and it really hit the spot: not too spicy, not too mild. The second time I had their vegetarian sushi, and was very pleased at the combination of flavors it portrayed. Now if only I could figure out what the rf-1 means...
author: Benjamin M.

description: Technically, I haven't eaten at Delica RF-1.  But my girlfriend stopped by and got me a to go meal when she was at the Ferry Building, and dropped it off for me when I was at work.  She got me a tofu steak and seaweed salad, and the meal was amazing.  Maybe my memories are warped by the state of hunger I was in when I ate it, but this was one of the best meals I've had in the recent past.
author: Evan K.

description: great place for a quick lunch. yummy curry. reasonable prices.
author: Judy k.

description: Very fresh ingredients, and creative fusion dishes make this place one of the go-to place in the ferry building.  The tempura udon was really flavorful.  The prices tend to be on the expensive side, however.
author: Min L.

description: Normally I would not write about a place I had not eaten at, however...I want to like this place so I always go in but never end up ordering. It is all so sterile and hygenic looking. It feels like a clean room where you might do something like make computer chips, never something so dirty as eat.
author: Amy E.

description: On a sunny day, this is a good place to grab a healthy boxed lunch and eat outside by the water. Every item sold here taste like home made food you get in Japan. Tasty and healthy. mmm
author: Mai K.

description: Of all the stores in the Ferry Building, I think this place offers the best value and taste.  For $10, you can easily sample 2 selections, I believe, of their very healthy and also delicious selections of Asian fusion entrees.  Fear not about the portions, as rest assured that you will be heartily filled, without too much concern whether or not you've done your healthy any damage.
author: Ginni S.

description: Yummy!  i love this place.  it's a japanese deli.  they offer salads, fried stuff, and expensive green and fruit teas.  i had the bento box today.  for $9.50 you get rice, green bean sesame salad, seaweed salad, and a fried shrimp cake.  they are expensive but they are good.  what i like most is their beef curry.  i love japanese curry and i haven't found a place that serves japanese curry!  unless i'm not looking at the right places.  anyways, the bento box looks small but it was filling.  the shrimp cake alone is $3.75.  it does have shrimp in it!  the seaweed salad comes with edamame, fried tofu, and these reddish orange fruits.  the green bean salad is refreshing.  next on my list to try:  eggplant salad, roast beef sushi, and baked summer peach with custard! all of their food looks fresh and healthly!   must try if you are near the ferry marketplace!  yum!
author: D W.

description:
I am a super big fan of this place.  I have been coming here for so many years I wish I can get some frequent miles credit. Or something like 10% off for loyal customer. But the staff change face year after year. 
    
     I love the fast self-service and their eggplant, (out of season right )  Also their green beans and the dark hijiki seaweed salad are some of my favorites.  It is healthy and tasty. I usually stay away from the fried stuff except for the crab puff.  Their miso soup is better than Japanese restaurants. It has real chunks of tofu and seaweed.
    
      I want to give them four stars, but my last visit, they no longer have crab puffs.  My other complaint is why do they serve white rice only.
author: A Z.

description: 2 salads (edamame salad and green beans with sesame sauce) and rice was like 6.50. It was also filling enough for lunch and I can eat to no end. The ingredients are fresh and it wasn't the most "authentic" Japanese food I ever had but why does it have to be in order to be good? To all the price-whiners: If you're looking for cheap food, what are you doing looking inside the Ferry Building?
author: aaron f.

description: Delica, in the Ferry Building, was my favorite lunch spot downtown.  I loved the potato croquettes, the meatballs, the egg and beef over rice, and the bento boxes.  The ingredients were always fresh, and the food was always so neatly presented.  Love the shops in the Ferry Building in general, and definitely love Delica!
author: Rose W.

description:
This is my fave at the Ferry Building: clean unadulterated flavors and high quality ingredients that justify the higher prices.
The croquettes are great: crunchy on the outside (thanks to breadcrumbs from leftover Acme pain de mie) then creamy and voluptuous on the inside. The salmon, crab and shrimp are delish but the potato, the most humble one at $1.50, is the deal (don't forget to ask for the free matching sauces as well).
The salads are so well dressed too...
author: Sara K.

description: Delica is one of my favorite lunch spots in the city!  Eating here is rewarding because of the frest taste and the superb quality of food.  I was told their food resembles much like the food in Japan and if that's a true statement I can't wait to go to Japan!  I've had the curry, shrimp cakes, chicken dumplings but my absolute favorite are the salads!  Whether its the soybean / hijiki, green bean or seaweed salds they're all very well put together.  I've even taken my mom here for lunch who's not a particular fan of Japanese food but she loves Delica.
author: Michelle D.

description:
While walking to a meeting in the Ferry Building, I noticed Yasuhiro Iwata was setting up a table outside of his restaurant. He told me that he was setting it up to prepare for the coming tourist season and that he wanted to serve his regular customers...
This place is always packed so the pre-packed Bento Boxes are a great idea. He even rounded the prices down to an even 10 and 12 dollars so that the money exchange can go faster. Kudos to you Yasuhiro !
See a short video of the place @ http://sf-lunch.com/2008/04/04/bite-byte-delica-rf-1-%e2%80%93-japanese-delicatessen/
author: SF Luncher z.

description:
Located in the Ferry Building, Delica rf-1 is a rare Japanese find with healthy alternatives! I came on a Saturday afternoon, and this place was continuously packed. At first I was quite flustered since the place was crowded and there were two lines that seemed to have different purposes, but with a little help with some of the customers, we figured out the right line was for taking ready to go meals or to order to be made items like curry, and the left line was the line to pick and choose which pre-cooked items behind the glass you wanted. 

We went with the sushi roll, beef curry, tofu steak with miso sauce, spicy burdock root salad and wasabi garlic potato salad. My favorites were the tofu steak and potato salad. The miso sauce atop the tofu steak totally made the dish. It was perfectly flavored and not too salty. Put with the tofu, it became very refreshing and light. I was wary at first to try the potato salad since it had wasabi, but boy was I glad to have given it a try! There was only the slightest bit of wasabi flavor! The potato salad was drowned with mayo like other restaurants mistakenly do, instead it was lightly coated. The curry was pretty average.
