It was perfectly cooked not. too thick and not too watery, which is another rare find. The sushi was quite interesting in that instead of a seaweed wrapper they used soy wraps. There was barely any rice, but more lettuce. You could almost say it's what happens when Japanese sushi meets Vietnamese spring rolls. The sashimi that was placed on top wasn't very fresh, but otherwise the sushi was what you'd expect if it's been refrigerated and made into a take-out item.

The main reason why I love Delica is because their food is always light and you don't feel the slightest bit sluggish after eating their food.  The only minor problem with eating here and anywhere else in the Ferry building for that matter is because there's a lot of people/tourists making it  always hard to find places to sit. Delica has a few tables of their own, but they're always already taken. If you are able to find a seat, there's a superb view of the bay.
author: Gloria C.

description: The foods they have here remind me of a Japanese home - or at least mine. Albeit more fancy, the flavors and the style are about the same. Hijiki seaweed salad, rice, tofu with a miso sauce. So delicious and the portions are filling. It's nice to see that food like this exists away from home.
author: Ryan Y.

description: With better hours and/or shorter waits than some places in the ferry building, this place is pretty handy.  I like their beef curry, but unfortunately the portions are usually a little small and the beef a little fatty for full points.
author: Bailey S.

description: Some of the best Miso outside of Japan.  Everything was very yummy and I didn't think it was over priced at all.  Plenty of options - you can order ala carte, or get combinations of salad with rice.  The chicken dumplings in chili oil were amazing and not too spicy.  The place is very clean and stylish and feels very authentic.  Some of the stuff is obviously packaged for "grab-and-go" but don't let that turn you off.  Order out of the case and sit while watching the bay and the people go by.
author: Brent F.

description: I'm a big fan of the 3-salad combo, and I'm super happy that I can usually find 3 veggie options for it.  $8 for that doesn't seem too much like highway robbery to me.  The wasabi-mashed-potato salad is brilliant.  I wish it was more obvious how the queues work, as I'm not very clever when I'm hungry.
author: Andi T.

description: I'm a fan of the wasabi potato salad and the salmon and brown rice onigiri.
author: S. D.

description: I love this place! Unfortunately, I have to be in the mood to spend a lot of money because things don't come cheap here.  BUT well worth the price! They have very unique and delicious items. I'm a huge fan of the veggie sushi and the crab cheese croquettes!
author: Angela T.

description: What initially started to be a random lunch turned out to be a "mind-blowing awesome" meal. I was just blown away - such a clean modern space with an awesome view of the bay (you are in the ferry building after all). The Japanese curry was divine. For a real treat, do yourself a favor and get the crab cream croquette... wow, I want to go back right now.
author: Jon N.

description:
Coming to San Fran for a spur of the moment get away with the bf (and to check out the madness that is B2B), we ducked in here after getting some beautiful morning photos of the bay bridge and the hub-bub and hustle of the market outside. There were plenty of options but with a name like Delica rf-1, it's pretty unique and stirred the memory senses of my yelp browsing from yester years. I was a little overwhelmed by the know-how of the regulars and where to stand to order what and such so I took a second to get a lay of the land, perused the deli counter and the bento boxes and decided a sampler plate would be best. I scooped up a bento with a creamy crab croquette, white rice, asparagus salad with a sesame dressing and hijiki and soybean salad. I then went to the counter to custom create a lunch plate #1 with a choice of one entree and two salads.  I picked the tofu and chicken hijiki patty, mushroom salad and a wonderfully aromatic and zesty burdock and lotus root salad. Everything was perfectly prepared, not over-dressed and the proportions were nice. The flavors were especially clean and most had a light "tang" that was a nice contract to the rice and fried croquette. With a bottle of green tea, my total came to just over $22. I recommend getting the lunch plates or bento boxes because some of the salads were costly, upwards of $15.00 a lb. and since they are dressed, the ounces can add up.  My favorites were the hijiki salad and tofu and chicken hijiki patty - didn't really care for the creamy texture to the croquette but of course I ate it anyway. Over-all: 
DELISH DELICA!

****sidenote**** 
You can request to taste anything before you buy. They really DO NOT mind. In fact, they encourage it.
author: Michele B.

description: I love the tonkotsu here and all the salad are fresh and crisp.  Although not your typical Japanese flare, I really enjoy lunch here.
author: Ginny M.

description: The food is fresh here.  But my consistent favorite has been their currys with the croquette in mines and their chicken salad.   Everything else is pretty much okay in terms of flavor.   A bit overprice yes but remember your location. Everything in the Ferry Building is pretty much overpriced except for a few places I can think of.
author: Chris C.

description: Expensive but very high quality.  I have not been disappointed in a single dish.  It's very hard to go wrong with anything on the menu.  The wasabi potato edamame salad, the roast beef sushi, the hijiki salad...everything is really delicious.  I would eat here more often if I could afford it!
author: Margaret F.

description: Expensive, yes.  But so yummy!  Whenever I visit the Ferry Building, I stop by Delica to have a little snack.  I love getting little bites of a variety of things...even their tonkatsu tastes extra yummy.  The bento boxes look like little works of art.  Grab a couple of those and sit out by the water and have a little picnic.  Don't forget to invite me!
author: happy t.

description: They have excellent sushi rolls that are made with rice paper instead of seaweed. Try the salmon and crab ones, delicious!!
author: Shana G.

description:
best tonkatsu ever!!!  the pork is tender, and the panko breading is always crispy.  i hear they make their panko fresh every day with bread from the acme bread co.  quality stuff!  same comments go for the potato croquettes.  soo good!

their salads are really good too.  i usually get the chinese chicken salad, which is chock full of tender chicken.  or, the wasabi potato salad, which is very light and fresh.

i get the lunch special for $7.5 which includes a main item, a salad, and rice.  fills me up for lunch.
author: Cindy K.

description:
panko-fantastique! best croquettes in SF thus far. very pleasing, delicate flavored cold salads: green beans with sesame dressing, hijiki and soybean salad, potato wasabi mash. yum. lots of goodies to fill the bento box. the chicken chili dumplings were tasty, too.

while i would rather go eat oysters at the ferry bldg, delica is a nice change. they have my favorite jasmine tea as well! oh and they're clean and decor is simple, nothing extravagant, but fitting. i'll be back to try the curry!
author: Ligaya T.

description: Super fresh, super tasty.  Hot, cold, fried, steamed, raw.  Whatever you're craving.  Personal faves: $1.50 salmon-rice-seaweed triangle, chicken-tofu-waterchestnut patty, wasabi potato salad with edemame, crunchy romaine & daikon.
author: Melanie C.

description: I love the shrimp cakes and the chicken dumplings here. We stopped by the ferry building to go to Sur La Table and popped in to grab a snack. I had to show my gf my favorite thing to order here. I'd give it more stars but as good as it is, it is ridiculously over priced. A guilty pleasure everyone once in awhile.
author: Hyung L.

description: Delica totally rocks my taste buds with their Californian influenced Japanese food.  This place is really cheap compared to the Westfield Food Emporium's Mr.Hana ( My thoughts of Mr.Hana are nasty overpriced unauthentic Japanese food wannabe).  How could anybody beat their 5 item Bento box for $9.75?  I would've expected this place to cost more than your regular lunch take-out spots, since it's located inside the Ferry Building too.  All of their salads are outta of the world, especially the spicy burdock roots salad and chinese chicken salad.  My favorite dish from here will definitely be the tofu chicken patty topped off with shaved daikon.  All I gotta say this place is a bargain and they have the best selection of non-traditional Japanese food.  Did I mention the food they served are totally healthy? Even their fried items aren't greasy and oily at all.
author: KC K.

description: There's just something about eating seaweed and tofu that makes me feel all healthy and virtuous, so I go to Delica rf-1 at least once a week to get my fix. I'm not sure how many places can make seaweed and tofu taste so delicious, so cheers to Delica rf-1 for creating such wonderful salads and bento boxes. They get extra bonus stars for figuring out a way to incorporate California's seasonal ingredients into Japanese cuisine. One star deduction because sometimes the seaweed gives me a momentary feeling of ickiness.
author: Heather F.

description: Working at the Ferry Building, I try to eat something other then the food that is served at the restaurant I work at. (not that it's not good, I just get tired of eating Vietnamese food all the time) So I  went to grab some food here. Got a bento box with four different things. Deep fried scallops, shrimp cake, a ground chicken patty with tofu and some vegetables. The scallops were juicy and the chicken patty was deliciously well seasoned. My meal was definitely satisfying!
author: Juliane N.

description: Fresh-a-rama! Oh my, was it ever a beautiful San Francisco day today.. Its mid-January my friends and the embarcadero was lit up like the end of August! Who'd have thunk it? The best news is my morning meeting was right near the Ferry Bldg, which meant I was high-tailin' it over to this eatery for amazing, organic japanese food I could sit on a bench with and be delighted by. I was not disappointed. I love their salads, the mushroom and seaweed are both fantastic, and anything with tofu here is a good choice, its tender! Fish is also succulent.. oh, i could go on and on.. Just go here, pick and choose a picnic worth and sit out in the glorious city and think "gratitude gratitude gratitude..."
author: Rachel S.

description: We went to the Ferry building to get something to eat after the Pride Parade and ended up at DELICA rf-1. I got a bento box with many different things including my favorite - wasabi potato salad. Everything in that box was amazing - great flavors and incredibly fresh. The people working the registers are very friendly and there are many choices of yummy food for fairly cheap. Next time I am at Farmers market, I am definitely stopping there for a snack.
author: Maria V.

description: Nice find inside the Ferry Building!  Everything was very good.  We had the tofu steak, the hijiki salad, the spinach/sesame salad, the potato/wasabi salad, the burdock/lotus root salad, and the tofu/chicken patty.  All dishes tasted great and were executed well in terms of quality of ingredients, freshness, and seasoning.
author: Michelle T.

description: The Lotus Root fries r to die 4:) They should go on the menu.
author: priya j.

description:
came here by chance while checking out the ferry building's farmer's market.  absolute perfect place to come after shopping around & sampling @ the farmer's market.  

japanese bento boxes / deli food.   exactly what my hub was craving for!    
we shared a:
-- bento box w/ spicy fried chicken, eggplant side, a green bean w/ mayo side, & rice.  sides complimented the main entree well.  
we also ordered:
--  1 crab cream croquette (hub didn't care for this.  i thought it was good -- but feels bad -- very rich, creamy & fried on top of that)
-- 1 shrimp & veggie tempura nest tower -- good, but bet it would've tasted so much better right off the fryer.      

we took it to go & sat on one of the benches off the side of the ferry building overlooking the bay.  it was a gorgeous, warm sunny summer day w/ a slight breeze.  another simple pleasure in life............

its a bit pricey -- $9.50 for a bento box.  but good to treat ourselves to once in awhile.........
author: Cindi N.

description: One of the best lunch places in the financial district.  The food is freshly made, tastes delicious, and isn't overwhelming.  I usually get the chicken bento box with the Japanese seaweed salad, which goes for about 9 bucks.  It's a little pricey so I only go here occasionally but it's a real treat when I go.
author: Stephen G.

description:
I have been coming here for about 2 years for lunch at least once a week since I work close by. The freshness and consistent quality of their food is excellent. Not to mention they use local organic produce so you know what you are putting into your body. My favorite items are thier salads, tofu patty, curry beef, and their soba soup noodles. Almost anything you order will taste great. 

I was in Japan for vacation and came back still craving for Delica rf-1! Absolutely top rated in my book.
author: Sherry C.

description: I'll echo the I'd-eat-here-every-day-if-I-could sentiment.  Yummy, healthy, super-fresh and interesting food.   The Summer Bento Box is amazing and the perfect amount of food.  The fact that a place like Delica exists and thrives here is one of the reasons I love SF!
author: Shan K.

description:
I am a frequent consumer at many of the various ferry building eateries.  DELICA RF is unlike any place I have ever been before.  Its a Japanese Deli.  
Initially I was skeptical about this strange concept, but now Delica holds a dear dear place in my tum tum.  Lotus root, with a dumpling and croquette?  Sounds wierd but suprisingly amazing!  Take your Delica box back to your office, or eat outside and check out the serene scenery of the ferry building.  Man I sound like a fairy but it really is good. 
Minus one star for the incompetent, degenerate, employees.
author: Buddy Garrity L.

description: Eh... it was okay.. the kind of food you have to slather in chili sauce to get your satisfaction... yet are still not satisfied....
author: Jessica R.

description: talk about overpriced mediocre japanese food. i got the SMALL beef curry bowl plus a green tea drink and it was over $11.. really? ok i understand that this is all organic and whatever but just because its healthy doesnt mean its gotta taste mediocre. the flavors were not the best and it wouldnt kill ya to give me more meat. for the average commuter lunch, this place is way too pricey.
author: edward k.

description:
A great place to catch a quick lunch. Delicious (and nutritious) bento boxes which remind me of my time in Japan ^_^. 

They use fresh ingredients and have great (authentic) selections. I try to go whenever I can!
author: S. B.

description: I think I start my reviews the same every time. How boring. Anyhow, how did I not know abouT Delica RF-1 and how good it was? It's sorta hidden in one of the side walkways of the Ferry Building, maybe that's why. They have lots of seating, too which is very convenient. The food is sorta Japanese food meets deli. Things like little tonkatsus with sauce, roast beef sushi, okonomiyaki, wasabi potato salad, etc. I had the chicken okonomiyaki and a mini tonkatsu and it was delicious. This is my new favorite lunch place in the Ferry building. About 10 bucks for lunch is acceptable. Yum.
author: Maren P.

description: Although I couldn't get enough of the wasabi soy dressing on the seared tuna salad, I just couldn't help but feel a little meh towards Delica's other offerings. But I'm sure everyone who loves this place is glad there will be one less person in line! :)
author: Nathalie L.

description: the little medallions of tonkatsu, tailor-made for my little bites. SO GOOD!
author: Diana L.

description: First local (and perhaps first USA) outlet of a well-known chain of Japanese take-out delis.  Impeccable quality and presentation, and homesick Japanese and Hawaiians can have a field day here.  Pre-prepared Bento boxes, squid salads, etc.  In the Ferry building, so great view and atmosphere.  Try the Karokke, the Japanese version (in tyical fashion they have improved matters by both adapting and mispronouncing the original) of a Croquette.  Prices a little high under the circumstances.
author: Gil S.

description: Love love love love this Ferry Building take-out eatery.  The flavors are exquisite.  Balanced and consistent yet a delight for the tastebuds.  Recommend the chicken-tofu patty, the fried chicken pieces (3 per order), the Chicken Dumplings and the many salads and bento boxes.  Feels like I am the prepared foods section of a high-end Tokyo department store -- you who have been there know what I mean.  Like Harrods only great-tasting and with endless choices.  That's my Delica!
author: Xander S.

description: Not your typical Japanese fare.  It definitely has a different audience in mind.  Prices are in-line with the rest of the stuff at the Ferry Building, so don't be surprised.  The different salads, fried scallop and shrimp cake are good.  I wasn't impressed with the roast beef sushi and some fresh spring roll\sashimi thing.  You won't find kick-ass sushi and sashimi, but you will find organic ingredients prepared in a contemporary Japanese fashion.
author: Jason A.

description: Delica rf-1 serves good quality Japenese deli food.  I have tried a large array of their offering and I have liked it I have not Loved it!   For me it is not a place to sit down and enjoy-- it is too busy with Peets across the way.   If there was a more of a sit down environment it might feel different.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
umm... wow.  why have i not eaten here until today.

$7.75 for the regular portion of eggplant curry (which is dynamite, $9.75 for the large) and pair it with a $2.00 corn and potato croquette and a $2.00 (unnecessary price gouging, but i knew it would fit the meal) ito en oi ocha green tea (engrish m*&$%#$%@, do you speak it?!) and you have yourself a KILLER tuesday lunch.

it's the good japanese curry, even though it's eggplant, it's nice and starchy and complete with little meat chunks so you'll feel super guilty and have to hit the gym right after work.  the croquette, fried to perfection.  not to oily and delightfully crisp. you're at mixt greens three out of five days of the week anyway.  you might as well throw some carbs and fried goodies in to your diet. 

the gf and i met up for lunch and she had the bento box which looked just as good.  i'll go for that next time... and there will be many next times.  this is quite possibly the best financial district lunch i've ever had.
author: Steven C.

description:
For everyday lunch, pricey. 

But so good - freshness, flavor, and for Japanese bento, stunningly authentic, everything as I remembered it! The vegetable mixes (hijiki, konnyaku, etc.) are a highlight, and the fried stuff (including croquette) is great. They have several small a la carte items too, including a beef sushi which I'll have to try soon...

I have to mention the space - the large open kitchen, high ceiling, clean lines comprised of wood, glass and steel, make it a comfortable place for you to choose your food. Thanks for bringing me, Uni!
author: Josh L.

description: Dropped by here yesterday after the Tuesday farmer's market at Ferry Building. Ordered a small half-pint of Asparagus salad and a potato croquet to go. The salad is soo yummy! although a little on the expensive side.. (a 3/4 filled half-pint of container cost me $5!) Don't forget to ask for a packet of Japanese croquet sauce next time you stop by.
author: Joy H.

description: Expensive.  I'm always surprised to spend $16 on a "sushi" roll, half pint of eggplant salad, and green tea.  Then again, I keep on coming back....Hmm....very Oishii Desu!  Great presentation for takeaway food, and if youre strolling through the ferry building and get thirsty, their Green Tea in the bottles is refreshing and refueling.  Not as crowded as most of the other places in the ferry building too, which is a plus.  I always grab an item or 2 on my way to the Amtrak, and everyone on the train looks very jealous of me :)
author: Cathleya G.

description: Very nice food - fresh, light, delish.  Just a little on the overpriced side, though.
author: Serena Y.

description: Delica is delicious!  The food there is always so fresh and yummy!  It can be a little pricey but worth it.  All of the salads are wonderful!  You can't go wrong with any of them
author: stephanie ..

description: Delica is a great lunch spot.  The place is spotless, service is efficient and they use top quality ingredients.  I like the lamb curry quite a bit.  It's great in cold weather - very hearty.   The fried shrimp cake totally rocks.  It's basically a crab cake made with rock and gulf shrimp instead.  And it has very little filler - just shrimpy goodness.  The crab croquette is mighty tasty too.  I like the Bechamel sauce that's blended with the crab meat.  The roast beef sushi sounds weird, but it's actually quite good... along the lines of a tartar.  The chicken dumpling with sweet chili sauce is also a good choice.  I usually will opt for a curry and another smaller item, but it'd be easy to make a meal out of the smaller items.
author: Saw T.

description: Super Fresh food-- and who can beat the waterfront digs? don't miss the marinated eggplant salad (cold) or the curries. For J-style comfort food, the triangular salmon rice ball hits the spot. No, there is no sugar in the green tea here. It's pretty OG. Yes, the prices are about $2 more than they should be but considering that everything else in the Ferry Building is $3 more than it should be, it's actually a decent deal.
author: Sita B.

description: I come here for lunch at least once a week. $10 for a bento box might seem steep (not including a bottle of green tea), but I think it's worth it. Usually grab some ohashi and eat outside by the bay. Favorites are the chicken balls and the wasabi mashed potatoes...although I've never eaten anything here I don't like.
author: Mi M.

description: Fresh cuisine with unique tastes & presentation styles.  I like ordering from their ala carte offerings.  They offer samples of their dishes so you can be sure to order dishes that are to your tastes.  Small seating area inside and additional common seating areas within the Ferry Building.
author: Atif Q.

description: I love finger foods!  I like to go for lunch and pick up a few little treats. I love their crab croquettes! It's sort of pricey when you load up on a la carte items, but I like a little taste of everything! Plus you can sit there and people watch.
author: Jennifer H.

description: I love it here.  It's fresh, light and they give you the vitamins/nutrients found in their food.  Doesn't get better than that.  $10 for a lunch may seem expensive, but to eat healthy, it's not that expensive.  Their bento boxes let you pick out 1 entree and 2 salads and it's actually enough food.  Plenty of vegetarian and vegan options and they let you know which one is vegan and which isn't.  They are a honest, healthy, great tasting restaurant.  I would come back again and again.
author: AhLin C.

description: Great bento boxes. So great I had to quit going because I was afraid I had a bento box addiction. Which made me think about their bento boxes all the time. I broke down last week, went back and only had one. Oh well.
author: Mitsi M.

description: I come here almost every time I'm at the Ferry Building, be it for lunch or just a snack.  The curries are good, and all the fried stuff is too, but my favorite might be the roast beef sushi.  It's nice that everything is organic, but don't come here expecting a cheap meal.
author: Camila L.

description: The lamb curry rice bowl is the king of comfort food...especially for a cold day spent on the waterfront.
author: carrie c.

description: I wanted to like this place, I really did. Their bento boxes are pretty good, but their beef curry was tomatoey-- what's up with that? And it didn't seem that they stewed it long enough, because the beef was pretty tough...
author: Lester L.

description:
yummmmm.

super cool japanese deli. i had their seared ahi tuna and seaweed/poki over rice and furikake. their crab croquettes were so creamy. and they had rice balls and triangles. i suggest the salmon and brown rice.  but what i love is their selection of Ito-en drinks!

they have Ito-en green tea in apple, and mango flavors. and i can't find them in any asian food store up till now. 

prices are very very very reasonable and you can sit in the deli or outside at the picnic tables on the patio.
author: Maureen M.

description: Not sure where all the love is coming from.  Not bad, but very pricey for what you get.  $9.50 for a 4 item bento box of which one item is white rice.  So really, a 3 item bento box.  The wasabi potato salad was ok, the green beans were overpoweringly drenched in some kind of mayonnaise based dressing that was just too much for me to be able to finish.  The chicken cutlet (like tonkatsu only with chicken) was okay.  I will say that their items seemed like they were made with very fresh ingredients.
author: A L.

description: Without a doubt one of the most unique Japanese eateries in SF.  The food is inspired by traditional recipes but incorporate a modern and organic theme.  I solely come here for the "cold food" which include a wide variety of salads and side dishes.  The flavors are fresh, with each item embodying a distinctly different taste.  A healthy lunch where you walk away knowing you still can blow your daily fat intake on something else later in the day.
author: Brent N.

description: I've taken out food from here several times and I just fine the flavors too jumbled up to be good--too many things all which would be good indivdually all throw in together so the flavors get muddied by everything else.  They are trying too hard to be different and have lost the nice, clean, crisp tastes of the individual ingredients normally found in Japanese foods.  Lots of deep fried things which kills the flavor of whatever the food stuff is.   Priced rather high for the amount of food you get.  Obviously this place is for non-Japanese who really don't know real Japanese food, and tourist who are willing pay for overpriced food.
author: Kai T.

description: Love their salad...yum..yum..perfect light lunch..
author: Eve L.

description: I think they're fried stuff is delicious because it's not greasy at all and it's actually pretty light. It ain't cheap but I like how it's a snacky kind of food that you can enjoy outside or while you're on the ferry to Sausalito or Larkspur. Their bento boxes and salads look good too!
author: Gina R.

description: I went here for lunch to day just to grab a quick bite. The staff was super friendly despite the place being busy during lunch hour. I got the spinach w/ sesame salad, the green bean salad, sweet & spicy chicken and a rice & wild salmon ball. I walked outta there spending $10, thinking i got totally jipped for the small portions i got. But back at my desk, totally full and happily fulfilled, i'm definitely going to go back. Maybe i'll try hanging out there for lunch next time since it seemed like a cool & clean space. Definitely a case of 'you get what you pay for..."
author: Ikeb I.

description: Five stars for the salads, 3 or 4 stars for everything else. Just go for the three-salad combo of Hijiki and Soybean Salad, Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad, and Spinach with Sesame Dressing (Goma-ae). You will feel like a new man or woman, or some combination of the two...and there's nothing wrong with that! Besides the salads, I can only recommend the Roast Beef Sushi. Sounds odd, but I give that bad boy five stars! Also, just ten feet away from one of the best views in California, which...face it, is really the best state on earth.
author: Johnny O.

description: This restaurant reminded me of one of the many thousands of restaurants you find in Tokyo's depaatos -- from the look to the food-- and, that's a good thing!!!  Plenty of cooked and raw food options, fast service, and a decent selection of Japanese drinks.  Oishii desu ne!
author: Tim G.

description:
i've always been curious about their name somes like deli racing team.

the food is pretty and pretty damn good.  it's priced fair considering it's at the ferry building.  good place to go to if you want something quick, but tired of the usual suspects; they really have some cool little bites that you wouldn't find at other japanese restaurants or markets.
author: Alan N.

description: It's so nice to have Japanese food that isn't dominated by sub-par chicken drenched in overly sweet teriyaki sauce.  Delica rf1 serves fresh, flavorful, interesting food for a pretty penny - $9 for the lunch combo of one main item and two salads, or $11 for a 9-item bento box filled with sushi, corn salad, wasabi potato salad, shrimp dumplings, and other deliciousness.  I had the summer bento box this afternoon after spending the morning trekking through the city, and although each individual item was small, the combination of flavors and overall volume of the meal was totally satisfying.  The wasabi potato salad, which also appeared to have some edamame mixed in, was my absolute favorite.  The only thing that was a little off was the sushi - but for sushi, I can go elsewhere.  For Japanese salads that are quick, fresh, flavorful, and satisfying, Delica rf1 is it.
author: Rachel B.

description: Delica rf-1, truly you have mastered the art of Japanese rice. Each perfectly formed kernel is plump, glossy, and firm yet slightly sticky. And the mabo tofu salad? Genius!  I'd have to say Delica serves up one of the best tasting lunches in San Francisco.
author: Will A.

description: I had the shrimp cake and the crab croquette. They were both delicious. I love the yummy panko crumbs that coat them. I'll have to try other things there next time.
author: Diana S.

description: My review of this place is limited to the snacks I grab: they have a great roast beef sushi (they put a little bit of horseradish on the top as garnish): excellent.  And they have a brown rice and salmon triangle (forget the formal name for it, but it is a great little hand-size rice ball in the shape of a 3D triangle) that my kids love for a snack.  Food is fresh, good prices and very yummy.
author: Greg R.

description: If you're looking for a quick and interesting snack, you can stop by here. It's Japanese, sort of. I had a great squash soup and some fried veggies. You just have to be in the mood for it. And there isn't really anything you can eat on the go.
author: Tamara M.

description: For Delica newbies, go with a bento box, an excellent chance to try several of their offerings in one shot. The croquette, wasabi potato salad, the chicken/tofu patty... The bento was 5 for 5 in excellence. Docked a star for being steep in price. What's with the cyberpunk anime name anyway?
author: Maximillian M.

description: This place is just so-so.  i had the eggplant curry. it reminded me of indian curry. it was just okay to me.
author: B B.

description:
I come to the place often to enjoy something healthy and sit by the water and enjoy the outdoors. I usually get the #4 which is steamed rice, a salad and an entree. I get the chicken patty heated and my salad of choice is the potato wasabi salad. Love the edamame beans! 

I recently tried the  chicken okonomiyaki and it was okay. but on the dry side. They have it ready to go on the griddle, and I don't know how long it was there. I do appreciate the time the guy took to put the sauce, mayo and the bonito flakes. Man, those flakes are good and salty. More good though, don't get me wrong. However, I don't think I'll be ordering this again. Unless they make it to order. 

But, awesome food! There are stil new things for me to try. I'll try the roast beef sushi and the curry next.

When I pull out my $10 bill and get change back I sometimes wince, but it's good, it's healthy and I'd rather get this than a cold sandwich for $7.
author: Pauline S.

description: Very tasty!  I love their shrimp cake and their rice dishes are great.  It can be really busy, but that gives you a chance to decide what you want.  Their curries are good, too.  A little pricey, which explains the three star rating.
author: Michelle C.

description: Yummy though really expensive for the quantity you get. And they made me wait inline twice because I was apparently in the wrong one the 1st time! It was a fun experience and we enjoyed what we ate but probably won't go back anytime soon - or at least not when I'm really hungry.
author: Sydney L.

description: I'm from San Diego and I always stop by the Ferry Building to buy wine and other snacks to take home.  So I thought to kill 2 birds with one stone and eat lunch while shopping here.  All their sit down spots were packed as we went during lunch hour so we thought to just get some "to-go" food and eat it outside and enjoy the beautiful scenery.  When we got there, I didn't realize there were 2 separate lines - one for bento and one for plated dishes.  So I picked up one of the bento boxes on the table which had 3 or 4 pieces of sweet and spicy chicken, hijiki and soybean salad, and mushroom salad.  My fiance, on the other hand is quite picky and doesn't really eat too many veggies so he passed on the bento boxes and decided to order fried items by pieces: katsu and sweet and spicy chicken.  I do wish they had more items, not so much for me, but for my fiance and for anyone who is somewhat picky.  But as for my meal and me being not so picky, I really enjoyed the hijiki salad and the sweet and spicy chicken.  The salads were really fresh and had bold flavor.  I also ordered 1 piece of the chicken dumpling which I thought was yummy.  This place would be great for little snacks  to pick up or if you want some flavorful salads and the salads were healthy and fresh to offset the deep fried goodies.  However, my fiance describes this place as a quick fix and nothing more.
author: Allison J.

description: I'm not an avid fan of Japanese food/sushi, but I'm catching on.  This place is excellent!  Our company has this catered in and I have to say this is the best Japanese they've ever had.   I love the Wasabi Garlic Potato Salad  and the Pork Cutlet (Tonkatsu) is delicious.  The sushi rolls are also scrumptious.  The food is always fresh.   I'm giving this place 5 stars because it definitely deserves it.
author: Roddster V.

description: I love this place. They make premade yummy Japanese version of deli food. Actually, places like Delica is common in Japan, they are usually  located in foodcourt area of major shopping centers.   I recommend trying out their Japanes style curry, and Croquet. Decor of this place is very cool - very organic!!
author: ji k.

description: Yes the lamb curry is delicious and so are the potato croquettes but why don't they offer seaweed salad? Also it can get pretty pricey!
author: Alexis D.

description: Dont miss the fried shrimp cake or the croquette or the chicken dumpling.  It may be hard to part with but I highly suggest you refrain from stuffing all your food down and share the wealth with some friends and order a variety.  Its all delicious!
author: Porfirio R.

description: Excellent fast japanese food in the ferry building.  The combo platters always do me really well when I am waiting for my ferry to Sausalito on the way to work.....oh yeah......
author: Francis K.

description: I'm one of those people who orders something at a restaurant, and, if I like it, I order it EVERY time I go (are there other people like that besides me??). Drives my boyfriend NUTS! Anywho, I love Delica because they have my favorite combination every time I go: chicken, tofu and hijiki patty (warmed up, of course), chinese chicken salad, and the hijiki and soybean salad. SOMETIMES, I'll substitute the spicy burdock and lotus root salad for the chinese chicken salad, but not often. AND, after I gorge on all the food, I don't feel tired!
author: Nini G.

description: THE GREEN BEAN MISO SALAD!  What's in it that makes me walk 20 minutes just to get that tiny, expensive salad?
author: Lisa L.

description: I've never had a Bento box before!  Man, that's a lot of food!  I got the 4 item box.  SO GOOD.  The people in there are very friendly and the food is good and you can go right outside and sit on the pier!  What's not to love?
author: Bree W.

description:
this place is quite overpriced.  i try to get the 2 salad and rice plate for $6.

my friends really like their curry.  i used to get their chicken salad a lot.
author: Dorothy L.

description: The name kind of confuses me and management could definitely take a class in queueing theory since the lunch line is often confusing and slow.  But I've enjoyed my lunches here, especially the chicken/tofu patty and the salads.  The beef or lamb curry is great on a foggy day.  Just stay away from the "sushi."  It's weird.
author: Marcus C.

description: Great lunch spot downtown for casual lunch. Good selection of different things (for you fish-chick-atarians) and you can trick yourself into thinking that they are all light, even something might be fried. Really unique mix of food and the tea is really good.
author: Yaz J.

description:
@ The Ferry Bldg so it automatically gets points, while busy at lunch, the line moves fast

Kinda steep at around $10, them bento boxes are pretty solid, I like the beef curry, I can see how it can get plain

Pork cutlet good too although the salad it is served with has some weird greens
author: xo x.

description:
i love the shrimp cake and all it's deep fried goodness.  dip it in tartar sauce and you're on your way to shrimp cake heaven.  the roast beef sushi is not bad either.

the quality of the food is high that's why the price is a little bit steep. plus, they are in the ferry building- so what do you expect?!
author: J S.

description: Sigh... This place is okay. $12.00  for a little rice and some mixed salads. I know people love this place. As do i when I don't want to get my moneys worth for lunch. Perfect for a snack, not filling for lunch.
author: Dustin H.

description:
I really enjoyed going to lunch here today. Before the review, I am going to say straight-away that I gave this place four stars ONLY because of the lack of seating. 

I ordered a Tonkatsu bento here today, and it was very tender and the meat was brown, the way it should be. 

What impressed me most about this place was the rice: It was just the right texture and tasted like the rice I ate in Japan. The rice can make or break a meal, and it is way too often overlooked. 

In a similar fashion, not all the dishes here are "traditional" to japan, but they are all prepared meticulously and the quality is consistent. 

For a place so good and reasonably priced, its a shame that they don't have many tables to sit down and enjoy a good meal. That may be a fault of the ferry building however.
author: Philip T.

description: I went to this place for the first time today.  I had one of those pre-made bento boxes.  It had 2 sweet and sour chicken dumpling, a lotus root salad, a mobo tofu salad, and white rice with black sesames on it.  The mobo tofu salad was excellent.  Very flavorful and uniquely asian!  The rest were sadly average.
author: Mindy K.

description: I went here with 2 coworkers for lunch today, since one was leaving (boo). We walked to ferry building and wandered around and decided to try delica. There is one line for already made/packed meals, and another line with deli food that happens to be japanese. We got in the latter line. I had a lunch special that lets you choose one main meal, one salad, and rice. I had a tofu and chicken patty with hijiki as my main thing, and some kind of tofu salad as my salad, and then of course the white rice. I also got a hot japanese tea, which comes in a starbucks style mug, and all together it was $10 something. The thing was, it looked like the hot food/deli counter at wholefoods. You can even find the same sort of foods there. Only at wholefoods, they have more seats and tables. Delica had a counter with some chairs, but not many, and they were full. All the seats around the place were full, but we walked down over to the dock and found a bench there. The food was good.  The patty looked like it would be hot so I kept blowing on it by accident. Of course it was cold, since it had been sitting on a deli plate with the others. All 3 of us liked our food. It filled me up at the time, but less than 2 hrs later, and im really hungry. It's not as filling as my usual sandwich. Overall, this is a good place to go if you're in the area and want lunch. It's not special, but I guess there's nothing like it in walking distance. Pretty good.
author: Merredith L.

description:
0 stars.

I GOT FOOD POISONING FROM THIS PLACE!  This past weekend, while vacationing with close friends, we were at the ferry building and casually decided to dine here while walking by.  I got the bento box with the tofu salad, tonkatsu, and lotus salad.  An hour later, I started to feel sick and went back to our hotel room.  I was vomiting (among other things) throughout the rest of the trip and our vacation was ruined.  I was pretty upset since this was a vacation we had been planning for a long time.  I'm positive that it was one of the salads through poor food handling and contamination.  There is no other explanation since my friends didn't get sick (and they had ordered other dishes).

Please don't take your chances and don't order any of the salads/raw food here.  It's SO not worth it.
author: Grace L.

description: Need I say more after 270+ reviews? Yes, the place is very good. The portion looks small but it is actually very filling. Japanese people like to eat in small portions. Duh.  The crab croquette is a must get, but try to get them to customize the box for you. That way, the croquettes will be warm, instead of getting the ones that's been sitting in the boxes in the fridge for who knows how long. The hijike salad is a bit salty/sea-tasty for me but it is healthy at least. A ferry building must-stop.
author: Annie C.

description: 2.5 stars.  I was so excited to try this place that I made this my first stop when I got to SF.  There was a slight line and we were too tired and hungry, so we went for the pre-made food.  Grabbed two steak donburi bowls ($9ish each), a salmon rice ball ($2) and a smoked salmon roll ($9).  The steak donburi bowls were pretty good.  A lot of tasty marinated meat over salad and rice.  Quite filling too.  The salmon rice ball was just chopped pieces of smoked salmon mixed with rice.  Bf didn't like it b/c it was too plain, but I enjoyed it-- smokey and just the right balance of saltiness w/ the rice.  Smoked salmon roll was OK.  I can't remember what vegetables were in it, but honestly it doesn't matter.  All I tasted was onion.  It definitely overpowered everything else, even the salmon.  And the roll was poorly made-- fell apart right away.  Overall, it was an OK experience...so why not a higher rating?  Because I paid $30 for a pre-made takeout meal.  $9 for a crappy roll?  Really?  I could have paid $30 for a decent dine-in meal, tip and all.  Overhyped for sure.
author: Jennifer C.

description: we had the wasabi garlic potato salad, lotus root salad, soybean salad, and the tofu and they were ALL delicious.  All the salads are unusual and most importantly FRESH.  A good quick n grabber lunch for financial districters.
author: stephanie n.

description:
one of the better places in the ferry building for lunch!  ill take this 9 times out of 10 over slanted door (which is just trendy, overpriced vietnamese).

i havent tried the curries/soups etc but they look damn good.

every single one of the fried items are exquisite.  the scallops come back later, but i dont even like scallops and i love these.  things like the crab croquette and the asparagus cream croquette are mighty tasty.  great breading, nice fry job (more difficult than you think) and fresh ingredients.

their other prepared salads and items are also good.  string beans or asparagus in seasame dressing, chicken salad with carrots/celery... simple items that are fresh and tasty.  get a few!  

yes, the place is a bit expensive.  but then again, everything in the ferry building is, and you get what you pay for...
author: Junglist S.

description: Excellent sushi rolls. Always delicious and fresh. Also like the plum rice ball, a totally weird tangy flavor that is not often found in American food but should be. Too expensive, but hey, it's Ferry Plaza.
author: Liboo K.

description: I've been to this shop numerous times before but always on the weekends around Iunchtime.  Last Wednesday, I went to the Ferry Bldg. after work in search of take out food.  I was not expecting to get anyything from Delica because it was never an option at this time of the day (around 5:45pm) in my previous food hunts there.  This time, however, their doors were wide open and customers were still coming and going.  Overjoyed, I got in line and ordered their 3 salad combo.  I chose their green beans, tofu and potato salad.  While everything taste great individually, combined in one container with nothing to neutralize the intensity of each, the sum total became a bit overwhelming and I regretted not orderig a side of rice for that purpose.  I was also somewhat put off by the crunchy rawness of the potato slices used on their potato salad.  But I finished the whole thing anyway, ready to return with a modifed food order plan next time.
author: Yvette F.

description: Good and healthy! The curry rice was kind of kokyu, and I liked the goma spinach salad. Good bento boxes.
author: hugh k.

description: Beef curry Craving. This i would say hit the spot. But alas doesn't have the same feel as a hole in the wall ramen shop.
author: Tobi X.

description: Just OK - it definitely didn't leave me needing/wanting more. Surprising, given all the hype I've heard consistently around it.
author: Melanie L.

description: been going here for a while now..sorta! the reason that i don't go much is because they skimp on their shizz for a ridiculous price! mmhmmmm.. but other than that, i like that they have some vegetarian/vegan options, and their shizz are accessible for the public during lunch! not typical for a japanese place around... =)
author: Marc K.

description: my go-to spot at the ferry building - can't find another place like this! delica combines japanese simplicity and ingredients with a slight californian flavor.   never have to wait too long, especially when i go on weekends and every other place is bombarded by tourists.   my usual order is the 3 salads combo plus a salmon rice ball.  i'm always very satisfied after. my husband isn't a fan of salads for lunch so he'll get the curry rice - which is also very good. my favorite salads are the mapo tofu salad (yummy - the flavors!), the wasabi potato (always hits the spot - potatoes, romaine, edamame with a good balanced wasabi flavor), the hijiki salad (because it appears to be really healthy and good for you with the seaweed, soybeans and goji berries), the eggplant salad and the green bean salad with a sesame sauce. I also really like the chicken and tofu patty and the chicken dumpling. i've never really tried their soups, fried items so can't comment on those. i definitely would recommend the deli items over the sushi though.
author: Eleanor C.

description: Despite all comments...excellent sushi, friendly staff, owner is very nice.  Delica is a good blend of traditional Japanese and California style.  The sushi is very fresh and you do pay but it is not unreasonable if you really enjoy for what is being served to you.  Watch the sushi chef and he will check to see if you enjoy. I would recommend the toro - very good.  I am from Japan and really appreciate the quality of the sushi there.  Steamed clams are very nice.  I know it's not Sushi Midori in Ginza, but it is good  good sushi.
author: duffy m.

description: it's really expensive, which makes it just like being in japan. i like that the selection is different than what you'd find at a japanese restaurant. so if you're thinking you'll find the same stuff, you'll be very disappointed. my favorite item there is the beef bowl. think yoshinoya's, but edible. slightly marinated ground beef, with slivers of egg, green onion, and ginger, over rice. subtle, but oh so oishii!
author: Shinn Z.

description: I got off work and got off at Embarcadero station feeling extremely hungry. I just wanted to shove something in my stomach before I got after work drinks and then I realized, YES! Delica is a a short walk away. I'm a fan of the fried products and I usually end up forgetting about the left side of the counter. I ordered the potato croquettes, the chicken dumplings, the shrimp cake and the pork ton-katsu. At $3.50 I really don't think the shrimp cake is worth it, although it is very meaty  with no filler. I don't know. The potato croquette treats me just as well and is two bucks cheaper. At the higher  price I'd prefer a double cheese burger from McDonald's for a dollar. The pork ton-katsu was very good, as always, although I still wish they didn't put the sauce on already. They should really have a bottle on the side. Despite all my complaints it's all still very good and reminds me of the food my mom from Osaka made while I was growing up. If they started serving Okonomomiyaki and cleaned up a few minor problems they might go up to five stars. For those of you not it the know omo... is a Japanese pancake made out of fish broth, flour, pork and cabbage. It's hard to find as it's a more home cooked thing than a restaurant thing, sorta akin to a sloppy joe. You grow up eating it but you don't really find it in a restaurant.
author: Steve Q.

description: i got a little hockey puck of mushrooms, eggs, and cabbage it was smothered in mayo and bbq sauce, it was real good, thats all i have to say.
author: Jared Z.

description: I had mixed feelings after eating at Delica several times.  Each time I've ordered soup (to go) they leave more than an inch of the container empty - that was my first dislike.  The flavor of the food is generally greasier than I like - many of the items are fried and even some of the ones that are not contain a filmy oil.  When asked what type of oil they use in their cooking no one seemed to know.  The potatoe salad is barely cooked which is very dissappointing.  The seaweed salad left much to be desired - not much flavor.  The chicken dumplings - again disappointing.  Their sushi is just mediocre.    This is not my favorite Japanese take out.
author: Hope O.

description: a great place to grab lunch at the ferry building. i love the potato croquettes, which comes with rice and a salad, and I get the chicken noodle one. a little expensive, but it's worth it. it's just walking distance from the embarcadero BART station and it's right next to Recchutti for chocolates for dessert!
author: Cristina D.

description: For a food-court-type restaurant, Delica is fantastic. I had the Kobe beef rice bowl, and the seasoning was perfect. They have a huge selection of entrees, salads and drinks. Something for every price range and most any appetite.
author: Laura C.

description: This is a great place to get take out lunch if you work downtown.  The bento box lunches are good. I personally like their potato croquettes and pork katsu. Yummy! The service is always very quick, too.
author: Winnie L.

description: The hubby and I missed the ferry to sausalito by about 1 minute so we had over an hour to kill at the Ferry Building. Pretty great place to have an unexpected hour to kill if I do say so myself. We wandered around until we found this spot which neither of us had ever tried. Our eyes were definitely bigger than our stomaches as we ordered about 1 of everything,  for each of us! I really liked their soba noodle soup. The tempura shrimp thing in it was so-so. The chicken dumplings were delish with a really nice sauce on the outside. Miguel got a few different rolls, I loved their spring roll with shrimp, had a really nice sauce in it. He  also got the sweet sour chicken, which wasnt that great, but would have been better if it were served hot instead of cold like they do. The shrimp cakes were awesome. If I go back I will probably order those with rice and their really tasty mashed potatoes, garlic, wasabi and edamame. Yum. Great lunch spot - although it ended up being about $50 for lunch, but we got a ton of food so you could do it at a normal price too and still leave full.
author: Audrey V.

description: Loved it!  I went here for lunch over the weekend and had the chinese chicken salad, wasabi potato salad, and sesame green beans.  Lunch for under $8 at the Ferry Building on a weekend is not too bad in my book.  Plus they jam-packed the plate, so by the end of the meal I was totally stuffed.  -1/2 star for the confusing line setup (custom bento + lunch plates to the left, everything else to the right?  I'm still not sure...) but this rounds up to 5 stars.
author: Vicki M.

description: Delica used to be one of my favorite places to eat lunch.  They have lots of vegetarian and vegan options and their wasabi potato salad is bomb, however, my fondness of this place came to an abrupt end when I became violently ill after dining there one sunny afternoon.  I'll forever remember the episode as the worst food poisoning of my life.  I kid you not, I yaked about 12 times, from the evening to the early dawn.  I thought I'd have to be hospitalized, but I survived.  Thank.  God.  Was it the asparagus salad that made me oh so ill?...hmm...i don't think so.  Or was it the miso tofu beef thingy?...possibly...or was it the mushroom salad?...yes, i think that was the culprit.  Anyway, this experience traumatized me.  Unfortunately, I have to walk by this place to get my morning cup of brew at Peet's and just the smell of the food makes my stomach curl.  Delica, you let me down, so I must give you a lousy two stars because your food POISONED ME.  And because of you I won't be able to eat asparagus, tofu, or mushrooms for a very long time.  Oh, and I missed the Serj Tankien concert at the Warfield cuz of you.  Jerks.  Folks, beware the mushroom salad.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Quality, fresh ingredients and attention to detail make the hot and cold items offered here terrific.  It's nice that you can build your own lunch plate or just select items a la carte.  My favorites are the seaweed salad, the spinach salad, and the addictive potato croquettes.
author: Grace R.

description: ok, i finally tried the tonkatsu. how could i not at its low price?! it was excellent!
author: Marina N.

description: you could get comparable japanese eats cheaper elsewhere, but at delica you're paying for the novelty of it being at the ferry building.  high prices aside the food is tasty.  i love their green bean salad and the new shrimp kakiage is delish!
author: Niki M.

description: geeeeeeeez $10 for a potato croquette???? ok.. im exaggerating but seriously... it's not worth it... there are plenty of other authentic japanese restaurants other than this wanna be elite "gourmet" japanese food. the best thing about this place is the packaging. maybe that's why it's so expensive.
author: Marina K.

description: this place has really fresh and clean japanese deli items...many catering to vegetarians.  we got the wasabi potato salad and the veggie rolls yesterday.  the potato salad is interesting, b/c there are romaine hearts in it, providing for some crunch.  the veggie rolls were not bad.  when asked whether we can get some ginger for the rolls, however, the guy at the counter looked at us like we were from outer space and said, "we don't serve ginger here."  is that such an odd question to ask?  he gave us soy sauce but no wasabi either.
author: Helen T.

description: After Mistral, this is my second-favorite lunchtime destination in the Ferry Building.  Always fresh and flavorful food, and SOME of the combos are a very good value.  A solid four stars.
author: Dennis H.

description: a trip here is like a trip down memory lane.  and also, a trip down to last weekend, cuz my mom cooked me some good japanese food.  =)  but you know what i mean.  sometimes i get here too late though, and a lot of their good stuff is gone, or has been sitting out for too long.
author: Reina M.

description: they had this freaky-deaky mascarpone corn salad thing during the summer.  danky shit.  i am waiting for it to come back to me with crossed fingers.  and you can't go wrong with those chicken balls and fried pork.  again, minus 1 star for being mildly out of the price range for daily lunching.
author: Katie M.

description: Yummy japanese deli items.  I love their persimmon salad and lamb curry.  Little pricy but organic ingredients make it worth the price.  On a sunny day, take a stroll to ferry building during lunch.  It refreshes your day!
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: reminds me japanese deli section in gallery lafayette.. yum
author: Angie Y.

description: I'm kind of biased because I used to work here...but i can tell you that absolutely love everything made at Delica-rf-1.
author: Ziva A.

description: Delica gets all the tips I earn at work. I am not a FiDi yuppie, and I will never become one. I adore this place.
author: Alex C.

description: 2nd visit - much smaller portions, no rice with lunch plate, cold entree (chicken dumpling), unclean tables, poor service. what can i say other than 1 star. 1st visit was much better.
author: Devang S.

description: Pricey but so fresh and delicious!  The meals are something to really savor.  Everything *really* is very delicate.  Great salads.  Even the fried foods are somehow delicate.  The sushi rolls are delicious.  I've even searched to see if these guys have a cookbook.  I like their food that much.
author: G P.

description: I love Delica. Everything is delicous. While staying true to Japanese flavors, the food is a Japanese take on American deli food. The wasabi potato salad is a favorite, as is the roast beef sushi. I also appreciate that you can buy the fried items individually.
author: erin a.

description: Normally I don't like fast food, but this place was exceptional. The food (even fast and already prepared) were great. Especially the Steak Sushi and Tofu Chicken with Hijiki Patty. Just SO.... YUMMY!!!
author: Virginia T.

description: Delica is excellent with its Asian fusion cuisine, a little pricey, but worth it for the quality and occasional veering from traditional food.  Crab crokettes are crispy with a mouthwatering crab meat filling.  Fried shrimp cakes are also crispy on the outside with succulent shrimp inside.  Salmon and sesame brown rice rolls are firm with earthy, nutty brown rice and sesame seeds and fresh, tender salmon.  You get your choice of tarter or tomato sauce which are both excellent.  The soba noodle soup is excellent with fish, shrimp tempura, edumumi, and vegetables with firm, aldentae soba noodles in a sweet and salty miso broth.  For excellent Asian fusion, Delica cannot be beat.  The asparagus salad is fresh with tender stocks of asparagus, sesame seeds, and edema's.  Wusabi potato salad is excellent with fresh potatoes and a wusubi dressing that packs a one-two punch that will make you not want to eat traditional American or German potato salad again.  The romaine lettuce that comes with it is needless to say fresh and crisp.  I can hardly wait to go back and try the rest of their dishes.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: the vegetarian bento box to go - was amazing!! you have to try it - the potato gratin, noodles, broccoli, tofu, all of it was great. can't wait to go back just for the bento box!!
author: bhavna p.

description: i am addicted to their wasabe potato salad.  this place rocks!  i happily drop $10 bucks for lunch here.
author: noone n.
